noun.definition: A large and widespread genus of small mosquitoes (family Culicidae) including several vectors of human disease, notably Aedes aegypti, the principal carrier of yellow fever. Also (in form aedes): a mosquito of this genus (more fully "aedes mosquito").

Aedes.origin: Mid 19th century. From scientific Latin Aedes from ancient Greek ἀηδής unpleasant, disagreeable from ἀ- + ἦδος delight, pleasure from the same Indo-European base as sweet.

noun.definition: A simple bomb made and used by unofficial or unauthorized forces.

adjective.definition: Of or characteristic of the Mediterranean Sea, the countries bordering it, or their inhabitants.
adjective.example: a leisurely Mediterranean cruise

noun.definition: The Mediterranean Sea or the countries bordering it.
noun.example: a permanent American naval presence in the Mediterranean

noun.definition: A native of a Mediterranean country.
noun.example: an admiring audience of Mediterraneans

Mediterranean.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin mediterraneus ‘inland’ (from medius ‘middle’ + terra ‘land’) + -an.

noun.definition: Complete lack of inhibition or restraint.
noun.example: she sings and sways with total abandon

verb.definition: Cease to support or look after (someone); desert.
verb.example: her natural mother had abandoned her at an early age

verb.definition: Give up completely (a practice or a course of action)
verb.example: he had clearly abandoned all pretence of trying to succeed

verb.definition: Allow oneself to indulge in (a desire or impulse)
verb.example: they abandoned themselves to despair

abandon.origin: Late Middle English from Old French abandoner, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + bandon ‘control’ (related to ban). The original sense was ‘bring under control’, later ‘give in to the control of, surrender to’ (abandon (sense 3 of the verb)).

verb.definition: Take (someone) away illegally by force or deception; kidnap.
verb.example: the millionaire who disappeared may have been abducted

verb.definition: (of a muscle) move (a limb or part) away from the midline of the body or from another part.
verb.example: the posterior rectus muscle, which abducts the eye

abduct.origin: Early 17th century from Latin abduct- ‘led away’, from the verb abducere, from ab- ‘away, from’ + ducere ‘to lead’.

abductor.example: Police rescued an abducted boy of comilla district and arrested the abductor from haji eidgah math area at dimla upazila in nilphamari on saturday, police sources said.

noun.definition: A person who abducts another person.
noun.example: she endured a two-hour ordeal at the hands of her abductors

abductor.origin: Early 17th century (as a term in anatomy): modern Latin (see abduct).

ablaze.example: A housewife succumbed to her injuries today four days after she set herself ablaze as she was tortured by her husband allegedly for dowry.

adjective.definition: Burning fiercely.
adjective.example: his clothes were ablaze

verb.definition: Exist in large numbers or amounts.
verb.example: rumours of a further scandal abound

abound.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘overflow, be abundant’): from Old French abunder, from Latin abundare ‘overflow’, from ab- ‘from’ + undare ‘surge’ (from unda ‘a wave’).

verb.definition: Take in or soak up (energy or a liquid or other substance) by chemical or physical action.
verb.example: buildings can be designed to absorb and retain heat

verb.definition: Take up the attention of (someone); interest greatly.
verb.example: she sat in an armchair, absorbed in a book

absorb.origin: Late Middle English from Latin absorbere, from ab- ‘from’ + sorbere ‘suck in’.

adjective.definition: Wildly unreasonable, illogical, or inappropriate.
adjective.example: the allegations are patently absurd

noun.definition: An absurd state of affairs.
noun.example: the incidents that followed bordered on the absurd

absurd.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin absurdus ‘out of tune’, hence ‘irrational’; related to surdus ‘deaf, dull’.

adjective.definition: Existing or available in large quantities; plentiful.
adjective.example: there was abundant evidence to support the theory

abundant.origin: Late Middle English from Latin abundant- ‘abounding’, from the verb abundare (see abound).

adverb.definition: In large quantities; plentifully.
adverb.example: the plant grows abundantly in the wild

abysmal.example: "I think over the last few months the behaviour has been abysmal in international cricket," arthur, who is currently pakistan's head coach, said.

adjective.definition: Extremely bad; appalling.
adjective.example: the quality of her work is abysmal

adjective.definition: Very deep.
adjective.example: waterfalls that plunge into abysmal depths

abysmal.origin: Mid 17th century (used literally as in abysmal (sense 2)): from abysm. abysmal (sense 1) dates from the early 19th century.

noun.definition: A person who helps another commit a crime.
noun.example: an accomplice in the murder

accomplice.origin: Mid 16th century alteration (probably by association with accompany) of Middle English complice ‘an associate’, via Old French from late Latin complex, complic- ‘allied’, from com- ‘together’ + the root of plicare ‘to fold’.

verb.definition: Achieve or complete successfully.
verb.example: the planes accomplished their mission

accomplish.origin: Late Middle English from Old French acompliss-, lengthened stem of acomplir, based on Latin ad- ‘to’ + complere ‘to complete’.

noun.definition: An official agreement or treaty.
noun.example: opposition groups refused to sign the accord

verb.definition: Give or grant someone (power, status, or recognition)
verb.example: the powers accorded to the head of state

verb.definition: (of a concept or fact) be harmonious or consistent with.
verb.example: his views accorded well with those of Merivale

accord.origin: Old English, from Old French acorder ‘reconcile, be of one mind’, from Latin ad- ‘to’ + cor, cord- ‘heart’; influenced by concord.

noun.definition: A report or description of an event or experience.
noun.example: a detailed account of what has been achieved

noun.definition: A record or statement of financial expenditure and receipts relating to a particular period or purpose.
noun.example: the barman was doing his accounts

noun.definition: An arrangement by which a body holds funds on behalf of a client or supplies goods or services to them on credit.
noun.example: a bank account

noun.definition: An arrangement by which a user is given personalized access to a computer, website, or application, typically by entering a username and password.
noun.example: we've reset your password to prevent others from accessing your account

noun.definition: Importance.
noun.example: money was of no account to her

verb.definition: Consider or regard in a specified way.
verb.example: her visit could not be accounted a success

verb.definition: Give or receive an account for money received.
verb.example: after 1292 he accounted to the Westminster exchequer

account.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘counting’, ‘to count’): from Old French acont (noun), aconter (verb), based on conter ‘to count’.

verb.definition: Charge (someone) with an offence or crime.
verb.example: he was accused of murdering his wife's lover

accuse.origin: Middle English from Old French acuser, from Latin accusare ‘call to account’, from ad- ‘towards’ + causa ‘reason, motive, lawsuit’.

verb.definition: Make someone or something accept (something) as normal or usual.
verb.example: I accustomed my eyes to the lenses

accustom.origin: Late Middle English from Old French acostumer, from a- (from Latin ad ‘to, at’) + costume ‘custom’.

adjective.definition: Very good.
adjective.example: an ace swimmer

noun.definition: A playing card with a single spot on it, ranked as the highest card in its suit in most card games.
noun.example: the ace of diamonds

noun.definition: A person who excels at a particular sport or other activity.
noun.example: a motorcycle ace

noun.definition: (in tennis and similar games) a service that an opponent is unable to return and thus wins a point.
noun.example: Nadal banged down eight aces in the set

verb.definition: (in tennis and similar games) serve an ace against (an opponent)
verb.example: he can ace opponents with serves of no more than 62 mph

verb.definition: Achieve high marks in (a test or exam)
verb.example: I aced my grammar test

ace.origin: Middle English (denoting the ‘one’ on dice): via Old French from Latin as ‘unity, a unit’.

adjective.definition: (of a person) having no sexual feelings or desires; asexual.
adjective.example: I didn't realize that I was ace for a long time

noun.definition: A person who has no sexual feelings or desires.
noun.example: both asexual, they have managed to connect with other aces offline

ace.origin: Early 21st century abbreviation of asexual, with alteration of spelling on the model of ace.

noun.definition: A continuous or prolonged dull pain in a part of one's body.
noun.example: the ache in her head worsened

verb.definition: Suffer from a continuous dull pain.
verb.example: my legs ached from the previous day's exercise

ache.origin: Old English æce (noun), acan (verb). In Middle English and early modern English the noun was spelled atche and rhymed with ‘batch’ and the verb was spelled and pronounced as it is today. The noun began to be pronounced like the verb around 1700. The modern spelling is largely due to Dr Johnson, who mistakenly assumed its derivation to be from Greek akhos ‘pain’.

verb.definition: Buy or obtain (an asset or object) for oneself.
verb.example: I managed to acquire all the books I needed

verb.definition: Learn or develop (a skill, habit, or quality)
verb.example: you must acquire the rudiments of Greek

acquire.origin: Late Middle English acquere, from Old French aquerre, based on Latin acquirere ‘get in addition’, from ad- ‘to’ + quaerere ‘seek’. The English spelling was modified (c1600) by association with the Latin word.

noun.definition: An asset or object bought or obtained, typically by a library or museum.
noun.example: the legacy will be used for new acquisitions

noun.definition: The learning or developing of a skill, habit, or quality.
noun.example: the acquisition of management skills

acquisition.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘act of acquiring something’): from Latin acquisitio(n-), from the verb acquirere (see acquire).

adjective.definition: Temporarily doing the duties of another person.
adjective.example: the acting supervisor

noun.definition: The art or occupation of performing fictional roles in plays, films, or television.
noun.example: she studied acting in New York

adjective.definition: Refusing to be persuaded or to change one's mind.
adjective.example: he is adamant that he is not going to resign

noun.definition: A legendary rock or mineral to which many properties were attributed, formerly associated with diamond or lodestone.
noun.example: As for the magical metal, asiceton, it sounds like adamant.

adamant.origin: Old English (as a noun), from Old French adamaunt-, via Latin from Greek adamas, adamant-, ‘untameable, invincible’ (later used to denote the hardest metal or stone, hence diamond), from a- ‘not’ + daman ‘to tame’. The phrase to be adamant dates from the 1930s, although adjectival use had been implied in such collocations as ‘an adamant heart’ since the 16th century.

noun.definition: The action or process of adapting or being adapted.
noun.example: the adaptation of teaching strategy to meet students' needs

adaptation.origin: Early 17th century from French, from late Latin adaptatio(n-), from Latin adaptare (see adapt).

noun.definition: An item of additional material added at the end of a book or other publication.
The radial distance from the pitch circle of a cogwheel or wormwheel to the crests of the teeth or ridges.

addendum.origin: Late 17th century Latin, ‘that which is to be added’, gerundive of addere (see add).

adjective.definition: Satisfactory or acceptable in quality or quantity.
adjective.example: this office is perfectly adequate for my needs

adequate.origin: Early 17th century from Latin adaequatus ‘made equal to’, past participle of the verb adaequare, from ad- ‘to’ + aequus ‘equal’.

verb.definition: Stick fast to (a surface or substance)
verb.example: paint won't adhere well to a greasy surface

verb.definition: Believe in and follow the practices of.
verb.example: I do not adhere to any organized religion

adhere.origin: Late 15th century from Latin adhaerere, from ad- ‘to’ + haerere ‘to stick’.

verb.definition: Break off (a meeting, legal case, or game) with the intention of resuming it later.
verb.example: the meeting was adjourned until December 4

adjourn.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘summon someone to appear on a particular day’): from Old French ajorner, from the phrase a jorn (nome) ‘to an (appointed) day’.

verb.definition: Confess to be true or to be the case.
verb.example: the Home Office finally admitted that several prisoners had been injured

verb.definition: Allow (someone) to enter a place.
verb.example: old-age pensioners are admitted free to the museum

verb.definition: Accept as valid.
verb.example: the courts can refuse to admit police evidence which has been illegally obtained

verb.definition: Allow the possibility of.
verb.example: the need to inform him was too urgent to admit of further delay

admit.origin: Late Middle English from Latin admittere, from ad- ‘to’ + mittere ‘send’.

noun.definition: The period following the onset of puberty during which a young person develops from a child into an adult.
noun.example: Mary spent her childhood and adolescence in Europe

adolescence.origin: Late Middle English from French, from Latin adolescentia, from adolescere ‘grow to maturity’ (see adolescent).

adjective.definition: Used in adulterating something.
adjective.example: They argued that because the bacteria is naturally occurring, it is not an "adulterant" substance subject to regulation by the government.

noun.definition: A substance used to adulterate another.

adulterant.origin: Mid 18th century from Latin adulterant- ‘corrupting’, from the verb adulterare (see adulterate).

noun.definition: The action of making something poorer in quality by the addition of another substance.

adulteration.origin: Early 16th century from Latin adulterat- ‘corrupted’, from the verb adulterare + -ion.

adjective.definition: Preventing success or development; harmful; unfavourable.
adjective.example: taxes are having an adverse effect on production

adverse.origin: Late Middle English from Old French advers, from Latin adversus ‘against, opposite’, past participle of advertere, from ad- ‘to’ + vertere ‘to turn’. Compare with averse.

aerial.example: 1. The dhaka city corporation (dcc) is now ready for aerial spraying of larvicide to combat mosquitoes. 2. The indian border security force yesterday said it has no plan to deploy unmanned aerial vehicles, popularly known as drone.

adjective.definition: Existing, happening, or operating in the air.
adjective.example: an aerial battle

noun.definition: A rod, wire, or other structure by which signals are transmitted or received as part of a radio or television transmission or receiving system.
A type of freestyle skiing in which the skier jumps from a ramp and carries out manoeuvres in the air.

aerial.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘thin as air, imaginary’): via Latin aerius from Greek aerios (from aēr ‘air’) + -al.

adjective.definition: Concerned with beauty or the appreciation of beauty.
adjective.example: the pictures give great aesthetic pleasure

noun.definition: A set of principles underlying the work of a particular artist or artistic movement.
noun.example: the Cubist aesthetic

aesthetic.origin: Late 18th century (in the sense ‘relating to perception by the senses’): from Greek aisthētikos, from aisthēta ‘perceptible things’, from aisthesthai ‘perceive’. The sense ‘concerned with beauty’ was coined in German in the mid 18th century and adopted into English in the early 19th century, but its use was controversial until much later in the century.

adverb.definition: In a way that gives pleasure through beauty.
adverb.example: the buildings and gardens of the factory have been aesthetically designed and laid out

verb.definition: Have an effect on; make a difference to.
verb.example: the dampness began to affect my health

affect.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘attack as a disease’): from French affecter or Latin affect- ‘influenced, affected’, from the verb afficere (see affect).

verb.definition: Pretend to have or feel (something)
verb.example: as usual I affected a supreme unconcern

affect.origin: Late Middle English from French affecter or Latin affectare ‘aim at’, frequentative of afficere ‘work on, influence’, from ad- ‘at, to’ + facere ‘do’. The original sense was ‘like, love’, hence ‘(like to) use, assume, etc.’.

noun.definition: Emotion or desire as influencing behaviour.

affect.origin: Late 19th century coined in German from Latin affectus ‘disposition’, from afficere ‘to influence’ (see affect).

noun.definition: A person or organization officially attached to a larger body.
noun.example: the firm established links with American affiliates

verb.definition: Officially attach or connect (a subsidiary group or a person) to an organization.
verb.example: they are national associations affiliated to larger organizations

affiliate.origin: Mid 18th century from medieval Latin affiliat- ‘adopted as a son’, from the verb affiliare, from ad- ‘towards’ + filius ‘son’.

noun.definition: The state or process of affiliating or being affiliated.
noun.example: the group has no affiliation to any preservation society

affiliation.origin: Late 18th century from French, from medieval Latin affiliatio(n-), from the verb affiliare (see affiliate).

adjective.definition: (especially of a group or area) having a great deal of money; wealthy.
adjective.example: the affluent societies of the western world

adjective.definition: (of water) flowing freely or in great quantity.
adjective.example: He replied that the water was affluent and that they had not reviewed this in detail.

noun.definition: A tributary stream.

affluent.origin: Late Middle English (in affluent (sense 2 of the adjective)): via Old French from Latin affluent- ‘flowing towards, flowing freely’, from the verb affluere, from ad- ‘to’ + fluere ‘to flow’.

adjective.definition: On fire; burning.
adjective.example: the whole mill was afire

adjective.definition: Denoting a thing or person previously mentioned.
adjective.example: songs from the aforementioned album

adjective.definition: Feeling fear or anxiety; frightened.
adjective.example: I'm afraid of dogs

afraid.origin: Middle English past participle of the obsolete verb affray, from Anglo-Norman French afrayer (see affray).

noun.definition: The consequences or after-effects of a significant unpleasant event.
noun.example: food prices soared in the aftermath of the drought

noun.definition: New grass growing after mowing or harvest.

aftermath.origin: Late 15th century (in aftermath (sense 2)): from after (as an adjective) + dialect math ‘mowing’, of Germanic origin; related to German Mahd.

verb.definition: Make (a problem, injury, or offence) worse or more serious.
verb.example: military action would only aggravate the situation

verb.definition: Annoy or exasperate.

aggravate.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin aggravat- ‘made heavy’, from the verb aggravare, from ad- (expressing increase) + gravis ‘heavy’.

adjective.definition: Formed or calculated by the combination of several separate elements; total.
adjective.example: the aggregate amount of grants made

noun.definition: A whole formed by combining several separate elements.
noun.example: the council was an aggregate of three regional assemblies

noun.definition: A material or structure formed from a mass of fragments or particles loosely compacted together.
noun.example: the specimen is an aggregate of rock and mineral fragments

verb.definition: Form or group into a class or cluster.
verb.example: socio-occupational groups aggregate men sharing similar kinds of occupation

aggregate.origin: Late Middle English from Latin aggregat- ‘herded together’, from the verb aggregare, from ad- ‘towards’ + grex, greg- ‘a flock’.

verb.definition: Make (someone) troubled or nervous.
verb.example: the thought of questioning Toby agitated him extremely

verb.definition: Stir or disturb (something, especially a liquid) briskly.
verb.example: agitate the water to disperse the oil

verb.definition: Campaign to arouse public concern about an issue in the hope of prompting action.
verb.example: they agitated for a reversal of the decision

agitate.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘drive away’): from Latin agitat- ‘agitated, driven’, from agitare, frequentative of agere ‘do, drive’.

noun.definition: A state of anxiety or nervous excitement.
noun.example: she was wringing her hands in agitation

noun.definition: Brisk stirring or disturbance of a liquid.
noun.example: the techniques mostly involve agitation by stirring

noun.definition: The arousing of public concern about an issue and pressing for action on it.
noun.example: widespread agitation for social reform

agitation.origin: Mid 16th century (in the sense ‘action, being active’): from Latin agitatio(n-), from the verb agitare (see agitate).

noun.definition: A person who urges others to protest or rebel.
noun.example: a political agitator

noun.definition: An apparatus for stirring liquid.

verb.definition: Undergo great mental anguish through worrying about something.
verb.example: I didn't agonize over the problem

agonize.origin: Late 16th century from French agoniser or late Latin agonizare, from Greek agōnizesthai ‘contend’, from agōn ‘contest’.

agree to disagree.bengali: To agree not to argue anymore about a difference of opinion
agree to disagree.example: He likes golf and his wife likes tennis, so when it comes to sports, they have agreed to disagree.

noun.definition: Help, typically of a practical nature.
noun.example: he saw the pilot slumped in his cockpit and went to his aid

noun.definition: A grant of subsidy or tax to a king or queen.

verb.definition: Help or support (someone or something) in the achievement of something.
verb.example: women were aided in childbirth by midwives

aid.origin: Late Middle English from Old French aide (noun), aidier (verb), based on Latin adjuvare, from ad- ‘towards’ + juvare ‘to help’.

alibi.bengali: অপরাধের অনুষ্ঠানকালে অন্যত্র থাকার অজুহাতে রেহাই পাইবার দাবি

noun.definition: A claim or piece of evidence that one was elsewhere when an act, typically a criminal one, is alleged to have taken place.
noun.example: she has an alibi for the whole of yesterday evening

verb.definition: Provide an alibi for.
verb.example: her friend agreed to alibi her

alibi.origin: Late 17th century (as an adverb in the sense ‘elsewhere’): from Latin, ‘elsewhere’. The noun use dates from the late 18th century.

noun.definition: A claim or assertion that someone has done something illegal or wrong, typically one made without proof.
noun.example: he made allegations of corruption against the administration

allegation.origin: Late Middle English from Latin allegatio(n-), from allegare ‘allege’.

verb.definition: Claim or assert that someone has done something illegal or wrong, typically without proof.
verb.example: he alleged that he had been assaulted

allege.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘declare on oath’): from Old French esligier, based on Latin lis, lit- ‘lawsuit’; confused in sense with Latin allegare ‘allege’.

adverb.definition: Used to convey that something is claimed to be the case or have taken place, although there is no proof.
adverb.example: he was allegedly a leading participant in the coup attempt

noun.definition: Loyalty or commitment to a superior or to a group or cause.
noun.example: those wishing to receive citizenship must swear allegiance to the republic

allegiance.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French, variant of Old French ligeance, from lige, liege (see liege), perhaps by association with Anglo-Latin alligantia ‘alliance’.

noun.definition: A narrow passageway between or behind buildings.
noun.example: he took a short cut along an alley

alley.origin: Late Middle English from Old French alee ‘walking or passage’, from aler ‘go’, from Latin ambulare ‘to walk’.

noun.definition: A toy marble made of marble, alabaster, or glass.

alley.origin: Early 18th century perhaps a diminutive of alabaster.

noun.definition: A union or association formed for mutual benefit, especially between countries or organizations.
noun.example: a defensive alliance between Australia and New Zealand

alliance.origin: Middle English from Old French aliance, from alier ‘to ally’ (see ally).

noun.definition: A state formally cooperating with another for a military or other purpose.
noun.example: debate continued among NATO allies

verb.definition: Combine or unite a resource or commodity with (another) for mutual benefit.
verb.example: he allied his racing experience with his father's business acumen

ally.origin: Middle English (as a verb): from Old French alier, from Latin alligare ‘bind together’, from ad- ‘to’ + ligare ‘to bind’; the noun is partly via Old French alie ‘allied’. Compare with alloy.

noun.definition: A noisy argument or disagreement, especially in public.
noun.example: I had an altercation with the ticket collector

altercation.origin: Late Middle English from Latin altercatio(n-), from the verb altercari (see altercate).

noun.definition: A mixture or blend.
noun.example: a curious amalgam of the traditional and the modern

amalgam.origin: Late 15th century from French amalgame or medieval Latin amalgama, from Greek malagma ‘an emollient’.

noun.definition: The quality of being open to more than one interpretation; inexactness.
noun.example: we can detect no ambiguity in this section of the Act

ambiguity.origin: Late Middle English from Old French ambiguite or Latin ambiguitas, from ambiguus ‘doubtful’ (see ambiguous).

noun.definition: A minor change or addition designed to improve a text, piece of legislation, etc.
noun.example: an amendment to existing bail laws

amendment.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘improvement, correction’): from Old French amendement, from amender (see amend).

adjective.definition: Having or displaying a friendly and pleasant manner.
adjective.example: the amiable young man greeted me enthusiastically

amiable.origin: Late Middle English (originally in the senses ‘kind’, and ‘lovely, lovable’): via Old French from late Latin amicabilis ‘amicable’. The current sense, influenced by modern French aimable ‘trying to please’, dates from the mid 18th century.

preposition.definition: Surrounded by; in the middle of.
preposition.example: our dream home, set amid magnificent rolling countryside

adjective.definition: Enough or more than enough; plentiful.
adjective.example: there is ample time for discussion

ample.origin: Late Middle English via French from Latin amplus ‘large, capacious, abundant’.

adjective.definition: Of, belonging to, or inherited from an ancestor or ancestors.
adjective.example: the family's ancestral home

ancestral.origin: Late Middle English from Old French ancestrel, from ancestre (see ancestor).

noun.definition: An area off the coast which is suitable for a ship to anchor.
An anchorite's dwelling place.

proper noun.definition: The largest city in Alaska, a seaport on an inlet of the Pacific Ocean; population 279,243 (est. 2008).

noun.definition: The joint connecting the foot with the leg.
noun.example: Jennie fell downstairs, breaking her ankle

verb.definition: Walk.
verb.example: we can ankle off to a new locale

verb.definition: Flex the ankles while cycling in order to increase pedalling efficiency.
verb.example: at higher cadences, the feet tend to flap when you are attempting to ankle

ankle.origin: Old English ancleow, of Germanic origin; superseded in Middle English by forms from Old Norse; related to Dutch enkel and German Enkel, from an Indo-European root shared by angle.

verb.definition: Make (someone) a little angry; irritate.
verb.example: the decision really annoyed him

verb.definition: Harm or attack repeatedly.
verb.example: a gallant Saxon, who annoyed this Coast

annoy.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘be hateful to’): from Old French anoier (verb), anoi (noun), based on Latin in odio in the phrase mihi in odio est ‘it is hateful to me’.

noun.definition: Something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected.
noun.example: there are a number of anomalies in the present system

noun.definition: The angular distance of a planet or satellite from its last perihelion or perigee.

anomaly.origin: Late 16th century via Latin from Greek anōmalia, from anōmalos (see anomalous).

noun.definition: The condition of being anonymous.
noun.example: the official spoke on condition of anonymity

verb.definition: Regard as probable; expect or predict.
verb.example: she anticipated scorn on her return to the theatre

verb.definition: Act as a forerunner or precursor of.
verb.example: he anticipated Bates's theories on mimicry and protective coloration

anticipate.origin: Mid 16th century (in the senses ‘to take something into consideration’, ‘mention something before the proper time’): from Latin anticipat- ‘acted in advance’, from anticipare, based on ante- ‘before’ + capere ‘take’.

adverb.definition: (of two or more people or things) separated by a specified distance in time or space.
adverb.example: two stone gateposts some thirty feet apart

adverb.definition: To or on one side; at a distance from the main body.
adverb.example: Isabel stepped away from Joanna and stood apart

adverb.definition: So as to be shattered; into pieces.
adverb.example: he leapt out of the car just before it was blown apart

apart.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, from Latin a parte ‘at the side’.

noun.definition: Lack of interest, enthusiasm, or concern.
noun.example: widespread apathy among students

apathy.origin: Early 17th century from French apathie, via Latin from Greek apatheia, from apathēs ‘without feeling’, from a- ‘without’ + pathos ‘suffering’.

adjective.definition: Of the nature of an aphrodisiac; stimulating sexual desire.
adjective.example: the aphrodisiac effects of ylang-ylang oil

noun.definition: A food, drink, or other thing that stimulates sexual desire.
noun.example: power is the ultimate aphrodisiac

aphrodisiac.origin: Early 18th century from Greek aphrodisiakos, from aphrodisios, from Aphroditē (see Aphrodite).

noun.definition: The technical equipment or machinery needed for a particular activity or purpose.
noun.example: firemen wearing breathing apparatus

noun.definition: The complex structure of a particular organization or system.
noun.example: the apparatus of government
one thing about the book's apparatus does irritate: the absence of an index of titles

apparatus.origin: Early 17th century Latin, from apparare ‘make ready for’, from ad- ‘towards’ + parare ‘make ready’.

noun.definition: Clothing.
noun.example: they were dressed in bright apparel

verb.definition: Clothe (someone)
verb.example: all the vestments in which they used to apparel their Deities

apparel.origin: Middle English (as a verb in the sense ‘make ready or fit’; as a noun ‘furnishings, equipment’): from Old French apareillier, based on Latin ad- ‘to’ (expressing change) + par ‘equal’.

adverb.definition: As far as one knows or can see.
adverb.example: the child nodded, apparently content with the promise

noun.definition: Approval or praise expressed by clapping.
noun.example: they gave him a round of applause

applause.origin: Late Middle English from medieval Latin applausus, from the verb applaudere (see applaud).

noun.definition: Anxiety or fear that something bad or unpleasant will happen.
noun.example: he felt sick with apprehension

noun.definition: Understanding; grasp.
noun.example: his first apprehension of such large issues

noun.definition: The action of arresting someone.
noun.example: they acted with intent to prevent lawful apprehension

apprehension.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘learning, acquisition of knowledge’): from late Latin apprehensio(n-), from apprehendere ‘seize, grasp’ (see apprehend).

apprise.example: We are apprised of the sufferings and hardships of women in our society.

verb.definition: Inform or tell (someone)
verb.example: I thought it right to apprise Chris of what had happened

apprise.origin: Late 17th century from French appris, apprise, past participle of apprendre ‘learn, teach’, from Latin apprehendere (see apprehend).

adjective.definition: Very appropriate to a particular situation.
adjective.example: the composer's reference to child's play is apropos

preposition.example: she remarked apropos of the initiative, ‘It's not going to stop the abuse’

apropos.origin: Mid 17th century from French à propos ‘(with regard) to (this) purpose’.

noun.definition: The use of an arbitrator to settle a dispute.
noun.example: Tayside Regional Council called for arbitration to settle the dispute

arbitration.origin: Use an arbitrator to settle a dispute.

adjective.definition: Involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
adjective.example: an arduous journey

arduous.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin arduus ‘steep, difficult’ + -ous.

areola.bengali: ব্রণ বা ফোড়ার চারপাশের গোলাকার লালচে জায়গা

noun.definition: A small circular area, in particular the ring of pigmented skin surrounding a nipple.

areola.origin: Mid 17th century (in the sense ‘small space or interstice’): from Latin, literally ‘small open space’, diminutive of area (see area).

noun.definition: The metal coverings formerly worn by soldiers or warriors to protect the body in battle.
noun.example: knights in armor

transitive verb.definition: Provide (someone) with emotional, social, or other defenses.
transitive verb.example: the knowledge armored him against her

armor.origin: Middle English from Old French armure, from Latin armatura, from armare ‘to arm’ (see arm).

noun.definition: A hollow under the arm at the shoulder.

armpit.origin: Deeply involved in a particular unpleasant situation or enterprise.

plural noun.definition: Money that is owed and should have been paid earlier.
plural noun.example: he was suing the lessee for the arrears of rent

arrears.origin: Middle English (first used in the phrase in arrear): from arrear (adverb) ‘behind, overdue’, from Old French arere, from medieval Latin adretro, from ad- ‘towards’ + retro ‘backwards’.

noun.definition: A person who has been or is being legally arrested.
The criminal act of deliberately setting fire to property.
noun.example: police are treating the fire as arson

arson.origin: Late 17th century an Anglo-Norman French legal term, from medieval Latin arsio(n-), from Latin ardere ‘to burn’.

ask out.bengali: 1. To ask someone to go on a date. 2. To invite someone to a social event or special occasion. 3. To invite someone to a distant location.
ask out.example: 1. you are asking me out? 2. Bill still hasn't asked me out—maybe he doesn't have romantic feelings for me after all. 3. I'm sorry, we're busy on friday night—my boss has asked us out to the theater.4. I have asked hannah out to our new place, but she never wants to drive all the way from the city.

noun.definition: A hope or ambition of achieving something.
noun.example: the needs and aspirations of the people

noun.definition: The action or process of drawing breath.
noun.example: These factors lead to either inhalation or aspiration of pathogens into the respiratory tract.

noun.definition: The action of pronouncing a sound with an exhalation of breath.
noun.example: there is no aspiration if the syllable begins with s

aspiration.origin: Late Middle English (in aspiration (sense 3)): from Latin aspiratio(n-), from the verb aspirare (see aspire).

noun.definition: A person who physically attacks another.
noun.example: the police have no firm leads about the identity of his assailant

noun.definition: A physical attack.
noun.example: his imprisonment for an assault on the film director

noun.definition: A concerted attempt to do something demanding.
noun.example: a winter assault on Mt Everest

verb.definition: Make a physical attack on.
verb.example: he pleaded guilty to assaulting a police officer

assault.origin: Middle English from Old French asaut (noun), assauter (verb), based on Latin ad- ‘to’ + saltare, frequentative of salire ‘to leap’. Compare with assail.

verb.definition: State a fact or belief confidently and forcefully.
verb.example: the company asserts that the cuts will not affect development

assert.origin: Early 17th century from Latin asserere ‘claim, affirm’, from ad- ‘to’ + serere ‘to join’.

verb.definition: Evaluate or estimate the nature, ability, or quality of.
verb.example: the committee must assess the relative importance of the issues

assess.origin: Late Middle English from Old French assesser, based on Latin assidere ‘sit by’ (in medieval Latin ‘levy tax’), from ad- ‘to, at’ + sedere ‘sit’. Compare with assize.

verb.definition: Suppose to be the case, without proof.
verb.example: topics which assume detailed knowledge of local events

verb.definition: Take or begin to have (power or responsibility)
verb.example: he assumed full responsibility for all organizational work

verb.definition: Begin to have (a specified quality, appearance, or extent)
verb.example: militant activity had assumed epidemic proportions

assume.origin: Late Middle English from Latin assumere, from ad- ‘towards’ + sumere ‘take’.

noun.definition: A positive declaration intended to give confidence; a promise.
noun.example: he gave an assurance that work would begin on Monday

noun.definition: Confidence or certainty in one's own abilities.
noun.example: she drove with assurance

noun.definition: Insurance, specifically life insurance.

assurance.origin: Late Middle English (in assurance (sense 2)): from Old French, from assurer ‘assure’.

verb.definition: Tell someone something positively to dispel any doubts.
verb.example: Tony assured me that there was a supermarket in the village

verb.definition: Make (something) certain to happen.
verb.example: victory was now assured

verb.definition: Cover (a life) by assurance.
verb.example: we guarantee to assure your life

assure.origin: Late Middle English from Old French assurer, based on Latin ad- ‘to’ (expressing change) + securus (see secure).

adverb.definition: Confidently.
adverb.example: the lad kept his cool and assuredly slipped the ball between the posts

adverb.definition: Used to express the speaker's certainty that something is true.
adverb.example: potted roses will most assuredly not survive winter without protection

noun.definition: The protection granted by a state to someone who has left their home country as a political refugee.
noun.example: she applied for asylum and was granted refugee status

noun.definition: An institution for the care of people who are mentally ill.
noun.example: he'd been committed to an asylum

asylum.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘place of refuge’, especially for criminals): via Latin from Greek asulon ‘refuge’, from asulos ‘inviolable’, from a- ‘without’ + sulon ‘right of seizure’. Current senses date from the 18th century.

adjective.definition: Reduced in force, effect, or physical thickness.
adjective.example: the doctrines of Christianity became very attenuate and distorted

verb.definition: Reduce the force, effect, or value of.
verb.example: her intolerance was attenuated by an unexpected liberalism

verb.definition: Reduce in thickness; make thin.

attenuate.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin attenuat- ‘made slender’, from the verb attenuare, from ad- ‘to’ + tenuare ‘make thin’ (from tenuis ‘thin’).

noun.definition: A person, typically a lawyer, appointed to act for another in business or legal matters.

attorney.origin: Middle English from Old French atorne, past participle of atorner ‘assign’, from a ‘towards’ + torner ‘to turn’ (see attorn).

noun.definition: The purple egg-shaped fruit of a tropical Old World plant, which is eaten as a vegetable.
noun.example: a puree of aubergine

noun.definition: The large plant of the nightshade family which bears aubergines.
noun.example: The capsicums are a genus of the family Solanaceae, and are therefore related to the New World tomato and potato, and, in the Old World, to the aubergine and deadly nightshade.

aubergine.origin: Late 18th century from French, from Catalan alberginia, from Arabic al-bāḏinjān (based on Persian bādingān, from Sanskrit vātiṃgaṇa).

adjective.definition: (of hair) of a reddish-brown colour.

noun.definition: A reddish-brown colour.

auburn.origin: Late Middle English from Old French auborne, alborne, from Latin alburnus ‘whitish’, from albus ‘white’. The original sense was ‘yellowish white’, but the word became associated with brown because in the 16th and 17th centuries it was often written abrune or abroun.

noun.definition: A vowel prefixed to past tenses of verbs in Greek and certain other Indo-European languages.

verb.definition: Make (something) greater by adding to it; increase.
verb.example: he augmented his summer income by painting houses

augment.origin: Late Middle English from Old French augmenter (verb), augment (noun), or late Latin augmentare, from Latin augere ‘to increase’.

noun.definition: A ruler who has absolute power.
noun.example: like many autocrats, Franco found the exercise of absolute power addictive

autocrat.origin: Early 19th century from French autocrate, from Greek autokratēs, from autos ‘self’ + kratos ‘power’.

noun.definition: A post-mortem examination to discover the cause of death or the extent of disease.
noun.example: a Home Office pathologist carried out the autopsy

verb.definition: Perform an autopsy on (a body or organ)
verb.example: the animal must be autopsied as soon as possible

autopsy.origin: Mid 17th century (in the sense ‘personal observation’): from French autopsie or modern Latin autopsia, from Greek, from autoptēs ‘eyewitness’, from autos ‘self’ + optos ‘seen’.

noun.definition: An organism that is able to form nutritional organic substances from simple inorganic substances such as carbon dioxide.
A strong dislike or disinclination.
noun.example: they made plain their aversion to the use of force

aversion.origin: Late 16th century (originally denoting the action of turning away or averting one's eyes): from Latin aversio(n-), from avertere ‘turn away from’ (see avert).

verb.definition: Turn away (one's eyes or thoughts)
verb.example: she averted her eyes while we made stilted conversation

verb.definition: Prevent or ward off (an undesirable occurrence)
verb.example: talks failed to avert a rail strike

avert.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘divert or deter someone from a place or a course of action’): from Latin avertere, from ab- ‘from’ + vertere ‘to turn’; reinforced by Old French avertir.

noun.definition: A feeling of reverential respect mixed with fear or wonder.
noun.example: they gazed in awe at the small mountain of diamonds

verb.definition: Inspire with awe.
verb.example: they were both awed by the vastness of the forest

awe.origin: Old English ege ‘terror, dread, awe’, replaced in Middle English by forms related to Old Norse agi.

noun.definition: A painted cloth hung at the back of a theatre stage as part of the scenery.

verb.definition: Lie behind or beyond; serve as a background to.
verb.example: the rolling hills that backdropped our camp

noun.definition: The motion of receding waves.
noun.example: the backwash is reduced in energy by the percolation of water into the shingle

verb.definition: Clean (a filter) by reversing the flow of fluid through it.
verb.example: the very fine mesh is backwashed to remove solids

adverb.definition: In an unsatisfactory, inadequate, or unsuccessful way.
adverb.example: England have played badly this year

adverb.definition: Used to emphasize the seriousness of an unpleasant event or action.
adverb.example: the building was badly damaged by fire

adverb.definition: In a guilty or regretful way.
adverb.example: I felt badly about my unfriendliness

badly.origin: At a disadvantage, especially by being poor.

adjective.definition: Impossible to understand; perplexing.
adjective.example: the crime is a baffling mystery for the police

noun.definition: The temporary release of an accused person awaiting trial, sometimes on condition that a sum of money is lodged to guarantee their appearance in court.
noun.example: he has been released on bail

verb.definition: Release or secure the release of (a prisoner) on payment of bail.
verb.example: nine were bailed on drugs charges

bail.origin: Middle English from Old French, literally ‘custody, jurisdiction’, from bailler ‘take charge of’, from Latin bajulare ‘bear a burden’.

noun.definition: Either of the two crosspieces bridging the stumps, which the bowler and fielders try to dislodge with the ball to get the batsman out.
noun.example: the Lancashire captain was at full stretch as the wicketkeeper took off the bails

noun.definition: A bar on a typewriter or computer printer which holds the paper steady.
A fastening that secures a crampon to the sole of a boot.
A bar or pole separating horses in an open stable.

verb.definition: Confront (someone) with the intention of robbing them.
verb.example: they bailed up Mr Dyason and demanded his money

verb.definition: Secure (a cow) during milking.

bail.origin: Middle English (denoting the outer wall of a castle): from Old French baile ‘palisade, enclosure’, baillier ‘enclose’, perhaps from Latin baculum ‘rod, stick’.

verb.definition: Scoop water out of (a ship or boat)
verb.example: the first priority is to bail out the boat with buckets

verb.definition: Abandon a commitment, obligation, or activity.

bail.origin: Early 17th century from obsolete bail ‘bucket’, from French baille, based on Latin bajulus ‘carrier’.

noun.definition: The fact or condition of being banal; unoriginality.
noun.example: there is an essential banality to the story he tells

noun.definition: A robber or outlaw belonging to a gang and typically operating in an isolated or lawless area.
noun.example: the bandit produced a weapon and demanded money

bandit.origin: Late 16th century from Italian bandito, ‘banned’, past participle of bandire ‘to ban’.

noun.definition: A roll of banknotes.

verb.definition: Support (a person, organization, or project) financially.
verb.example: the project is bankrolled by wealthy expatriates

noun.definition: A person who cuts men's hair and shaves or trims beards as an occupation.
noun.example: he had his hair cut at the local barber's

verb.definition: Cut or trim (a man's hair)
verb.example: his hair was neatly barbered

barber.origin: Middle English via Anglo-Norman French from Old French barbe (see barb).

noun.definition: A shop where a barber works.
A popular style of close harmony singing, typically for four male voices.
noun.example: a barbershop quartet

noun.definition: An agreement between two or more people or groups as to what each will do for the other.
noun.example: bargains between political parties supporting the government

noun.definition: A thing bought or offered for sale much more cheaply than is usual or expected.
noun.example: the table was a real bargain

verb.definition: Negotiate the terms and conditions of a transaction.
verb.example: he bargained with the local council to rent the stadium

verb.definition: Be prepared for; expect.
verb.example: I got more information than I'd bargained for

bargain.origin: Middle English from Old French bargaine (noun), bargaignier (verb); probably of Germanic origin and related to German borgen ‘borrow’.

noun.definition: A concentrated artillery bombardment over a wide area.
noun.example: his forces launched an artillery barrage on the city

noun.definition: An artificial barrier across a river or estuary to prevent flooding, aid irrigation or navigation, or to generate electricity by tidal power.
noun.example: they are considering a tidal barrage built across the Severn estuary

verb.definition: Bombard (someone) with questions, criticisms, complaints, etc.
verb.example: his doctor was barraged with unsolicited advice

barrage.origin: Mid 19th century (in barrage (sense 2 of the noun)): from French, from barrer ‘to bar’, of unknown origin.

barring.origin: Late 15th century from the verb bar+ -ing.

adjective.definition: (of a thing) no longer in its pure or original form; debased.
adjective.example: a bastard Darwinism

adjective.definition: Born of parents not married to each other; illegitimate.
adjective.example: a bastard child

noun.definition: An unpleasant or despicable person.
noun.example: he lied to me, the bastard!

noun.definition: A person born of parents not married to each other.

bastard.origin: Middle English via Old French from medieval Latin bastardus, probably from bastum ‘packsaddle’; compare with Old French fils de bast, ‘packsaddle son’ (i.e. the son of a mule driver who uses a packsaddle for a pillow and is gone by morning).

adjective.definition: Injured by repeated blows or punishment.
adjective.example: he finished the day battered and bruised

adjective.definition: (of food) coated in batter and deep-fried until crisp.

noun.definition: A broad inlet of the sea where the land curves inwards.
noun.example: a boat trip round the bay

bay.origin: Late Middle English from Old French baie, from Old Spanish bahia, of unknown origin.

noun.definition: An evergreen Mediterranean shrub with deep green leaves and purple berries. Its aromatic leaves are used in cooking and were formerly used to make triumphal crowns for victors.

bay.origin: Late Middle English (denoting the laurel berry): from Old French baie, from Latin baca ‘berry’.

noun.definition: A space created by a window line projecting outwards from a wall.
A compartment with a specified function in a vehicle, aircraft, or ship.
noun.example: a bomb bay

bay.origin: Late Middle English from Old French baie, from baer ‘to gape’, from medieval Latin batare, of unknown origin.

adjective.definition: (of a horse) brown with black points.

noun.definition: A bay horse.

bay.origin: Middle English from Old French bai, from Latin badius.

noun.definition: The sound of baying.
noun.example: the bloodhounds' heavy bay

verb.definition: (of a dog, especially a large one) bark or howl loudly.
verb.example: the dogs bayed

bay.origin: Middle English (as a noun): from Old French (a)bai (noun), (a)baiier (verb) ‘to bark’, of imitative origin.

noun.definition: A small piece of glass, stone, or similar material that is threaded with others to make a necklace or rosary or sewn on to fabric.
noun.example: long strings of beads

noun.definition: A drop of a liquid on a surface.
noun.example: beads of sweat

noun.definition: A small knob forming the foresight of a gun.
The reinforced inner edge of a pneumatic tyre that grips the rim of the wheel.
An ornamental plaster moulding resembling a string of beads or having a semicircular cross section.

verb.definition: Decorate or cover with beads.
verb.example: I beaded the jacket by hand

verb.definition: Cover (a surface) with drops of moisture.
verb.example: his face was beaded with perspiration

bead.origin: Old English gebed ‘prayer’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch bede and German Gebet, also to bid. Current senses derive from the use of a rosary, each bead representing a prayer.

adjective.definition: Able to be endured.
adjective.example: things to make life in the tropics more bearable

noun.definition: A large semiaquatic broad-tailed rodent native to North America and northern Eurasia. It is noted for its habit of gnawing through trees to fell them in order to make dams.

verb.definition: Work hard.
verb.example: Bridget beavered away to keep things running smoothly
synonyms: work one's fingers to the bone
keep one's nose to the grindstone

beaver.origin: Old English beofor, befor, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch bever and German Biber, from an Indo-European root meaning ‘brown’.

noun.definition: The lower part of the face guard of a helmet in a suit of armour. The term is also used to refer to the upper part or visor, or to a single movable guard.
noun.example: The ghost wears the beaver, or visor, of the helmet raised.

beaver.origin: Late 15th century from Old French baviere ‘bib’, from baver ‘slaver’.

noun.definition: A woman's genitals or pubic area.
A bearded man.
noun.example: Skittish young girls would rush up to a bearded man in the street and tug his beard, yelling Beaver!.

verb.definition: (especially of something bad) happen to (someone)
verb.example: a tragedy befell his daughter

befall.origin: Old English befeallan ‘to fall’ (early use being chiefly figurative); related to German befallen.

adjective.definition: Appropriate to the occasion.
adjective.example: a country which can run the prestigious tournament in a befitting manner

verb.definition: Cause to become unable to think clearly.
verb.example: even in my befuddled state I could see that they meant trouble

verb.definition: Act or conduct oneself in a specified way, especially towards others.
verb.example: he always behaved like a gentleman

verb.definition: Conduct oneself in accordance with the accepted norms of a society or group.
verb.example: ‘Just behave, Tom,’ he said

behave.origin: Late Middle English from be-‘thoroughly’ + have in the sense ‘have or bear (oneself) in a particular way’.

adjective.definition: Hostile and aggressive.
adjective.example: the mood at the meeting was belligerent

noun.definition: A nation or person engaged in war or conflict, as recognized by international law.
noun.example: ships and goods captured at sea by a belligerent

belligerent.origin: Late 16th century from Latin belligerant- ‘waging war’, from the verb belligerare, from bellum ‘war’.

adjective.definition: Well meaning and kindly.
adjective.example: he was something of a benevolent despot

benevolent.origin: Late Middle English from Old French benivolent, from Latin bene volent- ‘well wishing’, from bene ‘well’ + velle ‘to wish’.

noun.definition: A ship's allotted place at a wharf or dock.
noun.example: the vessel had left its berth

noun.definition: A fixed bunk on a ship, train, or other means of transport.
noun.example: I'll sleep in the upper berth

noun.definition: (often in a sporting context) a position in an organization or event.
noun.example: he looked at home in an unfamiliar right-back berth

verb.definition: Moor (a ship) in its allotted place.
verb.example: they planned to berth HMS Impregnable at Portsmouth

verb.definition: (of a passenger ship) provide a sleeping place for (someone).

berth.origin: Early 17th century (in the sense ‘adequate sea room’): probably from a nautical use of bear+ -th.

noun.definition: The unknown, especially in references to life after death.
noun.example: messages from the beyond

preposition & adverb.definition: At or to the further side of.
preposition & adverb.example: he pointed to a spot beyond the concealing trees

preposition & adverb.definition: Happening or continuing after (a specified time, stage, or event)
Having progressed or achieved more than (a specified stage or level)
preposition & adverb.example: we need to get beyond square one

preposition & adverb.definition: To or in a degree or condition where a specified action is impossible.
preposition & adverb.example: the landscape has changed beyond recognition
beyond telling us that she was well educated, he has nothing to say about her

beyond.origin: Old English begeondan, from be ‘by’ + geondan of Germanic origin (related to yon and yonder).

noun.definition: An offer of a price, especially at an auction.
noun.example: at the fur tables, several buyers make bids for the pelts

noun.definition: An attempt or effort to achieve something.
noun.example: he made a bid for power in 1984

verb.definition: Offer (a certain price) for something, especially at an auction.
verb.example: a consortium of dealers bid a world record price for a snuff box

verb.definition: Make an effort or attempt to achieve.
verb.example: she's now bidding to become a top female model

bid.origin: Old English bēodan ‘to offer, command’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch bieden and German bieten.

verb.definition: Utter (a greeting or farewell) to.
verb.example: James bade a tearful farewell to his parents

verb.definition: Command or order (someone) to do something.
verb.example: I did as he bade me

bid.origin: Old English biddan ‘ask’, of Germanic origin; related to German bitten.

bladder.example: I have to void my bladder

noun.definition: A muscular membranous sac in the abdomen which receives urine from the kidneys and stores it for excretion.
noun.example: patients were asked to empty their bladders before going to bed

noun.definition: An inflated or hollow flexible bag or chamber.
noun.example: a dried bladder of seaweed

bladder.origin: Old English blǣdre, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch blaar and German Blatter, also to blow.

adjective.definition: Covering all cases or instances; total and inclusive.
adjective.example: a blanket ban on tobacco advertising

noun.definition: A large piece of woollen or similar material used as a covering on a bed or elsewhere for warmth.
noun.example: I slept on the ground covered by my blanket

noun.definition: A rubber surface used for transferring the image in ink from the plate to the paper in offset printing.

verb.definition: Cover completely with a thick layer of something.
verb.example: the countryside was blanketed in snow

verb.definition: Take wind from the sails of (another craft) by passing to windward.
verb.example: That should blanket the spinnaker behind the mainsail so that there is very little pressure on it.

blanket.origin: Middle English (denoting undyed woollen cloth): via Old Northern French from Old French blanc ‘white’, ultimately of Germanic origin.

noun.definition: A destructive wave of highly compressed air spreading outwards from an explosion.
noun.example: they were thrown backwards by the blast

noun.definition: A strong gust of wind or air.
noun.example: the icy blast hit them

noun.definition: A single loud note of a horn, whistle, or similar.
noun.example: a blast of the ship's siren

noun.definition: A severe reprimand.
noun.example: I braced myself for the inevitable blast

noun.definition: An enjoyable experience or lively party.
noun.example: it could turn out to be a real blast

verb.definition: Blow up or break apart (something solid) with explosives.
verb.example: the school was blasted by an explosion

verb.definition: Produce or cause to produce loud continuous music or other noise.
verb.example: music blasted out at full volume

verb.definition: Kick or strike (a ball) hard.
verb.example: the striker blasted the free kick into the net

verb.definition: Criticize fiercely.
verb.example: the school was blasted by government inspectors

verb.definition: (of a wind or other natural force) wither, shrivel, or blight (a plant)
verb.example: corn blasted before it be grown up

blast.origin: Old English blǣst, of Germanic origin; related to blaze.

adjective.definition: (of bad behaviour) done openly and unashamedly.
adjective.example: blatant lies

blatant.origin: Late 16th century perhaps an alteration of Scots blatand ‘bleating’. It was first used by Spenser as an epithet for a thousand-tongued monster produced by Cerberus and Chimaera, a symbol of calumny, which he called the blatant beast. It was subsequently used to mean ‘clamorous, offensive to the ear’, first of people (mid 17th century), later of things (late 18th century); the sense ‘unashamedly conspicuous’ arose in the late 19th century.

adjective.definition: (of an area of land) lacking vegetation and exposed to the elements.
adjective.example: a bleak and barren moor

bleak.origin: Old English blāc ‘shining, white’, or in later use from synonymous Old Norse bleikr; ultimately of Germanic origin and related to bleach.

noun.definition: A small silvery shoaling fish of the carp family, found in Eurasian rivers.

bleak.origin: Late 15th century from Old Norse bleikja.

adjective.definition: Wearing a blindfold.

adverb.definition: With a blindfold covering the eyes.
adverb.example: the reporter was driven blindfold to meet the gangster

noun.definition: A piece of cloth tied round the head to cover someone's eyes.

verb.definition: Deprive (someone) of sight by tying a piece of cloth round the head so as to cover the eyes.
verb.example: he was blindfolded and trussed up in a cupboard

blindfold.origin: Mid 16th century alteration, by association with fold, of blindfeld, past participle of obsolete blindfell ‘strike blind, blindfold’, from Old English geblindfellan(see blind, fell).

adjective.definition: (of hair) fair or pale yellow.
adjective.example: short-cropped blond hair

noun.definition: A person with fair or pale yellow hair (typically used of a woman).

blond.origin: Late 15th century from French blond, blonde, from medieval Latin blundus ‘yellow’, perhaps from Germanic.

noun.definition: An attempt to deceive someone into believing that one can or is going to do something.
noun.example: the offer was denounced as a bluff

verb.definition: Try to deceive someone as to one's abilities or intentions.
verb.example: he's been bluffing all along

bluff.origin: Late 17th century (originally in the sense ‘blindfold, hoodwink’): from Dutch bluffen ‘brag’, or bluf ‘bragging’. The current sense (originally US, mid 19th century) originally referred to bluffing in the game of poker.

adjective.definition: Direct in speech or behaviour but in a good-natured way.
adjective.example: a big, bluff, hearty man

bluff.origin: Early 18th century (in the sense ‘surly, abrupt in manner’): figurative use of bluff. The current positive connotation dates from the early 19th century.

adjective.definition: (of a cliff or a ship's bows) having a vertical or steep broad front.

noun.definition: A steep cliff, bank, or promontory.
A grove or clump of trees.

bluff.origin: Early 17th century (as an adjective, originally in nautical use): of unknown origin.

adjective.definition: (of a cutting implement) not having a sharp edge or point.
adjective.example: a blunt knife

adjective.definition: (of a person or remark) uncompromisingly forthright.
adjective.example: a blunt statement of fact

noun.definition: A hollowed-out cigar filled with cannabis.

verb.definition: Make or become less sharp.
verb.example: wood can blunt your axe

blunt.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘dull, insensitive’): perhaps of Scandinavian origin and related to Old Norse blunda ‘shut the eyes’.

noun.definition: An act of talking with excessive pride and self-satisfaction.
noun.example: I said I would win and it wasn't an idle boast

verb.definition: Talk with excessive pride and self-satisfaction about one's achievements, possessions, or abilities.
verb.example: she boasted about her many conquests

verb.definition: (of a person, place, or thing) possess (a feature that is a source of pride)
verb.example: the hotel boasts high standards of comfort

boast.origin: Middle English (as a noun): of unknown origin.

noun.definition: (in squash) a stroke in which the ball is made to hit one of the side walls before hitting the front wall.

boast.origin: Late 19th century perhaps from French bosse denoting a rounded projection in the wall of a court for real tennis.

bodacious.bengali: very large or important, or something that people enjoy or admire

adjective.definition: Excellent, admirable, or attractive.
adjective.example: bodacious babes

bodacious.origin: Mid 19th century (in sense ‘complete, thorough’): perhaps a variant of SW dialect boldacious, blend of bold and audacious.

noun.definition: A cannon of the earliest type, which fired a stone ball or large shot.

verb.definition: Attack (a place or person) continuously with bombs, shells, or other missiles.
verb.example: the city was bombarded by federal forces

bombard.origin: Late Middle English (as a noun denoting an early form of cannon, also a shawm) from Old French bombarde, probably based on Latin bombus ‘booming, humming’ (see bomb). The verb (late 16th century) is from French bombarder.

exclamation.definition: Said suddenly to surprise someone who is unaware of one's presence.
exclamation.example: ‘Boo!’ she cried, jumping up to frighten him

exclamation.definition: Said to show disapproval or contempt.

noun.definition: An utterance of ‘boo’ to show disapproval of a speaker or performer.
noun.example: the audience greeted this comment with boos and hisses

verb.definition: Say ‘boo’ to show disapproval of a speaker or performer.
verb.example: they booed and hissed when he stepped on stage

boo.origin: Early 19th century (in boo (sense 2 of the exclamation)): imitative of the lowing of oxen.

noun.definition: A person's boyfriend or girlfriend.

boo.origin: 1980s origin uncertain; probably an alteration of French beau ‘boyfriend, male admirer’.

noun.definition: A slope or other irregularity on a golf course which must be compensated for when playing a shot.

verb.definition: Take and use (something belonging to someone else) with the intention of returning it.
verb.example: he had borrowed a car from one of his colleagues

verb.definition: Allow (a certain distance) when playing a shot to compensate for sideways motion of the ball due to a slope or other irregularity.

borrow.origin: Old English borgian ‘borrow against security’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German borgen.

noun.definition: A person or organization that takes and uses something belonging to someone else with the intention of returning it.
noun.example: my last pair of secateurs were ruined by a careless borrower

adjective.definition: (of a friend) very close or intimate.
adjective.example: the two girls had become bosom friends

noun.definition: A woman's chest or breasts.
noun.example: her ample bosom

bosom.origin: Old English bōsm, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch boezem and German Busen.

noun.definition: An attractively arranged bunch of flowers, especially one presented as a gift or carried at a ceremony.
The characteristic scent of a wine or perfume.
noun.example: the aperitif has a faint bouquet of almonds

bouquet.origin: Early 18th century from French (earlier ‘clump of trees’), from a dialect variant of Old French bos ‘wood’. bouquet (sense 2) dates from the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: A knot tied with two loops and two loose ends, used especially for tying shoelaces and decorative ribbons.
noun.example: a girl with long hair tied back in a bow

noun.definition: A weapon for shooting arrows, typically made of a curved piece of wood joined at both ends by a taut string.
A long, partially curved rod with horsehair stretched along its length, used for playing the violin and other stringed instruments.
A curved stroke forming part of a letter (e.g. b, p).
A metal ring forming the handle of a key or pair of scissors.

verb.definition: Play (a stringed instrument or music) using a bow.
verb.example: the techniques by which the pieces were bowed

bow.origin: Old English boga ‘bend, bow, arch’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch boog and German Bogen, also to bow.

noun.definition: An act of bending the head or upper body as a sign of respect or greeting.
noun.example: the man gave a little bow

verb.definition: Bend the head or upper part of the body as a sign of respect, greeting, or shame.
verb.example: he turned and bowed to his father

verb.definition: Bend with age or under pressure.
verb.example: the roof trusses bowed as the wind fought to rip the roof free

verb.definition: (of a new film or product) be premiered or launched.
verb.example: the trailer bowed in theaters nationwide on December 23

bow.origin: Old English būgan ‘bend, stoop’, of Germanic origin; related to German biegen, also to bow.

noun.definition: The front end of a ship.
noun.example: water sprayed high over her bows

bow.origin: Late Middle English from Low German boog, Dutch boeg, ‘shoulder or ship's bow’; related to bough.

noun.example: he felt his bowels loosen

bowel.origin: Middle English from Old French bouel, from Latin botellus, diminutive of botulus ‘sausage’.

bowel movement.bengali: অন্ত্র-আন্দোলন; an act of passing usually solid waste through the rectum and anus
bowel movement.example: He had a two-day history of right lower abdominal pain… without bowel movements.

noun.definition: A device fitted to something, in particular a weak or injured part of the body, to give support.
noun.example: a neck brace

noun.definition: A pair of straps that pass over the shoulders and fasten to the top of trousers at the front and back to hold them up.
A pair of something, typically of birds or mammals killed in hunting.
noun.example: thirty brace of grouse

noun.definition: Either of the two marks { and }, used either to indicate that two or more items on one side have the same relationship as each other to the single item to which the other side points, or in pairs to show that words between them are connected.

verb.definition: Make (a structure) stronger or firmer with wood, iron, or other forms of support.
verb.example: the posts were braced by lengths of timber

brace.origin: Middle English (as a verb meaning ‘clasp, fasten tightly’): from Old French bracier ‘embrace’, from brace ‘two arms’, from Latin bracchia, plural of bracchium ‘arm’, from Greek brakhiōn.

noun.definition: Courageous behaviour or character.
noun.example: perhaps I'll get a medal for bravery

bravery.origin: Mid 16th century (in the sense ‘bravado’): from French braverie or Italian braveria ‘boldness’, based on Latin barbarus (see barbarous).

adjective.definition: Physically strong; muscular.
adjective.example: a great brawny brute

noun.definition: An act of breaking or failing to observe a law, agreement, or code of conduct.
noun.example: a breach of confidence

noun.definition: A gap in a wall, barrier, or defence, especially one made by an attacking army.
noun.example: a breach in the mountain wall

verb.definition: Make a gap in and break through (a wall, barrier, or defence)
verb.example: the river breached its bank

verb.definition: (of a whale) rise and break through the surface of the water.
verb.example: we saw whales breaching in the distance

breach.origin: Middle English from Old French breche, ultimately of Germanic origin; related to break.

noun.definition: A person or animal that breathes in a particular way.
noun.example: a heavy breather

noun.definition: A brief pause for rest.
noun.example: let's take a breather

noun.definition: A vent or valve to release pressure or to allow air to move freely around something.
noun.example: a cask breather

adjective.definition: Astonishing or awe-inspiring in quality, so as to take one's breath away.
adjective.example: the scene was one of breathtaking beauty

noun.definition: A kind of beer.
noun.example: small breweries which are able to offer rare brews

noun.definition: A cup or mug of tea or coffee.
noun.example: she took a sip of the hot reviving brew

noun.definition: A mixture of events, people, or things which interact to form a more potent whole.
noun.example: a dangerous brew of political turmoil and violent conflict

verb.definition: Make (beer) by soaking, boiling, and fermentation.
verb.example: within five years the company will brew as much beer in China as in Australia

verb.definition: Make (tea or coffee) by mixing it with hot water.
verb.example: I've just brewed some coffee

verb.definition: (of an unwelcome event or situation) begin to develop.
verb.example: there was more trouble brewing as the miners went on strike

noun.definition: A sum of money or other inducement offered or given to bribe someone.
noun.example: lawmakers were caught accepting bribes to bring in legalized gambling

verb.definition: Dishonestly persuade (someone) to act in one's favour by a gift of money or other inducement.

bribe.origin: Late Middle English from Old French briber, brimber ‘beg’, of unknown origin. The original sense was ‘rob, extort’, hence (as a noun) ‘theft, stolen goods’, also ‘money extorted or demanded for favours’, later ‘offer money as an inducement’ (early 16th century).

noun.definition: The giving or offering of a bribe.
noun.example: his opponent had been guilty of bribery and corruption

adjective.definition: Of or concerning a bride or a newly married couple.
adjective.example: her white bridal gown

bridal.origin: Late Middle English from Old English brȳd-ealu ‘wedding feast’, from brȳd ‘bride’ + ealu ‘ale-drinking’. Since the late 16th century, the word has been associated with adjectives ending in -al.

noun.definition: The projecting edge around the bottom of a hat.
noun.example: a soft hat with a turned-up brim

noun.definition: The upper edge or lip of a cup, bowl, or other container.
noun.example: he filled her glass to the brim

verb.definition: Be full to the point of overflowing.
verb.example: my eyes brimmed with tears

brim.origin: Middle English (denoting the edge of the sea or other body of water): perhaps related to German Bräme ‘trimming’.

noun.definition: The extreme edge of land before a steep slope or a body or water.
noun.example: the brink of the cliffs

adjective.definition: Active and energetic.
adjective.example: a good brisk walk

verb.definition: Quicken something.
verb.example: Mary brisked up her pace

brisk.origin: Late 16th century probably from French brusque (see brusque).

noun.definition: A person who buys and sells goods or assets for others.
noun.example: the centralized lenders operate through brokers

verb.definition: Arrange or negotiate (an agreement)
verb.example: fighting continued despite attempts to broker a ceasefire

adjective.definition: Savagely violent.
adjective.example: a brutal murder

brutal.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘relating to the lower animals’): from Old French, or from medieval Latin brutalis, from brutus ‘dull, stupid’ (see brute).

adjective.definition: Taking up much space; large and unwieldy.
adjective.example: a bulky carrier bag

noun.definition: A person who habitually seeks to harm or intimidate those whom they perceive as vulnerable.
noun.example: he is a ranting, domineering bully

verb.definition: Seek to harm, intimidate, or coerce (someone perceived as vulnerable)
verb.example: her 11- year-old son has been constantly bullied at school

bully.origin: Mid 16th century probably from Middle Dutch boele ‘lover’. Original use was as a term of endearment applied to either sex; it later became a familiar form of address to a male friend. The current sense dates from the late 17th century.

adjective.definition: Very good; excellent.
adjective.example: the statue really looked bully

bully.origin: Late 16th century (originally used of a person, meaning ‘admirable, gallant, jolly’): from bully. The current sense dates from the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: Corned beef.
An act of starting play in field hockey, in which two opponents strike each other's sticks three times and then go for the ball.

verb.definition: (in field hockey) start play with a bully.

bully.origin: Late 19th century (originally denoting a scrum in Eton football): of unknown origin.

adjective.definition: Of poor quality; bad or wrong.
adjective.example: not one bum note was played

noun.definition: A vagrant.
noun.example: bums had been known to wander up to their door and ask for a sandwich

noun.definition: A person who devotes a great deal of time to a specified activity.
noun.example: a ski bum

verb.definition: Travel with no particular purpose.

verb.definition: Get by asking or begging.
verb.example: they tried to bum quarters off us

noun.definition: A person's buttocks or anus.
noun.example: if you sit there you'll get a cold bum

bum.origin: Late Middle English of unknown origin.

noun.definition: An anchored float serving as a navigation mark, to show reefs or other hazards, or for mooring.

verb.definition: Keep (someone or something) afloat.
verb.example: the creatures could swim, both buoyed up and cooled by the water

verb.definition: Mark with a buoy.
verb.example: the wreck is often buoyed during summer months

noun.definition: A load, typically a heavy one.
The main theme or gist of a speech, book, or argument.
The refrain or chorus of a song.

verb.definition: Load heavily.
verb.example: she walked forwards burdened with a wooden box

burden.origin: Old English byrthen, of West Germanic origin; related to bear.

noun.definition: The action or practice of burying a dead body.
noun.example: his remains were shipped home for burial

burial.origin: Old English byrgels ‘place of burial, grave’ (interpreted as plural in Middle English, hence the loss of the final -s), of Germanic origin; related to bury.

adjective.definition: Placed or hidden underground.
adjective.example: buried treasure

noun.definition: An instance of breaking or splitting as a result of internal pressure or puncturing; an explosion.
noun.example: the mortar bursts were further away than before

noun.definition: A sudden brief outbreak.
noun.example: a burst of activity

noun.definition: A period of continuous and intense effort.
noun.example: he sailed 474 miles in one 24-hour burst

verb.definition: Break open or apart suddenly and violently, especially as a result of an impact or internal pressure.
verb.example: one of the balloons burst

verb.definition: Issue suddenly and uncontrollably.

verb.definition: Suddenly begin doing or producing something.
