verb.definition: Separate (continuous stationery) into single sheets.

burst.origin: Old English berstan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch bersten, barsten.

adjective.definition: (of a place) full of activity.
adjective.example: the bustling little town

noun.definition: Either of the two round fleshy parts of the human body that form the bottom.

buttock.origin: Old English buttuc, probably from the base of butt+ -ock.

noun.definition: An absurdly or surprisingly easy task.
noun.example: winning the league won't be a cakewalk for them

noun.definition: A dancing contest among black Americans in which a cake was awarded as a prize.

verb.definition: Achieve or win something easily.
verb.example: he cakewalked to a 5–1 triumph

verb.definition: Walk or dance in the manner of a cakewalk.
verb.example: a troupe of clowns cakewalked by

noun.definition: A young bovine animal, especially a domestic cow or bull in its first year.
noun.example: a heifer calf

noun.definition: A floating piece of ice detached from an iceberg.

calf.origin: Old English cælf, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kalf and German Kalb.

noun.definition: The fleshy part at the back of a person's leg below the knee.
noun.example: the calf muscles

calf.origin: Middle English from Old Norse kálfi, of unknown origin.

noun.definition: A cry made as a summons or to attract someone's attention.
noun.example: a nearby fisherman heard their calls for help

noun.definition: The characteristic cry of a bird or other animal.
noun.example: it is best distinguished by its call, a loud ‘pwit’

noun.definition: An instance of speaking to someone on the phone or attempting to contact someone by phone.
noun.example: I'll give you a call at around five

noun.definition: A brief visit, especially one made for social reasons.
noun.example: we paid a call on Ben and his family

noun.definition: An appeal or demand for something to happen or be done.
noun.example: the call for action was welcomed

noun.definition: An order or request for someone to be present.
noun.example: he was delighted that so many former players had heeded the call to attend the conference

noun.definition: (in sport) a decision or ruling made by an umpire or other official, traditionally conveyed by a shout, that the ball has gone out of play or that a rule has been breached.
noun.example: he was visibly irritated with the umpire's calls

noun.definition: A command to execute a subroutine.
noun.example: parameter values may be changed by calls to a special purpose input specification subroutine

noun.definition: A demand for payment of lent or unpaid capital.
(in a bar, club, etc.) denoting or made with relatively expensive brands of alcohol which customers request by name.
noun.example: try wines by the glass for $5, beer for $3, and call drinks for $8

verb.definition: Give (a baby or animal) a specified name.

verb.definition: Cry out (a word or words)
verb.example: he heard an insistent voice calling his name

verb.definition: Contact or attempt to contact (a person or number) by phone.
verb.example: could I call you back?

verb.definition: Order or request the attendance of.
verb.example: representatives of all three teams have been called to appear before the Monaco stewards

verb.definition: Announce or decide that (an event, especially a meeting, election, or strike) is to happen.
verb.example: there appeared to be no alternative but to call a general election

verb.definition: (of a person) pay a brief visit.

verb.definition: (of an umpire or other official in a game) pronounce (a ball, stroke, etc.) to be the thing specified.
verb.example: the linesman called the ball wide

verb.definition: Cause (a subroutine) to be executed.
verb.example: one subroutine may call another subroutine (or itself)

call.origin: Late Old English ceallian, from Old Norse kalla ‘summon loudly’.

noun.definition: A tall plant with a stiff upright stem, divided serrated leaves, and glandular hairs. It is used to produce hemp fibre and as a drug.
The practice of eating the flesh of one's own species.
noun.example: the film is quite disturbing at points with references to cannibalism

adjective.definition: Having or showing shrewdness and good judgement, especially in money or business matters.
adjective.example: canny investors will switch banks if they think they are getting a raw deal

adjective.definition: Pleasant; nice.

noun.definition: A deep gorge, typically one with a river flowing through it, as found in North America.

noun.definition: An instance of capsizing.
noun.example: do you know what to do in the event of a capsize?

verb.example: the craft capsized in heavy seas

adjective.definition: Imprisoned or confined.
adjective.example: the farm was used to hold prisoners of war captive

adjective.definition: (of a facility or service) controlled by, and typically for the sole use of, an organization.
adjective.example: a captive power plant

noun.definition: A person who has been taken prisoner or an animal that has been confined.

noun.definition: Sugar or syrup heated until it turns brown, used as a flavouring or colouring for food or drink or combined with butter or cream to form a thick, sweet sauce.
noun.example: a gateau frosted with caramel

noun.definition: A vehicle equipped for living in, typically towed by a car and used for holidays.
noun.example: they spent a fishing holiday in a caravan

noun.definition: A group of people, especially traders or pilgrims, travelling together across a desert in Asia or North Africa.

caravan.origin: Late 15th century (in caravan (sense 2)): from French caravane, from Persian kārwān. The sense ‘covered horse-drawn wagon’ dates from the early 19th century.

noun.definition: The aromatic seeds of a plant of the ginger family, used as a spice and also medicinally.
The SE Asian plant that bears cardamom seeds.

cardamom.origin: Late Middle English from Old French cardamome or Latin cardamomum, from Greek kardamōmon, from kardamon ‘cress’ + amōmon, the name of a kind of spice plant.

noun.definition: A person who makes and repairs wooden objects and structures.

verb.definition: Make by shaping wood.

carpenter.origin: Middle English from Anglo-Norman French, from Old French carpentier, charpentier, from late Latin carpentarius (artifex) ‘carriage (maker)’, from carpentum ‘wagon’, of Gaulish origin; related to car.

noun.definition: An act of carrying something from one place to another.
noun.example: we did a carry of equipment from the camp

noun.definition: The range of a gun or similar weapon.
The maintenance of an investment position in a securities market, especially with regard to the costs or profits accruing.
noun.example: if other short-term interest rates are higher than the current yield, the bond is said to involve a negative carry

verb.definition: Support and move (someone or something) from one place to another.
verb.example: medics were carrying a wounded man on a stretcher

verb.definition: Support the weight of.
verb.example: the bridge is capable of carrying even the heaviest loads

verb.definition: (of a sound, ball, missile, etc.) reach a specified point.
verb.example: his voice carried clearly across the room

verb.definition: Assume or accept (responsibility or blame)
verb.example: they must carry management responsibility for the mess they have got the company into

verb.definition: Have as a feature or consequence.
verb.example: being a combat sport, karate carries with it the risk of injury

verb.definition: Approve (a proposed measure) by a majority of votes.
verb.example: the resolution was carried by a two-to-one majority

carry.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French and Old Northern French carier, based on Latin carrus ‘wheeled vehicle’.

noun.definition: The starchy tuberous root of a tropical tree, used as food in tropical countries.
The shrubby tree from which cassava is obtained, native to tropical America and cultivated throughout the tropics.

cassava.origin: Mid 16th century from Taino casávi, cazábbi, influenced by French cassave.

noun.definition: An object made by pouring molten metal or other material into a mould.
noun.example: bronze castings

noun.definition: The removal of the testicles of a male animal or man.
noun.example: the castration of male calves was initiated to reduce fighting

noun.definition: A person killed or injured in a war or accident.
noun.example: the shelling caused thousands of civilian casualties

casualty.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘chance, a chance occurrence’): from medieval Latin casualitas, from casualis (see casual), on the pattern of words such as penalty.

noun.definition: An event causing great and usually sudden damage or suffering; a disaster.
noun.example: an environmental catastrophe

noun.definition: The denouement of a drama, especially a classical tragedy.
noun.example: This is an old insight, of course - as old as the domestic catastrophes of classical Greek drama.

catastrophe.origin: Mid 16th century (in the sense ‘denouement’): from Latin catastropha, from Greek katastrophē ‘overturning, sudden turn’, from kata- ‘down’ + strophē ‘turning’ (from strephein ‘to turn’).

adjective.definition: Involving or causing sudden great damage or suffering.
adjective.example: a catastrophic earthquake

categorically.example: Myanmar categorically denied the army's involvement in murder: মায়ানমার হত্যাকাণ্ডে সেনাবাহিনীর জড়িত থাকার বিষয়টি স্পষ্টভাবে অস্বীকার করেছে

adverb.definition: In a way that is unambiguously explicit and direct.
adverb.example: the rules state categorically, 'No Violence'

verb.definition: Provide people with food and drink at a social event or other gathering.
verb.example: my mother helped to cater for the party

verb.definition: Provide with what is needed or required.
verb.example: the school caters for children with learning difficulties

cater.origin: Late 16th century from obsolete cater ‘caterer’, from Old French acateor ‘buyer’, from acater ‘buy’ (see cate).

noun.definition: The provision of food and drink at a social event or other gathering.
noun.example: high standards of catering

noun.definition: The larva of a butterfly or moth, which has a segmented wormlike body with three pairs of true legs and several pairs of appendages similar to legs.

caterpillar.origin: Late Middle English perhaps from a variant of Old French chatepelose, literally ‘hairy cat’, influenced by obsolete piller ‘ravager’. The association with ‘cat’ is found in other languages, e.g. Swiss German Teufelskatz (literally ‘devil's cat’), Lombard gatta (literally ‘cat’). Compare with French chaton, English catkin, which resembles a hairy caterpillar.

verb.definition: Jump or dance around excitedly.
verb.example: the players cavorted about the pitch

verb.definition: Come or bring to an end.

cease.origin: Middle English from Old French cesser, from Latin cessare ‘stop’, from cedere ‘to yield’.

noun.definition: A large burial ground, especially one not in a churchyard.
noun.example: a military cemetery

cemetery.origin: Late Middle English via late Latin from Greek koimētērion ‘dormitory’, from koiman ‘put to sleep’.

noun.definition: A grain used for food, for example wheat, maize, or rye.
A breakfast food made from roasted grain, typically eaten with milk.
noun.example: a bowl of cereal

cereal.origin: Early 19th century (as an adjective): from Latin cerealis, from Ceres.

adverb.definition: Used to emphasize the speaker's belief that what is said is true.
adverb.example: the prestigious address certainly adds to the firm's appeal

adjective.definition: Relating to or denoting cetaceans.

noun.definition: A marine mammal of the order Cetacea; a whale, dolphin, or porpoise.
A repeated rhythmic phrase, typically one shouted or sung in unison by a crowd.
noun.example: a group of young people set up a chant of ‘Why are we waiting?’

noun.definition: A short musical passage in two or more phrases used for singing unmetrical words; a psalm or canticle sung to such music.

verb.definition: Say or shout repeatedly in a sing-song tone.
verb.example: protesters were chanting slogans

chant.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘sing’): from Old French chanter ‘sing’, from Latin cantare, frequentative of canere ‘sing’.

noun.definition: Complete disorder and confusion.
noun.example: snow caused chaos in the region

chaos.origin: Late 15th century (denoting a gaping void or chasm, later formless primordial matter): via French and Latin from Greek khaos ‘vast chasm, void’.

noun.definition: Either side of the face below the eye.
noun.example: tears rolled down her cheeks

noun.definition: Talk or behaviour regarded as rude or lacking in respect.
noun.example: he had the cheek to complain

verb.definition: Speak impertinently to.
verb.example: Frankie always got away with cheeking his elders

cheek.origin: Old English cē(a)ce, cēoce ‘cheek, jaw’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch kaak.

verb.definition: Protect and care for (someone) lovingly.
verb.example: he needed a woman he could cherish

cherish.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘treat with affection’): from Old French cheriss-, lengthened stem of cherir, from cher ‘dear’, from Latin carus.

adjective.definition: Chilly.
adjective.example: the chill grey dawn

adjective.definition: Very relaxed or easy-going.
adjective.example: in general, I am a pretty chill guy

noun.definition: An unpleasant feeling of coldness in the atmosphere, one's surroundings, or the body.
noun.example: there was a chill in the air

noun.definition: A metal mould, often cooled, designed to ensure rapid or even cooling of metal during casting.
noun.example: Thus, dry sand cores often are used in green sand molds, and metal chills can be used in sand molds to accelerate local cooling.

verb.definition: Make (someone) cold.
verb.example: they were chilled by a sudden wind

verb.definition: Horrify or frighten (someone)
verb.example: the city was chilled by the violence

verb.definition: Calm down and relax.
verb.example: they like to get home, have a bath, and chill out

chill.origin: Old English cele, ciele ‘cold, coldness’, of Germanic origin; related to cold.

noun.definition: A downward cutting blow or movement, typically with the hand.
noun.example: an effective chop to the back of the neck

noun.definition: A thick slice of meat, especially pork or lamb, adjacent to and often including a rib.
noun.example: he lived on liver or chops

noun.definition: A person's share of something.
Crushed or ground grain used as animal feed.
noun.example: the pile of chop was dropped into the calves' feeder

noun.definition: The broken motion of water, owing to the action of the wind against the tide.
noun.example: we started our run into a two-foot chop

verb.definition: Cut (something) into pieces with repeated sharp blows of an axe or knife.
verb.example: they chopped up the pulpit for firewood

verb.definition: Abolish or reduce the size of (something) in a way regarded as ruthless.
verb.example: their training courses are to be chopped

chop.origin: Late Middle English variant of chap.

verb.definition: Change one's opinions or behaviour repeatedly and abruptly.
verb.example: teachers are fed up with having to chop and change with every twist in government policy

chop.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘barter, exchange’): perhaps related to Old English cēap ‘bargaining, trade’; compare with chap- in chapman.

noun.definition: A trademark; a brand of goods.

chop.origin: Early 19th century from Hindi chāp ‘stamp, brand’ (see chaap).

noun.definition: A quiet or suppressed laugh.
noun.example: Melissa gave a chuckle

verb.definition: Laugh quietly or inwardly.
verb.example: I chuckled at the astonishment on her face

chuckle.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘laugh convulsively’): from chuck meaning ‘to cluck’ in late Middle English.

noun.definition: A close friend.
noun.example: she shared the cake with her chums

noun.definition: Used as a friendly or familiar form of address between men or boys.
noun.example: it's your own fault, chum

verb.definition: Form a friendship with someone.
verb.example: his sister chummed up with Sally

chum.origin: Late 17th century (originally Oxford University slang, denoting a room-mate): probably short for chamber-fellow. Compare with comrade and crony.

noun.definition: Chopped fish and other material thrown overboard as angling bait.
noun.example: the anglers anchored down and put out their blood chum

verb.definition: Fish using chum as bait.
verb.example: chumming is always a must when flounder fishing

noun.definition: A large North Pacific salmon that is commercially important as a food fish.

chum.origin: Early 20th century from Chinook Jargon tzum (samun), literally ‘spotted (salmon)’.

noun.definition: An aromatic spice made from the peeled, dried, and rolled bark of a SE Asian tree.
noun.example: a teaspoon of ground cinnamon

noun.definition: The tree which yields cinnamon.
noun.example: A Daoist tradition in China holds that the source of immortality, or at least long life, is the cinnamon tree in the moon, a tree that no amount of chopping can fell.

cinnamon.origin: Late Middle English from Old French cinnamome (from Greek kinnamōmon), and Latin cinnamon (from Greek kinnamon), both from a Semitic language and perhaps based on Malay.

noun.definition: The enclosing boundary of a curved geometric figure, especially a circle.

circumference.origin: Late Middle English from Old French circonference, from Latin circumferentia, from circum ‘around, about’ + ferre ‘carry, bear’.

noun.definition: A citation.

verb.definition: Refer to (a passage, book, or author) as evidence for or justification of an argument or statement, especially in a scholarly work.
verb.example: authors who are highly regarded by their peers tend to be cited

verb.definition: Praise (someone, typically a member of the armed forces) in an official report for a courageous act.
verb.example: he has been cited many times for his contributions in the intelligence area

verb.definition: Summon (someone) to appear in court.
verb.example: the writ cited only four of the signatories of the petition

cite.origin: Late Middle English (in cite (sense 3 of the verb), originally with reference to a court of ecclesiastical law): from Old French citer, from Latin citare, from ciere, cire ‘to call’.

noun.definition: Formal politeness and courtesy in behaviour or speech.
noun.example: I hope we can treat each other with civility and respect

civility.origin: Late Middle English from Old French civilite, from Latin civilitas, from civilis ‘relating to citizens’ (see civil). In early use the term denoted the state of being a citizen and hence good citizenship or orderly behaviour. The sense ‘politeness’ arose in the mid 16th century.

noun.definition: An act of striking together the palms of the hands.
noun.example: when they stop I give them a clap

noun.definition: An explosive sound, especially of thunder.
noun.example: a clap of thunder echoed through the valley

verb.definition: Strike the palms of (one's hands) together repeatedly, typically in order to applaud someone or something.
verb.example: Agnes clapped her hands in glee
synonyms: give someone a round of applause

verb.definition: Slap (someone) encouragingly on the back or shoulder.
verb.example: as they parted, he clapped Owen on the back

clap.origin: Old English clappan ‘throb, beat’, of imitative origin. clap (sense 1 of the verb) dates from late Middle English.

noun.definition: A venereal disease, especially gonorrhoea.
noun.example: she has given him the clap

clap.origin: Late 16th century from Old French clapoir ‘venereal bubo’.

noun.definition: A violent confrontation.
noun.example: there have been minor clashes with security forces

noun.definition: A mismatch of colours.
noun.example: a clash of tweeds and a striped shirt

noun.definition: A loud jarring sound, as of metal objects being struck together.
noun.example: a clash of cymbals

verb.definition: Meet and come into violent conflict.
verb.example: protestors demanding self-rule clashed with police

verb.definition: (of colours) appear discordant or ugly when placed close to each other.
verb.example: the yellow shirt clashed with her purple skirt

verb.definition: Strike (cymbals) together, producing a loud discordant sound.

noun.definition: A continuous rattling sound as of hard objects falling or striking each other.
noun.example: the horse spun round with a clatter of hooves

verb.definition: Make or cause to make a continuous rattling sound.
verb.example: her coffee cup clattered in the saucer

clatter.origin: Old English (as a verb), of imitative origin.

noun.definition: A unit of grammatical organization next below the sentence in rank and in traditional grammar said to consist of a subject and predicate.
A particular and separate article, stipulation, or proviso in a treaty, bill, or contract.

clause.origin: Middle English via Old French clause, based on Latin claus- ‘shut, closed’, from the verb claudere.

noun.definition: A sharp division; a split.
noun.example: the old cleavage between the forces of the right and left

noun.definition: The hollow between a woman's breasts when supported, especially as exposed by a low-cut garment.
noun.example: Holly and Bridget checked their cleavages and rearranged their hair

adjective.definition: Relating to the observation and treatment of actual patients rather than theoretical or laboratory studies.
adjective.example: clinical medicine

adjective.definition: Very efficient and without feeling; coldly detached.
adjective.example: nothing was left to chance—everything was clinical

clinical.origin: Late 18th century from Greek klinikē ‘bedside’ (see clinic) + -al.

noun.definition: A group of similar things or people positioned or occurring closely together.
noun.example: clusters of creamy-white flowers

verb.definition: Form a cluster or clusters.
verb.example: the children clustered round her skirts

cluster.origin: Old English clyster; probably related to clot.

adjective.definition: (in sport) denoting or occurring at a critical situation in which the outcome of a game or competition is at stake.
adjective.example: they both are hard-nosed players who seem to thrive in clutch situations

noun.definition: A tight grasp.
noun.example: she made a clutch at his body

noun.definition: A mechanism for connecting and disconnecting an engine and the transmission system in a vehicle, or the working parts of any machine.
noun.example: she let the clutch in and the car surged forward

noun.definition: A clutch bag.

verb.definition: Grasp (something) tightly.
verb.example: he stood clutching a microphone

clutch.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘bend, crook’): variant of obsolete clitch ‘close the hand’, from Old English clyccan ‘crook, clench’, of Germanic origin.

noun.definition: A group of eggs fertilized at the same time, laid in a single session and (in birds) incubated together.
noun.example: they lay fewer than ten eggs in a clutch

clutch.origin: Early 18th century probably a southern variant of northern English dialect cletch, related to Middle English cleck ‘to hatch’, from Old Norse klekja.

adjective.definition: Relating to cognition.
adjective.example: the cognitive processes involved in reading

cognitive.origin: Late 16th century from medieval Latin cognitivus, from cognit- ‘known’, from the verb cognoscere.

noun.definition: Knowledge or awareness.
noun.example: the Renaissance cognizance of Greece was limited

noun.definition: A distinctive emblem or badge formerly worn by retainers of a noble house.

cognizance.origin: Middle English conisance, from Old French conoisance, based on Latin cognoscere ‘get to know’. The spelling with g, influenced by Latin, arose in the 15th century and gradually affected the pronunciation.

noun.definition: Sexual intercourse.

coitus.origin: Mid 19th century from Latin, from coire ‘go together’ (see coition).

noun.definition: The main structural protein found in skin and other connective tissues, widely used in purified form for cosmetic surgical treatments.
noun.example: vitamin C plays a vital role in the formation of collagen

collagen.origin: Mid 19th century from French collagène, from Greek kolla ‘glue’ + French -gène (see -gen).

noun.definition: An instance of a structure falling down or giving way.
noun.example: the collapse of a railway bridge

verb.definition: (of a structure) suddenly fall down or give way.
verb.example: the roof collapsed on top of me

verb.definition: (of a person) fall down and become unconscious as a result of illness or injury.
verb.example: he collapsed from loss of blood

verb.definition: Fail suddenly and completely.
verb.example: the talks collapsed last week over territorial issues

verb.definition: Fold or be foldable into a small space.
verb.example: some cots collapse down to fit into a holdall

collapse.origin: Early 17th century (as collapsed): from medical Latin collapsus, past participle of collabi, from col- ‘together’ + labi ‘to slip’.

adjective.definition: Additional but subordinate; secondary.
adjective.example: the collateral meanings of a word

adjective.definition: Descended from the same stock but by a different line.
adjective.example: a collateral descendant of Robert Burns

adjective.definition: Situated side by side; parallel.
adjective.example: collateral veins

noun.definition: Something pledged as security for repayment of a loan, to be forfeited in the event of a default.
noun.example: she put her house up as collateral for the bank loan

noun.definition: A person having the same ancestor as another but through a different line.
noun.example: A few days later, two powerful Sandhanvalia Sardars, Atar Singh and Ajit Singh, collaterals of the royal contenders for the throne, arrived in Lahore and took over control.

collateral.origin: Late Middle English (as an adjective): from medieval Latin collateralis, from col- ‘together with’ + lateralis (from latus, later- ‘side’). collateral (sense 1 of the noun) (originally US) is from the phrase collateral security, denoting something pledged in addition to the main obligation of a contract.

verb.definition: Hit by accident when moving.
verb.example: she collided with someone

collide.origin: Early 17th century (in the sense ‘cause to collide’): from Latin collidere, from col- ‘together’ + laedere ‘to strike’.

noun.definition: A procedure in which a flexible fibre-optic instrument is inserted through the anus in order to examine the colon.
noun.example: a colonoscopy did not show any problem

noun.definition: Fighting between armed forces.
noun.example: five Hurricanes were shot down in combat

verb.definition: Take action to reduce or prevent (something bad or undesirable)
verb.example: an effort to combat drug trafficking

combat.origin: Mid 16th century (originally denoting a fight between two people or parties): from French combattre (verb), from late Latin combattere, from com- ‘together with’ + battere, variant of Latin batuere ‘to fight’.

noun.definition: Semen ejaculated at an orgasm.

preposition.definition: When a specified time is reached or event happens.
preposition.example: I don't think that they'll be far away from honours come the new season

verb.definition: Move or travel towards or into a place thought of as near or familiar to the speaker.
verb.example: Jess came into the kitchen

verb.definition: Occur; happen; take place.
verb.example: twilight had not yet come

verb.definition: Take or occupy a specified position in space, order, or priority.
verb.example: prisons come well down the list of priorities

verb.definition: Pass into a specified state, especially one of separation or disunion.
verb.example: his shirt had come undone

verb.definition: Be sold, available, or found in a specified form.
verb.example: the cars come with a variety of extras

verb.definition: Have an orgasm.

come.origin: Old English cuman, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch komen and German kommen.

adjective.definition: Deserving praise.
adjective.example: he showed commendable restraint

commendable.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin commendabilis, from commendare (see commend).

commuter.bengali: যে ব্যক্তি পরিবহনসংস্থাদির যানবাহনে যাতায়াত করে; নিত্যযাত্রী

noun.definition: A person who travels some distance to work on a regular basis.
noun.example: a fault on the line caused widespread delays for commuters

verb.definition: Force or oblige (someone) to do something.
verb.example: a sense of duty compelled Harry to answer her questions

compel.origin: Late Middle English from Latin compellere, from com- ‘together’ + pellere ‘drive’.

adjective.definition: Evoking interest, attention, or admiration in a powerfully irresistible way.
adjective.example: his eyes were strangely compelling

verb.definition: Give (someone) something, typically money, in recognition of loss, suffering, or injury incurred; recompense.
verb.example: payments were made to farmers to compensate them for cuts in subsidies

verb.definition: Reduce or counteract (something unwelcome or unpleasant) by exerting an opposite force or effect.
verb.example: the manager is hoping for victory to compensate for the team's dismal league campaign

compensate.origin: Mid 17th century (in the sense ‘counterbalance’): from Latin compensat- ‘weighed against’, from the verb compensare, from com- ‘together’ + pensare (frequentative of pendere ‘weigh’).

noun.definition: Something, typically money, awarded to someone in recognition of loss, suffering, or injury.
noun.example: he is seeking compensation for injuries suffered at work

noun.definition: The process of concealing or offsetting a psychological difficulty by developing in another direction.
The money received by an employee from an employer as a salary or wages.
noun.example: send your CV and current compensation to Executive Search Consultant

compensation.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin compensatio(n-), from the verb compensare ‘weigh against’ (see compensate).

noun.definition: A plaintiff in certain lawsuits.

complainant.origin: Late Middle English from French complaignant, present participle of complaindre ‘to lament’ (see complain).

noun.definition: A statement that something is unsatisfactory or unacceptable.
noun.example: I intend to make an official complaint

noun.definition: An illness or medical condition, especially a relatively minor one.
noun.example: she is receiving treatment for her skin complaint

complaint.origin: Late Middle English from Old French complainte, feminine past participle of complaindre ‘to lament’ (see complain).

noun.definition: A thing that contributes extra features to something else in such a way as to improve or emphasize its quality.
noun.example: local ales provide the perfect complement to fine food

noun.definition: A number or quantity of something, especially that required to make a group complete.
noun.example: at the moment we have a full complement of staff

noun.definition: One or more words, phrases, or clauses governed by a verb (or by a nominalization or a predicative adjective) that complete the meaning of the predicate. In generative grammar, all the constituents of a sentence that are governed by a verb form the complement.
A group of proteins present in blood plasma and tissue fluid which combine with an antigen–antibody complex to bring about the lysis of foreign cells.

verb.definition: Contribute extra features to (someone or something) in such a way as to improve or emphasize their qualities.
verb.example: a classic blazer complements a look that's smart or casual

complement.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘completion’): from Latin complementum, from complere ‘fill up’ (see complete). Compare with compliment.

adjective.definition: Combining in such a way as to enhance or emphasize the qualities of each other or another.
adjective.example: they had different but complementary skills

adjective.definition: Relating to complementary medicine.
adjective.example: complementary therapies such as aromatherapy

adjective.definition: Disposed to agree with others or obey rules, especially to an excessive degree; acquiescent.
adjective.example: a compliant labour force

adjective.definition: Meeting or in accordance with rules or standards.
adjective.example: food that is compliant with safety regulations

adjective.definition: Having the property of compliance.
adjective.example: the conversion of the gel to a much less compliant, rigid glass

verb.definition: Act in accordance with a wish or command.
verb.example: we are unable to comply with your request

comply.origin: Late 16th century from Italian complire, Catalan complir, Spanish cumplir, from Latin complere ‘fill up, fulfil’ (see complete). The original sense was ‘fulfil, accomplish’, later ‘fulfil the requirements of courtesy’, hence ‘to be agreeable, to oblige or obey’. Compare with compliment.

adjective.definition: Able to be understood; intelligible.
adjective.example: clear and comprehensible English

comprehensible.origin: Late 15th century from French compréhensible or Latin comprehensibilis, from comprehens- ‘seized, comprised’, from the verb comprehendere (see comprehend).

noun.definition: An agreement or settlement of a dispute that is reached by each side making concessions.
noun.example: eventually they reached a compromise

noun.definition: The expedient acceptance of standards that are lower than is desirable.
noun.example: sexism should be tackled without compromise

verb.definition: Settle a dispute by mutual concession.
verb.example: in the end we compromised and deferred the issue

verb.definition: Expediently accept standards that are lower than is desirable.
verb.example: we were not prepared to compromise on safety

verb.definition: Bring into disrepute or danger by indiscreet, foolish, or reckless behaviour.
verb.example: situations in which his troops could be compromised

compromise.origin: Late Middle English (denoting mutual consent to arbitration): from Old French compromis, from late Latin compromissum ‘a consent to arbitration’, neuter past participle of compromittere, from com- ‘together’ + promittere (see promise).

noun.definition: The action of conceiving a child or of one being conceived.
noun.example: an unfertilized egg before conception

noun.definition: The forming or devising of a plan or idea.
noun.example: the time between a product's conception and its launch

conception.origin: Middle English via Old French from Latin conceptio(n-), from the verb concipere (see conceive).

verb.definition: Bring or come to an end.
verb.example: they conclude their study with these words

verb.definition: Arrive at a judgement or opinion by reasoning.
verb.example: the doctors concluded that Esther had suffered a stroke

conclude.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘convince’): from Latin concludere, from con- ‘completely’ + claudere ‘to shut’.

adjective.definition: (of evidence or argument) having or likely to have the effect of proving a case; decisive.
adjective.example: conclusive evidence
synonyms: beyond a shadow of a doubt

conclusive.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘summing up’): from late Latin conclusivus, from Latin conclus- ‘closed up’, from the verb concludere (see conclusion).

noun.definition: Temporary unconsciousness or confusion and other symptoms caused by a blow on the head.
noun.example: he was carried off the pitch with concussion

noun.definition: A violent shock as from a heavy blow.
noun.example: the ground shuddered with the concussion of the blast

concussion.origin: Late Middle English from Latin concussio(n-), from the verb concutere ‘dash together, shake’ (see concuss).

verb.definition: Express complete disapproval of; censure.
verb.example: most leaders roundly condemned the attack

verb.definition: Sentence (someone) to a particular punishment, especially death.
verb.example: the rebels had been condemned to death

condemn.origin: Middle English (in condemn (sense 2)): from Old French condemner, from Latin condemnare, from con- (expressing intensive force) + damnare ‘inflict loss on’ (see damn).

noun.definition: An attitude of patronizing superiority; disdain.
noun.example: a tone of condescension

noun.definition: The manner in which a person behaves, especially in a particular place or situation.
noun.example: they were arrested for disorderly conduct

noun.definition: The manner in which an organization or activity is managed or directed.
noun.example: the conduct of the elections

verb.definition: Organize and carry out.
verb.example: in the second trial he conducted his own defence

verb.definition: Lead or guide (someone) to or around a particular place.
verb.example: he conducted us through his personal gallery of the Civil War

verb.definition: Transmit (a form of energy such as heat or electricity) by conduction.
verb.example: heat is conducted to the surface

verb.definition: Direct the performance of (a piece of music or an orchestra, choir, etc.)
verb.example: the concert is to be conducted by Sir Simon Rattle

verb.definition: Behave in a specified way.
verb.example: he conducted himself with the utmost propriety

conduct.origin: Middle English from Old French, from Latin conduct- ‘brought together’, from the verb conducere. The term originally denoted a provision for safe passage, surviving in safe conduct; later the verb sense ‘lead, guide’ arose, hence ‘manage’ and ‘management’ (late Middle English), later ‘management of oneself, behaviour’ (mid 16th century). The original form of the word was conduit, which was preserved only in the sense ‘channel’ (see conduit); in other uses the spelling was influenced by Latin.

verb.definition: Grant (a title, degree, benefit, or right)
verb.example: the Minister may have exceeded the powers conferred on him by Parliament

verb.definition: Have discussions; exchange opinions.
verb.example: the officials were conferring with allies

confer.origin: Late Middle English (in the general sense ‘bring together’, also in confer (sense 2)): from Latin conferre, from con- ‘together’ + ferre ‘bring’.

verb.definition: Admit that one has committed a crime or done something wrong.
verb.example: he confessed that he had attacked the old man

confess.origin: Late Middle English from Old French confesser, from Latin confessus, past participle of confiteri ‘acknowledge’, from con- (expressing intensive force) + fateri ‘declare, avow’.

adjective.definition: (of speech or writing) in which a person reveals private thoughts or admits to past incidents, especially ones about which they feel ashamed or embarrassed.
adjective.example: the autobiography is remarkably confessional

adjective.definition: Relating to confessions of faith or doctrinal systems.
adjective.example: the confessional approach to religious education

noun.definition: An enclosed stall in a church divided by a screen or curtain in which a priest sits to hear confessions.
noun.example: the secrets of the confessional

noun.definition: An acknowledgement that one has done something shameful or embarrassing; a confession.
noun.example: tabloid confessionals

confessional.origin: Late Middle English (as an adjective): the adjective from confession+ -al; the noun via French from Italian confessionale, from medieval Latin, neuter of confessionalis, from Latin confessio(n-), from confiteri ‘acknowledge’ (see confess).

noun.definition: The feeling or belief that one can have faith in or rely on someone or something.
noun.example: we had every confidence in the staff

noun.definition: The telling of private matters or secrets with mutual trust.
noun.example: someone with whom you may raise your suspicions in confidence

confidence.origin: Late Middle English from Latin confidentia, from confidere ‘have full trust’ (see confident).

adjective.definition: Intended to be kept secret.
adjective.example: confidential information

noun.definition: The borders or boundaries of a place, especially with regard to their restricting freedom of movement.
noun.example: within the confines of the hall escape was difficult

verb.definition: Keep or restrict someone or something within certain limits of (space, scope, or time)
verb.example: he does not confine his message to high politics

confine.origin: Late Middle English (as a noun): from French confins (plural noun), from Latin confinia, from confinis ‘bordering’, from con- ‘together’ + finis ‘end, limit’ (plural fines ‘territory’). The verb senses are from French confiner, based on Latin confinis.

verb.definition: Take or seize (someone's property) with authority.
verb.example: the guards confiscated his camera

confiscate.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin confiscat- ‘put away in a chest, consigned to the public treasury’, from the verb confiscare, based on con- ‘together’ + fiscus ‘chest, treasury’.

noun.definition: A hostile or argumentative situation or meeting between opposing parties.
noun.example: a confrontation with the legislature

noun.definition: The state of being congested.
noun.example: the new bridge should ease congestion in the area

congestion.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin congestio(n-), from congere ‘heap up’, from con- ‘together’ + gerere ‘bring’.

noun.definition: The subjugation and assumption of control of a place or people by military force.
noun.example: the conquest of the Aztecs by the Spanish

conquest.origin: Middle English from Old French conquest(e), based on Latin conquirere (see conquer).

noun.definition: Permission for something to happen or agreement to do something.
noun.example: no change may be made without the consent of all the partners

verb.definition: Give permission for something to happen.
verb.example: he consented to a search by a detective

consent.origin: Middle English from Old French consente (noun), consentir (verb), from Latin consentire, from con- ‘together’ + sentire ‘feel’.

noun.definition: A result or effect, typically one that is unwelcome or unpleasant.
noun.example: abrupt withdrawal of drug treatment can have serious consequences

noun.definition: Importance or relevance.
noun.example: the past is of no consequence

noun.definition: A game in which a narrative is made up by the players in turn, each ignorant of what has already been contributed.

consequence.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin consequentia, from consequent- ‘following closely’, from the verb consequi.

adjective.definition: Notably large in size, amount, or extent.
adjective.example: a position of considerable influence

considerable.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘capable of being considered’): from medieval Latin considerabilis ‘worthy of consideration’, from Latin considerare (see consider).

adverb.definition: By a notably large amount or to a notably large extent; greatly.
adverb.example: things have improved considerably over the last few years

noun.definition: A member of a Mafia family who serves as an adviser to the leader and resolves disputes within the family.

consigliere.origin: Italian, literally ‘a member of a council’.

noun.definition: A batch of goods destined for or delivered to someone.
noun.example: a consignment of drugs

noun.definition: A secret plan by a group to do something unlawful or harmful.
noun.example: a conspiracy to destroy the government

conspiracy.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French conspiracie, alteration of Old French conspiration, based on Latin conspirare ‘agree, plot’ (see conspire).

verb.definition: Make secret plans jointly to commit an unlawful or harmful act.
verb.example: they conspired against him

conspire.origin: Late Middle English from Old French conspirer, from Latin conspirare ‘agree, plot’, from con- ‘together with’ + spirare ‘breathe’.

adjective.definition: Affected with constipation.
adjective.example: regular heroin users can become constipated

constipated.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin constipat- ‘crowded or pressed together’, from the verb constipare, from con- ‘together’ + stipare ‘press, cram’.

verb.definition: Have or hold (someone or something) within.
verb.example: the cigarettes were thought to contain cannabis

verb.definition: Control or restrain (oneself or a feeling)
verb.example: he must contain his hatred

contain.origin: Middle English from Old French contenir, from Latin continere, from con- ‘altogether’ + tenere ‘to hold’.

adjective.definition: Having been made impure by exposure to or addition of a poisonous or polluting substance.
adjective.example: contaminated blood products

verb.definition: Look thoughtfully for a long time at.
verb.example: he contemplated his image in the mirrors

contemplate.origin: Late 16th century from Latin contemplat- ‘surveyed, observed, contemplated’, from the verb contemplari, based on templum ‘place for observation’.

adjective.definition: Living or occurring at the same time.
adjective.example: the event was recorded by a contemporary historian

adjective.definition: Belonging to or occurring in the present.
adjective.example: the tension and complexities of our contemporary society

noun.definition: A person or thing living or existing at the same time as another.
noun.example: he was a contemporary of Darwin

contemporary.origin: Mid 17th century from medieval Latin contemporarius, from con- ‘together with’ + tempus, tempor- ‘time’ (on the pattern of Latin contemporaneus and late Latin contemporalis).

noun.definition: The feeling that a person or a thing is worthless or beneath consideration.
noun.example: Pam stared at the girl with total contempt

contempt.origin: Late Middle English from Latin contemptus, from contemnere (see contemn).

adjective.definition: Deserving contempt; despicable.
adjective.example: a display of contemptible cowardice

contemptible.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, or from late Latin contemptibilis, from Latin contemnere (see contemn).

adjective.definition: In a state of peaceful happiness.
adjective.example: he seemed more content, less bitter

noun.definition: A state of satisfaction.
noun.example: the greater part of the century was a time of content

noun.definition: A member of the British House of Lords who votes for a particular motion.
noun.example: The chairman of the committee said he was disappointed at the prospect of the contents of the house leaving the country.

verb.definition: Satisfy (someone)
verb.example: nothing would content her apart from going off to Barcelona

content.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin contentus ‘satisfied’, past participle of continere (see contain).

noun.definition: The things that are held or included in something.
noun.example: she unscrewed the top of the flask and drank the contents

content.origin: Late Middle English from medieval Latin contentum (plural contenta ‘things contained’), neuter past participle of continere (see contain).

noun.definition: Heated disagreement.
noun.example: the captured territory was the main area of contention between the two countries

noun.definition: An assertion, especially one maintained in argument.
noun.example: Freud's contention that all dreams were wish fulfilment

contention.origin: Late Middle English from Latin contentio(n-), from contendere ‘strive with’ (see contend).

noun.definition: An event in which people compete for supremacy in a sport or other activity, or in a quality.
noun.example: a tennis contest

verb.definition: Engage in competition to attain (a position of power)
verb.example: she declared her intention to contest the presidency

verb.definition: Oppose (an action or theory) as mistaken or wrong.
verb.example: the former chairman contests his dismissal

contest.origin: Late 16th century (as a verb in the sense ‘swear to, attest’): from Latin contestari ‘call upon to witness, initiate (by calling witnesses)’, from con- ‘together’ + testare ‘to witness’. The senses ‘wrangle, struggle for’ arose in the early 17th century, whence the current noun and verb senses.

context.example: To put this in context: এ প্রসঙ্গে উল্লেখ্য

noun.definition: The circumstances that form the setting for an event, statement, or idea, and in terms of which it can be fully understood.
noun.example: the proposals need to be considered in the context of new European directives

context.origin: Late Middle English (denoting the construction of a text): from Latin contextus, from con- ‘together’ + texere ‘to weave’.

adjective.definition: Depending on or relating to the circumstances that form the setting for an event, statement, or idea.
adjective.example: he included contextual information in footnotes

adjective.definition: Imported or exported illegally, either in defiance of a total ban or without payment of duty.
adjective.example: contraband brandy

noun.definition: Goods that have been imported or exported illegally.
noun.example: customs men had searched the carriages for contraband

contraband.origin: Late 16th century from Spanish contrabanda, from Italian contrabando, from contra- ‘against’ + bando ‘proclamation, ban’.

noun.definition: The state of being strikingly different from something else in juxtaposition or close association.
noun.example: the day began cold and blustery, in contrast to almost two weeks of uninterrupted sunshine

verb.definition: Differ strikingly.
verb.example: his friend's success contrasted with his own failure

contrast.origin: Late 17th century (as a term in fine art, in the sense ‘juxtapose so as to bring out differences in form and colour’): from French contraste (noun), contraster (verb), via Italian from medieval Latin contrastare, from Latin contra- ‘against’ + stare ‘stand’.

adjective.definition: Giving rise or likely to give rise to controversy or public disagreement.
adjective.example: years of wrangling over a controversial bypass

controversial.origin: Late 16th century from late Latin controversialis, from controversia (see controversy).

noun.definition: Prolonged public disagreement or heated discussion.
noun.example: the design of the building has caused controversy

controversy.origin: Late Middle English from Latin controversia, from controversus ‘turned against, disputed’, from contro- (variant of contra- ‘against’) + versus, past participle of vertere ‘to turn’.

noun.definition: The state of being able to proceed with something without difficulty.
noun.example: services should be run to suit the convenience of customers, not of staff

noun.definition: A public toilet.
noun.example: the large council car park next to the public conveniences

convenience.origin: Late Middle English from Latin convenientia, from convenient- ‘assembling, agreeing’, from the verb convenire (see convene).

adjective.definition: Based on or in accordance with what is generally done or believed.
adjective.example: a conventional morality had dictated behaviour

adjective.definition: (of a bid) intended to convey a particular meaning according to an agreed convention.
adjective.example: West made a conventional bid showing a hand with at least 5 spades

conventional.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘relating to a formal agreement or convention’): from French conventionnel or late Latin conventionalis, from Latin conventio(n-) ‘meeting, covenant’, from the verb convenire (see convene).

noun.definition: A person found guilty of a criminal offence and serving a sentence of imprisonment.
noun.example: two escaped convicts kidnapped them at gunpoint

verb.definition: Declare (someone) to be guilty of a criminal offence by the verdict of a jury or the decision of a judge in a court of law.
verb.example: the theives were convicted of the robbery

convict.origin: Middle English from Latin convict- ‘demonstrated, refuted, convicted’, from the verb convincere (see convince). The noun is from obsolete convict ‘convicted’.

noun.definition: A formal declaration by the verdict of a jury or the decision of a judge in a court of law that someone is guilty of a criminal offence.
noun.example: she had a previous conviction for a similar offence

noun.definition: A firmly held belief or opinion.
noun.example: she takes pride in stating her political convictions

conviction.origin: Late Middle English from Latin convictio(n-), from the verb convincere (see convince).

verb.definition: Cause (someone) to believe firmly in the truth of something.
verb.example: Robert's expression had obviously convinced her of his innocence

convince.origin: Mid 16th century (in the sense ‘overcome, defeat in argument’): from Latin convincere, from con- ‘with’ + vincere ‘conquer’. Compare with convict.

adjective.definition: Capable of causing someone to believe that something is true or real.
adjective.example: there is no convincing evidence that advertising influences total alcohol consumption

noun.definition: A police officer.
noun.example: a cop in a patrol car gave chase

noun.definition: Shrewdness; practical intelligence.
noun.example: he had the cop-on to stay clear of Hugh Thornley

verb.definition: Catch or arrest (an offender)
verb.example: he was copped for speeding

verb.definition: Receive or attain (something welcome)
verb.example: she copped an award for her role in the film

verb.definition: Strike (an attitude or pose)
verb.example: I copped an attitude—I acted real tough

cop.origin: Early 18th century (as a verb): perhaps from obsolete cap ‘arrest’, from Old French caper ‘seize’, from Latin capere. The noun is from copper.

noun.definition: A conical mass of thread wound on to a spindle.

cop.origin: Late 18th century possibly from Old English cop ‘summit, top’.

noun.definition: Brown coins of low value made of copper or bronze.
A large copper or iron container for boiling laundry.
A reddish-brown colour like that of copper.
noun.example: she had copper-coloured hair

noun.definition: A small butterfly with bright reddish-brown wings.

verb.definition: Cover or coat (something) with copper.
verb.example: some iron hulls were sheathed with wood and then coppered

copper.origin: Old English copor, coper (related to Dutch koper and German Kupfer), based on late Latin cuprum, from Latin cyprium aes ‘Cyprus metal’ (so named because Cyprus was the chief source).

noun.definition: A police officer.
A line or circle of police, soldiers, or guards preventing access to or from an area or building.
noun.example: the crowd was halted in front of the police cordon

noun.definition: A fruit tree trained to grow as a single stem.
A projecting course of brick or stone on the face of a wall.

verb.definition: Prevent access to or from an area or building by surrounding it with police or other guards.
verb.example: the city centre was cordoned off after fires were discovered in two stores

cordon.origin: Late Middle English (denoting an ornamental braid): from Italian cordone, augmentative of corda, and French cordon, diminutive of corde, both from Latin chorda ‘string, rope’ (see cord). cordon (sense 3 of the noun), the earliest of the current noun senses, dates from the early 18th century.

noun.definition: A rank of non-commissioned officer in the army, above lance corporal or private first class and below sergeant.
another term for fallfish

corporal.origin: Mid 16th century from French, obsolete variant of caporal, from Italian caporale, probably based on Latin corpus, corpor- ‘body (of troops)’, with a change of spelling in Italian due to association with capo ‘head’.

adjective.definition: Relating to the human body.

corporal.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin corporalis, from corpus, corpor- ‘body’.

noun.definition: A cloth on which the chalice and paten are placed during the celebration of the Eucharist.

corporal.origin: Middle English from medieval Latin corporale (pallium) ‘body (cloth)’, from Latin corpus, corpor- ‘body’.

noun.definition: A dead body, especially of a human being rather than an animal.
noun.example: the corpse of a man lay there

verb.definition: Spoil a piece of acting by forgetting one's lines or laughing uncontrollably.
verb.example: Peter just can't stop himself corpsing when he is on stage

corpse.origin: Middle English (denoting the living body of a person or animal): alteration of corse by association with Latin corpus, a change which also took place in French (Old French cors becoming corps). The p was originally silent, as in French; the final e was rare before the 19th century, but now distinguishes corpse from corps.

adjective.definition: Corresponding.
adjective.example: However, correspondent payment can involve payment between two banks in the same jurisdiction, if payment is to be in foreign currency.

noun.definition: A person who writes letters on a regular basis.
noun.example: she wasn't much of a correspondent

noun.definition: A person employed to report for a newspaper or broadcasting organization.
noun.example: a cricket correspondent

correspondent.origin: Late Middle English (as an adjective): from Old French correspondant or medieval Latin correspondent- ‘corresponding’, from the verb correspondere (see correspond).

noun.definition: Advice, especially that given formally.
noun.example: with wise counsel a couple can buy a home that will be appreciating in value

noun.definition: A barrister or other legal adviser conducting a case.
noun.example: the counsel for the defence

verb.definition: Give advice to (someone)
verb.example: careers officers should counsel young people in making their career decisions

counsel.origin: Middle English via Old French counseil (noun), conseiller (verb), from Latin consilium ‘consultation, advice’, related to consulere (see consult). Compare with council.

noun.definition: A person or thing that corresponds to or has the same function as another person or thing in a different place or situation.
noun.example: the minister held talks with his French counterpart

noun.definition: One of two copies of a legal document.

noun.example: he was overthrown in an army coup

noun.definition: An instance of successfully achieving something difficult.
noun.example: it was a major coup to get such a prestigious contract

noun.definition: A direct pocketing of the cue ball, which is a foul stroke.
(among some North American Indian peoples) an act of touching an armed enemy in battle as a deed of bravery, or an act of first touching an item of the enemy's in order to claim it.

coup.origin: Late 18th century from French, from medieval Latin colpus ‘blow’ (see cope).

noun.definition: The ability to do something that frightens one; bravery.
noun.example: she called on all her courage to face the ordeal

courage.origin: Middle English (denoting the heart, as the seat of feelings): from Old French corage, from Latin cor ‘heart’.

noun.example: she will take the matter to court

noun.definition: A quadrangular area, either open or covered, marked out for ball games such as tennis or squash.
noun.example: a squash court

noun.definition: The courtiers, retinue, and household of a sovereign.
noun.example: the emperor is shown with his court

noun.definition: The qualified members of a company or a corporation.
noun.example: The decision on the succession rests with the nomination committee of the court of directors.

verb.definition: Be involved with (someone) romantically, with the intention of marrying.
verb.example: he was courting a girl from the neighbouring farm

verb.definition: Pay special attention to (someone) in an attempt to win their support or favour.
verb.example: Western politicians courted the leaders of the newly independent states

court.origin: Middle English from Old French cort, from Latin cohors, cohort- ‘yard or retinue’. The verb is influenced by Old Italian corteare, Old French courtoyer. Compare with cohort.

noun.definition: The showing of politeness in one's attitude and behaviour towards others.
noun.example: he treated the players with courtesy and good humour

noun.definition: A curtsy.

courtesy.origin: Middle English from Old French cortesie, from corteis (see courteous).

noun.definition: A baby's bed or cot, typically one mounted on rockers.
noun.example: the baby slept peacefully in its cradle

noun.definition: A framework on which a ship or boat rests during construction or repairs.

verb.definition: Hold gently and protectively.
verb.example: she cradled his head in her arms

verb.definition: Place (a telephone receiver) in its cradle.
verb.example: she cradled the receiver gently

cradle.origin: Old English cradol, of uncertain origin; perhaps related to German Kratte ‘basket’.

noun.definition: An activity involving skill in making things by hand.
noun.example: the craft of cobbling

noun.definition: Skill used in deceiving others.
noun.example: her cousin was not her equal in guile and evasive craft

noun.definition: A boat or ship.
noun.example: sailing craft

verb.definition: Exercise skill in making (an object), typically by hand.
verb.example: he crafted the chair lovingly

craft.origin: Old English cræft ‘strength, skill’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kracht, German Kraft, and Swedish kraft ‘strength’. craft (sense 3 of the noun), originally in the expression small craft ‘small trading vessels’, may be elliptical, referring to vessels requiring a small amount of ‘craft’ or skill to handle, as opposed to large ocean-going ships.

verb.definition: Completely fill (a place or container) to the point of overflowing.
verb.example: the ashtray by the bed was crammed with cigarette butts

verb.definition: Study intensively over a short period of time just before an examination.
verb.example: lectures were called off so students could cram for the semester finals

cram.origin: Old English crammian, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch krammen ‘to cramp or clamp’.

adjective.definition: Extremely poor in quality.

noun.definition: Something of extremely poor quality.
Excrement.

verb.definition: Defecate.
Talk at length in a foolish or boring way.

crap.origin: Late Middle English related to Dutch krappe, from krappen ‘pluck or cut off’, and perhaps also to Old French crappe ‘siftings’, Anglo-Latin crappa ‘chaff’. The original sense was ‘chaff’, later ‘residue from rendering fat’, also ‘dregs of beer’. Current senses date from the late 19th century.

noun.definition: A losing throw of 2, 3, or 12 in craps.

verb.definition: Make a losing throw at craps.
verb.example: he put all his chips on the table and rolled the dice—sooner or later he had to crap out

noun.definition: An act of moving on one's hands and knees or dragging one's body along the ground.
noun.example: they began the crawl back to their own lines

noun.definition: A swimming stroke involving alternate overarm movements and rapid kicks of the legs.
noun.example: she could do the crawl and so many other strokes

verb.definition: Move forward on the hands and knees or by dragging the body close to the ground.
verb.example: they crawled from under the table

verb.definition: Behave obsequiously or ingratiatingly in the hope of gaining someone's favour.
verb.example: a reporter's job can involve crawling to objectionable people
synonyms: try to get on the good side of

verb.definition: Be covered or crowded with (insects or people), to an extent that is objectionable.
verb.example: the floor was dirty and crawling with bugs

verb.definition: (of a program) systematically visit (a number of web pages) in order to create an index of data.
verb.example: its automated software robots crawl websites, grabbing copies of pages to index

crawl.origin: Middle English of unknown origin; possibly related to Swedish kravla and Danish kravle.

adjective.definition: Able to be believed; convincing.
adjective.example: few people found his story credible

credible.origin: Late Middle English from Latin credibilis, from credere ‘believe’.

noun.definition: A detestable person.
noun.example: I thought he was a nasty little creep

noun.definition: Slow steady movement, especially when imperceptible.
noun.example: an attempt to prevent this slow creep of costs

noun.definition: An opening in a hedge or wall for an animal to pass through.
noun.example: low in the wall are creeps, through which ewes gain access to grazing from the pastures behind

noun.definition: Solid food given to young farm animals in order to wean them.
noun.example: we've started to wean the lambs earlier and to keep them on creep

verb.definition: Move slowly and carefully in order to avoid being heard or noticed.
verb.example: he crept downstairs, hardly making any noise

verb.definition: (of a negative characteristic or fact) occur or develop gradually and almost imperceptibly.
verb.example: errors crept into his game

creep.origin: Old English crēopan ‘move with the body close to the ground’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kruipen. Sense 1 of the verb dates from Middle English.

adjective.definition: Causing an unpleasant feeling of fear or unease.
adjective.example: the creepy feelings one often gets in a strange house

adjective.definition: Of a rich deep red colour inclining to purple.
adjective.example: she blushed crimson with embarrassment

noun.definition: A rich deep red colour inclining to purple.
noun.example: a pair of corduroy trousers in livid crimson, they were horrid to behold

verb.definition: (of a person's face) become flushed, especially through embarrassment.
verb.example: my face crimsoned and my hands began to shake

crimson.origin: Late Middle English from obsolete French cramoisin or Old Spanish cremesin, based on Arabic qirmizī, from qirmiz (see kermes). Compare with carmine.

adjective.definition: Wilfully causing pain or suffering to others, or feeling no concern about it.
adjective.example: people who are cruel to animals

verb.definition: Spoil or ruin (an opportunity or a chance of success)
verb.example: Ernie nearly cruelled the whole thing by laughing

cruel.origin: Middle English via Old French from Latin crudelis, related to crudus (see crude).

noun.definition: A voyage on a ship or boat taken for pleasure or as a holiday and usually calling in at several places.
noun.example: a cruise down the Nile

verb.definition: Sail about in an area without a precise destination, especially for pleasure.
verb.example: they were cruising off the California coast

verb.definition: (of a motor vehicle or aircraft) travel smoothly at a moderate or economical speed.
verb.example: we sit in a jet, cruising at some 30,000 ft

verb.definition: (of a young child) walk while holding on to furniture or other structures, prior to learning to walk without support.
verb.example: my daughter cruised at seven months and didn't walk until just after her first birthday

cruise.origin: Mid 17th century (as a verb): probably from Dutch kruisen ‘to cross’, from kruis ‘cross’, from Latin crux.

noun.definition: A loud muffled grinding sound like that of something hard or brittle being crushed.
noun.example: Marco's fist struck Brian's nose with a crunch

noun.definition: A crucial point or situation, typically one at which a decision with important consequences must be made.
noun.example: when it comes to the crunch you chicken out

noun.definition: A physical exercise designed to strengthen the abdominal muscles; a sit-up.

verb.definition: Crush (a hard or brittle foodstuff) with the teeth, making a loud but muffled grinding sound.
verb.example: she paused to crunch a ginger biscuit

verb.definition: (especially of a computer) process (large quantities of information)
verb.example: the program crunches data from 14,000 sensors to decipher evolving patterns

crunch.origin: Early 19th century (as a verb): variant of 17th-century cranch (probably imitative), by association with crush and munch.

noun.definition: A long, green-skinned fruit with watery flesh, usually eaten raw in salads or pickled.
The climbing plant of the gourd family that yields cucumbers, native to the Chinese Himalayan region. It is widely cultivated but very rare in the wild.

cucumber.origin: Late Middle English from Old French cocombre, coucombre, from Latin cucumis, cucumer-.

noun.definition: A thing said or done that serves as a signal to an actor or other performer to enter or to begin their speech or performance.
noun.example: she had not yet been given her cue to come out on to the dais

noun.definition: A facility for playing through an audio or video recording very rapidly until a desired starting point is reached.

verb.definition: Give a cue to or for.
verb.example: Ros and Guil, cued by Hamlet, also bow deeply

verb.definition: Set a piece of audio or video equipment in readiness to play (a particular part of the recorded material)
verb.example: there was a pause while she cued up the next tape

noun.definition: A long straight tapering wooden rod for striking the ball in snooker, billiards, etc.

verb.definition: Use a cue to strike the ball.
verb.example: Mark cued well early on

cue.origin: Mid 18th century (denoting a long plait or pigtail): variant of queue.

noun.definition: A style or method of cooking, especially as characteristic of a particular country, region, or establishment.
noun.example: much Venetian cuisine is based on seafood

cuisine.origin: Late 18th century French, literally ‘kitchen’, from Latin coquina, from coquere ‘to cook’.

noun.definition: Responsibility for a fault or wrong; blame.
noun.example: a level of moral culpability

noun.definition: A person who is responsible for a crime or other misdeed.
noun.example: the car's front nearside door had been smashed in but the culprits had fled

culprit.origin: Late 17th century (originally in the formula Culprit, how will you be tried?, said by the Clerk of the Crown to a prisoner pleading not guilty): perhaps from a misinterpretation of the written abbreviation cul. prist for Anglo-Norman French Culpable: prest d'averrer notre bille ‘(You are) guilty: (We are) ready to prove our indictment’; in later use influenced by Latin culpa ‘fault, blame’.

noun.definition: The aromatic seeds of a plant of the parsley family, used as a spice, especially ground and used in curry powder.
noun.example: add a pinch of cumin

noun.definition: The small, slender plant which bears cumin seeds, occurring from the Mediterranean to central Asia.
noun.example: Yarrow, alyssum, fennel, cumin, & coriander all attract beneficial insects as well.

cumin.origin: Old English cymen, from Latin cuminum, from Greek kuminon, probably of Semitic origin and related to Hebrew kammōn and Arabic kammūn; superseded in Middle English by forms from Old French cumon, comin, also from Latin.

noun.definition: A check or restraint on something.
noun.example: plans to introduce tougher curbs on insider dealing

noun.definition: variant spelling of kerb
A swelling on the back of a horse's hock, caused by spraining a ligament.

verb.definition: Restrain or keep in check.
verb.example: she promised she would curb her temper

verb.definition: Lead (a dog being walked) near the curb to urinate or defecate, in order to avoid soiling buildings, pavements, etc.

curb.origin: Late 15th century (denoting a strap fastened to the bit): from Old French courber ‘bend, bow’, from Latin curvare (see curve).

noun.definition: A solemn utterance intended to invoke a supernatural power to inflict harm or punishment on someone or something.
noun.example: she'd put a curse on him

noun.definition: An offensive word or phrase used to express anger or annoyance.
noun.example: at every blow there was a curse

verb.definition: Invoke or use a curse against.
verb.example: it often seemed as if the family had been cursed

verb.definition: Utter offensive words in anger or annoyance.
verb.example: he cursed loudly as he burned his hand
synonyms: take the Lord's name in vain

adjective.definition: Hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed.
adjective.example: a cursory glance at the figures

cursory.origin: Early 17th century from Latin cursorius ‘of a runner’, from cursor (see cursor).

noun.definition: The protective care or guardianship of someone or something.
noun.example: the property was placed in the custody of a trustee

noun.definition: Imprisonment.
noun.example: my father was being taken into custody

custody.origin: Late Middle English from Latin custodia, from custos ‘guardian’.

cutie pie.bengali: Someone who is pretty and makes you laugh and pokes you every once in a while
cutie pie.example: The girl I like is my cutie pie.

cynical.example: "I have to say from the experience of the last 10 to 12 days, the russian engagement in the minsk process is rather cynical," british foreign secretary philip hammond said in the estonian capital tallinn.

adjective.definition: Believing that people are motivated purely by self-interest; distrustful of human sincerity or integrity.
adjective.example: he was brutally cynical and hardened to every sob story under the sun

adjective.definition: Concerned only with one's own interests and typically disregarding accepted standards in order to achieve them.
adjective.example: a cynical manipulation of public opinion

verb.definition: Make (someone) feel intimidated or apprehensive.
verb.example: some people are daunted by technology

daunt.origin: Middle English from Old French danter, from Latin domitare, frequentative of domare ‘to tame’.

adjective.definition: Seeming difficult to deal with in prospect; intimidating.
adjective.example: a daunting task

noun.definition: A situation, typically one involving opposing parties, in which no progress can be made.
noun.example: an attempt to break the deadlock

noun.definition: A type of lock requiring a key to open and close it, as distinct from a spring lock.

verb.definition: Cause (a situation or opposing parties) to come to a point where no progress can be made because of fundamental disagreement.
verb.example: the meeting is deadlocked

verb.definition: Secure (a door) with a deadlock.
verb.example: you can deadlock any exit door from the outside

adjective.definition: Lacking the power of hearing or having impaired hearing.
adjective.example: I'm a bit deaf so you'll have to speak up

deaf.origin: Old English dēaf, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch doof and German taub, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek tuphlos ‘blind’.

noun.definition: A sum of money that is owed or due.
noun.example: I paid off my debts

debt.origin: Middle English dette from Old French, based on Latin debitum ‘something owed’, past participle of debere ‘owe’. The spelling change in French and English was by association with the Latin word.

adjective.definition: Recently dead.
adjective.example: the deceased man's family

noun.definition: The recently dead person in question.
noun.example: the judge inferred that the deceased was confused as to the extent of his assets

verb.definition: Deliberately cause (someone) to believe something that is not true, especially for personal gain.
verb.example: I didn't intend to deceive people into thinking it was French champagne

deceive.origin: Middle English from Old French deceivre, from Latin decipere ‘catch, ensnare, cheat’.

adjective.definition: Conforming with generally accepted standards of respectable or moral behaviour.
adjective.example: a decent clean-living individual

adjective.definition: Of an acceptable standard; satisfactory.
adjective.example: people need decent homes

decent.origin: Mid 16th century (in the sense ‘suitable, appropriate’): from Latin decent- ‘being fitting’, from the verb decere.

noun.definition: A gradual and continuous loss of strength, numbers, quality, or value.
noun.example: a serious decline in bird numbers

verb.definition: (typically of something regarded as good) become smaller, fewer, or less; decrease.
verb.example: the birth rate continued to decline

verb.definition: Politely refuse (an invitation or offer)
verb.example: Caroline declined the coffee

verb.definition: (especially of the sun) move downwards.
verb.example: the sun began to creep round to the west and to decline

verb.definition: (in the grammar of Latin, Greek, and certain other languages) state the forms of (a noun, pronoun, or adjective) corresponding to case, number, and gender.

decline.origin: Late Middle English from Old French decliner, from Latin declinare ‘bend down, turn aside’, from de- ‘down’ + clinare ‘to bend’.

adjective.definition: Becoming smaller, fewer, or less; decreasing.
adjective.example: declining budgets

verb.definition: Regard or consider in a specified way.
verb.example: the event was deemed a great success

deem.origin: Old English dēman (also in the sense ‘act as judge’), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch doeman, also to doom.

defamation.example: The defamation case filed against the barguna uno

noun.definition: The action of damaging the good reputation of someone; slander or libel.
noun.example: she sued him for defamation

adjective.definition: (of remarks, writing, etc.) damaging the good reputation of someone; slanderous or libellous.
adjective.example: a defamatory allegation

noun.definition: Failure to fulfil an obligation, especially to repay a loan or appear in a law court.
noun.example: the company will have to restructure its debts to avoid default

noun.definition: A preselected option adopted by a computer program or other mechanism when no alternative is specified by the user or programmer.
noun.example: the default is fifty lines

verb.definition: Fail to fulfil an obligation, especially to repay a loan or to appear in a law court.
verb.example: the dealer could repossess the goods if the customer defaulted

verb.definition: (of a computer program or other mechanism) revert automatically to (a preselected option)
verb.example: when you start a fresh letter the system will default to its own style

default.origin: Middle English from Old French defaut, from defaillir ‘to fail’, based on Latin fallere ‘disappoint, deceive’.

noun.definition: An instance of defeating or being defeated.
noun.example: a 1–0 defeat by Grimsby

verb.definition: Win a victory over (someone) in a battle or other contest; overcome or beat.
verb.example: Garibaldi defeated the Neapolitan army

defeat.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘undo, destroy, annul’): from Old French desfait ‘undone’, past participle of desfaire, from medieval Latin disfacere ‘undo’.

verb.definition: Discharge faeces from the body.

defecate.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘clear of dregs, purify’): from Latin defaecat- ‘cleared of dregs’, from the verb defaecare, from de- (expressing removal) + faex, faec- ‘dregs’. The current sense dates from the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: A lack or shortage.
noun.example: deficiencies in material resources

verb.definition: Damage the purity or appearance of; mar or spoil.
verb.example: the land was defiled by a previous owner

defile.origin: Late Middle English alteration of obsolete defoul, from Old French defouler ‘trample down’, influenced by obsolete befile ‘befoul, defile’.

noun.definition: A steep-sided narrow gorge or passage (originally one requiring troops to march in single file)
noun.example: the twisting track wormed its way up a defile to level ground

verb.definition: (of troops) march in single file.
verb.example: we emerged after defiling through the mountainsides

defile.origin: Late 17th century from French défilé (noun), défiler (verb), from dé ‘away from’ + file ‘column, file’.

noun.definition: The action or process of deflecting or being deflected.
noun.example: the deflection of the light beam
