deflection.origin: Early 17th century from late Latin deflexio(n-), from deflectere ‘bend away’ (see deflect).

noun.definition: A person sent or authorized to represent others, in particular an elected representative sent to a conference.
noun.example: congress delegates rejected the proposals

verb.definition: Entrust (a task or responsibility) to another person, typically one who is less senior than oneself.
verb.example: she must delegate duties so as to free herself for more important tasks

delegate.origin: Late Middle English from Latin delegatus ‘sent on a commission’, from the verb delegare, from de- ‘down’ + legare ‘depute’.

noun.definition: A body of delegates or representatives; a deputation.
noun.example: a delegation of teachers

noun.definition: The action or process of delegating or being delegated.
noun.example: the delegation of power to the district councils

delegation.origin: Early 17th century (denoting the action or process of delegating; also in the sense ‘delegated power’): from Latin delegatio(n-), from delegare ‘send on a commission’ (see delegate).

noun.definition: Great pleasure.
noun.example: the little girls squealed with delight

verb.definition: Please (someone) greatly.
verb.example: an experience guaranteed to delight both young and old

delight.origin: Middle English from Old French delitier (verb), delit (noun), from Latin delectare ‘to charm’, frequentative of delicere. The -gh- was added in the 16th century by association with light.

noun.definition: Minor crime, especially that committed by young people.
noun.example: social causes of crime and delinquency

noun.definition: Neglect of one's duty.
noun.example: he relayed this in such a manner as to imply grave delinquency on the host's part

delinquency.origin: Mid 17th century from ecclesiastical Latin delinquentia, from Latin delinquent- ‘offending’ (see delinquent).

noun.definition: A severe flood.
noun.example: this may be the worst deluge in living memory

verb.definition: Overwhelm with a flood.
verb.example: caravans were deluged by the heavy rains

deluge.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, variant of diluve, from Latin diluvium, from diluere ‘wash away’.

noun.definition: A demonstration of a product or technique.
noun.example: a cookery demo

noun.definition: A public meeting or march protesting against something or expressing views on a political issue.
noun.example: a peace demo

verb.definition: Record (a song or piece of music) to demonstrate the capabilities of a musical group or performer or as preparation for a full recording.
verb.example: they've already demoed twelve new songs

verb.definition: Demonstrate the capabilities of (software or another product)
verb.example: Apple is expected to demo the newest version of its mobile operating system at the conference next week

demo.origin: Early 20th century abbreviation of demonstration and demonstrate.

noun.definition: short for demographic
noun.example: both channels managed to maintain ratings among young male demos

noun.definition: The study of statistics such as births, deaths, income, or the incidence of disease, which illustrate the changing structure of human populations.

demography.origin: Mid 19th century from Greek dēmos ‘the people’ + -graphy.

noun.definition: An act of showing that something exists or is true by giving proof or evidence.
noun.example: his demonstration of the need for computer corpora in language study is convincing

noun.definition: A practical exhibition and explanation of how something works or is performed.
noun.example: a microwave cookery demonstration

noun.definition: A public meeting or march protesting against something or expressing views on a political issue.
noun.example: a pro-democracy demonstration

demonstration.origin: Late Middle English (also in the senses ‘proof provided by logic’ and ‘sign, indication’): from Latin demonstratio(n-), from demonstrare ‘point out’ (see demonstrate). demonstration (sense 3) dates from the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: The action of denying something.
noun.example: she shook her head in denial

verb.definition: State that one refuses to admit the truth or existence of.
verb.example: both firms deny any responsibility for the tragedy

verb.definition: Refuse to give (something requested or desired) to (someone)
verb.example: the inquiry was denied access to intelligence sources

deny.origin: Middle English from Old French deni-, stressed stem of deneier, from Latin denegare, from de- ‘formally’ + negare ‘say no’.

verb.definition: Leave, especially in order to start a journey.
verb.example: they departed for Germany

depart.origin: Middle English from Old French departir, based on Latin dispertire ‘to divide’. The original sense was ‘separate’, also ‘take leave of each other’, hence ‘go away’.

noun.definition: The action of deporting a foreigner from a country.
noun.example: asylum seekers facing deportation

verb.definition: Remove from office suddenly and forcefully.
verb.example: he had been deposed by a military coup

verb.definition: Testify to or give (evidence) under oath, typically in a written statement.
verb.example: every affidavit shall state which of the facts deposed to are within the deponent's knowledge

depose.origin: Middle English from Old French deposer, from Latin deponere (see deponent), but influenced by Latin depositus and Old French poser ‘to place’.

verb.definition: Express disapproval of.
verb.example: what I deprecate is persistent indulgence

verb.definition: another term for depreciate (sense 2)
verb.example: he deprecates the value of children's television

deprecate.origin: Early 17th century (in the sense ‘pray against’): from Latin deprecat- ‘prayed against (as being evil)’, from the verb deprecari, from de- (expressing reversal) + precari ‘pray’.

noun.definition: Feelings of severe despondency and dejection.
noun.example: self-doubt creeps in and that swiftly turns to depression

noun.definition: A long and severe recession in an economy or market.
noun.example: the depression in the housing market

noun.definition: The action of lowering something or pressing something down.
noun.example: depression of the plunger delivers two units of insulin

noun.definition: A region of lower atmospheric pressure, especially a cyclonic weather system.
noun.example: hurricanes start off as loose regions of bad weather known as tropical depressions

noun.definition: The angular distance of an object below the horizon or a horizontal plane.

depression.origin: Late Middle English from Latin depressio(n-), from deprimere ‘press down’ (see depress).

verb.definition: Prevent (a person or place) from having or using something.
verb.example: the city was deprived of its water supplies

deprive.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘depose from office’): from Old French depriver, from medieval Latin deprivare, from de- ‘away, completely’ + privare (see private).

noun.definition: Contemptuous ridicule or mockery.
noun.example: my stories were greeted with derision and disbelief

derision.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from late Latin derisio(n-), from deridere ‘scoff at’.

verb.definition: Obtain something from (a specified source)
verb.example: they derived great comfort from this assurance

derive.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘draw a fluid through or into a channel’): from Old French deriver or Latin derivare, from de- ‘down, away’ + rivus ‘brook, stream’.

adjective.definition: Showing a critical or disrespectful attitude.
adjective.example: she tells me I'm fat and is always making derogatory remarks

derogatory.origin: Early 16th century (in the sense ‘impairing in force or effect’): from late Latin derogatorius, from derogat- ‘abrogated’, from the verb derogare (see derogate).

descend.example: Flood water has already started descending in many districts

verb.definition: Move or fall downwards.
verb.example: the aircraft began to descend

verb.definition: (of a road, path, or flight of steps) slope or lead downwards.
verb.example: a side road descended into the forest

verb.definition: Make a sudden attack on.
verb.example: the militia descended on Rye

verb.definition: Be a blood relative of (a specified ancestor)
verb.example: John Dalrymple was descended from an ancient Ayrshire family

descend.origin: Middle English from Old French descendre, from Latin descendere, from de- ‘down’ + scandere ‘to climb’.

adjective.definition: Appointed to an office or post but not yet installed.
adjective.example: the Director designate

verb.definition: Appoint (someone) to a specified office or post.
verb.example: he was designated as prime minister

designate.origin: Mid 17th century (as an adjective): from Latin designatus ‘designated’, past participle of designare, based on signum ‘a mark’.

noun.definition: A strong feeling of wanting to have something or wishing for something to happen.
noun.example: he resisted public desires for choice in education

verb.definition: Strongly wish for or want (something)
verb.example: he never achieved the status he so desired

desire.origin: Middle English from Old French desir (noun), desirer (verb), from Latin desiderare (see desiderate).

adjective.definition: Feeling or showing a hopeless sense that a situation is so bad as to be impossible to deal with.
adjective.example: a desperate sadness enveloped Ruth

adjective.definition: (of a person) having a great need or desire for something.
adjective.example: I am desperate for a cigarette

desperate.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘in despair’): from Latin desperatus ‘deprived of hope’, past participle of desperare (see despair).

noun.definition: A state of despair, typically one which results in rash or extreme behaviour.
noun.example: she wrote to him in desperation

desperation.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, from Latin desperatio(n-), from the verb desperare (see despair).

adjective.definition: Deserving hatred and contempt.
adjective.example: a despicable crime

despicable.origin: Mid 16th century from late Latin despicabilis, from despicari ‘look down on’.

noun.definition: Contemptuous treatment or behaviour; outrage.
noun.example: the despite done by him to the holy relics

noun.definition: Contempt; disdain.
noun.example: the theatre only earns my despite

preposition.definition: Without being affected by; in spite of.
preposition.example: he remains a great leader despite age and infirmity

despite.origin: Middle English (originally used as a noun meaning ‘contempt, scorn’ in the phrase in despite of): from Old French despit, from Latin despectus ‘looking down on’, past participle (used as a noun) of despicere (see despise).

verb.definition: Upset the stability of (a region or system); cause unrest or instability in.
verb.example: the accused were charged with conspiracy to destabilize the country

verb.definition: Keep (someone) from proceeding by holding them back or making claims on their attention.
verb.example: she made to open the door, but he detained her

detain.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘be afflicted with sickness or infirmity’): from Old French detenir, from a variant of Latin detinere, from de- ‘away, aside’ + tenere ‘to hold’.

noun.definition: The action of detaining someone or the state of being detained in official custody.
noun.example: the fifteen people arrested were still in police detention

detention.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘withholding of what is claimed or due’): from late Latin detentio(n-), from Latin detinere ‘hold back’ (see detain).

verb.definition: Become progressively worse.
verb.example: relations between the countries had deteriorated sharply

deteriorate.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘make worse’): from late Latin deteriorat- ‘worsened’, from the verb deteriorare, from Latin deterior ‘worse’.

verb.definition: Explode or cause to explode.
verb.example: two other bombs failed to detonate

detonate.origin: Early 18th century from Latin detonat- ‘thundered down or forth’, from the verb detonare, from de- ‘down’ + tonare ‘to thunder’.

adjective.definition: Highly destructive or damaging.
adjective.example: a devastating cyclone

noun.definition: A clause in a will leaving something, especially real estate, to someone.
noun.example: The issue, however, is whether the language of the devise of the Somerset Estate can fairly be interpreted so as to include the rights under the s. 2 reverter.

verb.definition: Plan or invent (a complex procedure, system, or mechanism) by careful thought.
verb.example: a training programme should be devised

verb.definition: Leave (something, especially real estate) to someone by the terms of a will.
verb.example: All the residue of my estate, including real and personal property, I give, devise, and bequeath to Earlham College.

devise.origin: Middle English the verb from Old French deviser, from Latin divis- ‘divided’, from the verb dividere (this sense being reflected in the original English sense of the verb); the noun is a variant of device (in the early sense ‘will, desire’).

verb.definition: Eat (food or prey) hungrily or quickly.
verb.example: he devoured half of his burger in one bite

devour.origin: Middle English from Old French devorer, from Latin devorare, from de- ‘down’ + vorare ‘to swallow’.

noun.definition: An order or principle that must be obeyed.
noun.example: the dictates of fashion

verb.definition: State or order authoritatively.
verb.example: the tsar's attempts to dictate policy

verb.definition: Say or read aloud (words to be typed, written down, or recorded on tape)
verb.example: I have four letters to dictate

dictate.origin: Late 16th century (in dictate (sense 2 of the verb)): from Latin dictat- ‘dictated’, from the verb dictare.

adjective.definition: Relating to or provided by diet.
adjective.example: dietary advice for healthy skin and hair

noun.definition: A regulated or restricted diet.

dietary.origin: Late Middle English (as a noun): from medieval Latin dietarium, from Latin diaeta (see diet).

noun.definition: The state or quality of being worthy of honour or respect.
noun.example: the dignity of labour

noun.definition: A composed or serious manner or style.
noun.example: he bowed with great dignity

dignity.origin: Middle English from Old French dignete, from Latin dignitas, from dignus ‘worthy’.

adjective.definition: (of a building or object) in a state of disrepair or ruin as a result of age or neglect.
adjective.example: old, dilapidated buildings

noun.definition: A situation in which a difficult choice has to be made between two or more alternatives, especially ones that are equally undesirable.
noun.example: he wants to make money, but he also disapproves of it: Den's dilemma in a nutshell

dilemma.origin: Early 16th century (denoting a form of argument involving a choice between equally unfavourable alternatives): via Latin from Greek dilēmma, from di- ‘twice’ + lēmma ‘premise’.

noun.definition: A person who cultivates an area of interest, such as the arts, without real commitment or knowledge.
noun.example: a wealthy literary dilettante

dilettante.origin: Mid 18th century from Italian, ‘person loving the arts’, from dilettare ‘to delight’, from Latin delectare.

adjective.definition: Extremely serious or urgent.
adjective.example: misuse of drugs can have dire consequences

adjective.definition: Of a very poor quality.
adjective.example: the concert was dire

dire.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin dirus ‘fearful, threatening’.

adjective.definition: Extending or moving from one place to another without changing direction or stopping.
adjective.example: there was no direct flight that day

adjective.definition: Without intervening factors or intermediaries.
adjective.example: the complications are a direct result of bacteria spreading

adjective.definition: (of a person or their behaviour) going straight to the point; frank.
adjective.example: he is very direct and honest

adjective.definition: Perpendicular to a surface; not oblique.
adjective.example: a direct butt joint between surfaces of steel

adverb.definition: With no one or nothing in between.
adverb.example: they seem reluctant to deal with me direct

verb.definition: Control the operations of; manage or govern.
verb.example: an economic elite directed the nation's affairs

verb.definition: Aim (something) in a particular direction or at a particular person.
verb.example: heating ducts to direct warm air to rear-seat passengers

verb.definition: Give (someone) an official order or authoritative instruction.
verb.example: the judge directed him to perform community service

direct.origin: Late Middle English from Latin directus, past participle of dirigere, from di- ‘distinctly’ or de- ‘down’ + regere ‘put straight’.

noun.definition: The board of directors of a company.
A section of a government department in charge of a particular activity.
noun.example: the Food Safety Directorate

verb.definition: Cease to be visible.
verb.example: he disappeared into the trees

disappear.origin: Late Middle English from dis- (expressing reversal) + appear, on the pattern of French disparaître.

verb.definition: Pay out (money from a fund)
verb.example: $67 million of the pledged aid had already been disbursed

disburse.origin: Mid 16th century from Old French desbourser, from des- (expressing removal) + bourse ‘purse’.

noun.definition: The payment of money from a fund.
noun.example: they established a committee to supervise the disbursement of aid

noun.definition: A thing rejected as no longer useful or desirable.

verb.definition: Get rid of (someone or something) as no longer useful or desirable.
verb.example: Hilary bundled up the clothes she had discarded

discard.origin: Late 16th century (originally in the sense ‘reject (a playing card’)): from dis- (expressing removal) + the noun card.

verb.definition: Make (secret or new information) known.
verb.example: they disclosed her name to the press

disclose.origin: Late Middle English from Old French desclos-, stem of desclore, based on Latin claudere ‘to close’.

disclosure.example: She said there should be a standardised information disclosure policy

noun.definition: The action of making new or secret information known.
noun.example: a judge ordered the disclosure of the government documents

disclosure.origin: Late 16th century from disclose, on the pattern of closure.

adjective.definition: Dissatisfied.
adjective.example: he was discontent with his wages

noun.definition: Dissatisfaction with one's circumstances; lack of contentment.
noun.example: voters voiced discontent with both parties

adjective.definition: Careful and prudent in one's speech or actions, especially in order to keep something confidential or to avoid embarrassment.
adjective.example: we made some discreet inquiries

discreet.origin: Middle English from Old French discret, from Latin discretus ‘separate’, past participle of discernere ‘discern’, the sense arising from late Latin discretio (see discretion). Compare with discrete.

verb.definition: Recognize a distinction; differentiate.
verb.example: babies can discriminate between different facial expressions

verb.definition: Make an unjust or prejudicial distinction in the treatment of different categories of people, especially on the grounds of race, sex, or age.
verb.example: existing employment policies discriminate against women

discriminate.origin: Early 17th century from Latin discriminat- ‘distinguished between’, from the verb discriminare, from discrimen ‘distinction’, from the verb discernere (see discern).

adjective.definition: Making or showing an unfair or prejudicial distinction between different categories of people or things, especially on the grounds of race, age, or sex.
adjective.example: discriminatory employment practices

verb.definition: Cause (someone) to be disappointed.
verb.example: he may have been disenchanted by the loss of his huge following

disenchant.origin: Late 16th century from French désenchanter, from dés- (expressing reversal) + enchanter (see enchant).

adjective.definition: (of a person's hair, clothes, or appearance) untidy; disordered.
adjective.example: a man with long disheveled hair

disheveled.origin: Late Middle English from obsolete dishevely, from Old French deschevele, past participle of descheveler (based on chevel ‘hair’, from Latin capillus). The original sense was ‘having the hair uncovered’; later, referring to the hair itself, ‘hanging loose’, hence ‘disordered, untidy’. Compare with unkempt.

dismal.example: The bangladeshi athletes put up dismal performances in the 5th youth commonwealth games

adjective.definition: Causing a mood of gloom or depression.
adjective.example: the dismal weather made the late afternoon seem like evening

dismal.origin: Late Middle English from earlier dismal (noun), denoting the two days in each month which in medieval times were believed to be unlucky, from Anglo-Norman French dis mal, from medieval Latin dies mali ‘evil days’.

verb.definition: Take (a machine or structure) to pieces.
verb.example: the engines were dismantled and the bits piled into a heap

dismantle.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘destroy the defensive capability of a fortification’): from Old French desmanteler, from des- (expressing reversal) + manteler ‘fortify’ (from Latin mantellum ‘cloak’).

verb.definition: Make (a doubt, feeling, or belief) disappear.
verb.example: the brightness of the day did nothing to dispel Elaine's dejection

dispel.origin: Late Middle English from Latin dispellere, from dis- ‘apart’ + pellere ‘to drive’.

adjective.definition: Denoting a phase dispersed in another phase, as in a colloid.
adjective.example: emulsions should be examined after storage for droplet size of the disperse phase

verb.definition: Distribute or spread over a wide area.
verb.example: storms can disperse seeds via high altitudes

disperse.origin: Late Middle English from Latin dispers- ‘scattered’, from the verb dispergere, from dis- ‘widely’ + spargere ‘scatter, strew’.

noun.definition: A feeling of annoyance or disapproval.
noun.example: he started hanging around the local pubs, much to the displeasure of his mother

verb.definition: Annoy; displease.
verb.example: not for worlds would I do aught that might displeasure thee

displeasure.origin: Late Middle English from Old French desplaisir (see displease), influenced by pleasure.

noun.definition: The action or process of getting rid of something.
noun.example: the disposal of radioactive waste

noun.definition: The sale of shares, property, or other assets.
noun.example: the disposal of his shares in the company

noun.definition: The arrangement of something.
noun.example: she brushed her hair carefully, as if her success lay in the sleek disposal of each gleaming black thread

disposal.origin: Available for one to use whenever or however one wishes.Ready to assist the person concerned in any way they wish.

verb.definition: Get rid of by throwing away or giving or selling to someone else.
verb.example: the waste is disposed of in the North Sea

verb.definition: Incline (someone) towards a particular activity or mood.
verb.example: prolactin, a calming hormone, is released, disposing you towards sleep

verb.definition: Arrange in a particular position.
verb.example: the chief disposed his attendants in a circle

dispose.origin: Late Middle English from Old French disposer, from Latin disponere ‘arrange’, influenced by dispositus ‘arranged’ and Old French poser ‘to place’.

adjective.definition: Too large or too small in comparison with something else.
adjective.example: people on lower incomes spend a disproportionate amount of their income on fuel

disproportionate.origin: Mid 16th century from dis- (expressing absence) + proportionate, on the pattern of French disproportionné.

verb.definition: Undergo disproportionation.
verb.example: water disproportionates to oxygen and hydrogen

noun.definition: A disagreement or argument.
noun.example: a territorial dispute between the two countries

verb.definition: Argue about (something)
verb.example: the point has been much disputed

verb.definition: Compete for; strive to win.
verb.example: the two drivers crashed while disputing the lead

dispute.origin: Middle English via Old French from Latin disputare ‘to estimate’ (in late Latin ‘to dispute’), from dis- ‘apart’ + putare ‘reckon’.

noun.definition: The state of being held in low esteem by the public.
noun.example: one of the top clubs in the country is bringing the game into disrepute

verb.definition: Interrupt (an event, activity, or process) by causing a disturbance or problem.
verb.example: flooding disrupted rail services

disrupt.origin: Late Middle English from Latin disrupt- ‘broken apart’, from the verb disrumpere.

noun.definition: A difference or contrast between similar things or people.
noun.example: there is a sharp distinction between domestic politics and international politics

noun.definition: Excellence that sets someone or something apart from others.
noun.example: a novelist of distinction

distinction.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘subdivision, category’): via Old French from Latin distinctio(n-), from the verb distinguere (see distinguish).

verb.definition: Prevent (someone) from concentrating on something.
verb.example: don't allow noise to distract you from your work

distract.origin: Late Middle English (also in the sense ‘pull in different directions’): from Latin distract- ‘drawn apart’, from the verb distrahere, from dis- ‘apart’ + trahere ‘to draw, drag’.

noun.definition: Extreme anxiety, sorrow, or pain.
noun.example: to his distress he saw that she was trembling

noun.definition: another term for distraint

verb.definition: Cause (someone) anxiety, sorrow, or pain.
verb.example: I didn't mean to distress you

verb.definition: Give (furniture or clothing) simulated marks of age and wear.
verb.example: the manner in which leather jackets are industrially distressed

distress.origin: Middle English from Old French destresce (noun), destrecier (verb), based on Latin distringere ‘stretch apart’.

adjective.definition: Causing anxiety, sorrow or pain; upsetting.
adjective.example: some very distressing news

adjective.definition: Tending to be different or develop in different directions.
adjective.example: divergent interpretations

adjective.definition: (of a series) increasing indefinitely as more of its terms are added.

noun.definition: The state of being diverse.
noun.example: there was considerable diversity in the style of the reports

diversity.origin: Middle English from Old French diversite, from Latin diversitas, from diversus ‘diverse’, past participle of divertere ‘turn aside’ (see divert).

verb.definition: Cause (someone or something) to change course or turn from one direction to another.
verb.example: a scheme to divert water from the river to irrigate agricultural land

verb.definition: Draw (the attention) of someone from something.
verb.example: public relations policies are sometimes intended to divert attention away from criticism

divert.origin: Late Middle English via French from Latin divertere, from di- ‘aside’ + vertere ‘to turn’.

adjective.definition: Of or like God or a god.
adjective.example: heroes with divine powers

adjective.definition: Very pleasing; delightful.
adjective.example: he had the most divine smile

noun.definition: A cleric or theologian.
Providence or God.

divine.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin divinus, from divus ‘godlike’ (related to deus ‘god’).

verb.definition: Discover (something) by guesswork or intuition.
verb.example: mum had divined my state of mind

verb.definition: Have supernatural or magical insight into (future events)
verb.example: frauds who claimed to divine the future in chickens' entrails

divine.origin: Late Middle English from Old French deviner ‘predict’, from Latin divinare, from divinus (see divine).

adjective.definition: Having or involving a sensation of spinning around and losing one's balance.
adjective.example: Jonathan had begun to suffer dizzy spells

verb.definition: Make (someone) feel unsteady, confused, or amazed.
verb.example: the dizzying rate of change

dizzy.origin: Old English dysig ‘foolish’, of West Germanic origin; related to Low German dusig, dösig ‘giddy’ and Old High German tusic ‘foolish, weak’.

auxiliary verb.definition: Used before a verb (except be, can, may, ought, shall, will) in questions and negative statements.
Used to refer back to a verb already mentioned.
auxiliary verb.example: he looks better than he did before

auxiliary verb.definition: Used to give emphasis to a positive verb.
auxiliary verb.example: I do want to act on this

auxiliary verb.definition: Used with inversion of a subject and verb when an adverbial phrase begins a clause for emphasis.

noun.definition: A party or other social event.
noun.example: the soccer club Christmas do

noun.definition: short for hairdo
noun.example: a bowl-shaped do of perfect silky hair
the air was rancid with the smell of donkey doo

noun.definition: A swindle or hoax.

verb.definition: Perform (an action, the precise nature of which is often unspecified)
verb.example: something must be done about the city's traffic

verb.definition: Achieve or complete.
Act or behave in a specified way.
verb.example: they are free to do as they please

verb.definition: Be suitable or acceptable.
verb.example: if he's anything like you, he'll do

verb.definition: Beat up or kill.
verb.example: one day I'll do him

verb.definition: Prosecute or convict.
verb.example: we got done for conspiracy to cause GBH

do.origin: Old English dōn, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch doen and German tun, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek tithēmi ‘I place’ and Latin facere ‘make, do’.

noun.definition: A sudden quick movement to avoid someone or something.
The dodging of a bell in change-ringing.

verb.definition: Avoid (someone or something) by a sudden quick movement.
verb.example: marchers had to dodge missiles thrown by loyalists

verb.definition: Expose (one area of a print) less than the rest during processing or enlarging.
(of a bell in change-ringing) move one place contrary to the normal sequence, and then back again in the following round.

dodge.origin: Mid 16th century (in the senses ‘dither’ and ‘haggle’): of unknown origin.

noun.definition: Death, destruction, or some other terrible fate.
noun.example: the aircraft was sent crashing to its doom in the water

verb.definition: Condemn to certain death or destruction.
verb.example: fuel was spilling out of the damaged wing and the aircraft was doomed

doom.origin: Old English dōm ‘statute, judgement’, of Germanic origin, from a base meaning ‘to put in place’; related to do.

noun.definition: A shower of water.
noun.example: I felt better for taking a daily douche

noun.definition: An obnoxious or contemptible person (typically used of a man)
noun.example: that guy is such a douche

verb.definition: Spray or shower with water.
verb.example: she did not douche herself and the smell, at times, was off-putting

douche.origin: Mid 18th century (as a noun): via French from Italian doccia ‘conduit pipe’, from docciare ‘pour by drops’, based on Latin ductus ‘leading’ (see duct).

noun.definition: A loss of power, prosperity, or status.
noun.example: the crisis led to the downfall of the government

noun.definition: A heavy fall of rain or snow.
noun.example: the wind was whipping up the downfall into deep drifts on the moor

noun.definition: A heavy fall of rain.
noun.example: a sudden downpour had filled the gutters and drains

adjective.definition: Moving or leading towards a lower place or level.
adjective.example: a downward trend in inflation

adverb.definition: Towards a lower place, point, or level.
adverb.example: he was lying face downward

downward.origin: Middle English shortening of Old English adūnweard.

noun.definition: An amount of property or money brought by a bride to her husband on their marriage.
noun.example: Elizabeth's dowry was to be £45,000 in diamonds

dowry.origin: Middle English (denoting a widow's life interest in her husband's estate): from Anglo-Norman French dowarie, from medieval Latin dotarium (see dower).

noun.definition: A preliminary version of a piece of writing.
noun.example: the first draft of the party's manifesto

noun.definition: A written order to pay a specified sum.
Compulsory recruitment for military service.
noun.example: 25 million men were subject to the draft

noun.definition: US spelling of draught (noun)

verb.definition: Prepare a preliminary version of (a document)
verb.example: I drafted a letter of resignation

verb.definition: Select (a person or group of people) and bring them somewhere for a certain purpose.
verb.example: riot police were drafted in to break up the blockade

draft.origin: Mid 16th century phonetic spelling of draught.

adjective.definition: Likely to have a strong or far-reaching effect; radical and extreme.
adjective.example: a drastic reduction of staffing levels

drastic.origin: Late 17th century (originally applied to the effect of medicine): from Greek drastikos, from dran ‘do’.

noun.definition: A picture or diagram made with a pencil, pen, or crayon rather than paint.
noun.example: a series of charcoal drawings on white paper

noun.definition: An instance of selecting the winner or winners in a lottery or raffle.
noun.example: entrants need not be present at the drawing

adjective.definition: (of a person) looking strained from illness, exhaustion, anxiety, or pain.
adjective.example: Cathy was pale and drawn and she looked tired out

verb.definition: past participle of draw

noun.definition: Saliva falling from the mouth.
noun.example: a fine trickle of drool leaked from the corner of his mouth

verb.definition: Drop saliva uncontrollably from the mouth.
verb.example: the baby begins to drool, then to cough

dubito, ergo cogito, ergo sum.bengali: I doubt, therefore i think, therefore i am

ducks and drakes.bengali: The pastime of skimming flat stones or shells along the surface of calm water
ducks and drakes.example: Play ducks and drakes with or make ducks and drakes of: played ducks and drakes with his money.

adjective.definition: Expected at or planned for at a certain time.
adjective.example: the baby's due in August

adjective.definition: Of the proper quality or extent.
adjective.example: driving without due care and attention

adverb.definition: (with reference to a point of the compass) exactly; directly.
adverb.example: we'll head due south again on the same road

noun.definition: One's right; what is owed to one.
noun.example: he thought it was his due

noun.definition: An obligatory payment; a fee.
noun.example: he had paid trade union dues for years

due.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘payable’): from Old French deu ‘owed’, based on Latin debitus ‘owed’, from debere ‘owe’.

noun.definition: A model or replica of a human being.
noun.example: a waxwork dummy

noun.definition: An object designed to resemble and serve as a substitute for the real or usual one.
noun.example: tests using stuffed owls and wooden dummies

noun.definition: (chiefly in rugby and soccer) a feigned pass or kick intended to deceive an opponent.
A stupid person.
The declarer's partner, whose cards are exposed on the table after the opening lead and played by the declarer.

verb.definition: (chiefly in rugby and soccer) feign a pass or kick in order to deceive an opponent.
verb.example: Blanco dummied past a static defence

verb.definition: Create a mock-up of (a book, document, etc.)
verb.example: officials dummied up a set of photos

dummy.origin: Late 16th century from dumb+ -y. The original sense was ‘a person who cannot speak’, then ‘an imaginary fourth player in whist’ (mid 18th century), whence ‘a substitute for the real thing’ and ‘a model of a human being’ (mid 19th century).

noun.definition: A victim of deception.
noun.example: men who were simply the dupes of their unscrupulous leaders

verb.definition: Deceive; trick.
verb.example: the newspaper was duped into publishing an untrue story

dupe.origin: Late 17th century from dialect French dupe ‘hoopoe’, from the bird's supposedly stupid appearance.

noun.definition: Threats, violence, constraints, or other action used to coerce someone into doing something against their will or better judgement.
noun.example: confessions extracted under duress

duress.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘harshness, severity, cruel treatment’): via Old French from Latin duritia, from durus ‘hard’.

noun.definition: Fine, dry powder consisting of tiny particles of earth or waste matter lying on the ground or on surfaces or carried in the air.
noun.example: the car sent up clouds of dust

noun.definition: An act of dusting.
noun.example: a quick dust, to get rid of the cobwebs

verb.definition: Remove the dust or dirt from the surface of (something) by wiping or brushing it.
verb.example: I broke the vase I had been dusting

verb.definition: Cover lightly with a powdered substance.
verb.example: roll out on a surface dusted with icing sugar

verb.definition: Beat up or kill someone.
verb.example: the officers dusted him up a little bit

dust.origin: Old English dūst, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch duist ‘chaff’.

adjective & adverb.example: the permitted number of duty-free goods

noun.definition: Goods that are exempt from payment of duty.
noun.example: a bag of duty-free

noun.definition: A person or animal that lives in or at a specified place.
noun.example: city dwellers

verb.definition: Diminish gradually in size, amount, or strength.
verb.example: traffic has dwindled to a trickle

dwindle.origin: Late 16th century frequentative of Scots and dialect dwine ‘fade away’, from Old English dwīnan, of Germanic origin; related to Middle Dutch dwīnen and Old Norse dvína.

adjective.definition: Not operating normally or properly.
adjective.example: the telephones are dysfunctional

noun.definition: A characteristic or identifying feature.
noun.example: this car has all the earmarks of a classic

noun.definition: A congressional directive that funds should be spent on a specific project.
A mark on the ear of a domesticated animal indicating ownership or identity.

verb.definition: Designate (funds or resources) for a particular purpose.
verb.example: the cash had been earmarked for a big expansion of the programme

verb.definition: Mark the ear of (a domesticated animal) as a sign of ownership or identity.
verb.example: Condition scoring is also useful for earmarking cattle as they come close to finish as sometimes farmers who are looking at the same cattle each day can be unaware of the degree of finish achieved.

adjective.definition: Resembling or suggestive of earth or soil.
adjective.example: an earthy smell

adjective.definition: (of a person or their language) direct and uninhibited, especially about sexual subjects or bodily functions.
adjective.example: their good-natured vulgarity and earthy humour

noun.definition: Absence of difficulty or effort.
noun.example: she gave up smoking with ease

verb.definition: Make (something unpleasant or intense) less serious or severe.
verb.example: a huge road-building programme to ease congestion

verb.definition: Move carefully or gradually.
verb.example: I eased down the slope with care

ease.origin: Middle English from Old French aise, based on Latin adjacens ‘lying close by’, present participle of adjacere. The verb is originally from Old French aisier, from the phrase a aise ‘at ease’; in later use from the noun.

noun.definition: A restaurant or cafe.

verb.definition: Secretly listen to a conversation.
verb.example: my father eavesdropped on my phone calls

eavesdrop.origin: Early 17th century back-formation from eavesdropper(late Middle English)‘a person who listens from under the eaves’, from the obsolete noun eavesdrop ‘the ground on to which water drips from the eaves’, probably from Old Norse upsardropi, from ups ‘eaves’ + dropi ‘a drop’.

noun.definition: A sound or sounds caused by the reflection of sound waves from a surface back to the listener.
noun.example: the walls threw back the echoes of his footsteps

noun.definition: A close parallel to an idea, feeling, or event.
noun.example: his love for her found an echo in her own feelings

noun.definition: A person who slavishly repeats the words or opinions of another.
noun.example: Clarendon, whom they reckoned the faithful echo of their master's intentions

noun.definition: A play by a defender of a higher card in a suit followed by a lower one in a subsequent trick, used as a signal to request a further lead of that suit by their partner.
A code word representing the letter E, used in radio communication.
Used in names of newspapers.
noun.example: the South Wales Echo

verb.definition: (of a sound) be repeated or reverberate after the original sound has stopped.
verb.example: their footsteps echoed on the metal catwalks

verb.definition: (of an object or event) be reminiscent of or have shared characteristics with.
verb.example: a blue suit that echoed the colour of her eyes

verb.definition: Send a copy of (an input signal or character) back to its source or to a screen for display.
verb.example: for security reasons, the password will not be echoed to the screen

verb.definition: (of a defender) play a higher card followed by a lower one in the same suit, as a signal to request one's partner to lead that suit.

echo.origin: Middle English from Old French or Latin, from Greek ēkhō, related to ēkhē ‘a sound’.

proper noun.definition: A nymph deprived of speech by Hera in order to stop her chatter, and left able only to repeat what others had said.

noun.definition: A change which is a result or consequence of an action or other cause.
noun.example: the lethal effects of hard drugs

noun.definition: The lighting, sound, or scenery used in a play, film, or broadcast.
noun.example: the production relied too much on spectacular effects

noun.definition: Personal belongings.
noun.example: the insurance covers personal effects

verb.definition: Cause (something) to happen; bring about.
verb.example: the prime minister effected many policy changes

effect.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, or from Latin effectus, from efficere ‘accomplish’, from ex- ‘out, thoroughly’ + facere ‘do, make’. effect (sense 3 of the noun), ‘personal belongings’, arose from the obsolete sense ‘something acquired on completion of an action’.

noun.definition: The state or quality of being efficient.
noun.example: greater energy efficiency

efficiency.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘the fact of being an efficient cause’): from Latin efficientia, from efficere ‘accomplish’ (see effect).

noun.definition: A sculpture or model of a person.
noun.example: a tomb effigy of Eleanor of Aquitaine

effigy.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin effigies, from effingere ‘to fashion (artistically)’, from ex- ‘out’ + fingere ‘to shape’.

electrocution.example: Five die from electrocution in panchagarh

noun.definition: The injury or killing of someone by electric shock.
noun.example: they switched off the power supply to avoid any risk of electrocution

verb.definition: Escape from or avoid (a danger, enemy, or pursuer), typically in a skilful or cunning way.
verb.example: he tried to elude the security men by sneaking through a back door

verb.definition: (of an achievement or something desired) fail to be attained by (someone)
verb.example: sleep still eluded her

elude.origin: Mid 16th century (in the sense ‘delude, baffle’): from Latin eludere, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out, away from’ + ludere ‘to play’.

adjective.definition: Difficult to find, catch, or achieve.
adjective.example: success will become ever more elusive

elusive.origin: Early 18th century from Latin elus- ‘eluded’ (from the verb eludere) + -ive.

noun.definition: A wall or bank of earth or stone built to prevent a river flooding an area.
noun.example: Chelsea Embankment

adjective.definition: Causing embarrassment.
adjective.example: an embarrassing muddle

verb.definition: Move out of or away from something and become visible.
verb.example: black ravens emerged from the fog

verb.definition: Become apparent or prominent.
verb.example: United have emerged as the bookies' clear favourite

verb.definition: Recover from or survive a difficult situation.
verb.example: the economy has started to emerge from recession

emerge.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘become known, come to light’): from Latin emergere, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out, forth’ + mergere ‘to dip’.

adjective.definition: (of the former holder of an office, especially a university professor) having retired but allowed to retain their title as an honour.
adjective.example: emeritus professor of microbiology

emeritus.origin: Mid 18th century from Latin, past participle of emereri ‘earn one's discharge by service’, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out of, from’ + mereri ‘earn’.

adjective.definition: (of a person) famous and respected within a particular sphere.
adjective.example: one of the world's most eminent statisticians

adjective.definition: (of a positive quality) present to a notable degree.
adjective.example: the book's scholarship and eminent readability

eminent.origin: Late Middle English from Latin eminent- ‘jutting, projecting’, from the verb eminere.

noun.definition: Special importance, value, or prominence given to something.
noun.example: they placed great emphasis on the individual's freedom

noun.definition: Stress given to a word or words when speaking to indicate particular importance.
noun.example: inflection and emphasis can change the meaning of what is said

emphasis.origin: Late 16th century via Latin from Greek, originally ‘appearance, show’, later denoting a figure of speech in which more is implied than is said (the original sense in English), from emphainein ‘exhibit’, from em- ‘in, within’ + phainein ‘to show’.

adverb.definition: In a forceful way.
adverb.example: she closed the door behind her emphatically

en route.example: 1. He reads en route 2. Arrived early despite en route delays

adjective.definition: Delightfully charming or attractive.
adjective.example: enchanting views

verb.definition: Surround and have or hold within.
verb.example: this area of London encompasses Piccadilly to the north and St James's Park to the south

verb.definition: Cause to take place.
verb.example: an act designed to encompass the death of the king

noun.definition: An attempt to achieve a goal.
noun.example: an endeavour to reduce serious injury

verb.definition: Try hard to do or achieve something.
verb.example: he is endeavouring to help the Third World

endeavour.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘exert oneself’): from the phrase put oneself in devoir ‘do one's utmost’ (see devoir).

verb.definition: Intensify, increase, or further improve the quality, value, or extent of.
verb.example: his refusal does nothing to enhance his reputation

enhance.origin: Middle English (formerly also as inhance): from Anglo-Norman French enhauncer, based on Latin in- (expressing intensive force) + altus ‘high’. The word originally meant ‘elevate’ (literally and figuratively), later ‘exaggerate, make appear greater’, also ‘raise the value or price of something’. Current senses date from the early 16th century.

adjective.definition: Very large in size, quantity, or extent.
adjective.example: enormous sums of money

enormous.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin enormis ‘unusual, huge’ (see enormity) + -ous.

intransitive verb.definition: Officially register as a member of an institution or a student on a course.

enroll.origin: Late Middle English (formerly also as inroll): from Old French enroller, from en- ‘in’ + rolle ‘a roll’ (names being originally written on a roll of parchment).

enrollment.example: 1. The public universities in the country enroll students once a year. 2. The gross enrollment rose to nearly 10 per cent during the last 11 years against the backdrop of stagnant primary school enrollment for almost 30 years, reports bss.

noun.definition: The action of enrolling or being enrolled.
noun.example: the amount due must be paid on enrollment in October

noun.definition: A person who is very interested in a particular activity or subject.
noun.example: a sports car enthusiast

noun.definition: A person of intense and visionary Christian views.

enthusiast.origin: Early 17th century (denoting a person believing that he or she is divinely inspired): from French enthousiaste or ecclesiastical Latin enthusiastes ‘member of a heretical sect’, from Greek enthousiastēs ‘person inspired by a god’, from the adjective enthous (see enthusiasm).

noun.definition: A messenger or representative, especially one on a diplomatic mission.
noun.example: the UN special envoy to Yugoslavia

noun.definition: A minister plenipotentiary, ranking below ambassador and above chargé d'affaires.

envoy.origin: Mid 17th century from French envoyé, past participle of envoyer ‘send’, from en voie ‘on the way’, based on Latin via ‘way’.

noun.definition: A feeling of discontented or resentful longing aroused by someone else's possessions, qualities, or luck.
noun.example: she felt a twinge of envy for the people on board

verb.definition: Desire to have a quality, possession, or other desirable thing belonging to (someone else)
verb.example: he envied people who did not have to work at the weekends

envy.origin: Middle English (also in the sense ‘hostility, enmity’): from Old French envie (noun), envier (verb), from Latin invidia, from invidere ‘regard maliciously, grudge’, from in- ‘into’ + videre ‘to see’.

adjective.definition: Of the nature of an epidemic.
adjective.example: shoplifting has reached epidemic proportions

noun.definition: A widespread occurrence of an infectious disease in a community at a particular time.
noun.example: a flu epidemic

epidemic.origin: Early 17th century (as an adjective): from French épidémique, from épidémie, via late Latin from Greek epidēmia ‘prevalence of disease’, from epidēmios ‘prevalent’, from epi ‘upon’ + dēmos ‘the people’.

eradication.example: Mosquito eradication programme: মশা নির্মূল প্রোগ্রাম

noun.definition: The complete destruction of something.
noun.example: the eradication of poverty

adverb.definition: Therefore.
adverb.example: she was the sole beneficiary of the will, ergo the prime suspect

verb.definition: (of wind, water, or other natural agents) gradually wear away (soil, rock, or land)
verb.example: the cliffs on this coast have been eroded by the sea

erode.origin: Early 17th century from French éroder or Latin erodere, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out, away’ + rodere ‘gnaw’.

noun.definition: The process of eroding or being eroded by wind, water, or other natural agents.
noun.example: the problem of soil erosion

erosion.origin: Mid 16th century via French from Latin erosio(n-), from erodere ‘wear or gnaw away’ (see erode).

adjective.definition: Erring or straying from the accepted course or standards.
adjective.example: an errant husband coming back from a night on the tiles

adjective.definition: Travelling in search of adventure.
adjective.example: that same lady errant

errant.origin: Middle English (in errant (sense 2)): errant (sense 1) from Latin errant- ‘erring’, from the verb errare; errant (sense 2) from Old French errant ‘travelling’, present participle of errer, from late Latin iterare ‘go on a journey’, from iter ‘journey’. Compare with arrant.

verb.definition: Increase rapidly.
verb.example: the price of tickets escalated

escalate.origin: 1920s (in the sense ‘travel on an escalator’): back-formation from escalator.

noun.definition: A rapid increase; a rise.
noun.example: cost escalations

noun.definition: The intrinsic nature or indispensable quality of something, especially something abstract, which determines its character.
noun.example: conflict is the essence of drama

noun.definition: An extract or concentrate obtained from a plant or other matter and used for flavouring or scent.
noun.example: vanilla essence

essence.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin essentia, from esse ‘be’.

noun.definition: The characteristic spirit of a culture, era, or community as manifested in its attitudes and aspirations.
noun.example: a challenge to the ethos of the 1960s

ethos.origin: Mid 19th century from modern Latin, from Greek ēthos ‘nature, disposition’, (plural) ‘customs’.

noun.definition: A man who has been castrated, especially (in the past) one employed to guard the women's living areas at an oriental court.

eunuch.origin: Old English, via Latin eunuchus from Greek eunoukhos, literally ‘bedroom guard’, from eunē ‘bed’ + a second element related to ekhein ‘to hold’.

verb.definition: Remove (someone) from a place of danger to a safer place.
verb.example: several families were evacuated from their homes

verb.definition: Remove air, water, or other contents from (a container)
verb.example: when it springs a leak, evacuate the pond

evacuate.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘clear the contents of’): from Latin evacuat- ‘(of the bowels) emptied’, from the verb evacuare, from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out of’ + vacuus ‘empty’.

verb.definition: Escape or avoid (someone or something), especially by guile or trickery.
verb.example: friends helped him to evade capture for a time

evade.origin: Late 15th century from French évader, from Latin evadere from e- (variant of ex-) ‘out of’ + vadere ‘go’.

verb.definition: Form an idea of the amount, number, or value of; assess.
verb.example: the study will assist in evaluating the impact of recent changes

verb.definition: Find a numerical expression or equivalent for (an equation, formula, or function)
verb.example: substitute numbers in a simple formula and evaluate the answer

evaluate.origin: Mid 19th century (earlier (mid 18th century) as evaluation): from French évaluer, from es- (from Latin ex-) ‘out, from’ + Old French value ‘value’.

noun.definition: The action of evading something.
noun.example: their adroit evasion of almost all questions

evasion.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘prevaricating excuse’): via Old French from Latin evasio(n-), from evadere (see evade).

noun.definition: The available body of facts or information indicating whether a belief or proposition is true or valid.
noun.example: the study finds little evidence of overt discrimination

verb.definition: Be or show evidence of.
verb.example: the quality of the bracelet, as evidenced by the workmanship, is exceptional

evidence.origin: Middle English via Old French from Latin evidentia, from evident- ‘obvious to the eye or mind’ (see evident).

noun.definition: The action of excavating something, especially an archaeological site.
noun.example: the methods of excavation have to be extremely rigorous

adjective.definition: More than is necessary, normal, or desirable; immoderate.
adjective.example: he was drinking excessive amounts of brandy

excessive.origin: Late Middle English from Old French excessif, -ive, from medieval Latin excessivus, from Latin excedere ‘surpass’ (see exceed).

noun.definition: Waste matter discharged from the bowels; faeces.

excrement.origin: Mid 16th century from French excrément or Latin excrementum, from excernere ‘to sift out’ (see excrete).

noun.definition: The action of freeing or state of being free from an obligation or liability imposed on others.
noun.example: vehicles that may qualify for exemption from tax

exemption.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, or from Latin exemptio(n-), from eximere ‘take out, free’.

exile.example: A year in exile ends tomorrow

noun.definition: The state of being barred from one's native country, typically for political or punitive reasons.
noun.example: he knew now that he would die in exile

verb.definition: Expel and bar (someone) from their native country, typically for political or punitive reasons.
verb.example: a corrupt dictator who had been exiled from his country

exile.origin: Middle English the noun partly from Old French exil ‘banishment’ and partly from Old French exile ‘banished person’; the verb from Old French exiler; all based on Latin exilium ‘banishment’, from exul ‘banished person’.

adjective.definition: Originating in or characteristic of a distant foreign country.
adjective.example: exotic birds

noun.definition: An exotic plant or animal.
noun.example: he planted exotics in the sheltered garden

exotic.origin: Late 16th century via Latin from Greek exōtikos ‘foreign’, from exō ‘outside’.

adjective.definition: Denoting or relating to a person living outside their native country.
adjective.example: expatriate workers

noun.definition: A person who lives outside their native country.
noun.example: American expatriates in London

verb.definition: Send (a person or money) abroad.
verb.example: we expatriated the prisoners of war immediately after the end of the war

expatriate.origin: Mid 18th century (as a verb): from medieval Latin expatriat- ‘gone out from one's country’, from the verb expatriare, from ex- ‘out’ + patria ‘native country’.

verb.definition: Make (an action or process) happen sooner or be accomplished more quickly.
verb.example: he promised to expedite economic reforms

expedite.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘perform quickly’): from Latin expedire ‘extricate (originally by freeing the feet), put in order’, from ex- ‘out’ + pes, ped- ‘foot’.

verb.definition: Officially make (someone) leave a school or other organization.
verb.example: she was expelled from school

expel.origin: Late Middle English from Latin expellere, from ex- ‘out’ + pellere ‘to drive’.

noun.definition: The action or fact of treating someone unfairly in order to benefit from their work.
noun.example: the exploitation of migrant workers

noun.definition: The action of making use of and benefiting from resources.
noun.example: the Bronze Age saw exploitation of gold deposits

noun.definition: The action of forcing someone to leave an organization.
noun.example: his expulsion from the union

expulsion.origin: Late Middle English from Latin expulsio(n-), from expellere ‘drive out’ (see expel).

noun.definition: The practice of obtaining something, especially money, through force or threats.
noun.example: he used bribery and extortion to build himself a huge, art-stuffed mansion

extortion.origin: Middle English from late Latin extortio(n-), from Latin extorquere ‘wrest’ (see extort).

verb.definition: (with reference to moisture or a smell) discharge or be discharged slowly and steadily.
verb.example: the beetle exudes a caustic liquid

verb.definition: (of a person) display (an emotion or quality) strongly and openly.
verb.example: Sir Thomas exuded goodwill

exude.origin: Late 16th century from Latin exsudare, from ex- ‘out’ + sudare ‘to sweat’.

adjective.definition: Extraordinary, especially extraordinarily large.
adjective.example: fabulous riches

adjective.definition: Having no basis in reality; mythical.
adjective.example: fabulous creatures

fabulous.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘known through fable’): from French fabuleux or Latin fabulosus ‘celebrated in fable’, from fabula (see fable).

noun.definition: An item of unreliable information that is reported and repeated so often that it becomes accepted as fact.
noun.example: he addresses the facts and factoids which have buttressed the film's legend

adjective.definition: (of a sight, smell, or sound) barely perceptible.
adjective.example: the faint murmur of voices

adjective.definition: Feeling weak and dizzy and close to losing consciousness.
adjective.example: the heat made him feel faint

noun.definition: A sudden loss of consciousness.
noun.example: she hit the floor in a dead faint

verb.definition: Lose consciousness for a short time because of a temporarily insufficient supply of oxygen to the brain.
verb.example: I fainted from loss of blood

faint.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘feigned’, also ‘feeble, cowardly’, surviving in faint heart): from Old French faint, past participle of faindre (see feign). Compare with feint.

adjective.definition: Losing strength or momentum.
adjective.example: his faltering career

noun.definition: Extreme scarcity of food.
noun.example: drought resulted in famine throughout the region

famine.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, from faim ‘hunger’, from Latin fames.

adjective.definition: Elaborate in structure or decoration.
adjective.example: the furniture was very fancy

adjective.definition: (of a drawing, painting, or sculpture) created from the imagination rather than from life.
adjective.example: I used to take a seat and busy myself in sketching fancy vignettes

noun.definition: A superficial or transient feeling of liking or attraction.
noun.example: this was no passing fancy, but a feeling he would live by

noun.definition: The faculty of imagination.
noun.example: he is prone to flights of fancy
chocolate fancies

noun.definition: (in 16th and 17th century music) a composition for keyboard or strings in free or variation form.
noun.example: Division technique...penetrated nearly all 17th century English instrumental forms, including the venerable polyphonic fancy.

verb.definition: Feel a desire or liking for.
verb.example: do you fancy a drink?

verb.definition: Regard (a horse, team, or player) as a likely winner.
verb.example: I fancy him to win the tournament

verb.definition: Imagine; think.
verb.example: he fancied he could smell the perfume of roses

fancy.origin: Late Middle English contraction of fantasy.

adjective.definition: Relating to or resembling farce, especially because of absurd or ridiculous aspects.
adjective.example: he considered the whole idea farcical

noun.definition: The money paid for a journey on public transport.
noun.example: we should go to Seville, but we cannot afford the air fare

noun.definition: A range of food of a particular type.
noun.example: traditional Scottish fare

verb.definition: Perform in a specified way in a particular situation or over a particular period.
verb.example: the party fared badly in the elections

verb.definition: Travel.
verb.example: a knight fares forth

fare.origin: Old English fær, faru ‘travelling, a journey or expedition’, faran‘to travel’, also ‘get on (well or badly’), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch varen and German fahren ‘to travel’, Old Norse ferja ‘ferry boat’, also to ford. Sense 1 of the noun stems from an earlier meaning ‘a journey for which a price is paid’. Noun sense 2 was originally used with reference to the quality or quantity of food provided, probably from the idea of faring well or badly.

adjective.definition: Causing death.
adjective.example: a fatal accident

fatal.origin: Late Middle English (in the senses ‘destined by fate’ and ‘ominous’): from Old French, or from Latin fatalis, from fatum (see fate).

noun.definition: An occurrence of death by accident, in war, or from disease.
noun.example: 80 per cent of pedestrian fatalities occur in built-up areas

noun.definition: Helplessness in the face of fate.
noun.example: a sense of fatality gripped her

fatality.origin: Late 15th century (denoting the quality of causing death or disaster): from French fatalité or late Latin fatalitas, from Latin fatalis ‘decreed by fate’, from fatum (see fate). fatality (sense 1) dates from the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: An unattractive or unsatisfactory feature, especially in a piece of work or in a person's character.
noun.example: my worst fault is impatience

noun.definition: Responsibility for an accident or misfortune.
noun.example: if books were not selling, it wasn't the fault of the publishers

noun.definition: An extended break in a rock formation, marked by the relative displacement and discontinuity of strata on either side of a particular plane.
noun.example: a landscape broken by numerous faults

verb.definition: Criticize for inadequacy or mistakes.
verb.example: her superiors could not fault her dedication to the job

verb.definition: (of a rock formation) be broken by a fault or faults.
verb.example: the continental crust has been thinned and faulted as a result of geological processes

fault.origin: Middle English faut(e) ‘lack, failing’, from Old French, based on Latin fallere ‘deceive’. The -l- was added (in French and English) in the 15th century to conform with the Latin word, but did not become standard in English until the 17th century, remaining silent in pronunciation until well into the 18th.

noun.definition: The animals of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
noun.example: the flora and fauna of Siberia

fauna.origin: Late 18th century modern Latin application of Fauna, the name of a rural goddess, sister of Faunus.

adjective.definition: Made in imitation; artificial.
adjective.example: a rope of faux pearls

noun.definition: An unpleasant emotion caused by the threat of danger, pain, or harm.
noun.example: I cowered in fear as bullets whizzed past

verb.definition: Be afraid of (someone or something) as likely to be dangerous, painful, or harmful.
verb.example: I hated him but didn't fear him any more

fear.origin: Old English fǣr ‘calamity, danger’, fǣran ‘frighten’, also ‘revere’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch gevaar and German Gefahr ‘danger’.

adjective.definition: Possible to do easily or conveniently.
adjective.example: it is not feasible to put most finds from excavations on public display

feasible.origin: Late Middle English from Old French faisible, from fais-, stem of faire ‘do, make’, from Latin facere.

noun.definition: An achievement that requires great courage, skill, or strength.
noun.example: the new printing presses were considerable feats of engineering

feat.origin: Late Middle English (in the general sense ‘action or deed’): from Old French fait, from Latin factum (see fact).

noun.definition: non-standard spelling of fellow, used in representing speech in various dialects
noun.example: you can't blame the wee fella

noun.definition: A person's boyfriend or lover.
noun.example: she took a fancy to her best friend's fella

adjective.definition: Sharing a particular activity, quality, or condition with someone or something.
adjective.example: they urged the troops not to fire on their fellow citizens

noun.definition: A man or boy.
noun.example: he was an extremely obliging fellow

noun.definition: A person in the same position, involved in the same activity, or otherwise associated with another.
noun.example: he was learning with a rapidity unique among his fellows

noun.definition: A member of a learned society.
noun.example: a fellow of the Geological Society

fellow.origin: Late Old English fēolaga ‘a partner or colleague’ (literally ‘one who lays down money in a joint enterprise’), from Old Norse félagi, from fé ‘cattle, property, money’ + the Germanic base of lay.

noun.definition: Friendly association, especially with people who share one's interests.
noun.example: they valued fun and good fellowship as the cement of the community

noun.definition: The status of a fellow of a college or society.
noun.example: a fellowship in mathematics

noun.definition: The state or quality of being ferocious.
noun.example: the ferocity of the storm caught them by surprise

ferocity.origin: Mid 16th century from French, or from Latin ferocitas, from ferox, feroc- ‘fierce’.

noun.definition: A ceramic compound consisting of a mixed oxide of iron and one or more other metals which has ferrimagnetic properties and is used in high-frequency electrical components such as aerials.
A form of pure iron with a body-centred cubic crystal structure, occurring in low-carbon steel.
A form of sexual desire in which gratification is linked to an abnormal degree to a particular object, item of clothing, part of the body, etc.
noun.example: a man with a fetish for surgical masks

noun.definition: An inanimate object worshipped for its supposed magical powers or because it is considered to be inhabited by a spirit.

fetish.origin: Early 17th century (originally denoting an object used by the peoples of West Africa as an amulet or charm): from French fétiche, from Portuguese feitiço ‘charm, sorcery’ (originally an adjective meaning ‘made by art’), from Latin facticius (see factitious).

noun.definition: A woman to whom someone is engaged to be married.
noun.example: he went back to the valley to marry his fiancée

noun.definition: Faithfulness to a person, cause, or belief, demonstrated by continuing loyalty and support.
noun.example: his fidelity to liberal ideals

noun.definition: The degree of exactness with which something is copied or reproduced.
noun.example: the 1949 recording provides reasonable fidelity

fidelity.origin: Late Middle English from Old French fidelite or Latin fidelitas, from fidelis ‘faithful’, from fides ‘faith’. Compare with fealty.

adjective.definition: Disgustingly dirty.
adjective.example: a filthy hospital with no sanitation

adverb.definition: To an extreme extent.
adverb.example: he has become filthy rich

adjective.definition: Relating to government revenue, especially taxes.
adjective.example: monetary and fiscal policy

noun.definition: A legal or treasury official in some countries.
noun.example: As early as 1711, an Oberfiscal was appointed aided by a staff of fiscals who had to be secret appointments as they had the task of checking the honesty and integrity of government officials.

fiscal.origin: Mid 16th century from French, or from Latin fiscalis, from fiscus ‘purse, treasury’ (see fisc).

adjective.definition: Becoming tired or less dynamic; declining in strength.
adjective.example: she wants to revive her flagging career

noun.definition: The ship in a fleet which carries the commanding admiral.
The tendency to attract attention because of one's exuberance, confidence, and stylishness.
noun.example: he had a reputation for flair and flamboyance

adjective.definition: (especially of an item of clothing) having a shape that widens progressively towards the end or bottom.
adjective.example: a flared skirt

adjective.definition: (of the nostrils) dilated.
adjective.example: horses snorted impatiently through flared nostrils

adjective.definition: Having or characterized by a fundamental weakness or imperfection.
adjective.example: a fatally flawed strategy

adjective.definition: Without any imperfections or defects; perfect.
adjective.example: her smooth flawless skin

verb.definition: Run away from a place or situation of danger.
verb.example: to escape the fighting, his family fled from their village

flee.origin: Old English flēon, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vlieden and German fliehen.

noun.definition: A group of ships sailing together, engaged in the same activity, or under the same ownership.
noun.example: the small port supports a fishing fleet

fleet.origin: Old English flēot ‘ship, shipping’, from flēotan ‘float, swim’ (see fleet).

adjective.definition: Fast and nimble in movement.
adjective.example: a man of advancing years, but fleet of foot

fleet.origin: Early 16th century probably from Old Norse fljótr, of Germanic origin and related to fleet.

noun.definition: A marshland creek, channel, or ditch.
noun.example: Sam explained that the 3,000 acres of the Nature Reserve is the largest in the English lowlands, the main area being grazing marsh divided by a network of ditches and fleets.

noun.definition: A stream, now wholly underground, running into the Thames east of Fleet Street.

fleet.origin: Old English flēot, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vliet, also to fleet.

verb.definition: Move or pass quickly.
verb.example: a variety of expressions fleeted across his face

fleet.origin: Old English flēotan ‘float, swim’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vlieten and German fliessen, also to flit and float.

adjective.definition: (of water) shallow.

adverb.definition: At or to a small depth.

fleet.origin: Early 17th century perhaps based on an Old English cognate of Dutch vloot ‘shallow’ and related to fleet.

noun.definition: Behaviour that demonstrates a playful sexual attraction to someone.
noun.example: Fabia was in no mood for his light-hearted flirtation

noun.definition: A number of birds of one kind feeding, resting, or travelling together.
noun.example: a flock of gulls

verb.definition: (of birds) congregate in a flock.
verb.example: sandgrouse are liable to flock with other species

flock.origin: Old English flocc, of unknown origin. The original sense was ‘a band or body of people’: this became obsolete, but has been reintroduced as a transferred use of the sense ‘a number of animals kept together’.

noun.definition: A soft material for stuffing cushions, quilts, and other soft furnishings, made of wool refuse or torn-up cloth.
noun.example: flock mattresses

flock.origin: Middle English from Old French floc, from Latin floccus (see floccus).

flora.bengali: উদ্ভিদকুল; Flora and fauna: The flora and fauna of a place are its plants and animals.
flora.example: 1. The flora and fauna of santal life have been clearly indicated in his work and captured with passion.

noun.definition: The plants of a particular region, habitat, or geological period.
noun.example: Britain's native flora

flora.origin: Late 18th century from Latin flos, flor- ‘flower’.

flora.bengali: উদ্ভিদকুল; Flora and fauna: The flora and fauna of a place are its plants and animals.
flora.example: 1. The flora and fauna of santal life have been clearly indicated in his work and captured with passion.

verb.definition: Rise and fall irregularly in number or amount.
verb.example: trade with other countries tends to fluctuate from year to year

fluctuate.origin: Mid 17th century (earlier (late Middle English) as fluctuation): from Latin fluctuat- ‘undulated’, from the verb fluctuare, from fluctus ‘flow, current, wave’, from fluere ‘to flow’.

verb.definition: Perplex (someone) greatly; bewilder.
verb.example: I was completely flummoxed by the whole thing

flummox.origin: Mid 19th century probably of dialect origin; flummock ‘to make untidy, confuse’ is recorded in western counties and the north Midlands.

verb.definition: Fail to reach the required standard in (an examination, test, or course of study)
verb.example: I flunked biology in the tenth grade

flunk.origin: Early 19th century (in the general sense ‘back down, fail utterly’; originally US): perhaps related to funk or to US flink ‘be a coward’, perhaps a variant of flinch.

noun.definition: The track or scent of a hunted animal.
A setback in an enterprise; a defeat.

verb.definition: Prevent (something considered wrong or undesirable) from succeeding.
verb.example: a brave policewoman foiled the armed robbery

foil.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘trample down’): perhaps from Old French fouler ‘to full cloth, trample’, based on Latin fullo ‘fuller’. Compare with full.

noun.definition: Metal hammered or rolled into a thin flexible sheet, used chiefly for covering or wrapping food.
noun.example: aluminium foil

noun.definition: A person or thing that contrasts with and so emphasizes and enhances the qualities of another.
noun.example: his white cravat was a perfect foil for his bronzed features

noun.definition: A leaf-shaped curve formed by the cusping of an arch or circle.

foil.origin: Middle English via Old French from Latin folium ‘leaf’.

noun.definition: A light, blunt-edged fencing sword with a button on its point.
Each of the structures fitted to a hydrofoil's hull to lift it clear of the water at speed.

adjective.definition: Relating to the traditional art or culture of a community or nation.
adjective.example: a revival of interest in folk customs

adjective.definition: Relating to folk music.
adjective.example: a folk club

noun.example: some folk will do anything for money

noun.definition: Folk music.
noun.example: a mixture of folk and reggae

folk.origin: Old English folc, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch volk and German Volk.

noun.definition: An act of fondling.

verb.definition: Stroke or caress lovingly or erotically.
verb.example: he kissed and fondled her

fondle.origin: Late 17th century (in the sense ‘pamper’): back-formation from obsolete fondling ‘much-loved or petted person’, from fond+ -ling.

adjective.definition: Copied fraudulently; fake.
adjective.example: they have illegally entered the UK using forged travel documents

adjective.definition: Inspiring fear or respect through being impressively large, powerful, intense, or capable.
adjective.example: a formidable opponent

formidable.origin: Late Middle English from French, or from Latin formidabilis, from formidare ‘to fear’.

noun.definition: An original source of something.
noun.example: he was the sole fountainhead of advice

fowl.origin: Old English fugol ‘bird’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch vogel and German Vogel, also to fly.

adjective.definition: (of an object) easily broken or damaged.
adjective.example: fragile items such as glass and china

fragile.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘morally weak’): from Latin fragilis, from frangere ‘to break’. The sense ‘liable to break’ dates from the mid 16th century.

noun.definition: A rigid structure that surrounds something such as a picture, door, or windowpane.
A person's body with reference to its size or build.
noun.example: a shiver shook her slim frame

noun.definition: A basic structure that underlies or supports a system, concept, or text.
noun.example: the establishment of conditions provides a frame for interpretation

noun.definition: A structural environment within which a class of words or other linguistic units can be correctly used. For example I — him is a frame for a large class of transitive verbs.
A single complete picture in a series forming a cinema, television, or video film.
noun.example: video footage slowed down to 20 frames a second

noun.definition: The triangular structure for positioning the red balls in snooker.

verb.definition: Place (a picture or photograph) in a frame.
verb.example: he had had the photo framed

verb.definition: Formulate (a concept, plan, or system)
verb.example: staff have proved invaluable in framing the proposals

verb.definition: Produce false evidence against (an innocent person) so that they appear guilty.
verb.example: he claims he was framed

frame.origin: Old English framian ‘be useful’, of Germanic origin and related to from. The general sense in Middle English, ‘make ready for use’, probably led to frame (sense 2 of the verb); it also gave rise to the specific meaning ‘prepare timber for use in building’, later ‘make the wooden parts (framework) of a building’, hence the noun sense ‘structure’ (late Middle English).

noun.definition: A very unusual and unexpected event or situation.
noun.example: the teacher says the accident was a total freak
a few freaks have been discovered, one amazing cat tipping the scales at no less than 43 lbs

noun.definition: A person who is obsessed with a particular activity or interest.
noun.example: a fitness freak

noun.definition: A sudden arbitrary change of mind; a whim.
noun.example: follow this way or that, as the freak takes you

verb.definition: Behave or cause to behave in a wild and irrational way, typically because of the effects of extreme emotion or drugs.
verb.example: he freaked out and smashed the place up

verb.definition: Fleck or streak randomly.
verb.example: the white pink and the pansy freaked with jet
