freak.origin: Mid 16th century (in freak (sense 4 of the noun)): probably from a dialect word.

verb.definition: Make (someone) afraid or anxious.
verb.example: the savagery of his thoughts frightened him

noun.definition: A line or border separating two countries.
noun.example: international crime knows no frontiers

frontier.origin: Late Middle English from Old French frontiere, based on Latin frons, front- ‘front’.

adjective.definition: Frustrated.

verb.definition: Prevent (a plan or attempted action) from progressing, succeeding, or being fulfilled.
verb.example: the rescue attempt was frustrated by bad weather

verb.definition: Cause (someone) to feel upset or annoyed as a result of being unable to change or achieve something.
verb.example: it frustrated me that more couldn't be done for her

frustrate.origin: Late Middle English from Latin frustrat- ‘disappointed’, from the verb frustrare, from frustra ‘in vain’.

noun.definition: The feeling of being upset or annoyed as a result of being unable to change or achieve something.
noun.example: tears of frustration rolled down her cheeks

noun.definition: The prevention of the progress, success, or fulfilment of something.
noun.example: the frustration of their wishes

frustration.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin frustratio(n-), from frustrare ‘disappoint’ (see frustrate).

fugitive.example: Fugitive abu borhan chowdhury, chairman of everest holding and technologies ltd, was convicted in a graft case filed over misappropriation of tk 15 core from rupali bank…

adjective.definition: Quick to disappear; fleeting.
adjective.example: the fugitive effects of light

noun.definition: A person who has escaped from captivity or is in hiding.
noun.example: fugitives from justice

fugitive.origin: Late Middle English from Old French fugitif, -ive, from Latin fugitivus, from fugere ‘flee’.

noun.definition: An amount of gas or vapour that smells strongly or is dangerous to inhale.
noun.example: clouds of exhaust fumes spewed by cars

verb.definition: Feel, show, or express great anger.
verb.example: ‘We simply cannot have this’, she fumed

verb.definition: Emit gas or vapour.
verb.example: fragments of lava hit the ground, fuming and sizzling

fume.origin: Late Middle English from Old French fumer (verb), from Latin fumare ‘to smoke’.

adverb.definition: In addition; besides (used to introduce a fresh consideration in an argument)
adverb.example: It was also a highly desirable political end. Furthermore, it gave the English a door into France

adjective.definition: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble; secretive.
adjective.example: they spent a furtive day together

furtive.origin: Early 17th century from French furtif, -ive or Latin furtivus, from furtum ‘theft’.

noun.definition: Wild or violent anger.
noun.example: tears of fury and frustration

noun.definition: Extreme strength or violence in an action or a natural phenomenon.
noun.example: the fury of a gathering storm

fury.origin: Late Middle English from Old French furie, from Latin furia, from furiosus ‘furious’, from furere ‘be mad, rage’.

noun.definition: The main body of an aircraft.

fuselage.origin: Early 20th century from French, from fuseler ‘shape into a spindle’, from fuseau ‘spindle’.

adjective.definition: (of a horse) going at the pace of a gallop.
adjective.example: the sound of galloping hooves

adjective.definition: (of a process or event) progressing in a rapid and seemingly uncontrollable manner.
adjective.example: galloping inflation

noun.definition: An act of gambling.
noun.example: Dad likes a bit of a gamble

noun.definition: A risky action undertaken with the hope of success.
noun.example: we decided to take a gamble and offer him a place on our staff

verb.definition: Play games of chance for money; bet.
verb.example: he gambles on football
synonyms: try one's luck on the horses

verb.definition: Take risky action in the hope of a desired result.
verb.example: he was gambling on the success of his satellite TV channel
synonyms: take a leap in the dark
buy a pig in a poke

gamble.origin: Early 18th century from obsolete gamel ‘play games’, or from the verb game.

adjective.definition: (of a message, sound, or transmission) confused and distorted; unclear.
adjective.example: I got a garbled set of directions

noun.definition: A strong-smelling pungent-tasting bulb, used as a flavouring in cooking and in herbal medicine.
noun.example: garlic butter

noun.definition: The central Asian plant, closely related to the onion, which produces garlic.

garlic.origin: Old English gārlēac, from gār ‘spear’ (because the shape of a clove resembles the head of a spear) + lēac ‘leek’.

noun.definition: An instrument that measures and gives a visual display of the amount, level, or contents of something.
noun.example: a fuel gauge

noun.definition: The thickness, size, or capacity of something, especially as a standard measure.
The position of a sailing ship to windward (the weather gage) or leeward (the lee gage) of another.
noun.example: the French fleet was heavily outnumbered but had the weather gage

verb.definition: Estimate or determine the amount, level, or volume of.
verb.example: astronomers can gauge the star's intrinsic brightness

verb.definition: Measure the dimensions of (an object) with a gauge.
verb.example: when dry the assemblies can be gauged exactly

gauge.origin: Middle English (denoting a standard measure): from Old French gauge (noun), gauger (verb), variant of Old Northern French jauge (noun), jauger (verb), of unknown origin.

noun.definition: The quality of being kind and generous.
noun.example: I was overwhelmed by the generosity of friends and neighbours

noun.definition: The quality or fact of being plentiful or large.
noun.example: diners certainly cannot complain about the generosity of portions

generosity.origin: Late Middle English (denoting nobility of birth): from Latin generositas, from generosus ‘magnanimous’ (see generous). Current senses date from the 17th century.

adjective.definition: Relating to the human or animal reproductive organs.
adjective.example: the genital area

noun.definition: A person's or animal's external organs of reproduction.

genital.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, or from Latin genitalis, from genitus, past participle of gignere ‘beget’.

noun.definition: A movement of part of the body, especially a hand or the head, to express an idea or meaning.
noun.example: Alex made a gesture of apology

verb.definition: Make a gesture.
verb.example: she gestured meaningfully with the pistol

gesture.origin: Late Middle English from medieval Latin gestura, from Latin gerere ‘bear, wield, perform’. The original sense was ‘bearing, deportment’, hence ‘the use of posture and bodily movements for effect in oratory’.

adjective.definition: (chiefly of hair or fur) of a light reddish-yellow or orange-brown colour.

noun.definition: A hot, fragrant spice made from the rhizome of a plant, which may be chopped or powdered for cooking, preserved in syrup, or candied.
A SE Asian plant, which resembles bamboo in appearance, from which ginger is taken.
A light reddish-yellow or orange-brown colour.
A quality of energy or spiritedness.
noun.example: the ginger had gone out of the men

verb.definition: Flavour with ginger.
verb.example: gingered chicken wings

verb.definition: Make someone or something more lively.
verb.example: she slapped his hand lightly to ginger him up

ginger.origin: Late Old English gingifer, conflated in Middle English with Old French gingimbre, from medieval Latin gingiber, from Greek zingiberis, from Pali siṅgivera, of Dravidian origin.

noun.definition: (in ancient Rome) a man trained to fight with weapons against other men or wild animals in an arena.

gladiator.origin: Late Middle English from Latin, from gladius ‘sword’.

glimpse.example: 1. Europe's top central bankers who met their global peers in japan this weekend may have caught a glimpse of their own future. 2. A glimpse into the pre-modern islamic culture in bengal.

noun.definition: A momentary or partial view.
noun.example: she caught a glimpse of the ocean

verb.definition: See or perceive briefly or partially.
verb.example: he glimpsed a figure standing in the shade

glimpse.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘shine faintly’): probably of Germanic origin; related to Middle High German glimsen, also to glimmer.

noun.definition: Partial or total darkness.
noun.example: he strained his eyes peering into the gloom

noun.definition: A state of depression or despondency.
noun.example: a year of economic gloom for the car industry

noun.definition: A short prayer of thanks said before or after a meal.

noun.definition: (in Greek mythology) three beautiful goddesses (Aglaia, Thalia, and Euphrosyne) believed to personify and bestow charm, grace, and beauty.

noun.definition: Bribery and other corrupt practices used to secure illicit advantages or gains in politics or business.

graft.origin: Mid 19th century perhaps related to the phrase spade's graft ‘the amount of earth that one stroke of a spade will move’, based on Old Norse grǫftr ‘digging’.

humanitarian.origin: The primary sense of humanitarian is 'concerned with or seeking to promote human welfare’. Since the 1930s a new sense, exemplified by phrases such as the worst humanitarian disaster this country has seen, has been gaining currency, and is now broadly established, especially in journalism, although it is not considered good style by all. In the Oxford English Corpus the second most common collocation of humanitarian is crisis

verb.definition: Pretend to be (another person) for entertainment or fraud.
verb.example: it's a very serious offence to impersonate a police officer

impersonate.origin: Early 17th century (in the sense ‘personify’): from in-‘into’ + Latin persona ‘person’, on the pattern of incorporate.

adjective.definition: (of an argument or statement) not seeming reasonable or probable; failing to convince.
adjective.example: this is a blatantly implausible claim

noun.definition: A tool, utensil, or other piece of equipment that is used for a particular purpose.
noun.example: garden implements

noun.definition: Performance of an obligation.

verb.definition: Put (a decision, plan, agreement, etc.) into effect.
verb.example: the scheme to implement student loans

implement.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘article of furniture, equipment, or dress’): partly from medieval Latin implementa (plural), partly from late Latin implementum ‘filling up, fulfilment’, both from Latin implere ‘fill up’ (later ‘employ’), from in- ‘in’ + Latin plere ‘fill’. The verb dates from the early 18th century.

noun.definition: A thing implied.
noun.example: The dual nature of the Heart represents the meeting of the changeless and the changing, the inevitable and the contingent, the implicate and the manifest.

verb.definition: Show (someone) to be involved in a crime.
verb.example: he implicated his government in the murders of three judges

verb.definition: Convey (a meaning) indirectly through what one says, rather than stating it explicitly.
verb.example: by saying that coffee would keep her awake, Mary implicated that she didn't want any

implicate.origin: Late Middle English from Latin implicatus ‘folded in’, past participle of implicare (see imply). The original sense was ‘entwine’; compare with employ and imply. The earliest modern (implicate (sense 2 of the verb)), dates from the early 17th century.

verb.definition: Collapse or cause to collapse violently inwards.
verb.example: both the windows had imploded

implode.origin: Late 19th century from in-‘within’ + Latin plodere, plaudere ‘to clap’, on the pattern of explode.

verb.definition: Indicate the truth or existence of (something) by suggestion rather than explicit reference.
verb.example: salesmen who use jargon to imply superior knowledge

imply.origin: Late Middle English from Old French emplier, from Latin implicare, from in- ‘in’ + plicare ‘to fold’. The original sense was ‘entwine’; in the 16th and 17th centuries the word also meant ‘employ’. Compare with employ and implicate.

verb.definition: Force (an unwelcome decision or ruling) on someone.
verb.example: the decision was theirs and was not imposed on them by others

verb.definition: Take advantage of someone by demanding their attention or commitment.
verb.example: she realized that she had imposed on Mark's kindness

verb.definition: Arrange (pages of type) so as to be in the correct order after printing and folding.

impose.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘impute’): from French imposer, from Latin imponere ‘inflict, deceive’ (from in- ‘in, upon’ + ponere ‘put’), but influenced by impositus ‘inflicted’ and Old French poser ‘to place’.

adjective.definition: Grand and impressive in appearance.
adjective.example: an imposing 17th-century manor house

adjective.definition: Not likely to be true or to happen.
adjective.example: this account of events was seen by the jury as most improbable

improbable.origin: Late 16th century from French, or from Latin improbabilis ‘hard to prove’, from in- ‘not’ + probabilis (see probable).

noun.definition: The action of improvising.
noun.example: she specializes in improvisation on the piano

verb.definition: Create and perform (music, drama, or verse) spontaneously or without preparation.
verb.example: he invited actors to improvise dialogue
synonyms: make it up as one goes along

improvise.origin: Early 19th century (earlier (late 18th century) as improvisation): from French improviser or its source, Italian improvvisare, from improvviso ‘extempore’, from Latin improvisus ‘unforeseen’, based on provisus, past participle of providere ‘make preparation for’.

adjective.definition: Lacking the quality or quantity required; insufficient for a purpose.
adjective.example: these labels prove to be wholly inadequate

adverb.definition: Without intention; accidentally.
adverb.example: his name had been inadvertently omitted from the list

noun.definition: The beginning or introduction of a system, policy, or period.
noun.example: the inauguration of an independent prosecution service

adjective.definition: Unable to do or achieve (something)
adjective.example: Wilson blushed and was incapable of speech

adjective.definition: Unable to behave rationally or manage one's affairs.
adjective.example: the pilot may become incapable from the lack of oxygen

incapable.origin: Late 16th century from French, or from late Latin incapabilis, from in- ‘not’ + capabilis (see capable).

adjective.definition: (of a person or mental process) intelligently analytical and clear-thinking.
adjective.example: she was an incisive critic

adjective.definition: (of an action) quick and direct.
adjective.example: the most incisive move of a tight match

incisive.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘cutting, penetrating’): from medieval Latin incisivus, from Latin incidere ‘cut into’ (see incise).

adjective.definition: (of the weather) unpleasantly cold or wet.
adjective.example: walkers should be prepared for inclement weather

inclement.origin: Early 17th century from French inclément or Latin inclement-, from in- ‘not’ + clement- ‘clement’.

noun.definition: An inclined surface or plane; a slope, especially on a road or railway.
noun.example: the road climbs a long incline through a forest

verb.definition: Be favourably disposed towards or willing to do something.
verb.example: he was inclined to accept the offer

verb.definition: Have a tendency to do something.
verb.example: she's inclined to gossip with complete strangers

verb.definition: Lean or turn away from a given plane or direction, especially the vertical or horizontal.
verb.example: the bunker doors incline outwards

incline.origin: Middle English (originally in the sense ‘bend (the head or body) towards something’; formerly also as encline): from Old French encliner, from Latin inclinare, from in- ‘towards’ + clinare ‘to bend’.

verb.definition: Become subject to (something unwelcome or unpleasant) as a result of one's own behaviour or actions.
verb.example: I will pay any expenses incurred

incur.origin: Late Middle English from Latin incurrere, from in- ‘towards’ + currere ‘run’.

noun.definition: Indecent behaviour.
noun.example: seven offences of rape and indecency

noun.definition: A formal charge or accusation of a serious crime.
noun.example: an indictment for conspiracy

noun.definition: A thing that serves to illustrate that a system or situation is bad and deserves to be condemned.
noun.example: these rapidly escalating crime figures are an indictment of our society

indictment.origin: Middle English enditement, inditement, from Anglo-Norman French enditement, from enditer (see indict).

adjective.definition: Having no particular interest or sympathy; unconcerned.
adjective.example: he gave an indifferent shrug

adjective.definition: Neither good nor bad; mediocre.
adjective.example: a pair of indifferent watercolours

indifferent.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘having no partiality for or against’): via Old French from Latin indifferent- ‘not making any difference’, from in- ‘not’ + different- ‘differing’ (see different).

adjective.definition: Done at random or without careful judgement.
adjective.example: the indiscriminate use of antibiotics can cause problems

indiscriminate.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘haphazard, not selective’): from in-‘not’ + Latin discriminatus, past participle of discriminare (see discriminate).

adjective.definition: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
adjective.example: war was inevitable

noun.definition: A situation that is unavoidable.
noun.example: by the morning he had accepted the inevitable

inevitable.origin: Late Middle English from Latin inevitabilis, from in- ‘not’ + evitabilis ‘avoidable’ (from evitare ‘avoid’).

noun.definition: An intense but short-lived passion or admiration for someone or something.
noun.example: he had developed an infatuation with the girl

verb.definition: Deduce or conclude (something) from evidence and reasoning rather than from explicit statements.
verb.example: from these facts we can infer that crime has been increasing

infer.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘bring about, inflict’): from Latin inferre ‘bring in, bring about’ (in medieval Latin ‘deduce’), from in- ‘into’ + ferre ‘bring’.

adjective.definition: Lower in rank, status, or quality.
adjective.example: schooling in inner-city areas was inferior to that in the rest of the country

adjective.definition: Low or lower in position.
adjective.example: ulcers located in the inferior and posterior wall of the duodenum

adjective.definition: (of a letter, figure, or symbol) written or printed below the line.

noun.definition: A person lower than another in rank, status, or ability.
noun.example: her social and intellectual inferiors

noun.definition: An inferior letter, figure, or symbol.
noun.example: This mark indicates that the letter is superior to an inferior.

inferior.origin: Late Middle English (in inferior (sense 2 of the adjective)): from Latin, comparative of inferus ‘low’.

adjective.definition: Capable of being filled with air.
adjective.example: an inflatable mattress

noun.definition: A plastic or rubber object that must be filled with air before use.
noun.example: three sailors manned the inflatable

influx.example: The rohingya influx has caused 14.3 percent wage reduction of all labourers among the host community in teknaf

noun.definition: An arrival or entry of large numbers of people or things.
noun.example: a massive influx of tourists

noun.definition: An inflow of water into a river, lake, or the sea.
noun.example: the lakes are fed by influxes of meltwater

influx.origin: Late 16th century (denoting an inflow of liquid, gas, or light): from late Latin influxus, from influere ‘flow in’ (see influence).

noun.definition: A violation or infringement of a law or agreement.

infraction.origin: Late Middle English from Latin infractio(n-), from the verb infringere (see infringe).

verb.definition: Make (someone) extremely angry and impatient.
verb.example: I was infuriated by your article

infuriate.origin: Mid 17th century from medieval Latin infuriat- ‘made angry’, from the verb infuriare, from in- ‘into’ + Latin furia ‘fury’.

noun.definition: A drink, remedy, or extract prepared by soaking tea leaves or herbs in liquid.
noun.example: a strong rosemary infusion

noun.definition: The introduction of a new element or quality into something.
noun.example: the infusion of $6.3 million for improvements

noun.definition: The slow injection of a substance into a vein or tissue.
noun.example: a four-hour intravenous infusion

infusion.origin: Late Middle English (denoting the pouring in of a liquid): from Latin infusio(n-), from the verb infundere (see infuse).

verb.definition: Bring oneself into favour with someone by flattering or trying to please them.
verb.example: a sycophantic attempt to ingratiate herself with the local aristocracy
synonyms: get on the good side of

ingratiate.origin: Early 17th century from Latin in gratiam ‘into favour’, on the pattern of obsolete Italian ingratiare, earlier form of ingraziare.

noun.definition: An instance of being injured.
noun.example: she suffered an injury to her back

noun.definition: Damage to a person's feelings.
noun.example: compensation for injury to feelings

injury.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French injurie, from Latin injuria ‘a wrong’, from in- (expressing negation) + jus, jur- ‘right’.

noun.definition: The state, quality, or fact of being innocent of a crime or offence.
noun.example: they must prove their innocence

innocence.origin: Middle English from Old French, from Latin innocentia, from innocent- ‘not harming’ (based on nocere ‘injure’).

noun.definition: An act of asking for information.

inquiry.origin: Late Middle English (as enquery): from inquire + -y.

adjective.definition: In a state of mind which prevents normal perception, behaviour, or social interaction; seriously mentally ill.
adjective.example: he had gone insane

adjective.definition: Shocking; outrageous.
adjective.example: they were making insane amounts of money

insane.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin insanus, from in- ‘not’ + sanus ‘healthy’.

noun.definition: The state of being seriously mentally ill; madness.
noun.example: he suffered from bouts of insanity

insanity.origin: Late 16th century from Latin insanitas, from insanus (see insane).

adjective.definition: Impossible to understand or interpret.
adjective.example: Guy looked blankly inscrutable

inscrutable.origin: Late Middle English from ecclesiastical Latin inscrutabilis, from in- ‘not’ + scrutari ‘to search’ (see scrutiny).

noun.definition: The capacity to gain an accurate and deep understanding of someone or something.
noun.example: his mind soared to previously unattainable heights of insight

insight.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘inner sight, wisdom’): probably of Scandinavian and Low German origin and related to Swedish insikt, Danish indsigt, Dutch inzicht, and German Einsicht.

verb.definition: Demand something forcefully, not accepting refusal.
verb.example: she insisted on carrying her own bag
synonyms: not take no for an answer

insist.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘persist, persevere’): from Latin insistere ‘persist’, from in- ‘upon’ + sistere ‘stand’.

noun.definition: The fact or quality of insisting that something is the case or should be done.
noun.example: Alison's insistence on doing the washing-up straight after the meal

noun.definition: An example or single occurrence of something.
noun.example: a serious instance of corruption

verb.definition: Cite (a fact, case, etc.) as an example.
verb.example: I instanced Bob as someone whose commitment had certainly got things done

instance.origin: Middle English via Old French from Latin instantia ‘presence, urgency’, from instare ‘be present, press upon’, from in- ‘upon’ + stare ‘to stand’. The original sense was ‘urgency, urgent entreaty’, surviving in at the instance of. In the late 16th century the word denoted a particular case cited to disprove a general assertion, derived from medieval Latin instantia ‘example to the contrary’ (translating Greek enstasis ‘objection’); hence the meaning ‘single occurrence’.

noun.definition: An organization founded for a religious, educational, professional, or social purpose.
noun.example: an academic institution

noun.definition: An established law or practice.
noun.example: the institution of marriage

noun.definition: The action of instituting something.
noun.example: a delay in the institution of proceedings

institution.origin: Late Middle English (in institution (sense 2, institution sense 3)): via Old French from Latin institutio(n-), from the verb instituere (see institute). institution (sense 1) dates from the early 18th century.

noun.definition: A tool or implement, especially one for precision work.
noun.example: a surgical instrument

noun.definition: A measuring device used to gauge the level, position, speed, etc. of something, especially a motor vehicle or aircraft.
noun.example: a new instrument for measuring ozone levels
the value of learning to play a musical instrument

noun.definition: A formal or legal document.
noun.example: execution involves signature and unconditional delivery of the instrument

verb.definition: Equip (something) with measuring instruments.
verb.example: engineers have instrumented rockets to study the upper atmosphere

instrument.origin: Middle English from Old French, or from Latin instrumentum ‘equipment, implement’, from the verb instruere ‘construct, equip’.

adjective.definition: Too extreme to bear; intolerable.
adjective.example: the heat would be insufferable by July
synonyms: more than flesh and blood can stand
enough to tax the patience of a saint
enough to test the patience of a saint
enough to try the patience of a saint

insufferable.origin: Late Middle English perhaps via French (now dialect) insouffrable, based on Latin sufferre ‘endure’ (see suffer).

noun.definition: The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles.
noun.example: a gentleman of complete integrity

noun.definition: The state of being whole and undivided.
noun.example: upholding territorial integrity and national sovereignty

integrity.origin: Late Middle English (in integrity (sense 2)): from French intégrité or Latin integritas, from integer ‘intact’ (see integer). Compare with entirety, integral, and integrate.

adjective.definition: Planned or meant.
adjective.example: the intended victim escaped

noun.definition: The person one intends to marry; one's fiancé or fiancée.
noun.example: she used to be my intended

adjective.definition: Of extreme force, degree, or strength.
adjective.example: the job demands intense concentration

adjective.definition: Having or showing strong feelings or opinions; extremely earnest or serious.
adjective.example: an intense young woman, passionate about her art

intense.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, or from Latin intensus ‘stretched tightly, strained’, past participle of intendere (see intend).

verb.definition: Become or make more intense.
verb.example: the dispute began to intensify

verb.definition: Increase the opacity of (a negative) using a chemical.
verb.example: the negative may be intensified with bichloride

noun.definition: An act or instance of intercepting something.
noun.example: he read the file of radio intercepts

verb.definition: Obstruct (someone or something) so as to prevent them from continuing to a destination.
verb.example: intelligence agencies intercepted a series of telephone calls

intercept.origin: Late Middle English (in the senses ‘contain between limits’ and ‘halt (an effect’)): from Latin intercept- ‘caught between’, from the verb intercipere, from inter- ‘between’ + capere ‘take’.

adjective.definition: Occurring at irregular intervals; not continuous or steady.
adjective.example: intermittent rain

intermittent.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin intermittent- ‘ceasing’, from the verb intermittere (see intermit).

noun.definition: A student or trainee who works, sometimes without pay, in order to gain work experience or satisfy requirements for a qualification.

verb.definition: Confine (someone) as a prisoner, especially for political or military reasons.
verb.example: the family were interned for the duration of the war as enemy aliens

verb.definition: Serve as an intern.

intern.origin: Early 16th century (as an adjective in the sense ‘internal’): from French interne (adjective), interner (verb), from Latin internus ‘inward, internal’. Current senses date from the 19th century.

noun.definition: The action of interrogating or the process of being interrogated.
noun.example: would he keep his mouth shut under interrogation?

verb.definition: Take part in something so as to prevent or alter a result or course of events.
verb.example: he acted outside his authority when he intervened in the dispute

verb.definition: Occur in the time between events.
verb.example: to occupy the intervening months she took a job in a hospital

intervene.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘come in as an extraneous factor or thing’): from Latin intervenire, from inter- ‘between’ + venire ‘come’.

noun.definition: The action or process of intervening.
noun.example: a high degree of state intervention in the economy

intervention.origin: Late Middle English from Latin interventio(n-), from the verb intervenire (see intervene).

intestine.example: Rotavirus causes gastroenteritis, an inflammation of the stomach and intestines.

noun.definition: (in vertebrates) the lower part of the alimentary canal from the end of the stomach to the anus.
noun.example: the contents of the intestine

intestine.origin: Late Middle English from Latin intestinum, neuter of intestinus, from intus ‘within’.

noun.definition: Close familiarity or friendship.
noun.example: the intimacy between a husband and wife

adjective.definition: Closely acquainted; familiar.
adjective.example: intimate friends

adjective.definition: Private and personal.
adjective.example: intimate details of his sexual encounters

noun.definition: A very close friend.
noun.example: his circle of intimates

intimate.origin: Early 17th century (as a noun): from late Latin intimatus, past participle of Latin intimare ‘impress, make familiar’, from intimus ‘inmost’.

verb.definition: State or make known.
verb.example: Mr Hutchison has intimated his decision to retire

intimate.origin: Early 16th century (earlier (late Middle English) as intimation) from late Latin intimat- ‘made known’, from the verb intimare (see intimate).

verb.definition: Frighten or overawe (someone), especially in order to make them do what one wants.
verb.example: the forts are designed to intimidate the nationalist population

intimidate.origin: Mid 17th century from medieval Latin intimidat- ‘made timid’, from the verb intimidare (based on timidus ‘timid’).

noun.definition: The action of intimidating someone, or the state of being intimidated.
noun.example: the intimidation of witnesses and jurors

verb.definition: (of alcoholic drink or a drug) cause (someone) to lose control of their faculties or behaviour.
verb.example: he was charged with operating a vehicle while intoxicated

verb.definition: Poison (someone).

intoxicate.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘poison’): from medieval Latin intoxicare, from in- ‘into’ + toxicare ‘to poison’, from Latin toxicum (see toxic).

adjective.definition: Existing or taking place within, or administered into, a vein or veins.
adjective.example: an intravenous drip

adjective.definition: Very complicated or detailed.
adjective.example: an intricate network of canals

intricate.origin: Late Middle English from Latin intricat- ‘entangled’, from the verb intricare, from in- ‘into’ + tricae ‘tricks, perplexities’.

adjective.definition: Arousing one's curiosity or interest; fascinating.
adjective.example: an intriguing story

adverb.definition: In a manner that arouses one's curiosity or interest; fascinatingly.

verb.definition: Overwhelm (someone) with things or people to be dealt with.
verb.example: we've been inundated with complaints from listeners

verb.definition: Flood.
verb.example: the islands may be the first to be inundated as sea levels rise

inundate.origin: Late 16th century (earlier (late Middle English) as inundation) from Latin inundat- ‘flooded’, from the verb inundare, from in- ‘into, upon’ + undare ‘to flow’ (from unda ‘a wave’).

adverb.definition: In every case or on every occasion; always.
adverb.example: ranch meals are invariably big and hearty

verb.definition: Persuade (someone) to do something by means of deception or flattery.
verb.example: we cannot inveigle him into putting pen to paper

inveigle.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘beguile, deceive’; formerly also as enveigle): from Anglo-Norman French envegler, alteration of Old French aveugler ‘to blind’, from aveugle ‘blind’.

verb.definition: Call on (a deity or spirit) in prayer, as a witness, or for inspiration.
Cite or appeal to (someone or something) as an authority for an action or in support of an argument.
verb.example: the antiquated defence of insanity is rarely invoked in England

verb.definition: Cause (a procedure) to be carried out.

invoke.origin: Late 15th century from French invoquer, from Latin invocare, from in- ‘upon’ + vocare ‘to call’.

adverb.definition: Without will or conscious control.
adverb.example: she shuddered involuntarily at the memory

adverb.definition: Against someone's will; without someone's cooperation.
adverb.example: Alicia had her husband involuntarily hospitalized

noun.definition: Anger.
noun.example: the plans provoked the ire of conservationists

ire.origin: Middle English via Old French from Latin ira.

verb.definition: Irritate; annoy.
verb.example: it irks her to think of the runaround she received

irk.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘be annoyed or disgusted’): perhaps from Old Norse yrkja ‘to work’.

adjective.definition: Not connected with or relevant to something.
adjective.example: an irrelevant comment

it's not what it looks like..bengali: এটি দেখতে যেমন দেখাচ্ছে তেমন নয়।
it's not what it looks like..word: it's not what it looks like.

noun.definition: A device for lifting heavy objects, especially one for raising the axle of a motor vehicle off the ground so that a wheel can be changed or the underside inspected.
A playing card bearing a representation of a soldier, page, or knave, normally ranking next below a queen.
A small white ball in bowls, at which the players aim.
A game played by tossing and catching small round pebbles or star-shaped pieces of metal or plastic.

noun.example: he had that world-weary look of the working Jack who'd seen everything

noun.definition: A small version of a national flag flown at the bow of a vessel in harbour to indicate its nationality.
noun.example: At daylight we hoisted the jack for a pilot and a Delaware pilot came off, Boat C, but couldn't take us to New York.

noun.definition: Money.
A device for turning a spit.
noun.example: When running a spit from a weight driven clockwork jack, it is essential to ensure that the joint or bird is properly centred, or the spit may stop running.

noun.definition: A part of the mechanism in a spinet or harpsichord that connects a key to its corresponding string and causes the string to be plucked when the key is pressed down.
A marine fish that is typically laterally compressed with a row of large spiky scales along each side, important in many places as food or game fish.
The male of various animals, especially a merlin or (US) an ass.
noun.example: A mule results from a cross between a female horse, or mare, and a male donkey, or jack.

noun.definition: Used in names of animals that are smaller than similar kinds, e.g. jack snipe.
noun.example: The Jack Snipe is an extremely difficult bird to see, partly because they are not very common but mostly because they are so well-camouflaged they will often sit unnoticed and let you walk past them.

noun.definition: short for jack shit

jack.origin: Late Middle English from Jack, pet form of the given name John. The term was used originally to denote an ordinary man (jack (sense 6)), also a youth (mid 16th century), hence the ‘knave’ in cards and ‘male animal’. The word also denoted various devices saving human labour, as though one had a helper (jack (sense 1, jack sense 3, jack sense 9, jack sense 10), and in compounds such as jackhammer and jackknife); the general sense ‘labourer’ arose in the early 18th century and survives in cheapjack, lumberjack, steeplejack, etc. Since the mid 16th century a notion of ‘smallness’ has arisen, hence jack (sense 4, jack sense 5, jack sense 7, jack sense 13).

noun.definition: another term for blackjack (sense 5)
A sleeveless padded tunic worn by foot soldiers.

verb.definition: Take (something) illicitly; steal.
verb.example: what's wrong is to jack somebody's lyrics and not acknowledge the fact

adjective.definition: Tired of or bored with someone or something.
adjective.example: people are getting jack of strikes

jack.origin: Late 19th century from jack up ‘give up’ (see jack up).

noun.definition: A slender long-legged wild dog that feeds on carrion, game, and fruit and often hunts cooperatively, found in Africa and southern Asia.

jackal.origin: Early 17th century from Turkish çakal, from Persian šagāl. The change in the first syllable was due to association with jack.

adjective.definition: Feeling or showing an envious resentment of someone or their achievements, possessions, or perceived advantages.
adjective.example: she was always jealous of me

jealous.origin: Middle English from Old French gelos, from medieval Latin zelosus (see zealous).

verb.definition: Put (someone or something) into a situation in which there is a danger of loss, harm, or failure.
verb.example: a devaluation of the dollar would jeopardize New York's position as a financial centre

jibber-jabber.bengali: Jibber jabber is Incoherent and unintelligible rapid speech often in slang or patois. Used in the UK as a disparaging name for other languages such as French, Spanish or American.
jibber-jabber.example:
“It was all jibber jabber. Couldn’t understand a dam’ word the wretched feller was sayin’, Jeeves.”
“But, Milord, he was an American.”
“Yes?”

noun.definition: Rapid and excited speech that is difficult to understand.
noun.example: enough jibber-jabber from me; let's get on with the story!

verb.definition: Talk in a rapid and excited way that is difficult to understand.
verb.example: he was jibber-jabbering with his wife through the entire first piece

jibber-jabber.origin: Early 19th century related to gibber, jabber.

adjective.definition: Happy and cheerful.
adjective.example: he was a jolly man full of jokes

adverb.definition: Very; extremely.
adverb.example: he is jolly busy

noun.definition: A party or celebration.
noun.example: these events were jollies

verb.definition: Encourage (someone) in a friendly way.
verb.example: he jollied people along

jolly.origin: Middle English from Old French jolif, an earlier form of joli ‘pretty’, perhaps from Old Norse jól (see Yule).

noun.definition: A clinker-built ship's boat that is smaller than a cutter, typically hoisted at the stern of the ship.

jolly.origin: Early 18th century perhaps related to yawl.

noun.definition: An abrupt rough or violent movement.
noun.example: he felt a jolt when the plane started to climb

verb.definition: Push or shake (someone or something) abruptly and roughly.
verb.example: a surge in the crowd behind him jolted him forwards

noun.definition: A special anniversary of an event, especially one celebrating twenty-five or fifty years of a reign or activity.
noun.example: to celebrate its jubilee, the club is holding a tournament

noun.definition: A year of emancipation and restoration, kept every fifty years.
A period of remission from the penal consequences of sin, granted by the Roman Catholic Church under certain conditions for a year, usually at intervals of twenty-five years.

jubilee.origin: Late Middle English from Old French jubile, from late Latin jubilaeus (annus) ‘(year) of jubilee’, based on Hebrew yōḇēl, originally ‘ram's-horn trumpet’, with which the jubilee year was proclaimed.

adjective.definition: Having or showing eagerness or enthusiasm.
adjective.example: a keen gardener

adjective.definition: (of a sense) highly developed.
adjective.example: I have keen eyesight

adjective.definition: (of the edge or point of a blade) sharp.
adjective.example: the keen blade went through the weeds

adjective.definition: (of activity or feeling) intense.
adjective.example: there could be keen competition to provide the service

adjective.definition: Excellent.
adjective.example: I would soon fly to distant stars—how keen!

keen.origin: Old English cēne ‘wise, clever’, also ‘brave, daring’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch koen and German kühn ‘bold, brave’. Current senses date from Middle English.

noun.definition: An Irish funeral song accompanied by wailing in lamentation for the dead.

verb.definition: Wail in grief for a dead person.
verb.example: the body of Johnny was taken by his own people who keened over him

keen.origin: Mid 19th century from Irish caoinim ‘I wail’.

kid.example: 1. I kid you not: আমি আপনার সাথে ঠাট্টা করছি না2. I kid, of course.

noun.definition: A child or young person.
noun.example: she collected the kids from school

noun.definition: A young goat.

verb.definition: (of a goat) give birth.
verb.example: milk fever usually occurs in heavy milkers shortly after kidding

kid.origin: Middle English (in kid (sense 2 of the noun)): from Old Norse kith, of Germanic origin; related to German Kitze.

kid.example: 1. I kid you not: আমি আপনার সাথে ঠাট্টা করছি না2. I kid, of course.

verb.definition: Deceive (someone) in a playful way; tease.
verb.example: you're kidding me!

kid.origin: Early 19th century perhaps from kid, expressing the notion ‘make a child or goat of’.

kid.example: 1. I kid you not: আমি আপনার সাথে ঠাট্টা করছি না2. I kid, of course.

noun.definition: A small wooden tub, especially a sailor's mess tub for grog or rations.

kid.origin: Mid 18th century perhaps a variant of kit.

noun.definition: A furnace or oven for burning, baking, or drying, especially one for calcining lime or firing pottery.

kiln.origin: Old English cylene, from Latin culina ‘kitchen, cooking stove’.

noun.definition: A fund of money for communal use, made up of contributions from a group of people.
(in bowls) the jack.

kitty.origin: Early 19th century (denoting a jail): of unknown origin.

noun.definition: A pet name or a child's name for a kitten or cat.

kmn.example:
Person 1: when will all these election ads be done?
Person 2: november.
Person 1: kmn

noun.definition: The joint between the thigh and the lower leg in humans.
An angled piece of wood or metal frame used to connect and support the beams and timbers of a wooden ship.
noun.example: The deck and hull are through bolted on an inward flange and structural knees and bulkheads are securely attached.

noun.definition: An abrupt obtuse or approximately right-angled bend in a graph between parts where the slope varies smoothly.

verb.definition: Hit (someone) with one's knee.
verb.example: she kneed him in the groin

knee.origin: Old English cnēow, cnēo, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch knie and German Knie, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin genu and Greek gonu.

knock (one) off (one's) feet.bengali: To thoroughly impress, overwhelm, or excite one.
knock (one) off (one's) feet.example: 1. you knocked me off my feet 2. The final 30 minutes of the film completely knocked me off my feet.

adverb.definition: In a way that suggests one has secret knowledge or awareness.
adverb.example: Amy looked at me knowingly

adverb.definition: In full awareness or consciousness; deliberately.
adverb.example: when a journalist knowingly misleads their readers

adjective.definition: Heavily loaded or weighed down.
adjective.example: a tree laden with apples

laden.origin: Late 16th century past participle of lade.

noun.example: a time lag between infection and symptoms

noun.definition: A retardation in an electric current or movement.
noun.example: With a longitudinal bias field, there was a lag of about 3.5 ns as the magnetization responded to the switching pulse.

verb.definition: Fail to keep up with another or others in movement or development.
verb.example: they waited for Tim who was lagging behind

verb.definition: another term for string (sense 6 of the verb)

lag.origin: Early 16th century (as a noun in the sense ‘hindmost person in a game, race, etc.’, also ‘dregs’): related to the dialect adjective lag(perhaps from a fanciful distortion of last, or of Scandinavian origin: compare with Norwegian dialect lagga ‘go slowly’).

verb.definition: Enclose or cover (a boiler, pipes, etc.) with material that provides heat insulation.
verb.example: all pipes and tanks in the attic should be lagged

lag.origin: Late 19th century from earlier lag ‘piece of insulating cover’.

noun.definition: A person who has been frequently convicted and sent to prison.
noun.example: both old lags were sentenced to ten years' imprisonment

verb.definition: Arrest or send to prison.
verb.example: they were nearly lagged by the constables

lag.origin: Late 16th century (as a verb in the sense ‘carry off, steal’): of unknown origin. Current senses date from the 19th century.

noun.definition: A collapse of a mass of earth or rock from a mountain or cliff.
noun.example: the road was blocked by a landslide

noun.definition: An overwhelming majority of votes for one party or candidate in an election.
noun.example: they won by a landslide

verb.definition: (of a person, animal, or plant) lose or lack vitality; grow weak.
verb.example: plants may appear to be languishing simply because they are dormant

verb.definition: Be forced to remain in an unpleasant place or situation.
verb.example: he has been languishing in jail since 1974

languish.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘become faint, feeble, or ill’): from Old French languiss-, lengthened stem of languir ‘languish’, from a variant of Latin languere, related to laxus ‘loose, lax’.

noun.definition: The active immature form of an insect, especially one that differs greatly from the adult and forms the stage between egg and pupa, e.g. a caterpillar or grub.

larva.origin: Mid 17th century (denoting a disembodied spirit or ghost): from Latin, literally ‘ghost, mask’.

noun.definition: A sharp blow or stroke with a whip or rope.
noun.example: he was sentenced to fifty lashes for his crime

noun.definition: An eyelash.
noun.example: she fluttered her long dark lashes

verb.definition: Strike or beat with a whip or stick.
verb.example: they lashed him repeatedly about the head

verb.definition: (of an animal) move (a part of the body, especially the tail) quickly and violently.
verb.example: the cat was lashing its tail back and forth

verb.definition: Fasten (something) securely with a cord or rope.
verb.example: the hatch was securely lashed down

lash.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘make a sudden movement’): probably imitative.

noun.definition: A thin flat strip of wood, especially one of a series forming a foundation for the plaster of a wall.

verb.definition: Cover with laths.

lath.origin: Old English lætt, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch lat and German Latte, also to lattice.

noun.definition: Praise.
noun.example: all glory, laud, and honour to Thee Redeemer King

verb.definition: Praise (a person or their achievements) highly.
verb.example: the obituary lauded him as a great statesman and soldier

laud.origin: Late Middle English the noun from Old French laude, the verb from Latin laudare, both from Latin laus, laud- ‘praise’ (see also lauds).

adjective.definition: Not sufficiently strict, severe, or careful.
adjective.example: lax security arrangements at the airport

adjective.definition: (of the limbs or muscles) relaxed.
adjective.example: muscles have more potential energy when they are stretched than when they are lax

lax.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘loose’, said of the bowels): from Latin laxus.

noun.definition: Lacrosse.
noun.example: I wore pads and a helmet whenever I played lax

lax.origin: 1950s abbreviation of lacrosse, with x representing crosse (by association with cross).

noun.definition: A light-emitting diode (a semiconductor diode which glows when a voltage is applied)
noun.example: light sources can be fluorescent tubes, optical fibres, or LEDs

noun.definition: A lascivious or unpleasant look.
noun.example: he gave me a sly leer

verb.definition: Look or gaze in a lascivious or unpleasant way.
verb.example: bystanders were leering at the nude painting

leer.origin: Mid 16th century (in the general sense ‘look sideways or askance’): perhaps from obsolete leer ‘cheek’, from Old English hlēor, as though the sense were ‘to glance over one's cheek’.

adjective.definition: Denoting or relating to software or hardware that has been superseded but is difficult to replace because of its wide use.

noun.definition: An amount of money or property left to someone in a will.
noun.example: my grandmother died and unexpectedly left me a small legacy

noun.definition: An applicant to a particular college or university who is regarded preferentially because a parent or other relative attended the same institution.
noun.example: being a legacy increased a student's chance of being accepted to a highly selective college by up to 45 per cent

legacy.origin: Late Middle English (also denoting the function or office of a deputy, especially a papal legate): from Old French legacie, from medieval Latin legatia ‘legateship’, from legatus ‘person delegated’ (see legate).

adjective.definition: Conforming to the law or to rules.
adjective.example: his claims to legitimate authority

adjective.definition: Able to be defended with logic or justification; valid.
adjective.example: a legitimate excuse for being late

adjective.definition: Constituting or relating to serious drama as distinct from musical comedy, revue, etc.
adjective.example: the legitimate theatre

verb.definition: Make lawful or justify.
verb.example: the regime was not legitimated by popular support

legitimate.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘born of parents lawfully married to each other’): from medieval Latin legitimatus ‘made legal’, from the verb legitimare, from Latin legitimus ‘lawful’, from lex, leg- ‘law’.

noun.definition: The action of allowing a person or organization the use of a sum of money under an agreement to pay it back later.
noun.example: balance sheets weakened by unwise lending

noun.definition: A high-protein pulse which is dried and then soaked and cooked prior to eating.
The plant which yields lentils, native to the Mediterranean and Africa and grown also for fodder.
noun.example: Settlements began to encourage the growth of plants such as barley and lentils and the domestication of pigs, sheep and goats.

lentil.origin: Middle English from Old French lentille, from Latin lenticula, diminutive of lens, lent- ‘lentil’.

conjunction.definition: With the intention of preventing (something undesirable); to avoid the risk of.
conjunction.example: he spent whole days in his room, wearing headphones lest he disturb anyone

lest.origin: Old English thȳ lǣs the ‘whereby less that’, later the læste.

noun.definition: An act of levying a tax, fee, or fine.
noun.example: police forces receive 49 per cent of their funding via a levy on the rates

noun.definition: An act of enlisting troops.
noun.example: Edward I and Edward II had made substantial use of the feudal levy for raising an army

verb.definition: Impose (a tax, fee, or fine)
verb.example: a tax of two per cent was levied on all cargoes

verb.definition: Enlist (someone) for military service.
verb.example: he sought to levy one man from each vill for service

levy.origin: Middle English (as a noun): from Old French levee, feminine past participle of lever ‘raise’, from Latin levare, from levis ‘light’.

adjective.definition: Responsible by law; legally answerable.
adjective.example: the credit-card company is liable for any breach of contract

adjective.definition: Likely to do or to be something.
adjective.example: patients were liable to faint if they stood up too suddenly

liable.origin: Late Middle English perhaps from Anglo-Norman French, from French lier ‘to bind’, from Latin ligare.

noun.definition: Sexual desire.
noun.example: loss of libido

libido.origin: Early 20th century from Latin, literally ‘desire, lust’.

noun.definition: A platform or compartment housed in a shaft for raising and lowering people or things to different levels.
noun.example: Alice went up to the second floor in the lift

noun.definition: An act of lifting.
noun.example: weightlifters attempting a particularly heavy lift

noun.definition: A free ride in another person's vehicle.
noun.example: Miss Green is giving me a lift to school

noun.definition: A feeling of confidence or cheerfulness.
noun.example: winning this match has given everyone a lift

verb.definition: Raise to a higher position or level.
verb.example: he lifted his trophy over his head

verb.definition: Pick up and move to a different position.
verb.example: he lifted her down from the pony's back

verb.definition: Raise (a person's spirits or confidence)
verb.example: we heard inspiring talks which lifted our spirits

verb.definition: Formally remove or end (a legal restriction, decision, or ban)
verb.example: the European Community lifted its oil embargo against South Africa

verb.definition: Carry off or win (a prize or event)
verb.example: she staged a magnificent comeback to lift the British Open title

lift.origin: Middle English from Old Norse lypta, of Germanic origin; related to loft.

light-headed.bengali: 1. লঘুচিত্ত 2 : mentally disoriented : dizzy 3 : lacking in maturity or seriousness : frivolous

adjective.definition: Dizzy and slightly faint.
adjective.example: she felt light-headed with relief

noun.definition: Alcoholic drink, especially distilled spirits.
Liquid in which something has been steeped or cooked.
noun.example: These had been slightly glazed with concentrated poaching liquor and dusted with what tasted like ground-down, caramelised peach crisps.

verb.definition: Dress (leather) with grease or oil.
Steep (something, especially malt) in water.

liquor.origin: Middle English (denoting liquid or something to drink): from Old French lic(o)ur, from Latin liquor; related to liquare ‘liquefy’, liquere ‘be fluid’.

noun.definition: A means of securing the necessities of life.

livelihood.origin: Old English līflād ‘way of life’, from līf ‘life’ + lād ‘course’ (see lode). The change in the word's form in the 16th century was due to association with lively and -hood.

noun.definition: Farm animals regarded as an asset.
noun.example: markets for the trading of livestock

verb.definition: Feel intense dislike or disgust for.
verb.example: she loathed him on sight

loathe.origin: Old English lāthian, of Germanic origin; related to loath.

noun.definition: (in sport) a ball lobbed over an opponent or a stroke producing this result.

verb.definition: Throw or hit (a ball or missile) in a high arc.
verb.example: he lobbed the ball over their heads

lob.origin: Late 16th century (in the senses ‘cause or allow to hang heavily’ and ‘behave like a lout’): from the archaic noun lob ‘lout’, ‘pendulous object’, probably from Low German or Dutch (compare with modern Dutch lubbe ‘hanging lip’). The current sense dates from the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: A room providing a space out of which one or more other rooms or corridors lead, typically one near the entrance of a public building.
noun.example: they went into the hotel lobby

noun.definition: (in the UK) any of several large halls in the Houses of Parliament in which MPs may meet members of the public.
A group of people seeking to influence legislators on a particular issue.
noun.example: members of the anti-abortion lobby

verb.definition: Seek to influence (a legislator) on an issue.
verb.example: they insist on their right to lobby Congress

lobby.origin: Mid 16th century (in the sense ‘monastic cloister’): from medieval Latin lobia, lobium ‘covered walk, portico’. The verb sense (originally US) derives from the practice of frequenting the lobby of a house of legislature to influence its members into supporting a cause.

noun.definition: A large marine crustacean with a cylindrical body, stalked eyes, and the first of its five pairs of limbs modified as pincers.

verb.definition: Catch lobsters.
verb.example: he has been lobstering in Maine for 50 years

lobster.origin: Old English lopustre, alteration of Latin locusta ‘crustacean, locust’.

adjective.definition: (of a crop) flattened by wind or rain.
adjective.example: in lodged crops there is rapid leaf decay

adjective.definition: Of imposing height.
adjective.example: the elegant square was shaded by lofty palms

adjective.definition: (of wool and other textiles) thick and resilient.
adjective.example: Because fleece is such a lofty, stretchy fabric, use a 3 mm or 3.5 mm stitch length.

lofty.origin: Middle English from loft, influenced by aloft.

loggerhead.example: Two groups of recruiting agencies are at loggerheads over the saudi embassy move to start visa service centres in dhaka under two leading recruiting agents.

noun.definition: A foolish person.

loggerhead.origin: Late 16th century (in loggerhead (sense 3)): from dialect logger ‘block of wood for hobbling a horse’ + head.

plural noun.definition: The detailed organization and implementation of a complex operation.
plural noun.example: the logistics of a large-scale rock show demand certain necessities

noun.definition: The part of the body on both sides of the spine between the lowest (false) ribs and the hip bones.

loin.origin: Middle English from Old French loigne, based on Latin lumbus.

verb.definition: Stand or wait around without apparent purpose.

loiter.origin: Late Middle English perhaps from Middle Dutch loteren ‘wag about’.

adjective.definition: Having no companions; solitary or single.
adjective.example: I approached a lone drinker across the bar

adjective.definition: (of a place) unfrequented and remote.
adjective.example: houses in lone rural settings

lone.origin: Late Middle English shortening of alone.

adjective.definition: Continuing for a long time, especially for longer than is necessary.
adjective.example: long-drawn-out negotiations

noun.definition: A toilet.
noun.example: loo paper

loo.origin: 1940s many theories have been put forward about the word's origin: one suggests the source is Waterloo, a trade name for iron cisterns in the early part of the century; the evidence remains inconclusive.

noun.definition: A gambling card game, popular from the 17th to the 19th centuries, in which a player who fails to win a trick must pay a sum to a pool.

loo.origin: Late 17th century abbreviation of obsolete lanterloo from French lanturlu, a meaningless song refrain.

noun.definition: An apparatus for making fabric by weaving yarn or thread.

loom.origin: Old English gelōma ‘tool’, shortened to lome in Middle English.

noun.definition: A vague and often exaggerated first appearance of an object seen in darkness or fog, especially at sea.
noun.example: the loom of the land

verb.example: vehicles loomed out of the darkness

loom.origin: Mid 16th century probably from Low German or Dutch; compare with East Frisian lōmen ‘move slowly’, Middle High German lüemen ‘be weary’.

noun.definition: A lubricant.
noun.example: a wide variety of lubes and waxes

verb.definition: Lubricate (something)
verb.example: lube the hinge with some oil

lucky duck.bengali: An incredibly lucky person; one who falls into good fortune.
lucky duck.example: A: "I won another bet in the basketball tournament—that's three in a row now!" B: "Wow, you lucky duck!"

adjective.definition: Producing a great deal of profit.
adjective.example: a lucrative career as a stand-up comedian

lucrative.origin: Late Middle English from Latin lucrativus, from lucrat- ‘gained’, from the verb lucrari, from lucrum (see lucre).

noun.definition: A single payment made at a particular time, as opposed to a number of smaller payments or instalments.
noun.example: your pension plan can provide a cash lump sum at retirement as well as a regular income

noun.definition: An abrupt uncontrolled movement, especially an unsteady tilt or roll.
noun.example: the boat gave a violent lurch and he missed his footing

verb.definition: Make an abrupt, unsteady, uncontrolled movement or series of movements; stagger.
verb.example: the car lurched forward

lurch.origin: Late 17th century (as a noun denoting the sudden leaning of a ship to one side): of unknown origin.

noun.definition: Leave an associate or friend abruptly and without assistance or support when they are in a difficult situation.
noun.example: he left you in the lurch when you needed him most

lurch.origin: Mid 16th century (denoting a state of discomfiture): from French lourche, the name of a game resembling backgammon, used in the phrase demeurer lourche ‘be discomfited’.

lynch.example: It is abhorrent and disguting to see people falling victims of public lynching in several parts of the country over a period of several days.

verb.definition: (of a group of people) kill (someone) for an alleged offence without a legal trial, especially by hanging.
verb.example: her father had been lynched for a crime he didn't commit

lynch.origin: Mid 19th century from Lynch's law, named after Capt. William Lynch, head of a self-constituted judicial tribunal in Virginia c1780.

noun.definition: A medium-sized, chiefly forest-dwelling Old World monkey which has a long face and cheek pouches for holding food.

macaque.origin: Late 17th century via French and Portuguese; based on the Bantu morpheme ma (denoting a plural) + kaku ‘monkey’.

noun.definition: A broad, heavy knife used as an implement or weapon, originating in Central America and the Caribbean.

machete.origin: Late 16th century from Spanish, from macho ‘hammer’.

adjective.definition: Masculine in an overly assertive or aggressive way.
adjective.example: the big macho tough guy

noun.definition: A man who is aggressively proud of his masculinity.

noun.definition: A relatively dark, dense object, such as a brown dwarf, a low-mass star, or a black hole, of a kind believed to occur in a halo around a galaxy and to contain a significant proportion of the galaxy's mass.

macho.origin: 1990s acronym from Massive (Astrophysical) Compact Halo Object.

noun.definition: A civil officer who administers the law, especially one who conducts a court that deals with minor offences and holds preliminary hearings for more serious ones.

magistrate.origin: Late Middle English from Latin magistratus ‘administrator’, from magister ‘master’.

noun.definition: A grey-black magnetic mineral which consists of an oxide of iron and is an important form of iron ore.

verb.definition: Wound or injure (a person or animal) so that part of the body is permanently damaged.
verb.example: 100,000 soldiers were killed or maimed

maim.origin: Middle English from Old French mahaignier, of unknown origin.

noun.definition: A complete transformation of the appearance of someone or something.
noun.example: win one of our special pampering makeovers

adjective.definition: Acting as an interim and temporary measure.
adjective.example: arranging a row of chairs to form a makeshift bed

noun.definition: A temporary substitute or device.
The desire to harm someone; ill will.
noun.example: I bear no malice towards anybody

malice.origin: Middle English via Old French from Latin malitia, from malus ‘bad’.

adjective.definition: Evil in nature or effect.
adjective.example: she had a strong and malign influence

verb.definition: Speak about (someone) in a spitefully critical manner.
verb.example: don't you dare malign her in my presence

malign.origin: Middle English via Old French maligne (adjective), malignier (verb), based on Latin malignus ‘tending to evil’, from malus ‘bad’.

verb.definition: Destroy or severely damage by tearing or crushing.
verb.example: the car was mangled almost beyond recognition

mangle.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French mahangler, perhaps a frequentative of mahaignier ‘maim’.

noun.definition: A machine having two or more rollers turned by a handle, between which wet laundry is squeezed to remove excess moisture.

verb.definition: Press or squeeze with a mangle.
verb.example: the hard household labour often involved pounding clothes in a dolly tub and mangling them with a hand wringer

mangle.origin: Late 17th century from Dutch mangel, from mangelen ‘to mangle’, from medieval Latin mango, manga, from Greek manganon ‘axis, engine of war’.

noun.definition: A dummy used to display clothes in a shop window.
The female of a horse or other equine animal.

mare.origin: Old English mearh ‘horse’, mere ‘mare’, from a Germanic base with cognates in Celtic languages meaning ‘stallion’.

noun.definition: A very unpleasant or frustrating experience.
noun.example: this week is going to be a bit of a mare but at least the end is in sight

noun.definition: A large, level basalt plain on the surface of the moon, appearing dark by contrast with highland areas.
noun.example: the maria are largely confined to the near side of the moon

mare.origin: Mid 19th century special use of Latin mare ‘sea’; these areas were once thought to be seas.

noun.definition: Cannabis, especially as smoked or consumed as a psychoactive (mind-altering) drug.
noun.example: the cops told us that he had been smoking marijuana

marijuana.origin: Late 19th century from Latin American Spanish.

adjective.definition: Of a brownish-red colour.
adjective.example: ornate maroon and gold wallpaper

noun.definition: A brownish-red colour.
noun.example: the hat is available in either white or maroon

noun.definition: A firework that makes a loud bang, used as a signal or warning.

maroon.origin: Late 17th century (in the sense ‘chestnut’): from French marron ‘chestnut’, via Italian from medieval Greek maraon. The sense relating to colour dates from the late 18th century.

verb.definition: Leave (someone) trapped and alone in an inaccessible place, especially an island.
verb.example: a novel about schoolboys marooned on a desert island

maroon.origin: Early 18th century from Maroon, originally in the form marooned ‘lost in the wilds’.

noun.definition: A member of any of various communities in parts of the Caribbean who were originally descended from escaped slaves. In the 18th century Jamaican Maroons fought two wars against the British, both of which ended with treaties affirming the independence of the Maroons.

maroon.origin: Mid 17th century from French marron ‘feral’, from Spanish cimarrón ‘wild’, (as a noun) ‘runaway slave’.

noun.definition: Motherhood.
noun.example: she is not a woman with an interest in maternity

maternity.origin: Early 17th century from French maternité, from Latin maternus, from mater ‘mother’.

verb.definition: Intend to convey or refer to (a particular thing); signify.
verb.example: I don't know what you mean

verb.definition: Intend (something) to occur or be the case.
verb.example: they mean no harm

verb.definition: Have as a consequence or result.
verb.example: the proposals are likely to mean another hundred closures

mean.origin: Old English mænan, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch meenen and German meinen, from an Indo-European root shared by mind.
mean.prep: by all means: যে কোন উপায়ে

adjective.definition: Unwilling to give or share things, especially money; not generous.
adjective.example: she felt mean not giving a tip

adjective.definition: Unkind, spiteful, or unfair.
adjective.example: I was mean to them over the festive season

adjective.definition: (especially of a place) poor in quality and appearance; shabby.
adjective.example: her home was mean and small

adjective.definition: Very skilful or effective; excellent.
adjective.example: he's a mean cook

mean.origin: Middle English, shortening of Old English gemǣne, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin communis ‘common’. The original sense was ‘common to two or more people’, later ‘inferior in rank’, leading to mean (sense 3) and a sense ‘ignoble, small-minded’, from which mean (sense 1 and mean sense 2) (which became common in the 19th century) arose.
mean.prep: by all means: যে কোন উপায়ে

adjective.definition: (of a quantity) calculated as a mean; average.
adjective.example: participants in the study had a mean age of 35 years

adjective.definition: Equally far from two extremes.
adjective.example: hope is the mean virtue between despair and presumption

noun.definition: The value obtained by dividing the sum of several quantities by their number; an average.
noun.example: acid output was calculated by taking the mean of all three samples

noun.definition: A condition, quality, or course of action equally removed from two opposite extremes.
noun.example: the measure expresses a mean between saving and splashing out

mean.origin: Middle English from Old French meien, from Latin medianus ‘middle’ (see median).
mean.prep: by all means: যে কোন উপায়ে

noun.definition: A plan or course of action taken to achieve a particular purpose.
noun.example: cost-cutting measures

noun.definition: A standard unit used to express the size, amount, or degree of something.
noun.example: a furlong is an obsolete measure of length

noun.definition: A certain quantity or degree of something.
noun.example: the states retain a large measure of independence

noun.definition: The rhythm of a piece of poetry or a piece of music.
noun.example: The golden measure of poetry does not yet exist, only the rhythm of the maracas, the exact sound of the kettledrum.

noun.definition: A group of rock strata.

verb.definition: Ascertain the size, amount, or degree of (something) by using an instrument or device marked in standard units.
verb.example: the amount of water collected is measured in pints

verb.definition: Assess the importance, effect, or value of (something)
verb.example: it is hard to measure teaching ability

verb.definition: Travel over (a certain distance or area)
verb.example: we must measure twenty miles today

measure.origin: Middle English (as a noun in the senses ‘moderation’, ‘instrument for measuring’, ‘unit of capacity’): from Old French mesure, from Latin mensura, from mens- ‘measured’, from the verb metiri.

adjective.definition: Connected indirectly through another person or thing; involving an intermediate agency.
adjective.example: public law institutions are a type of mediate state administration

verb.definition: Intervene in a dispute in order to bring about an agreement or reconciliation.
verb.example: Wilson attempted to mediate between the powers to end the war

verb.definition: Bring about (a result such as a physiological effect)
verb.example: the right hemisphere plays an important role in mediating tactile perception of direction

mediate.origin: Late Middle English (as an adjective in the sense ‘interposed’): from late Latin mediatus ‘placed in the middle’, past participle of the verb mediare, from Latin medius ‘middle’.

noun.definition: A person or thing that is likely to cause harm; a threat or danger.
noun.example: a new initiative aimed at beating the menace of drugs

verb.definition: Be a threat or possible danger to.
verb.example: Africa's elephants are still menaced by poaching

menace.origin: Middle English via Old French from late Latin minacia, from Latin minax, minac- ‘threatening’, from minae ‘threats’.

noun.definition: A repair in a material.
noun.example: the mend was barely visible

verb.definition: Repair (something that is broken or damaged)
verb.example: workmen were mending faulty cabling

verb.definition: Add fuel to (a fire)
verb.example: he mended the fire and turned the meat on the greenwood racks

adverb.definition: Just; only.
adverb.example: Gary, a silent boy, merely nodded

noun.definition: An expert in or student of meteorology; a weather forecaster.
noun.example: meteorologists predict rain for the rest of the week

adjective.definition: Not severe, serious, or harsh.
adjective.example: mild criticism

adjective.definition: Gentle and not easily provoked.
adjective.example: she was implacable, despite her mild exterior

noun.definition: A kind of dark beer not strongly flavoured with hops.

mild.origin: Old English milde (originally in the sense ‘gracious, not severe in command’), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German mild, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin mollis and Greek malthakos ‘soft’.

adverb.definition: In a mild or gentle manner.
adverb.example: ‘Don't be childish,’ he reproved mildly

mildly.origin: Used to imply that the reality is more extreme, usually worse.

adjective.definition: Favouring confrontational or violent methods in support of a political or social cause.

noun.definition: A militant person.

militant.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘engaged in warfare’): from Old French, or from Latin militant- ‘serving as a soldier’, from the verb militare (see militate). The current sense dates from the early 20th century.

cardinal number.definition: The number equivalent to the product of a thousand and a thousand; 1,000,000 or 10⁶

million.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, probably from Italian milione, from mille ‘thousand’ + the augmentative suffix -one.

noun.definition: An Australian acacia tree with delicate fernlike leaves and yellow flowers.
A plant of a genus that includes the sensitive plant.
A drink of champagne and orange juice.

mimosa.origin: Modern Latin, apparently from Latin mimus ‘mime’ (because the plant seemingly mimics the sensitivity of an animal) + the feminine suffix -osa.

noun.definition: A small freshwater Eurasian fish of the carp family, which typically forms large shoals.

minnow.origin: Late Middle English probably related to Dutch meun and German Münne, influenced by Anglo-Norman French menu ‘small, minnow’.

adjective.definition: Extremely small; tiny.
adjective.example: a minuscule fragment of DNA

adjective.definition: Of or in lower-case letters, as distinct from capitals or uncials.

noun.definition: Minuscule script.
noun.example: the humanistic hands of the 15th century were based on the Carolingian minuscule

minuscule.origin: Early 18th century from French, from Latin minuscula (littera) ‘somewhat smaller (letter)’.

noun.definition: A stretch of swampy or boggy ground.
noun.example: acres of land had been reduced to a mire

noun.definition: A complicated or unpleasant situation from which it is difficult to extricate oneself.
noun.example: the service is sinking in the mire of its own regulations

mire.origin: Middle English from Old Norse mýrr, of Germanic origin; related to moss.

noun.definition: Amusement, especially as expressed in laughter.
noun.example: his six-foot frame shook with mirth

mirth.origin: Old English myrgth, of Germanic origin; related to merry.

noun.definition: The action of misappropriating something; embezzlement.
noun.example: an alleged misappropriation of funds

adjective.definition: Badly conceived or planned.
adjective.example: someone's misbegotten idea of an English country house

noun.definition: Unacceptable or improper behaviour, especially by an employee or professional person.

noun.definition: Mismanagement, especially culpable neglect of duties.

verb.definition: Behave in an improper manner.

verb.definition: Mismanage (an activity)

adjective.definition: (of a person) behaving badly or unlawfully.

noun.definition: A person who has done something wrong or unlawful.

noun.definition: A wrong or inaccurate name or designation.

noun.definition: The action of reducing the severity, seriousness, or painfulness of something.

mitigation.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, or from Latin mitigatio(n-), from the verb mitigare ‘alleviate’ (see mitigate).

noun.definition: A large crowd of people, especially one that is disorderly and intent on causing trouble or violence.
noun.example: a mob of protesters

noun.definition: The Mafia or a similar criminal organization.

noun.definition: A flock or herd of animals.

adjective.definition: Not authentic or real, but without the intention to deceive.

noun.definition: Mock examinations.

adjective.definition: Unassuming in the estimation of one's abilities or achievements.

adjective.definition: (of an amount, rate, or level) relatively moderate, limited, or small.

noun.definition: The quality or state of being unassuming in the estimation of one's abilities.
noun.example: with typical modesty he insisted on sharing the credit with others

noun.definition: The quality of being relatively moderate, limited, or small in amount, rate, or level.
noun.example: the modesty of his political aspirations

noun.definition: Behaviour, manner, or appearance intended to avoid impropriety or indecency.
noun.example: modesty forbade her to undress in front of so many people

noun.definition: A small burrowing mammal with dark velvety fur, a long muzzle, and very small eyes, feeding mainly on worms, grubs, and other invertebrates.

mole.origin: Late Middle English from the Germanic base of Middle Dutch and Middle Low German mol.

noun.example: a mole on her arm had not been there at the beginning of the summer

mole.origin: Old English māl ‘discoloured spot’, of Germanic origin.

noun.definition: A large solid structure on a shore serving as a pier, breakwater, or causeway.

mole.origin: Mid 16th century from French môle, from Latin moles ‘mass’.

noun.definition: The SI unit of amount of substance, equal to the quantity containing as many elementary units as there are atoms in 0.012 kg of carbon-12.

mole.origin: Early 20th century from German Mol, from Molekul, from Latin (see molecule).

noun.definition: An abnormal mass of tissue in the uterus.

mole.origin: Late Middle English from French môle, from Latin mola in the sense ‘false conception’.

noun.definition: A highly spiced Mexican sauce made chiefly from chilli peppers and chocolate, served with meat.

mole.origin: Mexican Spanish, from Nahuatl molli ‘sauce, stew’.

noun.definition: A small to medium-sized primate that typically has a long tail, most kinds of which live in trees in tropical countries.
A sum of £500.

verb.definition: Ape; mimic.

verb.definition: Fill or preoccupy (the mind)
verb.example: her mind was occupied with alarming questions

verb.definition: Take control of (a place, especially a country) by military conquest or settlement.
verb.example: Syria was occupied by France under a League of Nations mandate

occupy.origin: Middle English formed irregularly from Old French occuper, from Latin occupare ‘seize’. A now obsolete vulgar sense ‘have sexual relations with’ seems to have led to the general avoidance of the word in the 17th and most of the 18th century.

cardinal number.example: there's only room for one person
all types of training meet one common standard
the one about the Englishman, the Irishman, and the Yank
a cool one after a day on the water
