the time when you one tackled a field of cane and finished before the others had even started

pronoun.definition: Referring to a person or thing previously mentioned or easily identified.
pronoun.example: her mood changed from one of moroseness to one of joy

pronoun.definition: A person of a specified kind.
pronoun.example: you're the one who ruined her life

pronoun.definition: Used to refer to the speaker, or any person, as representing people in general.
pronoun.example: one must admire him for his willingness

one.origin: Old English ān, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch een and German ein, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin unus. The initial w sound developed before the 15th century and was occasionally represented in the spelling; it was not accepted into standard English until the late 17th century.

noun.definition: A surging rush forward.
noun.example: the mesmerizing onrush of the sea

adjective & adverb.definition: Situated or occurring on land (often used in relation to the oil and gas industry)

verb.definition: (of a company) transfer (a business operation that was moved overseas) back to the country from which it was originally relocated.
verb.example: the case study showed improvement in many key areas once the company decided to onshore its call centre activity

noun.definition: Something that is one's duty or responsibility.
noun.example: the onus is on you to show that you have suffered loss

onus.origin: Mid 17th century from Latin, literally ‘load or burden’.

adjective.definition: Hopeful and confident about the future.
adjective.example: the optimistic mood of the Sixties

noun.definition: A naturally occurring solid material from which a metal or valuable mineral can be extracted profitably.
noun.example: a good deposit of lead-bearing ores

ore.origin: Old English ōra ‘unwrought metal’, of West Germanic origin; influenced in form by Old English ār ‘bronze’ (related to Latin aes ‘crude metal, bronze’).

noun.definition: A monetary unit of Sweden, equal to one hundredth of a krona.
noun.example: Today we use coins with the value 10 krona, 5 krona, 1 krona and 50 öre.

adjective.definition: Elaborately or highly decorated.
adjective.example: an ornate wrought-iron railing

ornate.origin: Late Middle English from Latin ornatus ‘adorned’, past participle of ornare.

adjective.definition: Following or conforming to the traditional or generally accepted rules or beliefs of a religion, philosophy, or practice.
adjective.example: Burke's views were orthodox in his time

adjective.definition: Of the ordinary or usual type; normal.
adjective.example: they avoided orthodox jazz venues

adjective.definition: Relating to Orthodox Judaism.
adjective.example: Orthodox Jewish boys

adjective.definition: Relating to the Orthodox Church.

orthodox.origin: Late Middle English from Greek orthodoxos (probably via ecclesiastical Latin), from orthos ‘straight or right’ + doxa ‘opinion’.

verb.definition: Exclude from a society or group.
verb.example: she was declared a witch and ostracized by the villagers

verb.definition: (in ancient Greece) banish (an unpopular or overly powerful citizen) from a city for five or ten years by popular vote.
verb.example: Themistocles was indeed out of favour at Athens by the end of the 470s, when he was ostracized

ostracize.origin: Mid 17th century from Greek ostrakizein, from ostrakon ‘shell or potsherd’ (on which names were written in voting to banish unpopular citizens).

noun.definition: A flightless swift-running African bird with a long neck, long legs, and two toes on each foot. It is the largest living bird, with males reaching a height of up to 2.75 m.
A person who refuses to face reality or accept facts.
noun.example: don't be an ostrich when it comes to security systems

ostrich.origin: Middle English from Old French ostriche, from Latin avis ‘bird’ + late Latin struthio (from Greek strouthiōn ‘ostrich’, from strouthos ‘sparrow or ostrich’).

noun.definition: Ejection from a property, especially wrongful ejection; deprivation of an inheritance.
noun.example: ouster proceedings to remove the husband from the matrimonial home

noun.definition: Dismissal or expulsion from a position.
noun.example: the junta's ouster of the Emperor

noun.definition: A period when a power supply or other service is not available or when equipment is closed down.
noun.example: frequent power outages

noun.definition: A sudden occurrence of something unwelcome, such as war or disease.
noun.example: the outbreak of World War II

verb.definition: Be far superior to.
verb.example: Villa totally outclassed us in the first half

noun.definition: An extremely strong reaction of anger, shock, or indignation.
noun.example: her voice trembled with outrage

verb.definition: Arouse fierce anger, shock, or indignation in (someone)
verb.example: the public were outraged at the brutality involved

outrage.origin: Middle English (in the senses ‘lack of moderation’ and ‘violent behaviour’): from Old French ou(l)trage, based on Latin ultra ‘beyond’. Sense development has been affected by the belief that the word is a compound of out and rage.

adjective.definition: Shockingly bad or excessive.
adjective.example: an outrageous act of bribery

adjective.definition: Very bold and unusual and rather shocking.
adjective.example: her outrageous leotards and sexy routines

outrageous.origin: Late Middle English from Old French outrageus, from outrage ‘excess’ (see outrage).

adjective.definition: (of the sky or weather) marked by a covering of grey cloud; dull.
adjective.example: a chilly, overcast day

adjective.definition: (of the edge of a piece of fabric) sewn with long slanting stitches to prevent fraying.
adjective.example: Make new zipper stops by hand sewing a few overcast stitches on the edge of each tape just above the last tooth.

noun.definition: Cloud covering a large part of the sky.
noun.example: the planes found the target obscured by overcast

verb.definition: Cover with clouds or shade.
verb.example: the pebbled beach, overcast with the shadows of the high cliffs

verb.definition: Stitch over (a raw edge) to prevent fraying.
verb.example: finish off the raw edge of the hem by overcasting it

noun.definition: A thorough examination of machinery or a system, with repairs or changes made if necessary.
noun.example: a major overhaul of environmental policies

verb.definition: Take apart (a piece of machinery or equipment) in order to examine it and repair it if necessary.
verb.example: the steering box was recently overhauled

verb.definition: Overtake (someone), especially in a sporting event.
verb.example: Jodami overhauled his chief rival

overhaul.origin: Early 17th century (originally in nautical use in the sense ‘release rope tackle by slackening’): from over-+ haul.

verb.definition: Give undue importance to; overemphasize.
verb.example: he thinks the idea of a special relationship between sitter and artist is much overplayed

overplay.origin: 1(in a card game) play or bet on one's hand with a mistaken optimism.2Spoil one's chance of success through excessive confidence in one's position.

adjective.definition: Very great in amount.
adjective.example: his party won overwhelming support

verb.definition: Have an obligation to pay or repay (something, especially money) in return for something received.
verb.example: they have denied they owe money to the company

owe.origin: Old English āgan ‘own, have it as an obligation’, of Germanic origin; from an Indo-European root shared by Sanskrit īs ‘possess, own’. Compare with ought.

adjective.definition: (of money) yet to be paid.
adjective.example: no rent was owing

owing.origin: Because of or on account of.

noun.definition: A single step taken when walking or running.
noun.example: Kirov stepped back a pace

noun.definition: Speed in walking, running, or moving.
noun.example: he's an aggressive player with plenty of pace

verb.definition: Walk at a steady speed, especially without a particular destination and as an expression of anxiety or annoyance.
verb.example: we paced up and down in exasperation

verb.definition: Move or develop (something) at a particular rate or speed.
verb.example: the action is paced to the beat of a perky march

pace.origin: Middle English from Old French pas, from Latin passus ‘stretch (of the leg)’, from pandere ‘to stretch’.

preposition.definition: With due respect to (someone or their opinion), used to express polite disagreement or contradiction.
preposition.example: narrative history, pace some theorists, is by no means dead

pace.origin: Latin, literally ‘in peace’, ablative of pax, as in pace tua ‘by your leave’.

adjective.definition: Light in colour or shade; containing little colour or pigment.
adjective.example: choose pale floral patterns for walls

adjective.definition: Inferior or unimpressive.
adjective.example: the new cheese is a pale imitation of continental cheeses

verb.definition: Become pale in one's face from shock or fear.
verb.example: I paled at the thought of what she might say

verb.definition: Seem or become less important.
verb.example: all else pales by comparison

pale.origin: Middle English from Old French pale, from Latin pallidus; the verb is from Old French palir.

noun.definition: A wooden stake or post used with others to form a fence.
An area within determined bounds, or subject to a particular jurisdiction.
noun.example: The 3 major English Lords whose estates were within the Pale continued to exist, and formed alliances with the neighbouring Irish and became very powerful.

noun.definition: A broad vertical stripe down the middle of a shield.
noun.example: A narrow pale is more likely if it is uncharged, that is, if it does not have other objects placed on it.

pale.origin: Middle English from Old French pal, from Latin palus ‘stake’.

verb.definition: Indulge with every attention, comfort, and kindness; spoil.
verb.example: famous people just love being pampered
synonyms: wait on someone hand and foot

pamper.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘cram with food’): probably of Low German or Dutch origin; compare with German dialect pampfen ‘cram, gorge’; perhaps related to pap.

noun.definition: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
noun.example: the panacea for all corporate ills

panacea.origin: Mid 16th century via Latin from Greek panakeia, from panakēs ‘all-healing’, from pan ‘all’ + akos ‘remedy’.

noun.definition: A sudden sharp pain or painful emotion.
noun.example: Lindsey experienced a sharp pang of guilt

pang.origin: Late 15th century perhaps an alteration of prong.

adjective.definition: Crammed or densely packed.
adjective.example: pang full of meat and bread

noun.definition: Sudden uncontrollable fear or anxiety, often causing wildly unthinking behaviour.
noun.example: she hit him in panic

verb.definition: Feel or cause to feel panic.
verb.example: the crowd panicked and stampeded for the exit

panic.origin: Early 17th century from French panique, from modern Latin panicus, from Greek panikos, from the name of the god Pan, noted for causing terror, to whom woodland noises were attributed.

noun.definition: A cereal and fodder grass of a group including millet.

panic.origin: Late Middle English from Latin panicum, from panus ‘ear of millet’ (literally ‘thread wound on a bobbin’), based on Greek pēnos ‘web’, pēnion ‘bobbin’.

plural noun.example: he thought we were going to be absolute pants

pants.origin: Mid 19th century abbreviation of pantaloons (see pantaloon).

noun.definition: A tropical fruit shaped like an elongated melon, with edible orange flesh and small black seeds.

papaya.origin: Late 16th century from Spanish and Portuguese (see pawpaw).

par.bengali: 1. the established value of the monetary unit of one country expressed in terms of the monetary unit of another country using the same metal as the standard of value 2. common level
par.example: 1. Judged the recording to be on a par with previous ones. 2. A partition storyteller par excellence (about kuldip nayar)

noun.definition: The number of strokes a first-class player should normally require for a particular hole or course.
noun.example: Woosnam had advanced from his overnight position of three under par

noun.definition: The face value of a share or other security, as distinct from its market value.
noun.example: the 9 per cent unsecured loan stock is redeemable at par

verb.definition: Play (a hole) in par.
verb.example: he calmly parred the 17th

par.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘equality of value or standing’): from Latin, ‘equal’, also ‘equality’. The golf term dates from the late 19th century.

par.bengali: 1. the established value of the monetary unit of one country expressed in terms of the monetary unit of another country using the same metal as the standard of value 2. common level
par.example: 1. Judged the recording to be on a par with previous ones. 2. A partition storyteller par excellence (about kuldip nayar)

noun.definition: A paragraph.
noun.example: fifteen pars on the front page

noun.definition: A public procession, especially one celebrating a special day or event.
noun.example: a St George's Day parade

noun.definition: A public square or promenade.
noun.example: we were walking along South Parade

noun.definition: A parade ground.

verb.definition: (of troops) assemble for a formal inspection or ceremonial occasion.
verb.example: the recruits were due to parade that day

verb.definition: Display (someone or something) while marching or moving around a place.
verb.example: they paraded national flags

parade.origin: Mid 17th century from French, literally ‘a showing’, from Spanish parada and Italian parata, based on Latin parare ‘prepare, furnish’.

noun.definition: A typical example or pattern of something; a pattern or model.
noun.example: society's paradigm of the ‘ideal woman’

noun.definition: A set of linguistic items that form mutually exclusive choices in particular syntactic roles.
noun.example: English determiners form a paradigm: we can say ‘a book’ or ‘his book’ but not ‘a his book’

noun.definition: (in the traditional grammar of Latin, Greek, and other inflected languages) a table of all the inflected forms of a particular verb, noun, or adjective, serving as a model for other words of the same conjugation or declension.

paradigm.origin: Late 15th century via late Latin from Greek paradeigma, from paradeiknunai ‘show side by side’, from para- ‘beside’ + deiknunai ‘to show’.

noun.definition: old-fashioned term for alkane

paraffin.origin: Mid 19th century from German, from Latin parum ‘little’ + affinis ‘related’ (from its low reactivity).

adjective.definition: Causing a person or part of the body to become partly or wholly incapable of movement.
adjective.example: the snake's paralyzing venom

particularly.example: I think it's safe to say that we've all done some things we are not particularly proud of.

adverb.definition: To a higher degree than is usual or average.
adverb.example: I don't particularly want to be reminded of that time

adverb.definition: So as to give special emphasis to a point; specifically.
adverb.example: he particularly asked that I should help you

noun.definition: The action of leaving or being separated from someone.
noun.example: they exchanged a few words on parting

noun.definition: The action of dividing something into parts.
noun.example: the parting of the Red Sea

noun.definition: A line of scalp revealed in a person's hair by combing the hair away in opposite directions on either side.
noun.example: his hair was dark, with a side parting

parting.origin: A point at which two people must separate or at which a decision must be taken.

noun.definition: A person who vigorously supports their country and is prepared to defend it against enemies or detractors.
noun.example: a true patriot

patriot.origin: Late 16th century from French patriote, from late Latin patriota ‘fellow countryman’, from Greek patriōtēs, from patrios ‘of one's fathers’, from patris ‘fatherland’.

adjective.definition: Having or expressing devotion to and vigorous support for one's country.
adjective.example: today's game will be played before a fiercely patriotic crowd

patriotic.origin: Mid 17th century via late Latin from Greek patriōtikos ‘relating to a fellow countryman’ (see patriot).

verb.definition: Treat in a way that is apparently kind or helpful but that betrays a feeling of superiority.
verb.example: she was determined not to be put down or patronized

verb.definition: Frequent (a shop, restaurant, or other establishment) as a customer.
verb.example: restaurants and bars regularly patronized by the stars were often crowded with paparazzi

adjective.definition: (of a piece of ground) covered with flat stones or bricks; laid with paving.
adjective.example: a paved courtyard

noun.definition: A raised paved or asphalted path for pedestrians at the side of a road.
noun.example: he fell and hit his head on the pavement

pavement.origin: Middle English from Old French, from Latin pavimentum ‘trodden down floor’, from pavire ‘beat, tread down’.

noun.definition: A surface made up of flat stones laid in a pattern.
noun.example: weeds had forced their way up through the cracked paving

adjective.definition: Different to what is normal or expected; strange.
adjective.example: he gave her some very peculiar looks

adjective.definition: Particular; special.
adjective.example: any attempt to explicate the theme is bound to run into peculiar difficulties

noun.definition: A parish or church exempt from the jurisdiction of the diocese in which it lies, and subject to the direct jurisdiction of the monarch or an archbishop.
noun.example: deans and canons of royal peculiars, notably Westminster Abbey and Windsor

peculiar.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘particular’): from Latin peculiaris ‘of private property’, from peculium ‘property’, from pecu ‘cattle’ (cattle being private property). The sense ‘strange’ dates from the early 17th century.

noun.definition: A person who sells illegal drugs or stolen goods.
noun.example: a drug peddler

noun.definition: variant spelling of pedlar

adjective.definition: (of an animal) pure-bred.
adjective.example: pedigree cats

noun.definition: The record of descent of an animal, showing it to be pure-bred.
noun.example: they are looking for animals with pedigrees

noun.definition: The recorded ancestry or lineage of a person or family.
noun.example: with a pedigree equal to many of the gentry

pedigree.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French pé de grue ‘crane's foot’, a mark used to denote succession in pedigrees.

noun.definition: A quick or furtive look.
noun.example: she sneaked a peek at the map

verb.definition: Look quickly or furtively.
verb.example: faces peeked from behind twitched curtains

peek.origin: Late Middle English pike, pyke, of unknown origin.

noun.definition: The outer covering or rind of a fruit or vegetable.
noun.example: pieces of potato peel

noun.definition: An act of exfoliating dead skin in the cosmetic treatment of microdermabrasion.

verb.definition: Remove the outer covering or skin from (a fruit, vegetable, or prawn)
verb.example: she watched him peel an apple with deliberate care

verb.definition: Remove a thin outer covering or part.
verb.example: I peeled off the tissue paper

verb.definition: (of a surface or object) lose parts of its outer layer or covering in small strips or pieces.
verb.example: the walls are peeling

peel.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘to plunder’): variant of dialect pill, from Latin pilare ‘to strip hair from’, from pilus ‘hair’. The differentiation of peel and pill may have been by association with the French verbs peler ‘to peel’ and piller ‘to pillage’.

noun.definition: A flat implement like a shovel, especially one used by a baker for carrying loaves or similar items of food into or out of an oven.
noun.example: a wooden pizza peel

peel.origin: Late Middle English from Old French pele, from Latin pala, from the base of pangere ‘fasten’.

noun.definition: A small square defensive tower of a kind built in the 16th century in the border counties of England and Scotland.

peel.origin: Probably short for synonymous peel-house peel from Anglo-Norman French pel ‘stake, palisade’, from Latin palus ‘stake’.

verb.definition: Send (another player's ball) through a hoop.
verb.example: the better players are capable of peeling a ball through two or three hoops

peel.origin: Late 19th century from the name of Walter H. Peel, founder of the All England Croquet Association, a leading exponent of the practice.

noun.definition: A quick or furtive look.
noun.example: Jonathan took a little peep at his watch

verb.definition: Look quickly and furtively at something, especially through a narrow opening.
verb.example: his door was ajar and she couldn't resist peeping in

peep.origin: Late 15th century symbolic; compare with peek.

noun.definition: A feeble, high-pitched sound made by a young bird or mammal.
A small sandpiper or similar wading bird.
noun.example: the peeps have returned to Fundy

noun.definition: A group of chickens.
noun.example: a peep of chickens pecking and scratching around the gate

verb.definition: Make a brief, high-pitched sound.
verb.example: Don peeped on his whistle

peep.origin: Late Middle English imitative; compare with cheep.

noun.definition: A piece of land almost surrounded by water or projecting out into a body of water.

peninsula.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin paeninsula, from paene ‘almost’ + insula ‘island’.

penis envy.example: Supposed envy of the male's possession of a penis, postulated by freud to account for some aspects of female behaviour (notably the castration complex) but controversial among modern theorists.

noun.definition: The continuous line forming the boundary of a closed geometrical figure.
noun.example: the perimeter of a rectangle

noun.definition: An instrument for measuring the extent and characteristics of a person's field of vision.

perimeter.origin: Late Middle English via Latin from Greek perimetros, based on peri- ‘around’ + metron ‘measure’.

verb.definition: Die, especially in a violent or sudden way.
verb.example: a great part of his army perished of hunger and disease
synonyms: go the way of all flesh
go to one's last resting place

verb.definition: (of rubber, food, etc.) lose its normal qualities; rot or decay.
verb.example: an abandoned tyre whose rubber had perished

verb.definition: Be suffering from extreme cold.
verb.example: I was perished with cold before the end of the day

perish.origin: Middle English from Old French periss-, lengthened stem of perir, from Latin perire ‘pass away’, from per- ‘through, completely’ + ire ‘go’.

verb.definition: Carry out or commit (a harmful, illegal, or immoral action)
verb.example: a crime has been perpetrated against a sovereign state

perpetrate.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin perpetrat- ‘performed’, from the verb perpetrare, from per- ‘to completion’ + patrare ‘bring about’. In Latin the act perpetrated might be good or bad; in English the verb was first used in the statutes referring to crime, hence the negative association.

perpetrator.example: Malaysia wants the perpetrators of atrocities against the rohingyas be tried immediately at the international criminal court (icc).

noun.definition: A person who carries out a harmful, illegal, or immoral act.
noun.example: the perpetrators of this horrific crime must be brought to justice

verb.definition: Continue in an opinion or course of action in spite of difficulty or opposition.
verb.example: the minority of drivers who persist in drinking
synonyms: not take no for an answer

persist.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin persistere, from per- ‘through, steadfastly’ + sistere ‘to stand’.

adjective.definition: Continuing firmly or obstinately in an opinion or course of action in spite of difficulty or opposition.
adjective.example: one of the government's most persistent critics

adjective.definition: Continuing to exist or occur over a prolonged period.
adjective.example: persistent rain will affect many areas

adjective.definition: (of a part of an animal or plant, such as a horn, leaf, etc.) remaining attached instead of falling off in the normal manner.

plural noun.definition: People employed in an organization or engaged in an organized undertaking such as military service.
plural noun.example: many of the personnel involved require training

personnel.origin: Early 19th century from French (adjective used as a noun), contrasted with matériel ‘equipment or materials used in an organization or undertaking’.

noun.definition: A substance used for destroying insects or other organisms harmful to cultivated plants or to animals.
A formal written request, typically one signed by many people, appealing to authority in respect of a particular cause.
noun.example: she was asked to sign a petition against plans to build on the local playing fields

verb.definition: Present a petition to (an authority) in respect of a particular cause.
verb.example: the organization is petitioning the EU for a moratorium on the patent

petition.origin: Middle English from Latin petitio(n-), from petit- ‘aimed at, sought, laid claim to’, from the verb petere.

noun.definition: The desire to promote the welfare of others, expressed especially by the generous donation of money to good causes.
noun.example: he acquired a considerable fortune and was noted for his philanthropy

philanthropy.origin: Early 17th century via late Latin from Greek philanthrōpia, from philanthrōpos ‘man-loving’ (see philanthrope).

noun.definition: An act or the right of selecting something from a number of alternatives.
noun.example: take your pick from our extensive menu

noun.definition: An act of blocking or screening a defensive player from the ball handler.

verb.definition: Detach and remove (a flower, fruit, or vegetable) from where it is growing.
verb.example: I went to pick some flowers for Jenny's room

verb.definition: Choose (someone or something) from a number of alternatives.
verb.example: maybe I picked the wrong career

verb.definition: Repeatedly pull at something with one's fingers.
verb.example: the old woman was picking at the sheet

verb.definition: Pluck the strings of (a guitar or banjo)
verb.example: people were singing and picking guitars

pick.origin: Middle English (earlier as pike, which continues in dialect use): of unknown origin. Compare with Dutch pikken ‘pick, peck’, and German picken ‘peck, puncture’, also with French piquer ‘to prick’.

noun.definition: A tool consisting of a long handle set at right angles in the middle of a curved iron or steel bar with a point at one end and a chisel edge or point at the other, used for breaking up hard ground or rock.
An instrument for picking.
noun.example: an ebony hair pick

noun.definition: A platform on pillars projecting from the shore into the sea, typically incorporating entertainment arcades and places to eat.
A long, narrow structure projecting from an airport terminal, giving passengers access to an aircraft.
A solid support designed to sustain vertical pressure.

pier.origin: Middle English from medieval Latin pera, of unknown origin.

noun.definition: A heap of things laid or lying one on top of another.
noun.example: he placed the books in a neat pile

noun.definition: A large imposing building or group of buildings.
noun.example: a Victorian Gothic pile

noun.definition: A series of plates of dissimilar metals laid one on another alternately to produce an electric current.
A nuclear reactor.

verb.definition: Place (things) one on top of the other.
verb.example: she piled all the groceries on the counter

verb.definition: (of a group of people) get into or out of (a vehicle) in a disorganized manner.
verb.example: ten of us piled into the minibus

pile.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, from Latin pila ‘pillar, pier’.

noun.definition: A heavy stake or post driven vertically into the bed of a river, soft ground, etc., to support the foundations of a superstructure.
A triangular charge or ordinary formed by two lines meeting at an acute angle, usually pointing down from the top of the shield.

verb.definition: Strengthen or support (a structure) with piles.
verb.example: an earlier bridge may have been piled

pile.origin: Old English pīl ‘dart, arrow’, also ‘pointed stake’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch pijl and German Pfeil, from Latin pilum ‘(heavy) javelin’.

noun.definition: The soft projecting surface of a carpet or a fabric such as velvet or flannel, consisting of many small threads.
noun.example: the thick pile of the new rugs

pile.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘downy feather’): from Latin pilus ‘hair’. The current sense dates from the mid 16th century.

noun.definition: A person who journeys to a sacred place for religious reasons.

noun.example: This is a monument dedicated in 1910 to commemorate the first landing of the Pilgrims in 1620 at Provincetown, where they wrote and signed the Mayflower Compact.

verb.definition: Travel or wander like a pilgrim.
verb.example: he pilgrimed to his old sporting places

pilgrim.origin: Middle English from Provençal pelegrin, from Latin peregrinus ‘foreign’ (see peregrine).

noun.definition: A pilgrim's journey.
noun.example: he wanted to go on a pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostela

verb.definition: Go on a pilgrimage.
verb.example: thousands pilgrimage there every year

pilgrimage.origin: Middle English from Provençal pelegrinage, from pelegrin (see pilgrim).

noun.definition: A man who controls prostitutes and arranges clients for them, taking a percentage of their earnings in return.
A telltale or informer.
noun.example: But he was put in a cell with two Hollywood labour leader pimps.

verb.definition: Act as a pimp.
verb.example: he was a good-looking guy, and some said he pimped on the side

verb.definition: Make (something) more showy or impressive.
verb.example: he pimped up the car with spoilers and twin-spoke 18-inch alloys

verb.definition: Inform on.
verb.example: they'd pimp on you as soon as look at you

noun.definition: A pineapple.

pine.origin: Old English, from Latin pinus, reinforced in Middle English by Old French pin.

verb.definition: Suffer a mental and physical decline, especially because of a broken heart.
verb.example: she thinks I am pining away from love

pine.origin: Old English pīnian ‘(cause to) suffer’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch pijnen, German peinen ‘experience pain’, also to obsolete pine ‘punishment’; ultimately based on Latin poena ‘punishment’.

noun.definition: Urine.
Alcoholic drink, especially beer.
noun.example: we'll need 70 cans of piss for the trip

verb.definition: Urinate.

piss.origin: Middle English from Old French pisser, probably of imitative origin.

noun.definition: A large hole in the ground.
A hollow or indentation in a surface.
An area at the side of a track where racing cars are serviced and refuelled.
noun.example: he had a flat tyre when he came into the pits

noun.definition: An orchestra pit.
A part of the floor of a stock exchange in which a particular stock or commodity is traded.
noun.example: pooled commodity funds liquidated positions in the corn and soybean pits

noun.definition: An enclosure in which animals are made to fight.
noun.example: a bear pit

noun.definition: A person's bed.
A person's armpit.

verb.definition: Set someone or something in conflict or competition with.
verb.example: you'll get the chance to pit your wits against the world champions

verb.definition: Make a hollow or indentation in the surface of.
verb.example: rain poured down, pitting the bare earth

verb.definition: Drive a racing car into the pits for fuel or maintenance.
verb.example: he pitted on lap 36 with sudden engine trouble

pit.origin: Old English pytt, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch put and German Pfütze, based on Latin puteus ‘well, shaft’.

noun.definition: The stone of a fruit.

verb.definition: Remove the pit from (fruit).

pit.origin: Mid 19th century apparently from Dutch; related to pith.

adjective.definition: Of crucial importance in relation to the development or success of something else.
adjective.example: Japan's pivotal role in the world economy

adjective.definition: Fixed on or as if on a pivot.
adjective.example: a sliding or pivotal motion

verb.definition: Make (someone) less angry or hostile.
verb.example: they attempted to placate the students with promises

placate.origin: Late 17th century from Latin placat- ‘appeased’, from the verb placare.

noun.definition: A contagious bacterial disease characterized by fever and delirium, typically with the formation of buboes (bubonic plague) and sometimes infection of the lungs (pneumonic plague).
An unusually large number of insects or animals infesting a place and causing damage.
noun.example: a plague of locusts

noun.definition: A thing causing trouble or irritation.
noun.example: staff theft is usually the plague of restaurants

verb.definition: Cause continual trouble or distress to.
verb.example: he has been plagued by ill health

plague.origin: Late Middle English Latin plaga ‘stroke, wound’, probably from Greek (Doric dialect) plaga, from a base meaning ‘strike’.

noun.definition: A person who brings a case against another in a court of law.
noun.example: the plaintiff commenced an action for damages

plaintiff.origin: Late Middle English from Old French plaintif ‘plaintive’ (used as a noun). The -f ending has come down through Law French; the word was originally the same as plaintive.

noun.definition: A low-growing plant that typically has a rosette of leaves and a slender green flower spike, widely growing as a weed in lawns.

plantain.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, from Latin plantago, plantagin-, from planta ‘sole of the foot’ (because of its broad prostrate leaves).

noun.definition: A banana containing high levels of starch and little sugar, which is harvested green and widely used as a cooked vegetable in the tropics.
The plant which bears the plantain.

plantain.origin: Mid 16th century from Spanish plá(n)tano, probably by assimilation of a South American word to the Spanish plá(n)tano ‘plane tree’.

adjective.definition: (of an argument or statement) seeming reasonable or probable.
adjective.example: a plausible explanation

plausible.origin: Mid 16th century (also in the sense ‘deserving applause or approval’): from Latin plausibilis, from plaus- ‘applauded’, from the verb plaudere.

noun.definition: A request made in an urgent and emotional manner.
noun.example: he made a dramatic plea for disarmament

noun.definition: A formal statement by or on behalf of a defendant or prisoner, stating guilt or innocence in response to a charge, offering an allegation of fact, or claiming that a point of law should apply.
noun.example: he changed his plea to not guilty

plea.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘lawsuit’): from Old French plait, plaid ‘agreement, discussion’, from Latin placitum ‘a decree’, neuter past participle of placere ‘to please’.

adverb.definition: Used in polite requests or questions.
adverb.example: please address letters to the Editor
synonyms: if you would be so good

verb.definition: Cause to feel happy and satisfied.
verb.example: he arranged a fishing trip to please his son

verb.definition: Take only one's own wishes into consideration in deciding how to act or proceed.
verb.example: this is the first time in ages that I can just please myself

please.origin: Middle English from Old French plaisir ‘to please’, from Latin placere.

adjective.definition: Satisfying or appealing.
adjective.example: the pleasing austerity of the surroundings

adjective.definition: Used or intended for entertainment rather than business.
adjective.example: pleasure boats

noun.definition: A feeling of happy satisfaction and enjoyment.
noun.example: she smiled with pleasure at being praised

verb.definition: Give sexual enjoyment or satisfaction to.
verb.example: tell me what will pleasure you

pleasure.origin: Late Middle English from Old French plaisir ‘to please’ (used as a noun). The second syllable was altered under the influence of abstract nouns ending in -ure, such as measure.

noun.definition: Spirited and determined courage.
noun.example: it must have taken a lot of pluck to walk along a path marked ‘Danger’

noun.definition: The heart, liver, and lungs of an animal as food.
noun.example: Put the pluck into cold salted water, boil, then skim and simmer for 1 hour.

verb.definition: Take hold of (something) and quickly remove it from its place.
verb.example: she plucked a blade of grass

verb.definition: Quickly or suddenly remove someone from a dangerous or unpleasant situation.
verb.example: the baby was plucked from a grim orphanage

verb.definition: Sound (a musical instrument or its strings) with one's finger or a plectrum.
verb.example: she picked up her guitar and plucked it idly

pluck.origin: Late Old English ploccian, pluccian, of Germanic origin; related to Flemish plokken; probably from the base of Old French (es)peluchier ‘to pluck’. Sense 1 of the noun is originally boxers' slang.

noun.definition: A person who fits and repairs the pipes, fittings, and other apparatus of water supply, sanitation, or heating systems.

plumber.origin: Late Middle English (originally denoting a person dealing in and working with lead): from Old French plommier, from Latin plumbarius, from plumbum ‘lead’.

noun.definition: An act of jumping or diving into water.
noun.example: fanatics went straight from the hot room to take a cold plunge

verb.definition: Jump or dive quickly and energetically.
verb.example: our little daughters whooped as they plunged into the sea

verb.definition: Push or thrust quickly.
verb.example: he plunged his hands into his pockets

plunge.origin: Late Middle English from Old French plungier ‘thrust down’, based on Latin plumbum ‘lead, plummet’.

adjective.definition: Denoting or relating to clothes of a size larger than those found in standard ranges.
adjective.example: a new line of plus-size bathing suits

noun.definition: A thickness or layer of a folded or laminated material.
noun.example: tiles that have a black PVC ply in the lamination

noun.definition: short for plywood

(in game theory) the number of levels at which branching occurs in a tree of possible outcomes, typically corresponding to the number of moves ahead (in chess strictly half-moves ahead) considered by a computer program.
noun.example: This creates a ‘tree’ of analysis with moves branching at each ply.

ply.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘fold’): from French pli ‘fold’, from the verb plier, from Latin plicare ‘to fold’.

verb.definition: Work steadily with (a tool)
verb.example: a tailor delicately plying his needle

verb.definition: (of a vessel or vehicle) travel regularly over a route, typically for commercial purposes.
verb.example: ferries ply across a strait to the island

verb.definition: Provide someone with (food or drink) in a continuous or insistent way.
verb.example: she plied me with tea and scones

ply.origin: Late Middle English shortening of apply.

verb.definition: Cook (an egg) without its shell in or over boiling water.
verb.example: a breakfast of poached egg and grilled bacon

poach.origin: Late Middle English from Old French pochier, earlier in the sense ‘enclose in a bag’, from poche ‘bag, pocket’.

verb.definition: Illegally hunt or catch (game or fish) on land that is not one's own or in contravention of official protection.
verb.example: 20 tigers are thought to have been poached from national parks

verb.definition: (of an animal) trample or cut up (turf) with its hoofs.
verb.example: zero-grazing saves the fields from poaching

poach.origin: Early 16th century (in the sense ‘push roughly together’): apparently related to poke; sense 1 is perhaps partly from French pocher ‘enclose in a bag’ (see poach).

verb.definition: Think about (something) carefully, especially before making a decision or reaching a conclusion.
verb.example: I pondered the question of what clothes to wear for the occasion

ponder.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘appraise, judge the worth of’): from Old French ponderer ‘consider’, from Latin ponderare ‘weigh, reflect on’, from pondus, ponder- ‘weight’.

noun.definition: A covered shelter projecting in front of the entrance of a building.
noun.example: the north porch of Hereford Cathedral

porch.origin: Middle English from Old French porche, from Latin porticus ‘colonnade’, from porta ‘passage’.

noun.definition: A small toothed whale with a low triangular dorsal fin and a blunt rounded snout.

verb.definition: Move through the water like a porpoise, alternately rising above it and submerging.
verb.example: the boat began to porpoise badly

porpoise.origin: Middle English from Old French porpois, based on Latin porcus ‘pig’ + piscis ‘fish’, rendering earlier porcus marinus ‘sea hog’.

noun.definition: The state of having, owning, or controlling something.
noun.example: she had taken possession of the sofa

noun.definition: Something that is owned or possessed.
noun.example: I had no money or possessions

noun.definition: The state of being controlled by a demon or spirit.
noun.example: they said prayers to protect the people inside the hall from demonic possession

possession.origin: Middle English from Old French, from Latin possessio(n-), from the verb possidere (see possess).

noun.definition: A thing suggested or assumed as true as the basis for reasoning, discussion, or belief.
noun.example: perhaps the postulate of Babylonian influence on Greek astronomy is incorrect

verb.definition: Suggest or assume the existence, fact, or truth of (something) as a basis for reasoning, discussion, or belief.
verb.example: his theory postulated a rotatory movement for hurricanes

verb.definition: (in ecclesiastical law) nominate or elect (someone) to an ecclesiastical office subject to the sanction of a higher authority.
verb.example: the chapter was then allowed to postulate the bishop of Bath

postulate.origin: Late Middle English (in postulate (sense 2 of the verb)): from Latin postulat- ‘asked’, from the verb postulare.

noun.definition: A deep natural underground cave formed by the erosion of rock, especially by the action of water.
A depression or hollow in a road surface caused by wear or subsidence.
noun.example: he drove very cautiously over the potholes in the road

verb.definition: Explore underground potholes as a pastime.
verb.example: they went potholing in the Pennines

pothole.origin: Early 19th century from Middle English pot ‘pit’ (perhaps of Scandinavian origin) + hole.

adjective.definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than theoretical considerations.
adjective.example: a pragmatic approach to politics

pragmatic.origin: Late 16th century (in the senses ‘busy, interfering, conceited’): via Latin from Greek pragmatikos ‘relating to fact’, from pragma ‘deed’ (from the stem of prattein ‘do’). The current senses date from the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: The expression of approval or admiration for someone or something.
noun.example: the audience was full of praise for the whole production

noun.definition: The expression of respect and gratitude as an act of worship.
noun.example: give praise to God

verb.definition: Express warm approval or admiration of.
verb.example: we can't praise Chris enough—he did a brilliant job

verb.definition: Express one's respect and gratitude towards (a deity), especially in song.
verb.example: we praise God for past blessings

praise.origin: Middle English (also in the sense ‘set a price on, attach value to’): from Old French preisier ‘to prize, praise’, from late Latin pretiare, from Latin pretium ‘price’. Compare with prize.

adjective.definition: Preceding in time, order, or importance.
adjective.example: a precedent case

noun.definition: An earlier event or action that is regarded as an example or guide to be considered in subsequent similar circumstances.
noun.example: there are substantial precedents for using interactive media in training

precedent.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, literally ‘preceding’.

noun.definition: The action or process of precipitating a substance from a solution.
Rain, snow, sleet, or hail that falls to or condenses on the ground.
noun.example: these convective processes produce cloud and precipitation

noun.definition: The fact or quality of acting suddenly and rashly.
noun.example: Cora was already regretting her precipitation

precipitation.origin: Late Middle English (denoting the action of falling or throwing down): from Latin praecipitatio(n-), from praecipitare ‘throw down or headlong’ (see precipitate).

adjective.definition: Marked by exactness and accuracy of expression or detail.
adjective.example: precise directions

precise.origin: Late Middle English from Old French prescis, from Latin praecis- ‘cut short’, from the verb praecidere, from prae ‘in advance’ + caedere ‘to cut’.

adverb.definition: In exact terms; without vagueness.
adverb.example: the guidelines are precisely defined

noun.example: if the premise is true, then the conclusion must be true

verb.definition: Base an argument, theory, or undertaking on.
verb.example: the reforms were premised on our findings

premise.origin: Late Middle English from Old French premisse, from medieval Latin praemissa (propositio) ‘(proposition) set in front’, from Latin praemittere, from prae ‘before’ + mittere ‘send’.

plural noun.definition: A house or building, together with its land and outbuildings, occupied by a business or considered in an official context.
plural noun.example: the company has moved to new premises

adjective.definition: Contrary to reason or common sense; utterly absurd or ridiculous.
adjective.example: a preposterous suggestion

preposterous.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin praeposterus ‘reversed, absurd’ (from prae ‘before’ + posterus ‘coming after’) + -ous.

noun.definition: A device for applying pressure to something in order to flatten or shape it or to extract juice or oil.
noun.example: a flower press

noun.definition: A printing press.
Newspapers or journalists viewed collectively.
noun.example: the incident was not reported in the press

noun.definition: An act of pressing something.
noun.example: the system summons medical help at the press of a button

noun.definition: An act of raising a weight to shoulder height and then gradually pushing it upwards above the head.
A large cupboard.

verb.definition: Move or cause to move into a position of contact with something by exerting continuous physical force.
verb.example: he pressed his face to the glass

verb.definition: Apply pressure to (something) to flatten, shape, or smooth it, typically by ironing.
verb.example: she pressed her nicest blouse

verb.definition: Forcefully put forward (an opinion, claim, or course of action)
verb.example: Rose did not press the point

verb.definition: Raise (a specified weight) by lifting it to shoulder height and then gradually pushing it upwards above the head.
Try too hard to achieve distance with a shot, at the risk of inaccuracy.
verb.example: This is not a good golf course to start pressing on.

press.origin: Middle English from Old French presse (noun), presser (verb), from Latin pressare ‘keep pressing’, frequentative of premere.

noun.definition: A forcible enlistment of men, especially for the navy.
noun.example: Any English-speaking, able-bodied, man on leave in a port might find himself swept up in the press.

verb.definition: Put someone or something to a specified use, especially as a temporary or makeshift measure.
verb.example: she was pressed into service as an interpreter

verb.definition: Force (a man) to enlist in the army or navy.
verb.example: At least a third had been pressed into the Navy.

press.origin: Late 16th century alteration (by association with press) of obsolete prest ‘pay given on enlistment, enlistment by such payment’, from Old French prest ‘loan, advance pay’, based on Latin praestare ‘provide’.

noun.definition: A reason given in justification of a course of action that is not the real reason.
noun.example: the rebels had the perfect pretext for making their move

pretext.origin: Early 16th century from Latin praetextus ‘outward display’, from the verb praetexere ‘to disguise’, from prae ‘before’ + texere ‘weave’.

verb.definition: Prove more powerful or superior.
verb.example: it is hard for logic to prevail over emotion

verb.definition: Persuade (someone) to do something.
verb.example: she was prevailed upon to give an account of her work

prevail.origin: Late Middle English from Latin praevalere ‘have greater power’, from prae ‘before’ + valere ‘have power’.

noun.definition: The fact or condition of being prevalent; commonness.
noun.example: the prevalence of obesity in adults

adjective.definition: Widespread in a particular area or at a particular time.
adjective.example: the social ills prevalent in society today

prevalent.origin: Late 16th century from Latin praevalent- ‘having greater power’, from the verb praevalere (see prevail).

noun.definition: The amount of money expected, required, or given in payment for something.
noun.example: land could be sold for a high price

noun.definition: An unwelcome experience or action undergone or done as a condition of achieving an objective.
noun.example: the price of their success was an entire day spent in discussion

verb.definition: Decide the amount required as payment for (something offered for sale)
verb.example: the watches are priced at £55

verb.definition: Discover or establish the price of (something for sale).

price.origin: Middle English the noun from Old French pris, from Latin pretium ‘value, reward’; the verb, a variant (by assimilation to the noun) of earlier prise ‘estimate the value of’ (see prize). Compare with praise.

adjective.definition: Expensive.
adjective.example: boutiques selling pricey clothes

noun.definition: A feeling or deep pleasure or satisfaction derived from one's own achievements, the achievements of those with whom one is closely associated, or from qualities or possessions that are widely admired.
noun.example: the faces of the children's parents glowed with pride

noun.definition: Confidence and self-respect as expressed by members of a group, typically one that has been socially marginalized, on the basis of their shared identity, culture, and experience.
Consciousness of one's own dignity.
noun.example: he swallowed his pride and asked for help

noun.definition: The best state of something; the prime.
noun.example: in the pride of youth

noun.definition: A group of lions forming a social unit.
noun.example: the males in the pride are very tolerant towards all the cubs

verb.definition: Be especially proud of (a particular quality or skill)
verb.example: he prided himself on his honesty
synonyms: pat oneself on the back for

pride.origin: Late Old English prȳde ‘excessive self-esteem’, variant of prȳtu, prȳte, from prūd (see proud).

adjective.definition: Likely to happen or be the case.
adjective.example: it is probable that the economic situation will deteriorate further

noun.definition: A person who is likely to become or do something, especially one who is likely to be chosen for a team.
noun.example: Merson and Wright are probables

probable.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘worthy of belief’): via Old French from Latin probabilis, from probare ‘to test, demonstrate’.

noun.definition: A blunt-ended surgical instrument used for exploring a wound or part of the body.
A thorough investigation into a crime or other matter.
noun.example: a probe into city hall corruption

noun.definition: A projecting device for engaging in a drogue, either on an aircraft for use in in-flight refuelling or on a spacecraft for use in docking with another craft.

verb.definition: Physically explore or examine (something) with the hands or an instrument.
verb.example: hands probed his body from top to bottom

probe.origin: Late Middle English (as a noun): from late Latin proba ‘proof’ (in medieval Latin ‘examination’), from Latin probare ‘to test’. The verb dates from the mid 17th century.

verb.definition: (of people or animals) produce young; reproduce.
verb.example: species that procreate by copulation

procreate.origin: Late Middle English from Latin procreat- ‘generated, brought forth’, from the verb procreare, from pro- ‘forth’ + creare ‘create’.

verb.definition: Obtain (something), especially with care or effort.
verb.example: food procured for the rebels

verb.definition: Persuade or cause (someone) to do something.
verb.example: he procured his wife to sign the mandate for the joint account

procure.origin: Middle English from Old French procurer, from Latin procurare ‘take care of, manage’, from pro- ‘on behalf of’ + curare ‘see to’.

noun.definition: The action of obtaining or procuring something.
noun.example: financial assistance for the procurement of legal advice

noun.definition: A set of related measures or activities with a particular long-term aim.
noun.example: an extensive programme of reforms

noun.definition: A presentation or item on television or radio, especially one broadcast regularly between stated times.
noun.example: a nature programme

noun.definition: A sheet or booklet giving details of items or performers at an event or performance.
noun.example: a theatre programme

verb.example: it is a simple matter to program the computer to recognize such symbols

verb.definition: Arrange according to a plan or schedule.
verb.example: we learn how to programme our own lives

verb.definition: Broadcast (an item)
verb.example: the station does not program enough contemporary works

programme.origin: Early 17th century (in the sense ‘written notice’): via late Latin from Greek programma, from prographein ‘write publicly’, from pro ‘before’ + graphein ‘write’.

adjective.definition: Continuing for a long time or longer than usual; lengthy.
adjective.example: the region suffered a prolonged drought

noun.definition: A paved public walk, typically one along the seafront at a resort.
noun.example: she took a shortcut along the prom

noun.definition: A ball or formal dance at a school or college, especially one held at the end of the academic year for students who are in their final year.
noun.example: he asked me to the school prom but I turned him down
the last night of the Proms

prom.origin: Late 19th century (originally US, in sense ‘formal dance’): short for promenade.

adjective.definition: Important; famous.
adjective.example: she was a prominent member of the city council

adjective.definition: Projecting from something; protuberant.
adjective.example: a man with big, prominent eyes like a lobster's

adjective.definition: Situated so as to catch the attention; noticeable.
adjective.example: the new housing estates are prominent landmarks

noun.definition: A stout drab-coloured moth with tufts on the forewings which stick up while at rest, the caterpillars of which typically have fleshy growths on the back.

prominent.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘projecting’): from Latin prominent- ‘jutting out’, from the verb prominere. Compare with eminent.

adjective.definition: Done without delay; immediate.
adjective.example: she would have died but for the prompt action of two ambulancemen

adverb.definition: Exactly (with reference to a specified time)
adverb.example: I set off at three-thirty prompt

noun.definition: An act of encouraging a hesitating speaker.
noun.example: with barely a prompt, Barbara talked on

noun.definition: The time limit for the payment of an account, stated on a prompt note.

verb.definition: (of an event or fact) cause or bring about (an action or feeling)
verb.example: the violence prompted a wave of refugees to flee the country

verb.definition: Encourage (a hesitating speaker) to say something.
verb.example: ‘And the picture?’ he prompted

prompt.origin: Middle English (as a verb): based on Old French prompt or Latin promptus ‘brought to light’, also ‘prepared, ready’, past participle of promere ‘to produce’, from pro- ‘out, forth’ + emere ‘take’.

noun.definition: A pole or beam used as a temporary support or to keep something in position.
noun.example: he looked around for a prop to pin the door open

noun.definition: A sudden stop made by a horse moving at speed.

verb.definition: Support or keep in position.
verb.example: she propped her chin in the palm of her right hand

verb.definition: (of a horse) come to a dead stop with the forelegs rigid.
verb.example: Kalanisi propped while galloping out and unseated exercise rider Wally Lowsby, who held on to the reins.

prop.origin: Late Middle English probably from Middle Dutch proppe ‘support (for vines)’.

noun.definition: A portable object other than furniture or costumes used on the set of a play or film.
An aircraft propeller.

adjective.definition: Intended to prevent disease.
adjective.example: prophylactic measures

noun.definition: A medicine or course of action used to prevent disease.
noun.example: I took malaria prophylactics

noun.definition: A condom.

prophylactic.origin: Late 16th century from French prophylactique, from Greek prophulaktikos, from pro ‘before’ + phulassein ‘to guard’.

adjective.definition: Corresponding in size or amount to something else.
adjective.example: the punishment should be proportional to the crime

proportional.origin: Late Middle English from late Latin proportionalis, from proportio(n-) (see proportion).

noun.definition: A statement or assertion that expresses a judgement or opinion.
noun.example: the proposition that high taxation is undesirable

noun.definition: A suggested scheme or plan of action, especially in a business context.
noun.example: a detailed investment proposition

noun.definition: A project, task, idea, etc. considered in terms of its likely success or difficulty.
noun.example: setting up your own business can seem an attractive proposition

verb.definition: Make a suggestion of sexual intercourse to (someone), especially in an unsubtle way.
verb.example: she had been propositioned at the party by a subeditor with bad breath

proposition.origin: Middle English from Old French, from Latin propositio(n-), from the verb proponere (see propound).

noun.definition: The institution and conducting of legal proceedings against someone in respect of a criminal charge.
noun.example: the organizers are facing prosecution for noise nuisance

noun.definition: The continuation of a course of action with a view to its completion.
noun.example: the BBC's prosecution of its commercial ends

prosecution.origin: Mid 16th century (in prosecution (sense 2)): from Old French, or from late Latin prosecutio(n-), from prosequi ‘pursue, accompany’ (see prosecute).

noun.definition: A gland surrounding the neck of the bladder in male mammals and releasing a fluid component of semen.

prostate.origin: Mid 17th century via French from modern Latin prostata, from Greek prostatēs ‘one that stands before’, from pro ‘before’ + statos ‘standing’.

noun.definition: The action of providing or supplying something for use.
noun.example: new contracts for the provision of services

noun.definition: An amount or thing supplied or provided.
noun.example: changing levels of transport provision

noun.definition: A condition or requirement in a legal document.
noun.example: the first private prosecution under the provisions of the 1989 Water Act

noun.definition: An appointment to a benefice, especially directly by the Pope rather than by the patron, and originally before it became vacant.
noun.example: Let us take another medieval example, the case of papal provisions in medieval England.

verb.definition: Supply with food, drink, or equipment, especially for a journey.
verb.example: civilian contractors were responsible for provisioning these armies

verb.definition: Set aside an amount in an organization's accounts for a known liability.
verb.example: financial institutions have to provision against loan losses

provision.origin: Late Middle English (also in the sense ‘foresight’): via Old French from Latin provisio(n-), from providere ‘foresee, attend to’ (see provide). The verb dates from the early 19th century.

adverb.definition: Subject to further confirmation; for the time being.
adverb.example: the film, provisionally entitled Skin, is due to be released next year

adjective.definition: Causing anger or another strong reaction, especially deliberately.
adjective.example: a provocative article

provocative.origin: Late Middle English from Old French provocatif, -ive, from late Latin provocativus, from provocat- ‘called forth, challenged’, from the verb provocare (see provoke).

adjective.definition: Causing annoyance; irritating.
adjective.example: there is evidence of provoking conduct and loss of self-control

adjective.definition: Giving rise to the specified reaction or emotion.
adjective.example: fear-provoking

noun.definition: Skill or expertise in a particular activity or field.
noun.example: his prowess as a fisherman

noun.definition: Bravery in battle.
noun.example: the hereditary nobility had no monopoly of skill and prowess in war

prowess.origin: Middle English (in prowess (sense 2)): from Old French proesce, from prou ‘valiant’. Sense 1 dates from the early 20th century.

puff.example: Tank engine with real puffing smoke

noun.definition: A short, explosive burst of breath or wind.
noun.example: a puff of wind swung the weathercock round

noun.definition: A light pastry case, typically one made of puff pastry, containing a sweet or savoury filling.
noun.example: a jam puff

noun.definition: A review of a work of art, book, or theatrical production, especially an excessively complimentary one.
noun.example: the publishers sent him a copy of the book hoping for a puff

noun.definition: A gathered mass of material in a dress or other garment.
A powder puff.
noun.example: she sent her a box of dusting powder with a swansdown puff

verb.definition: Breathe in repeated short gasps.
verb.example: exercises that make you puff

verb.definition: Swell or become swollen.
verb.example: he suddenly sucked his stomach in and puffed his chest out

verb.definition: Advertise with exaggerated or false praise.
verb.example: publishers have puffed the book on the grounds that it contains new discoveries
synonyms: put in a good word for

puff.origin: Middle English imitative of the sound of a breath, perhaps from Old English pyf (noun), pyffan (verb).

noun.definition: An act of pulling something.
noun.example: give the hair a quick pull and it comes out by the roots

noun.definition: A force drawing someone or something in a particular direction.
noun.example: the pull of the water tore her away

noun.definition: (in sport) a pulling stroke.
A printer's proof.
noun.example: Proof ‘pulls’ of World War propaganda posters are quite rare.

verb.definition: Exert force on (someone or something) so as to cause movement towards oneself.
verb.example: he pulled them down on to the couch

verb.definition: Move steadily in a specified direction or manner.
verb.example: the bus was about to pull away

verb.definition: Attract (someone) as a customer; cause to show interest in something.
verb.example: anyone can enter the show if they have a good act and the ability to pull a crowd

verb.definition: Cancel or withdraw (an entertainment or advertisement)
verb.example: the gig was pulled at the first sign of difficulty

verb.definition: Play (the ball) round to the leg side from the off.
(of a lineman) withdraw from and cross behind the line of scrimmage to block opposing players and clear the way for a runner.
verb.example: he may be their best ever lineman—he can run and pull with the best

verb.definition: Print (a proof).
verb.example: A proof sheet would be pulled, and read against the manuscript.

pull.origin: Old English pullian ‘pluck, snatch’; origin uncertain; the sense has developed from expressing a short sharp action to one of sustained force.

verb.definition: Expand and contract with strong regular movements.
verb.example: blood vessels throb and pulsate

pulsate.origin: Late 17th century (earlier (Middle English) as pulsation): from Latin pulsat- ‘throbbed, pulsed’, from the verb pulsare, frequentative of pellere ‘to drive, beat’.

noun.definition: A rhythmical throbbing of the arteries as blood is propelled through them, typically as felt in the wrists or neck.
noun.example: the doctor found a faint pulse

noun.definition: A single vibration or short burst of sound, electric current, light, or other wave.
noun.example: a pulse of gamma rays

noun.definition: The central point of energy and organization in an area or activity.
noun.example: those close to the financial and economic pulse maintain that there have been fundamental changes

noun.definition: A measured amount of an isotopic label given to a culture of cells.

verb.definition: Throb rhythmically; pulsate.
verb.example: a knot of muscles at the side of his jaw pulsed

verb.definition: Modulate (a wave or beam) so that it becomes a series of pulses.
verb.example: the current was pulsed

pulse.origin: Late Middle English from Latin pulsus ‘beating’, from pellere ‘to drive, beat’.

noun.definition: The edible seed of a leguminous plant, for example a chickpea, lentil, or bean.
noun.example: use pulses such as peas and lentils to eke out meat dishes

pulse.origin: Middle English from Old French pols, from Latin puls ‘porridge of meal or pulse’; related to pollen.

noun.definition: A large rounded orange-yellow fruit with a thick rind, the flesh of which can be used in sweet or savoury dishes.
The plant of the gourd family that produces pumpkins, having tendrils and large lobed leaves and native to warm regions of America.

pumpkin.origin: Late 17th century alteration of earlier pumpion, from obsolete French pompon, via Latin from Greek pepōn ‘large melon’ (see pepo).

noun.definition: An expert in a particular subject or field who is frequently called upon to give their opinions to the public.
noun.example: political pundits were tipping him for promotion

noun.definition: variant form of pandit

pundit.origin: Mid 17th century (in pundit (sense 2)): from Sanskrit paṇḍita ‘learned man’, use as noun of paṇḍita ‘learned, skilled’. pundit (sense 1)is first recorded in the early 19th century.

noun.definition: A purring sound.
noun.example: a contented purr

verb.definition: (of a cat) make a low continuous vibratory sound expressing contentment.
verb.example: the cat purred loudly, rubbing against her legs

noun.definition: A small pouch of leather or plastic used for carrying money, typically by a woman.
noun.example: she had enough in her purse for bus fare

noun.definition: A handbag.
noun.example: a young woman with a purse hanging from her elbow

verb.definition: (with reference to the lips) pucker or contract, typically to express disapproval or irritation.
verb.example: Marianne took a glance at her reflection and pursed her lips disgustedly

purse.origin: Late Old English, alteration of late Latin bursa ‘purse’, from Greek bursa ‘hide, leather’. The current verb sense (from the notion of drawing purse strings) dates from the early 17th century.

verb.definition: Follow or chase (someone or something)
verb.example: the officer pursued the van

verb.definition: Continue or proceed along (a path or route)
verb.example: the road pursued a straight course over the scrubland

pursue.origin: Middle English (originally in the sense ‘follow with enmity’): from Anglo-Norman French pursuer, from an alteration of Latin prosequi ‘prosecute’.

noun.definition: The action of pursuing someone or something.
noun.example: the cat crouched in the grass in pursuit of a bird

noun.definition: An activity of a specified kind, especially a recreational or sporting one.
noun.example: a whole range of leisure pursuits

pursuit.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French purseute ‘following after’, from pursuer (see pursue). Early senses included ‘persecution, annoyance’ and in legal contexts ‘petition, prosecution’.

noun.definition: An earthquake.
noun.example: a big quake east of the Rocky Mountains

verb.definition: (especially of the earth) shake or tremble.
verb.example: the rumbling vibrations set the whole valley quaking

noun.definition: A question, especially one expressing doubt or requesting information.
noun.example: if you have any queries please telephone our office

verb.definition: Ask a question about something, especially in order to express one's doubts about it or to check its validity or accuracy.
verb.example: many people queried whether any harm had been done

query.origin: Mid 17th century anglicized form of the Latin imperative quaere!, used in the 16th century in English as a verb in the sense ‘inquire’ and as a noun meaning ‘query’, from Latin quaerere ‘ask, seek’.

adjective.definition: Having or characterized by peculiar or unexpected traits or aspects.
adjective.example: her sense of humour was decidedly quirky

adjective.definition: (of a person's expression or behaviour) indicating mild or amused puzzlement.
adjective.example: she gave me a quizzical look

adjective.definition: Showing or feeling discrimination or prejudice against people of other races, or believing that a particular race is superior to another.
adjective.example: we are investigating complaints about racist abuse at a newsagents

noun.definition: A person who shows or feels discrimination or prejudice against people of other races, or who believes that a particular race is superior to another.
noun.example: I had a fear of being called a racist

noun.definition: A flat buoyant structure of timber or other materials fastened together, used as a boat or floating platform.
A layer of reinforced concrete forming the foundation of a building.

verb.definition: Travel on or as if on a raft.
verb.example: I have rafted along the Rio Grande

verb.definition: Bring or fasten together (a number of boats or other objects) side by side.
verb.example: we rafted the boats together off the shores of Murchison Island

raft.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘beam, rafter’): from Old Norse raptr ‘rafter’. The verb dates from the late 17th century.

noun.definition: A large amount of something.
noun.example: a raft of government initiatives

raft.origin: Mid 19th century alteration of dialect raff ‘abundance’ (perhaps of Scandinavian origin), by association with raft in the sense ‘floating mass’.

noun.definition: The sport or pastime of travelling down a river on a raft.
noun.example: activities include rafting and tennis

noun.definition: A rapid surprise attack on an enemy by troops, aircraft, or other armed forces.
noun.example: a bombing raid

verb.definition: Conduct a raid on.
verb.example: officers raided thirty homes yesterday

raid.origin: Late Middle English (as a noun): Scots variant of road in the early senses ‘journey on horseback’, ‘foray’. The noun became rare from the end of the 16th century but was revived by Sir Walter Scott; the verb dates from the mid 19th century.

abbreviation.definition: Redundant array of independent (or inexpensive) disks, a system for providing greater capacity, faster access, and security against data corruption by spreading data across several disk drives.

noun.definition: A mass meeting of people making a political protest or showing support for a cause.
noun.example: a banned nationalist rally

noun.definition: A long-distance race for motor vehicles over public roads or rough terrain, typically in several stages.
noun.example: a rally driver

noun.definition: A quick or marked recovery after a decline.
noun.example: the market staged a late rally

noun.definition: (in tennis and other racket sports) an extended exchange of strokes between players.
noun.example: a rally of more than three strokes was a rarity

verb.definition: (of troops) come together again in order to continue fighting after a defeat or dispersion.
verb.example: De Montfort's troops rallied and drove back the king's infantry

verb.definition: Recover or cause to recover in health, spirits, or poise.
verb.example: he floundered for a moment, then rallied again
synonyms: take a turn for the better
be given a new lease of life
take on a new lease of life

verb.definition: Drive in a rally.
verb.example: we're driving off to Spain to rally

rally.origin: Early 17th century (in the sense ‘bring together again’): from French rallier, from re- ‘again’ + allier ‘to ally’.

verb.definition: Subject (someone) to good-humoured ridicule; tease.
verb.example: he rallied her on the length of her pigtail

rally.origin: Mid 17th century from French railler ‘to rib, tease’ (see rail).

noun.definition: An uncastrated male sheep.
A battering ram.
The falling weight of a piledriving machine.
noun.example: He says one man with a hoe ram on a Bobcat can break the same amount of concrete that two or three men could do with a jackhammer.

noun.definition: A hydraulic water-raising or lifting machine.
noun.example: Burnside Autocyl Ltd, Tullow is a European leader in the manufacture of hydraulic cylinders and rams.

verb.definition: Roughly force (something) into place.
verb.example: he rammed his stick into the ground

verb.definition: (of a place) be very crowded.
verb.example: the club is rammed to the rafters every week

ram.origin: Old English ram(m), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch ram.

abbreviation.definition: (in the UK) Royal Academy of Music.

noun.definition: A walk taken for pleasure in the countryside.

verb.definition: Walk for pleasure in the countryside.
verb.example: I spent most of my spare time rambling and climbing

verb.definition: Talk or write at length in a confused or inconsequential way.
verb.example: Willy rambled on about Norman archways

verb.definition: (of a plant) put out long shoots and grow over walls or other plants.
verb.example: roses climbed, rambled, hung over walls

ramble.origin: Late Middle English (in ramble (sense 2 of the verb)): probably related to Middle Dutch rammelen, used of animals in the sense ‘wander about on heat’, also to the noun ram.

adjective.definition: (of writing or speech) lengthy and confused or inconsequential.
adjective.example: a rambling six-hour speech

adjective.definition: (of a plant) putting out long shoots and growing over walls or other plants.
adjective.example: rambling roses

noun.definition: The activity of walking in the countryside for pleasure.
noun.example: a rambling club

adjective.definition: (especially of something unwelcome) flourishing or spreading unchecked.
adjective.example: political violence was rampant

adjective.definition: (of an animal) represented standing on one hind foot with its forefeet in the air (typically in profile, facing the dexter side, with right hind foot and tail raised)
adjective.example: two gold lions rampant

rampant.origin: Middle English (as a heraldic term): from Old French, literally ‘crawling’, present participle of ramper (see ramp). From the original use describing a wild animal arose the sense ‘fierce’, whence the current notion of ‘unrestrained’.

adjective.definition: Sexually aroused or excited.
adjective.example: as nervous as a randy adolescent on a hot date

adjective.definition: Having a rude, aggressive manner.

randy.origin: Mid 17th century perhaps from obsolete rand ‘rant, rave’, from obsolete Dutch randen ‘to rant’.

adjective.definition: Acting or done without careful consideration of the possible consequences; impetuous.
adjective.example: it would be extremely rash to make such an assumption

rash.origin: Late Middle English (also in Scots and northern English in the sense ‘nimble, eager’): of Germanic origin; related to German rasch.

noun.definition: An area of redness and spots on a person's skin, appearing especially as a result of illness.
noun.example: a red itchy rash appeared on her legs

noun.definition: A series of things of the same type, especially when unwelcome, happening within a short space of time.
noun.example: a rash of strikes by health service workers

rash.origin: Early 18th century probably related to Old French rasche ‘eruptive sores, scurf’; compare with Italian raschia ‘itch’.

adverb.definition: Without careful consideration of the possible consequences; impetuously.
adverb.example: he rashly promised crime would fall sharply by September

adjective.definition: Making or constituting a disturbingly harsh and loud noise.
adjective.example: raucous youths

noun.definition: The destructive effects of something.
noun.example: his face had withstood the ravages of time

verb.definition: Cause severe and extensive damage to.
verb.example: the hurricane ravaged southern Florida

ravage.origin: Early 17th century from French ravager, from earlier ravage, alteration of ravine ‘rush of water’.

verb.definition: Completely destroy (a building, town, or other settlement)
verb.example: villages were razed to the ground

raze.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘scratch, incise’): from Old French raser ‘shave closely’, from Latin ras- ‘scraped’, from the verb radere.

noun.definition: The soldiers at the rear of a body of troops, especially those protecting a retreating army.
noun.example: the firing from our rearguard had stopped

rearguard.origin: Late Middle English (denoting the rear part of an army): from Old French rereguarde.

adjective.definition: Having sound judgement; fair and sensible.
adjective.example: no reasonable person could have objected

adjective.definition: As much as is appropriate or fair; moderate.
adjective.example: a police officer may use reasonable force to gain entry

reasonable.origin: Middle English from Old French raisonable, suggested by Latin rationabilis ‘rational’, from ratio (see reason).

verb.definition: Say or do something to remove the doubts or fears of (someone)
verb.example: he understood her feelings and tried to reassure her

noun.definition: A person who rises in opposition or armed resistance against an established government or leader.
noun.example: Tory rebels

verb.definition: Rise in opposition or armed resistance to an established government or leader.
verb.example: the Earl of Pembroke subsequently rebelled against Henry III

rebel.origin: Middle English from Old French rebelle (noun), rebeller (verb), from Latin rebellis (used originally with reference to a fresh declaration of war by the defeated), based on bellum ‘war’.

adjective.definition: Showing a desire to resist authority, control, or convention.
adjective.example: I became very rebellious and opted out

noun.definition: (in sporting contexts) a ball or shot that bounces back after striking a hard surface.
noun.example: he blasted the rebound into the net

noun.definition: An increase in value, amount, or strength after a previous decline.
noun.example: they revealed a big rebound in profits for last year

verb.definition: Bounce back through the air after hitting something hard.
verb.example: his shot hammered into the post and rebounded across the goal

verb.definition: Recover in value, amount, or strength after a decrease or decline.
verb.example: the Share Index rebounded to show a twenty-point gain

verb.definition: (of an event or action) have an unexpected adverse consequence for (someone, especially the person responsible for it)
verb.example: Nicholas's tricks are rebounding on him
