synonyms: cause one to be hoist with one's own petard

rebound.origin: Late Middle English from Old French rebondir, from re- ‘back’ + bondir ‘bounce up’.

noun.definition: An expression of sharp disapproval or criticism.
noun.example: he hadn't meant it as a rebuke, but Neil flinched

verb.definition: Express sharp disapproval or criticism of (someone) because of their behaviour or actions.
verb.example: she had rebuked him for drinking too much
synonyms: give someone a piece of one's mind

rebuke.origin: Middle English (originally in the sense ‘force back, repress’): from Anglo-Norman French and Old Northern French rebuker, from re- ‘back, down’ + bukier ‘to beat’ (originally ‘cut down wood’, from Old French busche ‘log’).

noun.definition: The action or faculty of remembering something learned or experienced.
noun.example: people's understanding and subsequent recall of stories or events

noun.definition: An act or instance of officially recalling someone or something.
noun.example: a recall of Parliament

noun.definition: The proportion of the number of relevant documents retrieved from a database in response to an inquiry.
noun.example: expert systems can produce solutions with the speed, recall, accuracy, and consistency that only a computer can provide

verb.definition: Bring (a fact, event, or situation) back into one's mind; remember.
verb.example: I can still vaguely recall being taken to the hospital

verb.definition: Officially order (someone) to return to a place.
verb.example: the Panamanian ambassador was recalled from Peru

recall.origin: Late 16th century (as a verb): from re-‘again’ + call, suggested by Latin revocare or French rappeler ‘call back’.

verb.definition: Go or move back or further away from a previous position.
verb.example: the floodwaters had receded

verb.definition: (of a quality, feeling, or possibility) gradually diminish.
verb.example: the prospects of an early end to the war receded

verb.definition: (of a man's hair) cease to grow at the temples and above the forehead.
verb.example: his dark hair was receding a little

recede.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘depart from a usual state or standard’): from Latin recedere, from re- ‘back’ + cedere ‘go’.

noun.definition: The practice of exchanging things with others for mutual benefit, especially privileges granted by one country or organization to another.
noun.example: the Community intends to start discussions on reciprocity with third countries

reciprocity.origin: Mid 18th century from French réciprocité, from réciproque, from Latin reciprocus ‘moving backwards and forwards’ (see reciprocate).

verb.definition: Establish by calculation.
verb.example: his debts were reckoned at £300,000

verb.definition: Be of the opinion.
verb.example: he reckons that the army should pull out entirely

verb.definition: Rely on or be sure of.
verb.example: they had reckoned on a day or two more of privacy

reckon.origin: Old English (ge)recenian ‘recount, relate’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch rekenen and German rechnen ‘to count (up)’. Early senses included ‘give an account of items received’ and ‘mention things in order’, which gave rise to the notion of ‘calculation’ and hence of ‘being of an opinion’.

verb.definition: Identify (someone or something) from having encountered them before; know again.
verb.example: I recognized her when her wig fell off

verb.definition: Acknowledge the existence, validity, or legality of.
verb.example: the defence is recognized in British law

recognize.origin: Late Middle English (earliest attested as a term in Scots law): from Old French reconniss-, stem of reconnaistre, from Latin recognoscere ‘know again, recall to mind’, from re- ‘again’ + cognoscere ‘learn’.

red tape.example: 1. Just because of red tape, a container full of relief materials donated by the indian navy for the victims of cyclone mora has been lying abandoned at the chittagong port for nearly seven months.

redeem.example: 1. We will redeem the old promise 2. Bangladesh's footballers will get a chance to redeem themselves after a disappointing show

verb.definition: Compensate for the faults or bad aspects of.
verb.example: a disappointing debate redeemed only by an outstanding speech

verb.definition: Gain or regain possession of (something) in exchange for payment.
verb.example: statutes enabled state peasants to redeem their land

verb.definition: Fulfil or carry out (a pledge or promise)
verb.example: the party prepared to redeem the pledges of the past three years

redeem.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘buy back’): from Old French redimer or Latin redimere, from re- ‘back’ + emere ‘buy’.

adjective.definition: Not or no longer needed or useful; superfluous.
adjective.example: an appropriate use for a redundant church

redundant.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘abundant’): from Latin redundant- ‘surging up’, from the verb redundare (see redound).

noun.definition: A ridge of jagged rock, coral, or sand just above or below the surface of the sea.

reef.origin: Late 16th century (earlier as riff): from Middle Low German and Middle Dutch rif, ref, from Old Norse rif, literally ‘rib’, used in the same sense; compare with reef.

noun.definition: Each of the several strips across a sail which can be taken in or rolled up to reduce the area exposed to the wind.
noun.example: We had to sail her with ‘two reefs in’, a reduced sail area for the rough conditions.

verb.definition: Take in one or more reefs of (a sail)
verb.example: reef the mainsail in strong winds

reef.origin: Middle English from Middle Dutch reef, rif, from Old Norse rif, literally ‘rib’, used in the same sense; compare with reef.

noun.definition: A cylinder on which film, wire, thread, or other flexible materials can be wound.
noun.example: a cotton reel

noun.definition: A lively Scottish or Irish folk dance.
noun.example: we put on the record player and danced reels

verb.definition: Wind something on to a reel by turning the reel.
verb.example: sailplanes are often launched by means of a wire reeled in by a winch

verb.definition: Lose one's balance and stagger or lurch violently.
verb.example: he punched Connolly in the ear, sending him reeling

verb.definition: Dance a reel.
verb.example: Anyone who wanted to dance could reel to the sound of the ceilidh band playing at the Butter Cross.

reel.origin: Old English hrēol, denoting a rotatory device on which spun thread is wound; of unknown origin.

noun.definition: A general vote by the electorate on a single political question which has been referred to them for a direct decision.

referendum.origin: Mid 19th century from Latin, gerund (‘referring’) or neuter gerundive (‘something to be brought back or referred’) of referre (see refer).

refrain.example: Per our roommate agreement, kindly refrain, from raucous laughter.

verb.definition: Stop oneself from doing something.
verb.example: she refrained from comment

refrain.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘restrain a thought or feeling’): from Old French refrener, from Latin refrenare, from re- (expressing intensive force) + frenum ‘bridle’.

refrain.example: Per our roommate agreement, kindly refrain, from raucous laughter.

noun.definition: A repeated line or number of lines in a poem or song, typically at the end of each verse.

refrain.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, from refraindre ‘break’, based on Latin refringere ‘break up’ (because the refrain ‘broke’ the sequence).

verb.definition: Prove (a statement or theory) to be wrong or false; disprove.
verb.example: these claims have not been convincingly refuted
synonyms: drive a coach and horses through

refute.origin: Mid 16th century : from Latin refutare ‘repel, rebut’.

noun.definition: Attention to or concern for something.
noun.example: the court must have regard to the principle of welfare

noun.definition: Best wishes (used to express friendliness in greetings)
noun.example: give her my regards

verb.definition: Consider or think of in a specified way.
verb.example: she regarded London as her base

verb.definition: (of a thing) relate to; concern.
verb.example: if these things regarded only myself, I could stand it with composure

regard.origin: Middle English from Old French regarder ‘to watch’, from re- ‘back’ (also expressing intensive force) + garder ‘to guard’.

preposition.example: your recent letter regarding the above proposal

adverb.definition: Despite the prevailing circumstances.
adverb.example: they were determined to carry on regardless

noun.definition: A government, especially an authoritarian one.
noun.example: ideological opponents of the regime

noun.definition: A system or ordered way of doing things.
noun.example: detention centres with a very tough physical regime

regime.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘regimen’): French régime, from Latin regimen ‘rule’ (see regimen). Sense 1 dates from the late 18th century (with original reference to the Ancien Régime).

noun.definition: A feeling of sadness, repentance, or disappointment over an occurrence or something that one has done or failed to do.
noun.example: she expressed her regret at Virginia's death

verb.definition: Feel sad, repentant, or disappointed over (something that one has done or failed to do)
verb.example: she immediately regretted her words

regret.origin: Late Middle English from Old French regreter ‘bewail (the dead)’, perhaps from the Germanic base of greet.

adjective.definition: (of conduct or an event) giving rise to regret; undesirable; unwelcome.
adjective.example: the loss of this number of jobs is regrettable

noun.definition: A course of treatment for drug or alcohol dependence, typically at a residential facility.
noun.example: the star has been in rehab for a week

noun.definition: A building that has been rehabilitated or restored.
noun.example: a homeowner who discovers his rehab straddles the San Andreas fault

noun.definition: Financial assistance provided by the Rehabilitation Department, established to support returned servicemen after the Second World War.
noun.example: he'd had to bum around for a few years before approaching the Rehab

verb.definition: Rehabilitate or restore.
verb.example: they don't rehab you at all in jail

verb.definition: Restore (someone) to health or normal life by training and therapy after imprisonment, addiction, or illness.
verb.example: helping to rehabilitate former criminals

rehabilitate.origin: Late 16th century (earlier (late 15th century) as rehabilitation) (in the sense ‘restore to former privileges’): from medieval Latin rehabilitat-, from the verb rehabilitare(see re-, habilitate).

noun.definition: The action of restoring someone to health or normal life through training and therapy after imprisonment, addiction, or illness.
noun.example: she underwent rehabilitation and was walking within three weeks

noun.definition: The period of rule of a monarch.
noun.example: the original chapel was built in the reign of Charles I

verb.definition: Hold royal office; rule as monarch.
verb.example: Queen Elizabeth reigns over the UK

reign.origin: Middle English from Old French reignier ‘to reign’, reigne ‘kingdom’, from Latin regnum, related to rex, reg- ‘king’.

noun.definition: A person or thing dismissed as inadequate or unacceptable.
noun.example: some of the team's rejects have gone on to prove themselves in championships

verb.definition: Dismiss as inadequate, unacceptable, or faulty.
verb.example: union negotiators rejected a 1.5 per cent pay award

reject.origin: Late Middle English from Latin reject- ‘thrown back’, from the verb reicere, from re- ‘back’ + jacere ‘to throw’.

noun.definition: A reply, especially a sharp or witty one.
noun.example: she would have made some cutting rejoinder but none came to mind

rejoinder.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French rejoindre (infinitive used as a noun) (see rejoin).

adjective.definition: Dependent on someone or something.
adjective.example: the company is heavily reliant on the baby market

noun.definition: A feeling of reassurance and relaxation following release from anxiety or distress.
noun.example: much to her relief, she saw the door open

noun.definition: Financial or practical assistance given to those in special need or difficulty.
noun.example: raising money for famine relief

noun.definition: A person or group of people replacing others who have been on duty.
noun.example: the relief nurse was late

noun.definition: The state of being clearly visible or obvious due to being accentuated.
noun.example: the setting sun threw the snow-covered peaks into relief

relief.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, from relever ‘raise up, relieve’, from Latin relevare ‘raise again, alleviate’.

verb.definition: Move to a new place and establish one's home or business there.
verb.example: sixty workers could face redundancy because the firm is relocating

noun.definition: Unwillingness or disinclination to do something.
noun.example: she sensed his reluctance to continue

noun.definition: The property of a magnetic circuit of opposing the passage of magnetic flux lines, equal to the ratio of the magnetomotive force to the magnetic flux.

adjective.definition: Unwilling and hesitant; disinclined.
adjective.example: she seemed reluctant to answer

reluctant.origin: Mid 17th century (in the sense ‘writhing, offering opposition’): from Latin reluctant- ‘struggling against’, from the verb reluctari, from re- (expressing intensive force) + luctari ‘to struggle’.

noun.definition: A committal to custody.
noun.example: the prosecutor applied for a remand to allow forensic evidence to be investigated

verb.definition: Place (a defendant) on bail or in custody, especially when a trial is adjourned.
verb.example: he was remanded in custody for a week

remand.origin: Late Middle English (as a verb in the sense ‘send back again’): from late Latin remandare, from re- ‘back’ + mandare ‘commit’. The noun dates from the late 18th century.

noun.definition: A written or spoken comment.
noun.example: I decided to ignore his rude remarks

verb.definition: Say something as a comment; mention.
verb.example: ‘Tom's looking peaky,’ she remarked

verb.definition: Regard with attention; notice.
verb.example: he remarked the man's inflamed eyelids

remark.origin: Late 16th century (in remark (sense 2 of the verb)): from French remarquer ‘note again’, from re- (expressing intensive force) + marquer ‘to mark, note’.

adjective.definition: Giving or intended as a remedy or cure.

remedial.origin: Mid 17th century from late Latin remedialis, from Latin remedium ‘cure, medicine’ (see remedy).

noun.definition: A medicine or treatment for a disease or injury.
noun.example: herbal remedies for aches and pains

noun.definition: The margin within which coins as minted may differ from the standard fineness and weight.

verb.definition: Set right (an undesirable situation)

remedy.origin: Middle English from Anglo-Norman French remedie, from Latin remedium, from re- ‘back’ (also expressing intensive force) + mederi ‘heal’.

noun.definition: The return of someone to their own country.
noun.example: the voluntary repatriation of refugees

verb.definition: Drive or force (an attack or attacker) back or away.
verb.example: government units sought to repel the rebels

verb.definition: Be repulsive or distasteful to.
verb.example: she was repelled by the permanent smell of drink on his breath

verb.definition: Refuse to accept (something, especially an argument or theory)

noun.definition: The action of repeating something that has already been said or written.
noun.example: her comments are worthy of repetition

noun.definition: The recurrence of an action or event.

repetition.origin: Late Middle English from Old French repeticion or Latin repetitio(n-), from repetere (see repeat).

adverb.definition: According to what some say (used to express the speaker's belief that the information given is not necessarily true)
adverb.example: he was in El Salvador, reportedly on his way to Texas

noun.definition: A cancellation or postponement of a punishment.

verb.definition: Cancel or postpone the punishment of (someone, especially someone condemned to death)
verb.example: under the new regime, prisoners under sentence of death were reprieved

reprieve.origin: Late 15th century (as the past participle repryed): from Anglo-Norman French repris, past participle of reprendre, from Latin re- ‘back’ + prehendere ‘seize’. The insertion of -v- (16th century) remains unexplained. Sense development has undergone a reversal, from the early meaning ‘send back to prison’, via ‘postpone a legal process’, to the current sense ‘rescue from impending punishment’.

noun.definition: An act of retaliation.
noun.example: three youths died in the reprisals which followed

reprisal.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French reprisaille, from medieval Latin reprisalia (neuter plural), based on Latin repraehens- ‘seized’, from the verb repraehendere (see reprehend). The current sense dates from the early 18th century.

adjective.definition: Made necessary by particular circumstances or regulations.

noun.definition: A thing that is necessary for the achievement of a specified end.
noun.example: she believed privacy to be a requisite for a peaceful life

requisite.origin: Late Middle English from Latin requisitus ‘searched for, deemed necessary’, past participle of requirere (see require).

noun.definition: The capacity to recover quickly from difficulties; toughness.

noun.definition: The ability of a substance or object to spring back into shape; elasticity.
noun.example: nylon is excellent in wearability, abrasion resistance and resilience

noun.definition: A resistant substance applied as a coating to protect a surface during a process, for example to prevent dye or glaze adhering.
noun.example: new lithographic techniques require their own special resists

verb.definition: Withstand the action or effect of.

resist.origin: Late Middle English from Old French resister or Latin resistere, from re- (expressing opposition) + sistere ‘stop’ (reduplication of stare ‘to stand’). The current sense of the noun dates from the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: A short period of rest or relief from something difficult or unpleasant.
noun.example: the refugee encampments will provide some respite from the suffering

verb.definition: Postpone (a sentence, obligation, etc.)

noun.definition: A measure or condition that keeps someone or something under control.

noun.definition: Unemotional, dispassionate, or moderate behaviour; self-control.

restraint.origin: Late Middle English from Old French restreinte, feminine past participle of restreindre ‘hold back’ (see restrain).

verb.definition: Continue to have (something); keep possession of.

verb.definition: Absorb and continue to hold (a substance)

verb.definition: Keep (something) in place; hold fixed.

verb.definition: Keep (someone) engaged in one's service.

verb.definition: Draw or be drawn back or back in.

verb.definition: Withdraw (a statement or accusation) as untrue or unjustified.

retract.origin: Late Middle English from Latin retract- ‘drawn back’, from the verb retrahere (from re- ‘back’ + trahere ‘drag’); the senses ‘withdraw (a statement’) and ‘go back on’ via Old French from retractare ‘reconsider’ (based on trahere ‘drag’).

noun.definition: An act of moving back or withdrawing.

noun.definition: A quiet or secluded place in which one can rest and relax.

noun.definition: (in a film or television programme) a final revelation of information that has previously been kept from the characters or viewers.

noun.definition: A person who has converted to the Islamic faith.

verb.definition: Return to (a previous state, practice, topic, etc.)

noun.definition: The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing, especially the exploitation of figures of speech and other compositional techniques.

noun.definition: A question or statement intentionally phrased so as to require ingenuity in ascertaining its answer or meaning.

noun.definition: A number of people or things in a more or less straight line.

row.origin: Old English rāw, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch rij and German Reihe.

row.example: A woman rows a boat carrying rice straw, to be used as cooking fuel.

row.origin: Old English rōwan, of Germanic origin; related to rudder; from an Indo-European root shared by Latin remus ‘oar’, Greek eretmon ‘oar’.

proper noun.definition: An industrial city and the principal port of Bulgaria, on the River Danube; population 156,959 (2008). Turkish during the Middle Ages, it was captured by Russia in 1877 and ceded to Bulgaria.

A thing of no value (used for emphasis)
noun.example: not one of them is worth a rush

rush.origin: Old English risc, rysc, of Germanic origin.

salvo.bengali: ফাঁকি; সামরিক অভিবাদনের অঙ্গস্বরূপ একটানা তোপধ্বনি

scour.origin: Middle English from Middle Dutch, Middle Low German schūren, from Old French escurer, from late Latin excurare ‘clean (off)’, from ex- ‘away’ + curare ‘to clean’.

scour.origin: Late Middle English related to obsolete scour ‘moving hastily’, of unknown origin.

adverb.definition: Not involving anyone or anything else; only.

adjective & adverb.definition: For or done by one person alone; unaccompanied.

noun.definition: A piece of vocal or instrumental music or a dance, or a part or passage in one, for one performer.

solo.origin: Late 17th century (as a musical term): from Italian, from Latin solus ‘alone’.

adjective.definition: Having, revealing, or involving a great deal of worldly experience and knowledge of fashion and culture.

noun.definition: The spiritual or immaterial part of a human being or animal, regarded as immortal.
Emotional or intellectual energy or intensity, especially as revealed in a work of art or an artistic performance.

noun.definition: The essence or embodiment of a specified quality.

soul.origin: Old English sāwol, sāw(e)l, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch ziel and German Seele.

adjective.definition: Feeling or expressing resentment, disappointment, or anger.

verb.definition: Plant (seed) by scattering it on or in the earth.

sow.origin: Old English sāwan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zaaien and German säen.

noun.definition: An adult female pig, especially one which has farrowed.
A large block of metal (larger than a ‘pig’) made by smelting.
noun.example: He said most of the stock is ingot, whereas more consumers prefer T-bar or sow.

sow.origin: Old English sugu; related to Dutch zeug, German Sau, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin sus and Greek hus ‘pig’.

noun.definition: A slap or series of slaps with one's open hand or a flat object.

noun.definition: A fall from a horse or bicycle.

noun.definition: Goods stolen or taken forcibly from a person or place.

noun.definition: Courage and determination.

noun.definition: Semen.

Early use referred generally to ‘position’, especially ‘position in life, status’, and specifically, in ecclesiastical use, to ‘a holy place of pilgrimage (visited as one of a succession’). The verb dates from the late 16th century.

Old English stēor, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stier and German Stier.

noun.definition: A pond or large tank for keeping fish for eating.

stone aggregates.example: Bhutan exports significant quantity of stone aggregates to bangladesh using the time-consuming land route.

adjective.definition: (of a person) rather fat or of heavy build.

noun.definition: A long, thin line or mark of a different substance or colour from its surroundings.
noun.example: a streak of oil

noun.definition: An element of a specified kind in someone's character.
noun.example: there's a streak of insanity in the family

noun.definition: An act of running naked in a public place so as to shock or amuse others.
noun.example: a streak for charity

verb.definition: Cover (a surface) with streaks.
verb.example: tears streaking her face, Cynthia looked up

verb.definition: Move very fast in a specified direction.
verb.example: the cat streaked across the street

verb.definition: Run naked in a public place so as to shock or amuse others.
verb.example: the singer admitted to streaking in his home town in the seventies

streak.origin: Old English strica, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch streek and German Strich, also to strike. The sense ‘run naked’ was originally US slang.

adjective.definition: Requiring or using great effort or exertion.
adjective.example: the government made strenuous efforts to upgrade the quality of the teaching profession

noun.definition: An act of stretching one's limbs or body.
noun.example: I got up and had a stretch

noun.definition: A continuous area or expanse of land or water.
noun.example: a treacherous stretch of road

noun.definition: A stretch limo.
noun.example: a chauffeur-driven stretch

verb.definition: (of something soft or elastic) be made or be capable of being made longer or wider without tearing or breaking.
verb.example: my jumper stretched in the wash

verb.definition: Straighten or extend one's body or a part of one's body to its full length, typically so as to tighten one's muscles or in order to reach something.
verb.example: the cat yawned and stretched

verb.definition: Extend or spread over an area or period of time.
verb.example: the beach stretches for over four miles

verb.definition: Make great demands on the capacity or resources of.
verb.example: the cost of the court case has stretched their finances to the limit

stretch.origin: Old English streccan, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch strekken and German strecken. The noun dates from the late 16th century.

adjective.definition: Seriously affected by an undesirable condition or unpleasant feeling.
adjective.example: the pilot landed the stricken aircraft

verb.definition: past participle of strike (sense 2 of the verb,

adjective.definition: Demanding that rules concerning behaviour are obeyed and observed.
adjective.example: my father was very strict

adjective.definition: (of a person) following rules or beliefs exactly.
adjective.example: a strict vegetarian

adjective.definition: Exact in correspondence or adherence to something; not allowing or admitting deviation or relaxation.
adjective.example: a strict interpretation of the law

strict.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘restricted in space or extent’): from Latin strictus, past participle of stringere ‘tighten, draw tight’.

noun.definition: A long, decisive step.
noun.example: he crossed the room in a couple of strides

noun.definition: A step or stage in progress towards an aim.
noun.example: great strides have been made towards equality
synonyms: move forward in leaps and bounds

noun.definition: Trousers.
Denoting or relating to a rhythmic style of jazz piano playing in which the left hand alternately plays single bass notes on the downbeat and chords an octave higher on the upbeat.
noun.example: he's a noted stride pianist

verb.definition: Walk with long, decisive steps in a specified direction.
verb.example: he strode across the road

verb.definition: Cross (an obstacle) with one long step.

stride.origin: Old English stride (noun) ‘single long step’, strīdan (verb) ‘stand or walk with the legs wide apart’, probably from a Germanic base meaning ‘strive, quarrel’; related to Dutch strijden ‘fight’ and German streiten ‘quarrel’.

noun.definition: A refusal to work organized by a body of employees as a form of protest, typically in an attempt to gain a concession or concessions from their employer.
noun.example: dockers voted for an all-out strike

noun.definition: A sudden attack, typically a military one.
noun.example: the threat of nuclear strikes

noun.definition: A discovery of gold, minerals, or oil by drilling or mining.
noun.example: the Lena goldfields strike of 1912

noun.definition: A batter's unsuccessful attempt to hit a pitched ball.
The horizontal or compass direction of a stratum, fault, or other geological feature.
noun.example: the mine workings follow the strike of the Bonsor Vein

noun.definition: short for fly strike

verb.definition: Hit forcibly and deliberately with one's hand or a weapon or other implement.
verb.example: he raised his hand, as if to strike me

verb.definition: (of a disaster, disease, or other unwelcome phenomenon) occur suddenly and have harmful or damaging effects on.
verb.example: a major earthquake struck the island

verb.definition: (of a thought or idea) come into the mind of (someone) suddenly or unexpectedly.
verb.example: a disturbing thought struck Melissa

verb.definition: (of a clock) indicate the time by sounding a chime or stroke.
verb.example: the church clock struck twelve

verb.definition: Ignite (a match) by rubbing it briskly against an abrasive surface.
verb.example: the match went out and he struck another

verb.definition: (of employees) refuse to work as a form of organized protest, typically in an attempt to obtain a particular concession or concessions from their employer.
verb.example: workers may strike over threatened job losses

verb.definition: Cancel, remove, or cross out with or as if with a pen.
verb.example: I will strike his name from the list

verb.definition: Make (a coin or medal) by stamping metal.
verb.example: they struck similar medals on behalf of the Normandy veterans

verb.definition: Reach, achieve, or agree to (something involving agreement, balance, or compromise)
verb.example: the team has struck a deal with a sports marketing agency

verb.definition: Discover (gold, minerals, or oil) by drilling or mining.
verb.example: if they do strike oil, there will be another test well in a year's time

verb.definition: Move or proceed vigorously or purposefully.
verb.example: she struck out into the lake with a practised crawl

verb.definition: Take down (a tent or the tents of an encampment)
verb.example: it took ages to strike camp

verb.definition: Insert (a cutting of a plant) in soil to take root.
verb.example: best results are obtained from striking them in a propagator

verb.definition: Secure a hook in the mouth of a fish by jerking or tightening the line after it has taken the bait or fly.

strike.origin: Old English strīcan ‘go, flow’ and ‘rub lightly’, of West Germanic origin; related to German streichen ‘to stroke’, also to stroke. The sense ‘deliver a blow’ dates from Middle English.

noun.definition: Material consisting of threads of cotton, hemp, or other material twisted together to form a thin length.
noun.example: unwieldy packs tied up with string

noun.definition: A set of things tied or threaded together on a thin cord.
noun.example: she wore a string of agates round her throat

noun.definition: A tough piece of fibre in vegetables, meat, or other food, such as a tough elongated piece connecting the two halves of a bean pod.
A G-string or thong.
short for stringboard
noun.example: Each of them is made of beautifully laid rough solid buff Cambridge-like brick with very precise precast concrete lintels and strings.

noun.definition: A hypothetical one-dimensional subatomic particle having the dynamical properties of a flexible loop.

verb.definition: Hang (something) so that it stretches in a long line.
verb.example: lights were strung across the promenade

verb.definition: Fit a string or strings to (a musical instrument, a racket, or a bow)
verb.example: the harp had been newly strung

verb.definition: Remove the strings from (a bean).
verb.example: String the beans and break into lengths as for cooking.

verb.definition: Hoax or trick (someone)
verb.example: I'm not stringing you—I'll eat my shirt if it's not true

verb.definition: Work as a stringer in journalism.
verb.example: he strings for almost every French radio service

verb.definition: Determine the order of play by striking the cue ball from baulk to rebound off the top cushion, first stroke going to the player whose ball comes to rest nearer the bottom cushion.
verb.example: To begin a game of English billiards, both players "string".

string.origin: Old English streng (noun), of Germanic origin; related to German Strang, also to strong. The verb (dating from late Middle English) is first recorded in the senses ‘arrange in a row’ and ‘fit with a string’.

adjective.definition: (of regulations, requirements, or conditions) strict, precise, and exacting.
adjective.example: stringent guidelines on air pollution

stringent.origin: Mid 17th century (in the sense ‘compelling, convincing’): from Latin stringent- ‘drawing tight’, from the verb stringere.

noun.definition: An act of undressing, especially in a striptease.
noun.example: she got drunk and did a strip on top of the piano

noun.definition: The identifying outfit worn by the members of a sports team while playing.
noun.example: the team's away strip is a garish mix of red, white, and blue

verb.definition: Remove all coverings from.
verb.example: they stripped the bed

verb.definition: Leave bare of accessories or fittings.
verb.example: thieves stripped the room of luggage

verb.definition: Deprive someone of (rank, power, or property)
verb.example: the lieutenant was stripped of his rank

verb.definition: Sell off (the assets of a company) for profit.
Tear the thread or teeth from (a screw, gearwheel, etc.).
(of a bullet) be fired from a rifled gun without spin owing to a loss of surface.

strip.origin: Middle English (as a verb): of Germanic origin; related to Dutch stropen. strip (sense 2 of the noun) arose in the late 20th century, possibly from the notion of clothing to which a player ‘strips’ down.

noun.definition: A long, narrow piece of cloth, paper, plastic, or some other material.
noun.example: a strip of linen

noun.definition: A comic strip.
noun.example: a strip cartoon

noun.definition: A programme broadcast regularly at the same time.
noun.example: he hosts a weekly two-hour advice strip

strip.origin: Late Middle English from or related to Middle Low German strippe ‘strap, thong’, probably also to stripe.

noun.definition: A female prostitute.

adjective.definition: Spending a lot of time studying or reading.
adjective.example: he was quiet and studious

adjective.definition: Done deliberately or with a purpose in mind.
adjective.example: his studious absence from public view

studious.origin: Middle English from Latin studiosus, from studium ‘painstaking application’.

noun.definition: An act of stumbling.
noun.example: he broke a bone in his foot in a stumble down an Alpine pass

verb.definition: Trip or momentarily lose one's balance; almost fall.
verb.example: her foot caught in the rug and she stumbled

stumble.origin: Middle English (as a verb): from Old Norse, from the Germanic base of stammer.

verb.definition: Knock unconscious or into a dazed or semi-conscious state.
verb.example: the man was stunned by a blow to the head

verb.definition: Astonish or shock (someone) so that they are temporarily unable to react.
verb.example: the community was stunned by the tragedy

stun.origin: Middle English shortening of Old French estoner ‘astonish’.

noun.definition: A tendency to stutter while speaking.
noun.example: ‘She's p-perfectly j-justified,’ he said with his intermittent stutter

verb.definition: Talk with continued involuntary repetition of sounds, especially initial consonants.
verb.example: the child was stuttering in fright

stutter.origin: Late 16th century (as a verb): frequentative of dialect stut, of Germanic origin; related to German stossen ‘strike against’.

verb.definition: Prevent or hinder the progress of.
verb.example: the changes must not be allowed to stymie new medical treatments

stymie.origin: Mid 19th century (originally a golfing term, denoting a situation on the green where a ball obstructs the shot of another player): of unknown origin.

sub-par.bengali: Below average. Deriving from the term in golf "par" meaning average, and sub meaning below.
sub-par.example: 1. Bangladesh lost by two wickets to new zealand at the oval on wednesday after being all out for a sub-par 244. 2. According to stand-in captain mahmudullah riyad, bangladesh's sub-par performances in the last six months is not about technique or lack of execution in skill.

adjective.definition: Of very great excellence or beauty.
adjective.example: Mozart's sublime piano concertos

adjective.definition: (of a person's attitude or behaviour) extreme or unparalleled.
adjective.example: he had the sublime confidence of youth

verb.definition: (of a solid substance) change directly into vapour when heated, typically forming a solid deposit again on cooling.
verb.example: the ice sublimed away, leaving the books dry and undamaged

verb.definition: Elevate to a high degree of moral or spiritual purity or excellence.
verb.example: let your thoughts be sublimed by the spirit of God

sublime.origin: Late 16th century (in the sense ‘dignified, aloof’): from Latin sublimis, from sub- ‘up to’ + a second element perhaps related to limen ‘threshold’, limus ‘oblique’.

verb.definition: Cause (something) to be under water.
verb.example: houses had been flooded and cars submerged

submerge.origin: Early 17th century from Latin submergere, from sub- ‘under’ + mergere ‘to dip’.

adjective.definition: Coming after something in time; following.
adjective.example: the theory was developed subsequent to the earthquake of 1906

subsequent.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, or from Latin subsequent- ‘following after’ (from the verb subsequi).

adverb.definition: After a particular thing has happened; afterwards.
adverb.example: the officer decided to stop and subsequently made an arrest
synonyms: at some point in the future
at some time in the future

verb.definition: Become less intense, violent, or severe.
verb.example: I'll wait a few minutes until the storm subsides

verb.definition: (of water) go down to a lower or the normal level.
verb.example: the floods subside almost as quickly as they arise

subside.origin: Late 17th century from Latin subsidere, from sub- ‘below’ + sidere ‘settle’ (related to sedere ‘sit’).

noun.definition: A sum of money granted by the state or a public body to help an industry or business keep the price of a commodity or service low.
noun.example: a farm subsidy

noun.definition: A parliamentary grant to the sovereign for state needs.

subsidy.origin: Late Middle English from Anglo-Norman French subsidie, from Latin subsidium ‘assistance’.

substandard.example: The court ordered the authorities concerned to stop production, selling or marketing of these substandard products and to take appropriate legal action against the persons responsible for producing, selling, marketing and supplying the products.

adjective.definition: Below the usual or required standard.
adjective.example: substandard housing

adjective.definition: another term for non-standard
adjective.example: sub-standard spellings

adjective.definition: Of considerable importance, size, or worth.
adjective.example: a substantial amount of cash

adjective.definition: Concerning the essentials of something.
adjective.example: there was substantial agreement on changing policies

adjective.definition: Real and tangible rather than imaginary.
adjective.example: spirits are shadowy, human beings substantial

substantial.origin: Middle English from Old French substantiel or Christian Latin substantialis, from substantia ‘being, essence’ (see substance).

verb.definition: Undermine the power and authority of (an established system or institution)
verb.example: an attempt to subvert democratic government

subvert.origin: Late Middle English from Old French subvertir or Latin subvertere, from sub- ‘from below’ + vertere ‘to turn’.

adjective.definition: Following one another or following others.
adjective.example: they were looking for their fifth successive win

successive.origin: Late Middle English from medieval Latin successivus, from success- ‘followed closely’, from the verb succedere (see succeed).

exclamation.definition: Used to express derision and defiance.

noun.definition: An act of sucking something.
noun.example: the fish draws the bait into its mouth with a strong suck

verb.definition: Draw into the mouth by contracting the muscles of the lips and mouth to make a partial vacuum.
verb.example: they suck mint juleps through straws

verb.definition: Involve (someone) in something without their choosing.
verb.example: I didn't want to be sucked into the role of dutiful daughter

verb.definition: Be very bad or unpleasant.
verb.example: I love your country but your weather sucks

suck.origin: Old English sūcan (verb), from an Indo-European imitative root; related to soak.

verb.definition: Institute legal proceedings against (a person or institution), typically for redress.
verb.example: she is to sue the baby's father

verb.definition: Appeal formally to a person for something.
verb.example: the rebels were forced to sue for peace

sue.origin: Middle English from Anglo-Norman French suer, based on Latin sequi ‘follow’. Early senses were very similar to those of the verb follow.

adjective.definition: Causing difficulty in breathing.
adjective.example: the suffocating heat

verb.definition: Damage the purity or integrity of.
verb.example: they were outraged that anyone should sully their good name

sully.origin: Late 16th century perhaps from French souiller ‘to soil’.

noun.definition: The highest point of a hill or mountain.
noun.example: she climbed back up the path towards the summit

noun.definition: A meeting between heads of government.
noun.example: two binding treaties were agreed at the summit

verb.definition: Reach the summit of (a mountain or hill)
verb.example: in 2013, 658 climbers summited Everest

summit.origin: Late Middle English (in the general sense ‘top part’): from Old French somete, from som ‘top’, from Latin summum, neuter of summus ‘highest’.

suo moto.bengali: Suo motu, meaning "on its own motion," is a Latin legal term, approximately equivalent to the term sua sponte. For example, it is used where a government agency acts on its own cognizance, as in "the Commission took suo motu control over the matter." Example - "there is no requirement that a court suo motu instruct a jury upon these defenses." State v. Pierson.

superiority complex.bengali: An attitude of superiority which conceals actual feelings of inferiority and failure.

noun.definition: A sudden powerful forward or upward movement, especially by a crowd or by a natural force such as the tide.
noun.example: flooding caused by tidal surges

verb.definition: (of a crowd or a natural force) move suddenly and powerfully forward or upward.
verb.example: the journalists surged forward

verb.definition: (of a rope, chain, or windlass) slip back with a jerk.

surge.origin: Late 15th century (in the sense ‘fountain, stream’): the noun (in early use) from Old French sourgeon; the verb partly from the Old French stem sourge-, based on Latin surgere ‘to rise’. Early senses of the verb included ‘rise and fall on the waves’ and ‘swell with great force’.

adjective.definition: Believed to exist or to be true, without certain proof.
adjective.example: a suspected heart condition

adjective.definition: (of a sentence) imposed by a judge or court but not enforced as long as no further offence is committed within a specified period.
adjective.example: he was given a suspended jail term of 22 months

adjective.definition: (of solid particles) dispersed through the bulk of a fluid.
adjective.example: suspended sediments inhibit the sun's energy from being used for reef building

adjective.definition: Supported by attachment from above; hanging.
adjective.example: small vents in the suspended ceilings supply fresh air

noun.definition: The action of suspending someone or something or the condition of being suspended.
noun.example: the suspension of military action

noun.definition: The system of springs and shock absorbers by which a vehicle is supported on its wheels.
noun.example: modifications have been made to the car's rear suspension

noun.definition: A mixture in which particles are dispersed throughout the bulk of a fluid.
noun.example: a suspension of maize starch in arachis oil

noun.definition: A discord made by prolonging a note of a chord into the following chord.

suspension.origin: Late Middle English from French, or from Latin suspensio(n-), from the verb suspendere (see suspend).

noun.definition: An effect or facility on a keyboard or electronic instrument whereby a note can be sustained after the key is released.

verb.definition: Strengthen or support physically or mentally.
verb.example: this thought had sustained him throughout the years
synonyms: be a source of strength to
be a tower of strength to

verb.definition: Undergo or suffer (something unpleasant, especially an injury)
verb.example: he sustained severe head injuries

verb.definition: Cause to continue for an extended period or without interruption.
verb.example: he cannot sustain a normal conversation

verb.definition: Uphold, affirm, or confirm the justice or validity of.
verb.example: the allegations of discrimination were sustained

sustain.origin: Middle English from Old French soustenir, from Latin sustinere, from sub- ‘from below’ + tenere ‘hold’.

noun.definition: An act of swallowing something, especially food or drink.
noun.example: he downed his drink in one swallow

verb.definition: Cause or allow (something, especially food or drink) to pass down the throat.
verb.example: she swallowed a mouthful slowly

verb.definition: Take in and cause to disappear; engulf.
verb.example: the dark mist swallowed her up

swallow.origin: Old English swelgan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zwelgen and German schwelgen.

noun.definition: A migratory swift-flying songbird with a forked tail and long pointed wings, feeding on insects in flight.

swallow.origin: Old English swealwe, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zwaluw and German Schwalbe.

verb.definition: Make a solemn statement or promise undertaking to do something or affirming that something is the case.
verb.example: Maria made me swear I would never tell anyone

verb.definition: Use offensive language, especially as an expression of anger.
verb.example: Peter swore under his breath

swear.origin: Old English swerian of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zweren, German schwören, also to answer.

noun.definition: An act of sweeping something with a brush.
noun.example: I was giving the floor a quick sweep

noun.definition: A long, swift curving movement.
noun.example: a grandiose sweep of his hand

noun.definition: A procedure for inducing labour in a pregnant woman, in which a medical practitioner moves a finger around within the opening of the cervix to detach the amniotic membranes.
noun.example: I went in for a sweep at 41 weeks

noun.definition: A comprehensive search or survey of a place or area.
noun.example: the police finished their sweep through the woods

noun.definition: A long, typically curved stretch of road, river, country, etc.
noun.example: we could see a wide sweep of country perhaps a hundred miles across

noun.definition: A sweepstake.
An instance of winning every event, award, or place in a contest.
noun.example: a World Series sweep

noun.definition: A long, heavy oar used to row a barge or other vessel.
noun.example: a big, heavy sweep oar

noun.definition: A sail of a windmill.
A long pole mounted as a lever for raising buckets from a well.

verb.definition: Clean (an area) by brushing away dirt or litter.
verb.example: I've swept the floor

verb.definition: Move swiftly and smoothly.
verb.example: a large black car swept past the open windows

verb.definition: Search (an area) for something.
verb.example: the detective swept the room for hair and fingerprints
synonyms: go through with a fine-tooth comb

sweep.origin: Old English swāpan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to German schweifen ‘sweep in a curve’.

adjective.definition: Extending or performed in a long, continuous curve.
adjective.example: sweeping, desolate moorlands

adjective.definition: Wide in range or effect.
adjective.example: we cannot recommend any sweeping alterations

noun.definition: Dirt or refuse collected by sweeping.
noun.example: the sweepings from the house

noun.definition: An item of confectionery or sweet food.
noun.example: he hurried back to his room like a schoolboy who has stolen a sweetmeat

adjective.definition: Excellent; very good.
adjective.example: you're looking swell

adverb.definition: Excellently; very well.
adverb.example: everything was just going swell

noun.definition: A full or gently rounded shape or form.
noun.example: the soft swell of her breast

noun.definition: A gradual increase in amount, intensity, or volume.
noun.example: a huge swell in the popularity of one-day cricket

noun.definition: A slow, regular movement of the sea in rolling waves that do not break.
noun.example: there was a heavy swell

noun.definition: A mechanism for producing a crescendo or diminuendo in an organ or harmonium.
A fashionable or stylish person of wealth or high social position.
noun.example: a crowd of city swells

verb.definition: (especially of a part of the body) become larger or rounder in size, typically as a result of an accumulation of fluid.
verb.example: her bruised knee was already swelling up

verb.definition: Become or make greater in intensity, number, amount, or volume.
verb.example: the low murmur swelled to a roar

swell.origin: Old English swellan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to German schwellen. Current senses of the noun date from the early 16th century; the informal adjectival use derives from noun swell (sense 5 of the noun) (late 18th century).

noun.definition: A person or animal that swims.
noun.example: the fastest freestyle swimmer in the world

noun.definition: A conference or meeting to discuss a particular subject.
A drinking party or convivial discussion, especially as held in ancient Greece after a banquet (and notable as the title of a work by Plato).

symposium.origin: Late 16th century (denoting a drinking party): via Latin from Greek sumposion, from sumpotēs ‘fellow drinker’, from sun- ‘together’ + potēs ‘drinker’.

noun.definition: The activity or trade of a tailor.
noun.example: they learnt woodwork, tailoring, and other trades

take a whiz.bengali: 1. to take a piss; to urinate 2. to send urine out of the body
take a whiz.example: I'll be right back. I have to take a whiz.

noun.definition: A restaurant or shop selling cooked food to be eaten elsewhere.
noun.example: a fast-food takeaway

noun.definition: A key fact, point, or idea to be remembered, typically one emerging from a discussion or meeting.
noun.example: the main takeaway for me is that we need to continue to communicate all the things we're doing for our customers

noun.definition: another term for backswing
noun.example: many golfers ruin the swing with a poor takeaway

noun.definition: (in football and hockey) an act of regaining the ball or puck from the opposing team.
A confused mass of something twisted together.
noun.example: a tangle of golden hair

noun.definition: A fight, argument, or disagreement.
noun.example: she got into a tangle with staff

verb.definition: Twist together into a confused mass.
verb.example: the broom somehow got tangled up in my long skirt

verb.definition: Become involved in a conflict or fight with.
verb.example: they usually come a cropper when they tangle with the heavy mobs

tangle.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘entangle, catch in a tangle’): probably of Scandinavian origin and related to Swedish dialect taggla ‘disarrange’.

noun.definition: Any of a number of brown seaweeds, especially oarweed.

tangle.origin: Mid 16th century probably from Norwegian tongul.

noun.definition: A tax or duty to be paid on a particular class of imports or exports.
noun.example: the reduction of trade barriers and import tariffs

verb.definition: Fix the price of (something) according to a tariff.
verb.example: these services are tariffed by volume

tariff.origin: Late 16th century (also denoting an arithmetical table): via French from Italian tariffa, based on Arabic ‘arrafa ‘notify’.

noun.definition: A remark made in order to anger, wound, or provoke someone.
noun.example: pupils will play truant rather than face the taunts of classmates about their ragged clothes

verb.definition: Provoke or challenge (someone) with insulting remarks.
verb.example: pupils began taunting her about her weight

taunt.origin: Early 16th century from French tant pour tant ‘like for like, tit for tat’, from tant ‘so much’, from Latin tantum, neuter of tantus. An early use of the verb was ‘exchange banter’.

taunting.example: 1. The advertisement in a way is taunting the supporters. 2. New zealand cricket have admonished a stadium announcer for taunting pakistan fast bowler mohammad amir during the third t20 on friday.

adjective.definition: Intended to provoke someone in an insulting or contemptuous manner.
adjective.example: taunting comments

noun.definition: A hole or split in something caused by it having been pulled apart forcefully.
noun.example: there was a tear in her dress

noun.definition: A brief spell of erratic or unrestrained behaviour; a binge or spree.
noun.example: one of my drinking buddies came for the weekend and we went on a tear

verb.definition: Pull (something) apart or to pieces with force.
verb.example: I tore up the letter

verb.definition: Move very quickly in a reckless or excited manner.
verb.example: she tore along the footpath on her bike

verb.definition: Be in a state of uncertainty between two conflicting options or parties.
verb.example: he was torn between his duty and his better instincts

tear.origin: Old English teran, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch teren and German zehren, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek derein ‘flay’. The noun dates from the early 17th century.

noun.definition: A drop of clear salty liquid secreted from glands in a person's eye when they cry or when the eye is irritated.
noun.example: a tear rolled down her cheek

verb.definition: (of the eye) produce tears.
verb.example: the freezing wind made her eyes tear

tear.origin: Old English tēar, of Germanic origin; related to German Zähre, from an Indo-European root shared by Old Latin dacruma (Latin lacrima) and Greek dakru.

noun.definition: A person who makes fun of someone playfully or unkindly.
noun.example: some think of him as a tease who likes to keep others guessing

noun.definition: An act of teasing someone.
noun.example: she couldn't resist a gentle tease

verb.definition: Make fun of or attempt to provoke (a person or animal) in a playful way.
verb.example: I used to tease her about being so house-proud

verb.definition: Gently pull or comb (tangled wool, hair, etc.) into separate strands.
verb.example: she was teasing out the curls into her usual hairstyle

tease.origin: Old English tǣsan (in tease (sense 2 of the verb)), of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch teezen and German dialect zeisen, also to teasel. Sense 1 is a development of the earlier and more serious ‘irritate by annoying actions’ (early 17th century), a figurative use of the word's original sense.

noun.definition: The speed at which a passage of music is or should be played.
The rate or speed of motion or activity; pace.
noun.example: the tempo of life dictated by a heavy workload

tempo.origin: Mid 17th century (as a fencing term denoting the timing of an attack): from Italian, from Latin tempus ‘time’.

noun.definition: (in South Asia) a light three-wheeled delivery van.
The conditions under which land or buildings are held or occupied.
The holding of an office.
noun.example: his tenure of the premiership would be threatened

noun.definition: Guaranteed permanent employment, especially as a teacher or lecturer, after a probationary period.
noun.example: tenure for university staff has been abolished

verb.definition: Give (someone) a permanent post, especially as a teacher or lecturer.
verb.example: I had recently been tenured and then promoted to full professor

tenure.origin: Late Middle English from Old French, from tenir ‘to hold’, from Latin tenere.

adjective.definition: On or relating to the earth.
adjective.example: increased ultraviolet radiation may disrupt terrestrial ecosystems

adjective.definition: Of or on dry land.
adjective.example: a submarine eruption will be much more explosive than its terrestrial counterpart

noun.definition: An inhabitant of the earth.

terrestrial.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘temporal, worldly, mundane’): from Latin terrestris (from terra ‘earth’) + -al.

adjective.definition: Extremely bad or serious.
adjective.example: a terrible crime

adjective.definition: Causing or likely to cause terror; sinister.
adjective.example: the stranger gave a terrible smile

terrible.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘causing terror’): via French from Latin terribilis, from terrere ‘frighten’.

noun.definition: An electronic musical instrument in which the tone is generated by two high-frequency oscillators and the pitch controlled by the movement of the performer's hand towards and away from the circuit.

theremin.origin: Early 20th century named after Lev Theremin (1896–1993), its Russian inventor.

noun.definition: A book that lists words in groups of synonyms and related concepts.

thesaurus.origin: Late 16th century via Latin from Greek thēsauros ‘storehouse, treasure’. The original sense ‘dictionary or encyclopedia’ was narrowed to the current meaning by the publication of Roget's Thesaurus of English Words and Phrases (1852).

think about it.bengali: 1. Take into consideration, have in view; "he entertained the notion of moving to south america" 2. Used when someone says something that, in the hands of someone with a dirty mind, can sound sexual.

thoroughfare.example: Buses clog up major thoroughfare in town

noun.definition: A road or path forming a route between two places.
noun.example: a scheme to stop the park being used as a thoroughfare

noun.definition: The passage which leads from the back of the mouth of a person or animal.
noun.example: her throat was parched with thirst

throat.origin: Old English throte, throtu, of Germanic origin; related to German Drossel. Compare with throttle.

noun.definition: A violent person, especially a criminal.
noun.example: he was attacked by a gang of thugs

thug.origin: Early 19th century (in thug (sense 2)): from Hindi ṭhag ‘swindler, thief’, based on Sanskrit sthagati ‘he covers or conceals’. thug (sense 1) arose in the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: Each in a series of rows or levels of a structure placed one above the other.
noun.example: a tier of seats

tier.origin: Late 15th century from French tire ‘sequence, order’, from tirer ‘elongate, draw’.

noun.definition: A sloping position or movement.
noun.example: the tilt of her head

noun.definition: A combat for exercise or sport between two men on horseback with lances; a joust.
A small hut in a forest.

verb.definition: Move or cause to move into a sloping position.
verb.example: the floor tilted slightly

verb.definition: (in jousting) thrust at with a lance or other weapon.
verb.example: he tilts at his prey

tilt.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘fall or cause to fall, topple’): perhaps related to Old English tealt ‘unsteady’, or perhaps of Scandinavian origin and related to Norwegian tylten ‘unsteady’ and Swedish tulta ‘totter’.

adjective.definition: Showing a lack of courage or confidence; easily frightened.
adjective.example: I was too timid to ask for what I wanted

timid.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin timidus, from timere ‘to fear’.

noun.definition: A light, clear ringing sound.
noun.example: the distant tinkle of a cow bell

noun.definition: An act of urinating.
noun.example: you have to pay to go in for a tinkle

verb.definition: Make or cause to make a light, clear ringing sound.
verb.example: cool water tinkled in the stone fountains

verb.definition: Urinate.
verb.example: I needed to tinkle

tinkle.origin: Late Middle English (also in the sense ‘tingle’): frequentative of obsolete tink ‘to chink or clink’, of imitative origin.

adjective.definition: Slightly drunk.
adjective.example: tipsy revellers

tipsy.origin: Late 16th century from the verb tip+ -sy.

verb.definition: Feel or cause to feel in need of rest or sleep.
verb.example: soon the ascent grew steeper and he began to tire

verb.definition: Lose interest in; become bored with.
verb.example: the media will tire of publicizing every protest

tire.origin: Old English tēorian ‘fail, come to an end’, also ‘become physically exhausted’, of unknown origin.

noun.definition: A young child who is just beginning to walk.
A charge payable to use a bridge or road.
noun.example: motorway tolls

noun.definition: The number of deaths or casualties arising from a natural disaster, conflict, accident, etc.
noun.example: the toll of dead and injured mounted

verb.definition: Charge a toll for the use of (a bridge or road)
verb.example: the report advocates motorway tolling

toll.origin: Old English (denoting a charge, tax, or duty), from medieval Latin toloneum, alteration of late Latin teloneum, from Greek telōnion ‘toll house’, from telos ‘tax’. toll (sense 2 of the noun) (late 19th century) arose from the notion of paying a toll or tribute in human lives (to an adversary or to death).

noun.definition: A single ring of a bell.
noun.example: she heard the Cambridge School bell utter a single toll

verb.definition: (with reference to a bell) sound or cause to sound with a slow, uniform succession of strokes, as a signal or announcement.
verb.example: the cathedral bells began to toll for evening service

toll.origin: Late Middle English probably a special use of dialect toll ‘drag, pull’.

noun.definition: The fleshy muscular organ in the mouth of a mammal, used for tasting, licking, swallowing, and (in humans) articulating speech.
Used in reference to a person's style or manner of speaking.
noun.example: he was a redoubtable debater with a caustic tongue

noun.definition: A strip of leather or fabric under the laces in a shoe, attached only at the front end.
The free-swinging metal piece inside a bell which is made to strike the bell to produce the sound.
A long, low promontory of land.
A projecting strip on a wooden board fitting into a groove on another.
The vibrating reed of a musical instrument or organ pipe.
A jet of flame.
noun.example: a tongue of flame flashed from the gun

verb.definition: Sound (a note) distinctly on a wind instrument by interrupting the air flow with the tongue.
verb.example: Eugene has worked out the correct tonguing

verb.definition: Lick or caress with the tongue.
verb.example: the other horse tongued every part of the colt's mane

tongue.origin: Old English tunge, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch tong, German Zunge, and Latin lingua.

adjective.definition: (of a substance or object) strong enough to withstand adverse conditions or rough handling.
adjective.example: tough rucksacks for climbers

adjective.definition: Able to endure hardship or pain.
adjective.example: she was as tough as old boots

adjective.definition: Demonstrating a strict and uncompromising approach.
adjective.example: police have been getting tough with drivers

adjective.definition: Strong and prone to violence.
adjective.example: tough young teenagers

noun.definition: A rough and violent man.
noun.example: a gang of toughs

verb.definition: Endure a period of hardship or difficulty.
synonyms: see it through to the end

tough.origin: Old English tōh, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch taai and German zäh.

noun.definition: A person who offers racing tips for a share of any resulting winnings.
An informer.

verb.definition: Attempt to sell (something), typically by a direct or persistent approach.
verb.example: Sanjay was touting his wares

verb.definition: Offer racing tips for a share of any resulting winnings.

tout.origin: Middle English tute ‘look out’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch tuit ‘spout, nozzle’. Later senses were ‘watch, spy on’ (late 17th century) and ‘solicit custom’ (mid 18th century). The noun was first recorded (early 18th century) in the slang use ‘thieves' lookout’.

determiner.definition: Used before the name of a city to refer to its high society or people of importance.

tout.origin: French, suggested by le tout Paris ‘all (of) Paris’, used to refer to Parisian high society.

tow.example: 1. The other ship which came under attack, the norwegian-operated front altair, was being towed away from iranian waters and would undergo a damage assessment later saturday, said a spokeswoman for its operator. 2. workers in paris and other cities swept up broken glass and towed away burnt-out cars while the government warned of slower economic growth and the judiciary said it would come down hard on looting and attacks on police.

noun.definition: An act of towing a vehicle or boat.
noun.example: the cruiser got a tow from a warship after its engine failed

verb.definition: (of a motor vehicle or boat) pull (another vehicle or boat) along with a rope, chain, or tow bar.
verb.example: a pickup van towing a trailer

tow.origin: Old English togian ‘draw, drag’, of Germanic origin; related to tug. The noun dates from the early 17th century.

tow.example: 1. The other ship which came under attack, the norwegian-operated front altair, was being towed away from iranian waters and would undergo a damage assessment later saturday, said a spokeswoman for its operator. 2. workers in paris and other cities swept up broken glass and towed away burnt-out cars while the government warned of slower economic growth and the judiciary said it would come down hard on looting and attacks on police.

noun.definition: The coarse and broken part of flax or hemp prepared for spinning.
noun.example: In this process, which is much faster than that using guillotine cutters, tow is dyed, finished, cut, dried, screened, and bagged in one continuous operation.

tow.origin: Old English (recorded in towcræft ‘spinning’), of Germanic origin.

tow.example: 1. The other ship which came under attack, the norwegian-operated front altair, was being towed away from iranian waters and would undergo a damage assessment later saturday, said a spokeswoman for its operator. 2. workers in paris and other cities swept up broken glass and towed away burnt-out cars while the government warned of slower economic growth and the judiciary said it would come down hard on looting and attacks on police.

noun.definition: A mark, object, or other indication of the existence or passing of something.
noun.example: remove all traces of the old adhesive

noun.definition: A very small quantity, especially one too small to be accurately measured.
noun.example: his body contained traces of amphetamines

noun.definition: A procedure to investigate the source of something, such as the place from which a telephone call was made.
noun.example: we've got a trace on the call

noun.definition: A line which represents the projection of a curve or surface on a plane or the intersection of a curve or surface with a plane.
A path or track.
The sum of the elements in the principal diagonal of a square matrix.

verb.definition: Find or discover by investigation.
verb.example: police are trying to trace a white van seen in the area

verb.definition: Copy (a drawing, map, or design) by drawing over its lines on a superimposed piece of transparent paper.
verb.example: trace a map of the world on to a large piece of paper

trace.origin: Middle English (first recorded as a noun in the sense ‘path that someone or something takes’): from Old French trace (noun), tracier (verb), based on Latin tractus (see tract).

noun.definition: Each of the two side straps, chains, or ropes by which a horse is attached to a vehicle that it is pulling.
noun.example: Ales broke off in mid-explanation to dive into the crowd, reappearing clasping a handkerchief waving teenage girl, and yoking her into the cart's rope traces.

trace.origin: Middle English (denoting a pair of traces): from Old French trais, plural of trait (see trait).

noun.definition: Vehicles moving on a public highway.
noun.example: a stream of heavy traffic

noun.definition: The messages or signals transmitted through a communications system.
noun.example: data traffic between remote workstations

noun.definition: The action of dealing or trading in something illegal.
noun.example: the traffic in stolen cattle

noun.definition: Dealings or communication between people.

verb.definition: Deal or trade in something illegal.
verb.example: the government will vigorously pursue individuals who traffic in drugs

traffic.origin: Early 16th century (denoting commercial transportation of merchandise or passengers): from French traffique, Spanish tráfico, or Italian traffico, of unknown origin. Sense 1 dates from the early 19th century.

noun.definition: A person who deals or trades in something illegal.
noun.example: a convicted drug trafficker

adjective.definition: Causing or characterized by extreme distress or sorrow.
adjective.example: the shooting was a tragic accident

adjective.definition: Relating to tragedy in a literary work.
adjective.example: the same rules apply whether the plot is tragic or comic

noun.definition: A boring or socially inept person, typically having an obsessive and solitary interest.
noun.example: at school she's not a complete tragic, but she's not exactly popular either

tragic.origin: Mid 16th century from French tragique, via Latin from Greek tragikos, from tragos ‘goat’, but associated with tragōidia (see tragedy).

noun.definition: A mark or a series of signs or objects left behind by the passage of someone or something.
noun.example: a trail of blood on the grass

noun.definition: A long thin part or line stretching behind or hanging down from something.
noun.example: smoke trails

noun.definition: A beaten path through the countryside.
noun.example: country parks with nature trails

noun.definition: A trailer for a film or broadcast.
noun.example: a recent television trail for ‘The Bill’

noun.definition: The rear end of a gun carriage, resting or sliding on the ground when the gun is unlimbered.

verb.definition: Draw or be drawn along behind someone or something.
verb.example: Alex trailed a hand through the clear water

verb.definition: Walk or move slowly or wearily.
verb.example: he baulked at the idea of trailing around the shops

verb.definition: Follow (a person or animal) by using marks or scent left behind.
verb.example: Sam suspected they were trailing him

verb.definition: Be losing to an opponent in a game or contest.
verb.example: the defending champions were trailing 10—5 at half-time

verb.definition: Give advance publicity to (a film, broadcast, or proposal)
verb.example: the bank's plans have been extensively trailed

verb.definition: Apply (slip) through a nozzle or spout to decorate ceramic ware.

trail.origin: Middle English (as a verb): from Old French traillier ‘to tow’, or Middle Low German treilen ‘haul a boat’, based on Latin tragula ‘dragnet’, from trahere ‘to pull’. Compare with trawl. The noun originally denoted the train of a robe, later generalized to denote something trailing.

noun.definition: An act or the sound of trampling.
noun.example: destruction's trample treads them down

verb.definition: Tread on and crush.
verb.example: the fence had been trampled down

trample.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘tread heavily’): frequentative of tramp.

noun.definition: A half-conscious state characterized by an absence of response to external stimuli, typically as induced by hypnosis or entered by a medium.
noun.example: she put him into a light trance

verb.definition: Put into a trance.
verb.example: she's been tranced and may need waking

trance.origin: Middle English (originally as a verb in the sense ‘be in a trance’): from Old French transir ‘depart, fall into trance’, from Latin transire ‘go across’.

noun.definition: An act of transferring donated blood, blood products, or other fluid into the circulatory system of a person or animal.
noun.example: major bleeding necessitating transfusions

transfusion.origin: Late Middle English from Latin transfusio(n-), from the verb transfundere (see transfuse).

trash talk.bengali: ফালতু কথা; in the course of a competitive situation putting down your opponent verbally or saying how good you think you are. 1) verbal abuse used during competition to upset the opposition.  2) to verbally abuse the opponent during competition. 3.  Disparaging, often insulting or vulgar speech about another person or group. – wikipedia.org

adjective.definition: Very great in amount, scale, or intensity.
adjective.example: Penny put in a tremendous amount of time

adjective.definition: Inspiring awe or dread.

tremendous.origin: Mid 17th century from Latin tremendus (gerundive of tremere ‘tremble’) + -ous.

noun.definition: A great victory or achievement.
noun.example: a garden built to celebrate Napoleon's many triumphs

noun.definition: The processional entry of a victorious general into ancient Rome.

verb.definition: Achieve a victory; be successful.
verb.example: they had no chance of triumphing over the Nationalists

verb.definition: (of a Roman general) ride into ancient Rome after a victory.
verb.example: Caesar triumphed at Rome four times in the same month, with a few days between each triumph.

triumph.origin: Late Middle English from Old French triumphe (noun), from Latin triump(h)us, probably from Greek thriambos ‘hymn to Bacchus’. Current senses of the verb date from the early 16th century.

triumphant.example: Kenya's world 800m record holder david rudisha on friday made a triumphant return to his hometown of kilgoris in western kenya where he was crowned a masai warrior.

adjective.definition: Having won a battle or contest; victorious.
adjective.example: two of their triumphant Cup team

triumphant.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘victorious’): from Old French, or from Latin triumphant- ‘celebrating a triumph’, from the verb triumphare (see triumph).

noun.definition: (in folklore) an ugly creature depicted as either a giant or a dwarf.

troll.origin: Early 17th century from Old Norse and Swedish troll, Danish trold. The first English use is from Shetland; the term was adopted more widely into English in the mid 19th century.

noun.definition: A person who makes a deliberately offensive or provocative online post.
noun.example: one solution is to make a troll's postings invisible to the rest of community once they've been recognized

noun.definition: A line or bait used in trolling for fish.

verb.definition: Make a deliberately offensive or provocative online post with the aim of upsetting someone or eliciting an angry response from them.
verb.example: if people are obviously trolling then I'll delete your posts and do my best to ban you

verb.definition: Carefully and systematically search an area for something.
verb.example: a group of companies trolling for partnership opportunities

verb.definition: Walk in a leisurely way; stroll.
verb.example: we all trolled into town

verb.definition: Sing (something) in a happy and carefree way.
verb.example: he trolled a note or two

troll.origin: Late Middle English (in the sense ‘stroll, roll’): origin uncertain; compare with Old French troller ‘wander here and there (in search of game)’ and Middle High German trollen ‘stroll’. The computing senses (first recorded in 1992) are probably influenced by troll.

noun.definition: A large brass wind instrument with straight tubing in three sections, ending in a bell over the player's left shoulder, different fundamental notes being made using a forward-pointing extendable slide.

trombone.origin: Early 18th century from French or Italian, from Italian tromba ‘trumpet’.

adjective.definition: Of, typical of, or peculiar to the tropics.
adjective.example: tropical countries

adjective.definition: Of or involving a trope; figurative.

troubled.example: Troubled water: a difficult or confusing situation

adjective.definition: Beset by problems or difficulties.
adjective.example: his troubled private life

noun.definition: An agreement between enemies or opponents to stop fighting or arguing for a certain time.
noun.example: the guerrillas called a three-day truce

truce.origin: Middle English trewes, trues (plural), from Old English trēowa, plural of trēow ‘belief, trust’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch trouw and German Treue, also to true.

noun.definition: The main woody stem of a tree as distinct from its branches and roots.
A person's or animal's body apart from the limbs and head.
The elongated, prehensile nose of an elephant.
A large box with a hinged lid for storing or transporting clothes and other articles.

trunk.origin: Late Middle English from Old French tronc, from Latin truncus.

turndown.example: No reason to turn it down

adjective.definition: (of a collar) turned down.
adjective.example: You can wear three basic types of shirts with a tuxedo: wing collar, turndown collar and mandarin collar.

noun.definition: A rejection or refusal.
noun.example: no idea should meet a flat turndown if there's a chance of a pay-off

noun.definition: A decline in something; a downturn.
noun.example: the company has suffered a dramatic turndown after a storm of bad publicity

adjective.definition: Existing beyond what is obvious or admitted; intentionally hidden.
adjective.example: could there be an ulterior motive behind his request?

ulterior.origin: Mid 17th century from Latin, literally ‘further, more distant’.

ulterior motive.bengali: অশুভ উদ্দেশ্য; when a person is trying has a hidden motive or hidden objective with another person secretely.

noun.definition: Offence or annoyance.
noun.example: she took umbrage at his remarks

noun.definition: Shade or shadow, especially as cast by trees.

umbrage.origin: Late Middle English (in umbrage (sense 2)): from Old French, from Latin umbra ‘shadow’. An early sense was ‘shadowy outline’, giving rise to ‘ground for suspicion’, whence the current notion of ‘offence’.

unabated.example: Road collapse as illegal sand lifting goes unabated

adjective.definition: Without any reduction in intensity or strength.
adjective.example: the storm was raging unabated

adjective.definition: (of a text) not cut or shortened; complete.
adjective.example: an unabridged edition

adjective.definition: Not intimidated or discouraged by difficulty, danger, or disappointment.
adjective.example: they were undaunted by the huge amount of work needed

adverb.definition: Used to emphasize that something cannot be denied or disputed.
adverb.example: effective, responsive government undeniably benefits businesses

undergo.bengali: মধ্য দিয়ে যাওয়া; সহ্য করা; বিশেষত চিকিৎসার মধ্যে দিয়ে যাওয়া
undergo.example: 1. Quader to undergo surgery today 2. Pathao undergoing massive downsizing

verb.definition: Experience or be subjected to (something, typically something unpleasant or arduous)
verb.example: he underwent a life-saving brain operation

verb.definition: Find (something) in the ground by digging.
verb.example: workmen unearthed an ancient artillery shell

verb.definition: Drive (an animal, especially a fox) out of a hole or burrow.
Open or spread out from a folded position.
verb.example: he unfolded the map and laid it out on the table

verb.definition: (of events or information) gradually develop or be revealed.
verb.example: there was a fascinating scene unfolding before me
