verb.definition: Make or become united, uniform, or whole.
verb.example: the government hoped to centralize and unify the nation

unify.origin: Early 16th century from French unifier or late Latin unificare ‘make into a whole’.

adjective.definition: Not conforming to, permitted by, or recognized by law or rules.
adjective.example: the use of unlawful violence

unlawful.origin: On the difference between unlawful and illegal, see illegal

adjective.definition: Not likely to happen, be done, or be true; improbable.
adjective.example: an unlikely explanation

verb.definition: Undo (twisted, knitted, or woven threads).
Investigate and solve or explain (something complicated or puzzling)
verb.example: they were attempting to unravel the cause of death

noun.definition: A state of dissatisfaction, disturbance, and agitation, typically involving public demonstrations or disorder.
noun.example: years of industrial unrest

adjective.definition: Disorderly and disruptive and not amenable to discipline or control.
adjective.example: a group of unruly children

unruly.origin: Late Middle English from un-‘not’ + archaic ruly ‘amenable to discipline or order’ (from rule).

verb.definition: Free from a tangled or twisted state.
verb.example: fishermen untangled their nets

verb.definition: Remove a veil or covering from, in particular uncover (a new monument or work of art) as part of a public ceremony.
verb.example: the Princess unveiled a plaque

uphill battle.bengali: চড়াই যুদ্ধ; a very difficult struggle
uphill battle.example: Egypt faces uphill battle against corruption

verb.definition: Confirm or support (something which has been questioned)
verb.example: the court upheld his claim for damages

adjective.definition: Relatively expensive and designed to appeal to affluent consumers; upmarket.
adjective.example: Hawaii's upscale boutique hotels

adverb.definition: Towards the more expensive or affluent sector of the market.
adverb.example: once known as the low-cost cousin of beef, fish has moved upscale

verb.definition: Increase the size or improve the quality of.
verb.example: he needs to extra funds to upscale the business

verb.definition: Convert (an image or video) so that it displays correctly in a higher resolution format.
verb.example: your HDTV will automatically upscale the content you watch

noun.definition: A strong desire or impulse.
noun.example: he felt the urge to giggle

verb.definition: Try earnestly or persistently to persuade (someone) to do something.
verb.example: he urged her to come and stay with us

urge.origin: Mid 16th century from Latin urgere ‘press, drive’.

noun.definition: The action of urging someone to do something.
noun.example: she bought a new one at Gregory's urging

noun.definition: A person who shows people to their seats, especially in a cinema or theatre or at a wedding.
An assistant teacher.
noun.example: It was modest in size, with perhaps 40 pupils taught by one master, assisted by an usher, in the room above the guildhall, both of which survive and are still used by the school.

verb.definition: Show or guide (someone) somewhere.
verb.example: a waiter ushered me to a table

verb.definition: Cause or mark the start of something new.
verb.example: the railways ushered in an era of cheap mass travel

usher.origin: Late Middle English (denoting a doorkeeper): from Anglo-Norman French usser, from medieval Latin ustiarius, from Latin ostiarius, from ostium ‘door’.

verb.definition: Take (a position of power or importance) illegally or by force.
verb.example: Richard usurped the throne

usurp.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘appropriate a right wrongfully’): from Old French usurper, from Latin usurpare ‘seize for use’.

uvula.origin: Late Middle English from late Latin, diminutive of Latin uva ‘grape’.

adverb.definition: In a way that is uncertain, indefinite or unclear; roughly.
adverb.example: he vaguely remembered talking to her once

adverb.definition: Slightly.
adverb.example: he looked vaguely familiar

adjective.definition: Having or showing an excessively high opinion of one's appearance, abilities, or worth.
adjective.example: their flattery made him vain

adjective.definition: Producing no result; useless.
adjective.example: a vain attempt to tidy up the room

vain.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘devoid of real worth’): via Old French from Latin vanus ‘empty, without substance’.

adjective.definition: Possessing or showing courage or determination.
adjective.example: she made a valiant effort to hold her anger in check

valiant.origin: Middle English (also in the sense ‘robust, well-built’): from Old French vailant, based on Latin valere ‘be strong’.

noun.definition: Action involving deliberate destruction of or damage to public or private property.
noun.example: an act of mindless vandalism

noun.definition: A sudden change of direction.
noun.example: In particular, Sword wants to discover what triggers the insects' specific movements - a sudden veer or turn or an increase in speed, for example.

noun.definition: An offensive play using a modified T-formation with a split backfield, which allows the quarterback the option of passing to the fullback, pitching to a running back, or running with the ball.
noun.example: The veer offensive requires the quarterback to make the decision to run or hand off the ball even faster.

verb.definition: Change direction suddenly.
verb.example: an oil tanker that had veered off course

veer.origin: Late 16th century from French virer, perhaps from an alteration of Latin gyrare (see gyrate).

verb.definition: Slacken or let out (a rope or cable) in a controlled way.

veer.origin: Late Middle English from Middle Dutch vieren.

noun.definition: A piece of fine material worn by women to protect or conceal the face.
noun.example: a white bridal veil

noun.definition: A membrane which is attached to the immature fruiting body of some toadstools and ruptures in the course of development, either (universal veil) enclosing the whole fruiting body or (partial veil) joining the edges of the cap to the stalk.
noun.example: Extending from the stem to the margin of the cap, and covering the gills, is the partial veil - a membranaceous, white texture of varying thickness.

verb.definition: Cover with or as if with a veil.
verb.example: she veiled her face

veil.origin: Middle English from Anglo-Norman French veil(e), from Latin vela, plural of velum (see velum).

adjective.definition: Relating to or in the form of words.
adjective.example: the root of the problem is visual rather than verbal

adjective.definition: Relating to or derived from a verb.
adjective.example: a verbal adjective

noun.definition: A word or words functioning as a verb.

noun.example: just a bit of air-wave verbals

noun.definition: The lyrics of a song or the dialogue of a film.
noun.example: it is the responsibility of the directors to do better with the verbals

noun.definition: A verbal statement containing a damaging admission alleged to have been made to the police, and offered as evidence by the prosecution.
noun.example: But the mischief that McKinney, after two decades of cases, the mischief was exactly the problem of verbals.

verb.definition: Attribute a damaging statement to (a suspect), especially dishonestly.

verbal.origin: Late 15th century (describing a person who deals with words rather than things): from French, or from late Latin verbalis, from verbum ‘word’ (see verb).

adverb.definition: By means of words.
adverb.example: she claimed to have been verbally abused

adverb.definition: With the function of a verb.

noun.definition: An edge or border.
noun.example: they came down to the verge of the lake

noun.definition: An extreme limit beyond which something specified will happen.
noun.example: I was on the verge of tears

verb.definition: Be very close or similar to.
verb.example: despair verging on the suicidal

verge.origin: Late Middle English via Old French from Latin virga ‘rod’. The current verb sense dates from the late 18th century.

noun.definition: A wand or rod carried before a bishop or dean as an emblem of office.
noun.example: ‘I will carry on looking after the verges until they (the council) shoot me,’ he said.

verge.origin: Late Middle English from Latin virga ‘rod’.

verb.definition: Incline in a certain direction or towards a particular state.
verb.example: his style verged into the art nouveau school

verge.origin: Early 17th century (in the sense ‘descend to the horizon’): from Latin vergere ‘to bend, incline’.

plural noun.definition: Pasta in the form of long slender threads.
Shreds of chocolate used to decorate cakes or other sweet foods.

vermicelli.origin: Italian, plural of vermicello, diminutive of verme ‘worm’, from Latin vermis.

noun.definition: A ship or large boat.
A hollow container, especially one used to hold liquid, such as a bowl or cask.
A duct or canal holding or conveying blood or other fluid.

vessel.origin: Middle English from Anglo-Norman French vessel(e), from late Latin vascellum, diminutive of vas ‘vessel’.

noun.definition: A person who has had long experience in a particular field.
noun.example: a veteran of two world wars

veteran.origin: Early 16th century from French vétéran or Latin veteranus, from vetus ‘old’.

adjective.definition: Deliberately cruel or violent.
adjective.example: a vicious assault

adjective.definition: Immoral.
adjective.example: every soul on earth, virtuous or vicious, shall perish

adjective.definition: (of language or a line of reasoning) imperfect; defective.

vicious.origin: Middle English (in the sense ‘characterized by immorality’): from Old French vicious or Latin vitiosus, from vitium ‘vice’.

adjective.definition: Relating to or denoting wine of high quality.
adjective.example: vintage claret

adjective.definition: Denoting something from the past of high quality, especially something representing the best of its kind.
adjective.example: a vintage Sherlock Holmes adventure

noun.definition: The year or place in which wine, especially wine of high quality, was produced.
noun.example: 1982 is one of the best vintages of the century

noun.definition: The time that something of quality was produced.
noun.example: rifles of various sizes and vintages

vintage.origin: Late Middle English alteration (influenced by vintner) of earlier vendage, from Old French vendange, from Latin vindemia (from vinum ‘wine’ + demere ‘remove’).

noun.definition: A solemn promise.

verb.definition: Solemnly promise to do a specified thing.
verb.example: the rebels vowed to continue fighting

verb.definition: Dedicate to someone or something, especially a deity.
verb.example: I vowed myself to this enterprise

vow.origin: Middle English from Old French vou, from Latin votum (see vote); the verb is from Old French vouer.

adjective.definition: Exposed to the possibility of being attacked or harmed, either physically or emotionally.
adjective.example: we were in a vulnerable position

vulnerable.origin: Early 17th century from late Latin vulnerabilis, from Latin vulnerare ‘to wound’, from vulnus ‘wound’.

noun.definition: An act of wading.

verb.definition: Walk with effort through water or another liquid or viscous substance.
verb.example: he waded out to the boat

verb.definition: Intervene in (something) or attack (someone) vigorously or forcefully.
verb.example: Seb waded into the melee and started to beat off the boys

wade.origin: Old English wadan ‘move onward’, also ‘penetrate’, from a Germanic word meaning ‘go (through)’, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin vadere ‘go’.

noun.definition: A fixed regular payment earned for work or services, typically paid on a daily or weekly basis.
noun.example: we were struggling to get better wages

verb.definition: Carry on (a war or campaign)
verb.example: it is necessary to destroy their capacity to wage war

wage.origin: Middle English from Anglo-Norman French and Old Northern French, of Germanic origin; related to gage and wed.

noun.definition: The part of the human body below the ribs and above the hips, often narrower than the areas above and below.
noun.example: he put an arm around her waist

noun.definition: A narrow part in the middle of something, such as a violin or hourglass.
noun.example: Wellington, a long almond biscuit, rounded at each end with a narrower waist.

noun.definition: A blouse or bodice.

waist.origin: Late Middle English apparently representing an Old English word from the Germanic root of wax.

verb.definition: Refrain from insisting on or using (a right or claim)
verb.example: he will waive all rights to the money

waive.origin: Middle English (originally as a legal term relating to removal of the protection of the law): from an Anglo-Norman French variant of Old French gaiver ‘allow to become a waif, abandon’.

noun.definition: An act or instance of waiving a right or claim.
noun.example: their acquiescence could amount to a waiver

noun.definition: An act of masturbating.

verb.definition: (typically used of a man) masturbate.

noun.definition: A dog kept to guard private property.

verb.definition: Monitor (a person, activity, or situation)
verb.example: how can we watchdog our investments?

verb.definition: Saturate with water; make (something) waterlogged.
verb.example: the open roof allowed rain to waterlog the field

waterlog.origin: Mid 18th century (originally in the sense ‘make (a ship) unmanageable by flooding’): from water + the verb log.

noun.definition: A particular style or manner in which something is woven.
noun.example: cloth of a very fine weave

noun.definition: A hairstyle created by weaving pieces of real or artificial hair into a person's existing hair, typically in order to increase its length or thickness.
noun.example: trailers show him with dyed blond hair and, in one scene, a flowing blond weave

verb.definition: Form (fabric or a fabric item) by interlacing long threads passing in one direction with others at a right angle to them.
verb.example: textiles woven from linen or wool

verb.definition: Make (a complex story or pattern) from a number of interconnected elements.
verb.example: he weaves colourful, cinematic plots

weave.origin: Old English wefan, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek huphē ‘web’ and Sanskrit ūrṇavābhi ‘spider’, literally ‘wool-weaver’. The current noun sense dates from the late 19th century.

verb.definition: Twist and turn from side to side while moving somewhere in order to avoid obstructions.
verb.example: he had to weave his way through the crowds

weave.origin: Late 16th century probably from Old Norse veifa ‘to wave, brandish’.

noun.definition: A person who weaves fabric.

adjective.definition: Tearful; inclined to weep.
adjective.example: seeing a bride always made her feel weepy

noun.definition: A sentimental film, book, or song.

weigh.example: I would like to weigh in here

verb.definition: Find out how heavy (someone or something) is, typically using scales.
verb.example: weigh yourself on the day you begin the diet

verb.definition: Assess the nature or importance of, especially with a view to a decision or action.
verb.example: the consequences of the move would need to be very carefully weighed

weigh.origin: Old English wegan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wegen ‘weigh’, German bewegen ‘move’, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin vehere ‘convey’. Early senses included ‘transport from one place to another’ and ‘raise up’.

weigh.example: I would like to weigh in here
weigh.origin: Late 18th century from an erroneous association with weigh anchor (see anchor).

adjective.definition: Suggesting something supernatural; unearthly.
adjective.example: weird, inhuman sounds

adjective.definition: Connected with fate.

noun.definition: A person's destiny.

verb.definition: Induce a sense of disbelief or alienation in someone.
verb.example: blue eyes weirded him out, and Ivan's were especially creepy

weird.origin: Old English wyrd ‘destiny’, of Germanic origin. The adjective (late Middle English) originally meant ‘having the power to control destiny’, and was used especially in the Weird Sisters, originally referring to the Fates, later the witches in Shakespeare's Macbeth; the latter use gave rise to the sense ‘unearthly’ (early 19th century).

noun.definition: The state of being comfortable, healthy, or happy.
noun.example: an improvement in the patient's well-being

noun.definition: A soft or confidential tone of voice; a whispered word or phrase.
noun.example: she spoke in a whisper

verb.definition: Speak very softly using one's breath rather than one's throat, especially for the sake of secrecy.
verb.example: Alison was whispering in his ear

whisper.origin: Old English hwisprian, of Germanic origin; related to German wispeln, from the imitative base of whistle.

adjective.definition: Very large.
adjective.example: a whopping £74 million loss

noun.definition: A prostitute.

verb.definition: (of a woman) work as a prostitute.
verb.example: she was forced to whore in order to support herself

whore.origin: Late Old English hōre, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch hoer and German Hure, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin carus ‘dear’.

noun.definition: The quality of being evil or morally wrong.
noun.example: the wickedness of the regime

noun.definition: A covering for the head made of real or artificial hair, typically worn by judges and barristers in law courts or by people trying to conceal their baldness.

verb.definition: Rebuke (someone) severely.
verb.example: I had often occasion to wig him for getting drunk

wig.origin: Early 19th century apparently from wig, perhaps from bigwig and associated with a rebuke given by a person in authority.

wildebeest.origin: Early 19th century from Afrikaans, literally ‘wild beast’.

adjective.definition: (of an immoral or illegal act or omission) intentional; deliberate.
adjective.example: willful acts of damage

willful.origin: Middle English from the noun will+ -ful.

wind up.bengali: গুটান; 1. verb to tighten the spring inside an item or device, as by twisting a knob. A noun or pronoun can be used between "wind" and "up." 2. verb to twist or coil something onto a particular surface or thing. A noun or pronoun can be used between "wind" and "up." 3. verb to cause someone or something to become more animated. A noun or pronoun can be used between "wind" and "up."
wind up.example: 1. Let me try winding up your watch—maybe that will get it going again. 2. The cat will keep playing with that yarn, unless you wind it up on the spool. 3. Please don't wind the kids up right before bedtime.

noun.definition: An act of wiping.
noun.example: Bert was giving the machine a final wipe over with an oily rag

noun.definition: A disposable cloth treated with a cleansing agent, for wiping things clean.
A cinematographic effect in which an existing picture seems to be wiped out by a new one as the boundary between them moves across the screen.

verb.definition: Clean or dry (something) by rubbing with a cloth, a piece of paper, or one's hand.
verb.example: Paulie wiped his face with a handkerchief

verb.definition: Remove or eliminate (something) completely.
verb.example: their life savings were wiped out

verb.definition: Pass (a swipe card) over an electronic reader.
verb.example: a customer wipes the card across the reader and enters his/her identification number

wipe.origin: Old English wīpian, of Germanic origin; related to whip.

noun.definition: The quality of having experience, knowledge, and good judgement; the quality of being wise.
noun.example: listen to his words of wisdom

noun.definition: Great sorrow or distress (often used hyperbolically)
noun.example: the Everton tale of woe continued

woe.origin: Natural exclamation of lament: recorded as wā in Old English and found in several Germanic languages.

adjective.definition: Characterized by, expressive of, or causing sorrow or misery.
adjective.example: her face was woeful

adjective.definition: Very bad; deplorable.
adjective.example: the remark was enough to establish his woeful ignorance about the theatre

verb.definition: Seek the favour, support, or custom of.
verb.example: pop stars are being wooed by film companies eager to sign them up

verb.definition: Try to gain the love of (someone), especially with a view to marriage.
verb.example: he wooed her with quotes from Shakespeare

woo.origin: Late Old English wōgian (intransitive), āwōgian (transitive), of unknown origin.

adjective.definition: Causing anxiety or concern.
adjective.example: a worrisome problem

adjective.definition: Equivalent in value to the sum or item specified.
adjective.example: jewellery worth £450 was taken

adjective.definition: Sufficiently good, important, or interesting to be treated or regarded in the way specified.
adjective.example: the museums in the district are well worth a visit

noun.definition: The level at which someone or something deserves to be valued or rated.
noun.example: they had to listen to every piece of gossip and judge its worth

noun.definition: The amount that could be achieved or produced in a specified time.
noun.example: the companies have debts greater than two years' worth of their sales

worth.origin: Old English w(e)orth (adjective and noun), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch waard and German wert.

noun.definition: Extreme anger.
noun.example: he hid his pipe for fear of incurring his father's wrath

wrath.origin: Old English wrǣththu, from wrāth (see wroth).

wreak.example: 1. flood wreaks havoc on croplands. 2. wreck it ralph

verb.definition: Cause (a large amount of damage or harm)
verb.example: torrential rainstorms wreaked havoc yesterday

wreak.origin: Old English wrecan ‘drive (out), avenge’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wreken and German rächen; compare with wrack, wreck, and wretch.

noun.definition: The remains of something that has been badly damaged or destroyed.
noun.example: firemen had to cut him free from the wreckage of the car

noun.definition: A form of written command in the name of a court or other legal authority to act, or abstain from acting, in a particular way.
noun.example: the two reinstated officers issued a writ for libel against the applicants

noun.definition: A piece or body of writing.
noun.example: And Percivale took it, and found therein a writ and so he read it, and devised the manner of the spindles and of the ship, whence it came, and by whom it was made.

writ.origin: Old English, as a general term denoting written matter, from the Germanic base of write.

adjective.definition: Having or showing a dislike of or prejudice against people from other countries.
adjective.example: xenophobic attitudes

noun.definition: The edible starchy tuber of a climbing plant that is widely grown in tropical and subtropical countries.
The cultivated plant that yields the yam.
A sweet potato.

yam.origin: Late 16th century from Portuguese inhame or obsolete Spanish iñame, probably of West African origin.

verb.definition: (of a cat) miaow.
verb.example: a cat slips up the driveway, yamming and trying to talk

noun.definition: Spun thread used for knitting, weaving, or sewing.
noun.example: hanks of pale green yarn

noun.definition: A long or rambling story, especially one that is implausible.
noun.example: he never let reality get in the way of a good yarn

verb.definition: Tell a long or implausible story.
verb.example: they were yarning about local legends and superstitions

yarn.origin: Old English gearn; of Germanic origin, related to Dutch garen.

noun.definition: A reflex act of opening one's mouth wide and inhaling deeply due to tiredness or boredom.
noun.example: he stretches and stifles a yawn

verb.definition: Involuntarily open one's mouth wide and inhale deeply due to tiredness or boredom.
verb.example: he began yawning and looking at his watch

verb.example: a yawning chasm

yawn.origin: Old English geonian, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin hiare and Greek khainein. Current noun senses date from the early 18th century.

yell.example: What to do when your boss is yelling at you

noun.definition: A loud, sharp cry of pain, surprise, or delight.
noun.example: her foot slipped and she gave a yell of fear

noun.definition: An extremely amusing person or thing.

verb.definition: Shout in a loud, sharp way.
verb.example: you heard me losing my temper and yelling at her
synonyms: call at the top of one's voice

yell.origin: Old English g(i)ellan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch gillen and German gellen.

yield.example: The growers successfully overcame the situation by taking additional measures as per instructions of the agro-officials and experts, resulting in good yield.

noun.definition: An amount produced of an agricultural or industrial product.
noun.example: the milk yield was poor

verb.definition: Produce or provide (a natural, agricultural, or industrial product)
verb.example: the land yields grapes and tobacco

verb.definition: Give way to arguments, demands, or pressure.
verb.example: the Western powers now yielded when they should have resisted

verb.definition: (of a mass or structure) give way under force or pressure.
verb.example: he reeled into the house as the door yielded

yield.origin: Old English g(i)eldan ‘pay, repay’, of Germanic origin. The senses ‘produce, bear’ and ‘surrender’ arose in Middle English.

yielding.example: Seed bodies of india and bangladesh yesterday formalised a move to cooperate on expediting trade of high-yielding varieties (hyv) of rice seeds for the benefit of the farmers of the two countries, and help boost food security.

adjective.definition: (of a substance or object) giving way under pressure; not hard or rigid.
adjective.example: she dropped on to the yielding cushions

adjective.definition: Giving a product or generating a financial return of a specified amount.
adjective.example: higher-yielding wheat

you owe me..bengali: You use this phrase to point out that you're doing something nice for someone that will have to be "paid back" later. You might also hear another version of this phrase, which is even stronger: you owe me, big time.
you owe me..example:
A: can you come and pick me up? Please?
B: ok, but you owe me one.
